('84', 0, 1, 2, 45) 1. LETTER TO ADDITIONAL SECRETARY, HOME DEPARTMENT, GOVERNMENT OF INDIA
('84', 0, 2, 3, 117) DETENTION CAMP, January 27, 1944
('84', 0, 3, 4, 150) ADDITIONAL SECRETARY TO THE GOVERNMENT OF INDIA (HOME DEPARTMENT) NEW DELHI
('84', 0, 4, 5, 226) SIR, Some days ago Shri Kasturba Gandhi told the Inspector General of prisons and Col.
('84', 0, 4, 6, 313) Shah that Dr. Dinshaw Mehta of Poona be invited to assist in her treatment.
('84', 0, 4, 7, 389) Nothing seems to have come out of her request.
('84', 0, 4, 8, 436) She has become insistent now and asked me if I had written to the Government in the matter.
('84', 0, 4, 9, 528) I, therefore, ask for immediate permission to bring in Dr. Mehta.
('84', 0, 4, 10, 594) She has also told me and my son that she would like to have some Ayurvedic physician to see her.
('84', 0, 4, 11, 691) 1 I suggest that the I.G.P. be authorized to permit such assistance when requested.
('84', 0, 4, 12, 775) 2. I have no reply as yet to my request 2 that Shri Kanu Gandhi, who is being permitted to visit the patient every alternate day, be allowed to remain in the camp as a whole time nurse.
('84', 0, 4, 13, 961) The patient shows no signs of recovery and night nursing is becoming more and more exacting.
('84', 0, 4, 14, 1054) Kanu Gandhi is an ideal nurse, having nursed the patient before.
('84', 0, 4, 15, 1119) And what is more, he can soothe her by giving her instrumental music and by singing bhajans.
('84', 0, 4, 16, 1212) I request early relief to relieve the existing pressure.
('84', 0, 4, 17, 1269) The matter may be treated as very urgent.
('84', 0, 4, 18, 1311) 3. The Superintendent of the camp informs me that when visitors come, one nurse only can be present.
('84', 0, 4, 19, 1412) Hitherto more than one nurse has attended when necessary.
('84', 0, 4, 20, 1470) The Superintendent used his discretion as to the necessity.
('84', 0, 4, 21, 1530) But when difficulty arose I made a reference to the I.G.P. The result was that an order was issued that a doctor in addition may be present.
('84', 0, 4, 22, 1671) I submit that the order has been issued in ignorance or disregard of the condition of the patient.She often requires to be helped by more persons than one.
('84', 0, 4, 23, 1827) Therefore I ask
('84', 0, 5, 24, 1843) 1 Vide the preceding item.
('84', 0, 5, 25, 1870) 2 Vide “Letter to Ardeshir E. Kateli”, 6 1 1944.
('84', 1, 0, 1, 1919) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 1, 1, 2, 1959) that there should be no restriction as to the number of the attendants.
('84', 1, 1, 3, 2031) 4. It would be wrong on my part, if I suppressed the fact that in the facilities being allowed to the patient grace has been sadly lacking.
('84', 1, 1, 4, 2171) The order about the attendants is the most glaring instance of pin pricks, besides being in defeat of the purpose for which attendance during visits of relatives is allowed.
('84', 1, 1, 5, 2345) Again, my three sons are in Poona.
('84', 1, 1, 6, 2380) The eldest, Harilal, who is almost lost to us, was not allowed yesterday, the reason being that the I.G.P. had no instructions to allow him to come again.
('84', 1, 1, 7, 2535) And yet the patient was naturally anxious to meet him.
('84', 1, 1, 8, 2590) To cite one more pin prick, every time visitors who are on the permitted list come, they have to apply to Government Office, Bombay, for permission.
('84', 1, 1, 9, 2739) The consequence is that there is unnecessary delay and heart burning.
('84', 1, 1, 10, 2809) The difficulty, I imagine, arises because neither the Superintendent nor the I.G.P. has any function except that of passing on my requests to Bombay.
('84', 1, 1, 11, 2959) 5. I am aware that Shri Kasturba is a Government patient, and that even as her husband I should have no say about her.
('84', 1, 1, 12, 3078) But, as the Government have been pleased to say that instead of being discharged she is being kept with me in her own interest, perhaps, in interpreting her wishes and feelings, I am doing what the Government would desire and appreciate.
('84', 1, 1, 13, 3316) Her recovery or at least mental peace when she is lingering is common cause between the Government and me.
('84', 1, 1, 14, 3423) Any jar tells on her.
('84', 1, 2, 15, 3445) I am, etc.,
('84', 1, 3, 16, 3457) M. K. GANDHI From a photostat: G.N. 3926

('84', 2, 4, 5, 4199) 3. TALK WITH RAMDAS GANDHI 1
('84', 2, 5, 6, 4228) January 28, 1944
('84', 2, 6, 7, 4245) Mr. Ramdas said that Government was taking unnecessary risk in detaining Mrs. Gandhi.
('84', 2, 6, 8, 4331) The old man (Gandhiji) replied that there was a greater risk in releasing her.
('84', 2, 6, 9, 4410) In case she was released and if she died, Government would be compelled to release him, which they did not like to risk.
('84', 2, 7, 10, 4531) Mr. Ramdas said that it was his impression that Harilal, being an irresponsible man, might give in papers anything about the Palace, and hence Government were reluctant to give Harilal frequent interviews.
('84', 2, 7, 11, 4737) Mr. Gandhi laughed and said: Perhaps I may take advantage of Harilal’s weakness and ask him to do something for me.
('84', 2, 8, 12, 4853) Bombay Secret Abstracts: Home Department, Special Branch (6), File No.
('84', 2, 8, 13, 4924) 76 1, 1943 44
('84', 2, 9, 14, 4938) 4. LETTER TO SECRETARY, HOME DEPARTMENT, GOVERNMENT OF BOMBAY
('84', 2, 10, 15, 5000) DETENTION CAMP, January 31, 1944
('84', 2, 11, 16, 5033) SECRETARY TO THE GOVERNMENT OF BOMBAY (H.D.) BOMBAY
('84', 2, 12, 17, 5085) SIR, I sent on the 27th instant a very urgent letter 2 addressed to the Government of India.
('84', 2, 12, 18, 5178) I am still without a reply.
('84', 2, 12, 19, 5206) The patient is no better.
('84', 2, 12, 20, 5232) The attendants are about to break down.
('84', 2, 12, 21, 5272) Four only can work—
('84', 2, 13, 22, 5292) 1 This is extracted from a letter dated January 29, 1944, addressed to Secretary, Home Department, Government of Bombay, by the Officer in charge, Aga Khan Palace.
('84', 2, 13, 23, 5456) 2Vide “Letter to Additional Secretary, Home Department, Government of India”, 27 1 1944.
('84', 3, 0, 1, 5545) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 3, 1, 2, 5585) two at a time on alternate nights.
('84', 3, 1, 3, 5620) All the four have to work during the day.
('84', 3, 1, 4, 5662) The patient herself is getting restive, and inquires: “When will Dr. Dinshaw come?” May I know as early as may be—even tomorrow, if possible: 1. Whether Shri Kanu Gandhi can come as full time nurse, 2. whether Dr. Dinshaw’s services may be enlisted for the present, and 3. whether the restriction on the number of attendants during visits can be removed.
('84', 3, 1, 5, 6017) I hope it may not have to be said that the relief came too late.
('84', 3, 2, 6, 6082) I am, etc., M. K. GANDHI

('84', 3, 7, 12, 6412) 228, the addressee’s reply dated February 3, 1944, read: (1) Government have agreed to Kanu Gandhi staying in for the purpose of helping in nursing Mrs. Gandhi on condition that he agrees to be bound by the same regulations as other security prisoners in the detention camp.
('84', 3, 7, 13, 6687) Government consider that with Kanu Gandhi staying in, the nursing assistance provided should be adequate and they cannot agree to any requests for further assistance.
('84', 3, 7, 14, 6854) (2) Government have decided that no outside doctors should be allowed unless the Government medical officer considers that it is absolutely necessary for medical reasons.
('84', 3, 7, 15, 7025) (3) Interviews with near relatives have been sanctioned for Mrs. Gandhi.
('84', 3, 7, 16, 7098) While Government have no objection to your being present during those interviews, they consider that other inmates should not be present except to the extent demanded by the condition of Mrs. Gandhi’s health.

('84', 4, 1, 5, 8205) If the permission is granted, it should be of a general character.
('84', 4, 1, 6, 8272) She is losing will power and I have to judge between a multiplicity of advice so long as I am permitted to have responsibility for her peace of mind, which is about all that is possible at this stage.

('84', 4, 3, 8, 8523) 6. LETTER TO VIJAYALAKSHMI PANDIT 1
('84', 4, 4, 9, 8559) AGA KHAN PALACE, February 1, 1944
('84', 4, 5, 10, 8593) THROUGH THE BOMBAY GOVERNMENT
('84', 4, 6, 11, 8623) DEAR DAUGHTER, Your letter 2 reached me yesterday about 2 p.m.
('84', 4, 6, 12, 8686) What can I write to you?
('84', 4, 6, 13, 8711) The news which I read in the papers was read out by me to Ba.
('84', 4, 6, 14, 8773) Thereupon with tears in her eyes Ba said: “Oh God (Rama) I am at death’s door and I am not taken away while Ranjit is taken away!
('84', 4, 6, 15, 8903) What will happen to Sarup?” I did not feel like that.
('84', 4, 6, 16, 8957) You cannot become helpless.
('84', 4, 6, 17, 8985) You are a brave daughter of a brave father,and brave sister of a similarly brave brother.
('84', 4, 6, 18, 9075) The disease of Ranjit was such that he had to go before his time.
('84', 4, 6, 19, 9141) His body was not meant to suffer jail life.
('84', 4, 6, 20, 9185) But all these are my imaginations.
('84', 4, 6, 21, 9220) The fact is that God gives you birth and whenever He likes He takes you up.
('84', 4, 6, 22, 9296) And this is all for the body.
('84', 4, 6, 23, 9326) Soul, however, neither takes birth nor dies.
('84', 4, 6, 24, 9371) You had married a soul named Ranjit.
('84', 4, 6, 25, 9408) You can never become a widow.
('84', 4, 6, 26, 9438) You have rightly stated that you will represent all the qualities of Ranjit.
('84', 4, 6, 27, 9515) May God satisfy this wish of yours.
('84', 4, 6, 28, 9551) You should look after your body and be engrossed in your duty.
('84', 4, 6, 29, 9614) It is good that Rita 3 is with you.
('84', 4, 6, 30, 9650) Please send my blessings to Chand 4 and Tara 5. Also give my blessings to Krishna 6, Feroze 7 and
('84', 4, 7, 31, 9748) 1 Originally written in Hindi, this is a translation by the jail authorities.
('84', 4, 7, 32, 9826) 2 Dated January 15, conveying the news of her husband’s death 3 Rita, addressee’s daughter 4 Chandralekha, addressee’s daughter 5 Nayantara, addressee’s daughter 6 Krishna Hutheesing, addressee’s sister 7 Feroze and Indira Gandhi
('84', 5, 0, 1, 10056) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 5, 1, 2, 10096) Indu 1. May God bless you.
('84', 5, 1, 3, 10123) Your letter has been delivered to me against the rules 2. And this will also be delivered against the rules.
('84', 5, 1, 4, 10232) This is my first letter from jail.
('84', 5, 1, 5, 10267) Ba has been counting her days in the hope of death.
('84', 5, 2, 6, 10319) Blessings to you from us both,
('84', 5, 3, 7, 10350) SHRIMATI VIJAYALAKSHMI PANDIT 2 MUKHERJI ROAD ALLAHABAD

('84', 5, 5, 10, 10490) 7. LETTER TO SECRETARY, HOME DEPARTMENT, GOVERNMENT OF BOMBAY
('84', 5, 6, 11, 10552) DETENTION CAMP, February 3, 1944
('84', 5, 7, 12, 10585) SECRETARY TO THE GOVERNMENT OF BOMBAY BOMBAY
('84', 5, 8, 13, 10630) SIR, Shri Kasturba asked me yesterday when Dr. Dinshaw was coming, and whether a vaidya (Ayurvedic physician) could see her and give her some drugs.
('84', 5, 8, 14, 10779) I told her, I was trying for both but that we were prisoners and could not have things as we liked.
('84', 5, 8, 15, 10879) She has since been repeatedly asking me whether I could not do something to hasten matters.
('84', 5, 8, 16, 10971) She had a restless night again.
('84', 5, 8, 17, 11003) This is, of course, nothing new for her at present.
('84', 5, 8, 18, 11055) I request immediate orders about Dr. Dinshaw and Vaidyaraj Sharma of Lahore.
('84', 5, 8, 19, 11132) The latter will be some time coming.
('84', 5, 8, 20, 11169) But Dr. Dinshaw can come even today if authority is given for calling him in.
('84', 5, 8, 21, 11247) I must confess that I do not understand this delay when a patient’s life is hanging in the balance and may be saved by timely
('84', 5, 9, 22, 11373) 1 Feroze and Indira Gandhi 2 Allowing security prisoners to correspond only with family members
('84', 6, 0, 1, 11469) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 7
('84', 6, 1, 2, 11514) After all, for a patient alleviation of pain is as important as the highest matters of State.
('84', 6, 2, 3, 11608) I am, etc., M. K. GANDHI

('84', 7, 7, 9, 12993) 10. NOTE TO INSPECTOR GENERAL OF PRISONS, BOMBAY 2
('84', 7, 8, 10, 13044) DETENTION CAMP, February 11, 1944 The responsibility for bringing in a non allopath assistant would be wholly mine, and the Government shall stand absolved from responsibility for any untoward result following such treatment.
('84', 7, 8, 11, 13270) I am not sure that I shall accept the advice that such vaidyas or hakims may give.
('84', 7, 8, 12, 13353) But if I do, and if the prescription is ineffective, I would like to reserve the right to revert to present treatment.
('84', 7, 9, 13, 13472) M. K. GANDHI
('84', 7, 10, 14, 13485) Gandhiji’s Correspondence with the Government, p.

('84', 8, 1, 2, 13999) 11. LETTER TO INSPECTOR GENERAL OF PRISONS, BOMBAY
('84', 8, 2, 3, 14050) Immediate DETENTION CAMP, February 14, 1944 THE INSPECTOR GENERAL OF PRISONS POONA
('84', 8, 3, 4, 14133) SIR, I told you yesterday that Shri Kasturba was so bad during the night that Dr. Nayyar got frightened and awakened Dr. Gilder.
('84', 8, 3, 5, 14262) I felt that she was going.
('84', 8, 3, 6, 14289) The doctors were naturally helpless.
('84', 8, 3, 7, 14326) Dr. Nayyar had, therefore, to wake up the Superintendent who kindly phoned the Vaidyaraj.
('84', 8, 3, 8, 14416) It was then about 1 a.m.
('84', 8, 3, 9, 14441) Had he been on the premises he would certainly have given relief.
('84', 8, 3, 10, 14507) I, therefore, asked you to let him stay at the camp during the night.
('84', 8, 3, 11, 14577) But you informed me, theGovernment orders did not cover night stay.
('84', 8, 3, 12, 14645) The Vaidyaraj, however, you said, could be called in during the night.
('84', 8, 3, 13, 14716) I pointed out the obvious danger of delay but you were sorry, the orders would not allow you to go further.
('84', 8, 3, 14, 14824) In vain I argued that the Government having given the authority to call in Vaidyaraj on condition that I absolved them from responsibility for any untoward result of the vaidic treatment, they could not contemplate any restriction on the duration of the physician’s stay at the camp so long as it was thought necessary in the interest of the patient.
('84', 8, 3, 15, 15175) In view of your rejection of my request, I had to trouble the Vaidyaraj to rest in his car in front of the gate so that in case of need he might be called in.
('84', 8, 3, 16, 15334) He very humanly consented.
('84', 8, 3, 17, 15361) He had to be called in and he was able to bring the desired relief.
('84', 8, 3, 18, 15429) The crisis has not passed as yet.
('84', 8, 3, 19, 15463) I, therefore, repeat my request and ask for immediate relief.
('84', 8, 3, 20, 15525) I would like, if I can, to avoid the last night’s experience.
('84', 8, 3, 21, 15587) I do wish that the vexations caused by the delay in granting my requests about the patient’s treatment came to an end.
('84', 8, 3, 22, 15706) Both Dr. Mehta and the Vaidyaraj were permitted to come in after protracted delay.
('84', 8, 3, 23, 15789) Precious time was lost making recovery more uncertain than it was.
('84', 8, 3, 24, 15856) I hope you will be able to secure the necessary authority for the vaid’s stay in the camp during night, if the patient’s condition requires it.
('84', 8, 3, 25, 16000) The patient needs constant and continuous attention.
('84', 8, 3, 26, 16053) I am, Yours, etc., M. K. GANDHI From a photostat: G.N. 3932; also Bombay Secret Abstracts: Home Department, Special Branch, File No.
('84', 9, 0, 1, 16186) 10 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 9, 1, 2, 16227) 12. LETTER TO INSPECTOR GENERAL OF PRISONS, BOMBAY
('84', 9, 2, 3, 16278) Immediate DETENTION CAMP,
('84', 9, 3, 4, 16304) February 16, 1944
('84', 9, 4, 5, 16322) THE INSPECTOR GENERAL OF PRISONS
('84', 9, 6, 6, 16355) SIR, This is in continuation of my letter 1 of the 14th instant.
('84', 9, 6, 7, 16420) When I asked 2 for Vaidyaraj and took upon myself the responsibility 3 of changing Shri Kasturba’s treatment, and absolved the Government physician of all responsibility, I naturally took for granted that the Vaidyaraj would be allowed such facilities as would in his opinion be necessary for carrying out his treatment.
('84', 9, 6, 8, 16741) The patient’s nights are much worse than her days and it is essentially at night that constant attendance is necessary.
('84', 9, 6, 9, 16861) The Vaidyaraj considers himself handicapped in his treatment of the case under the present arrangement.
('84', 9, 6, 10, 16965) In order to be within immediate call, he has been good enough to sleep in his car outside the gate of this camp for the last three nights, and every night he has had to be called up at least once.
('84', 9, 6, 11, 17162) This is an unnatural state of things and, though he seems to have infinite capacity for suffering inconvenience for the sake of the patient, I may not take undue advantage of his generous nature.
('84', 9, 6, 12, 17358) Besides, it means disturbing the Superintendent and his staff (in fact the whole camp) once or more often during the night.
('84', 9, 6, 13, 17482) For instance, last night she suddenly developed fever with rigor.
('84', 9, 6, 14, 17548) The Vaidyaraj, who had left the premises at 10.30 p.m., had to be called in at 12 midnight.
('84', 9, 6, 15, 17640) I had to request him to leave her soon afterwards, although he would have liked to have stayed with her longer, because so long as he stayed in, it would have meant keeping the Superintendent and his staff awake which might have been even for the whole night.
('84', 9, 6, 16, 17900) I would not do this even for saving my life long partner especially when I know that a
('84', 9, 7, 17, 17987) 1 Vide the preceding item.
('84', 9, 7, 18, 18014) 2Vide “Letter to Secretary, Home Department, Government of India”, 27 1 1944, “Silence DAy Note to Superintendent Detention Camp”, 31 1 1944 and “Note to Inspector General of Prisons, Bombay”, 11 2 1944. 3 ibid
('84', 10, 0, 1, 18225) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 11
('84', 10, 1, 2, 18271) humane way is open.
('84', 10, 1, 3, 18291) As I have said already, the Vaidyaraj considers it necessary to be in constant attendance on the patient.
('84', 10, 1, 4, 18397) He varies the drugs from moment to moment as the patient’s condition requires.
('84', 10, 1, 5, 18476) Gilder’s and Nayyar’s assistance is at my disposal all the time—they are more than friends and would do everything in their power for the patient.
('84', 10, 1, 6, 18623) But, as I have said in my last letter, they cannot help while treatment of a wholly different nature from theirs is going on.
('84', 10, 1, 7, 18749) Besides, being in its very nature impracticable, such a course would be unjust to the patient, to the Vaidyaraj and to themselves.
('84', 10, 1, 8, 18880) I, therefore, submit below the following three alternative proposals: I. Vaidyaraj should be permitted to remain in the camp day and night so long as he considers it necessary in the interests of the patient.
('84', 10, 1, 9, 19089) If the Government cannot agree to this, they may release the patient on parole to enable her to receive the full benefit of the physician’s treatment.
('84', 10, 1, 10, 19240) If neither of these two proposals are acceptable to the Government, I request that I be relieved of the responsibility of looking after the patient.
('84', 10, 1, 11, 19389) If I as her husband cannot procure for her the help she wants or that I think necessary, I ask for my removal to any other place of detention that the Government may choose.
('84', 10, 1, 12, 19563) I must not be made a helpless witness of the agonies the patient is passing through.
('84', 10, 1, 13, 19648) The Government have kindly permitted Dr. Mehta to visit the patient at her repeated requests.
('84', 10, 1, 14, 19742) His help is valuable, but he does not prescribe drugs.
('84', 10, 1, 15, 19797) She needs the physical therapy given by him which soothes her greatly but she cannot do without drug treatment either.
('84', 10, 1, 16, 19916) Drugs can only be prescribed by the doctors or the Vaidyaraj.
('84', 10, 1, 17, 19978) The doctors’ treatment has already been suspended.

('84', 12, 1, 2, 22463) 14. LETTER TO LORD WAVELL
('84', 12, 2, 3, 22489) February 17, 1944
('84', 12, 3, 4, 22507) DEAR FRIEND, Although I have not had the pleasure of meeting you, I address you on purpose as “dear friend”.
('84', 12, 3, 5, 22616) I am looked upon by the representatives of the British Government as a great, if not the greatest, enemy of the British.
('84', 12, 3, 6, 22737) Since I regard myself as a friend and servant of humanity including the British, in token of my goodwill I call you, the foremost representative of the British in India, my “friend”.
('84', 12, 3, 7, 22920) 2. I have received in common with some others, a notice informing me, for the first time, why I am detained and conferring on me the right of representation against my detention.
('84', 12, 3, 8, 23099) I have duly sent my reply 1, but I have as yet heard nothing from the Government.
('84', 12, 3, 9, 23181) A reminder 2, too, has gone after a wait of thirteen days.
('84', 12, 3, 10, 23240) 3. I have said some only have received notices because out of the six of us in this camp, only three have received them.
('84', 12, 3, 11, 23361) I presume that all will receive them in due course.
('84', 12, 3, 12, 23413) But my mind is filled with the suspicion that the notices have been sent as a matter of form only, and not with any intention to do justice.
('84', 12, 3, 13, 23554) I do not wish to burden this letter with argument.
('84', 12, 3, 14, 23605) I repeat what I said 3 in the correspondence with your predecessor, that the Congress and I are wholly innocent of the charges brought against us.
('84', 12, 3, 15, 23752) Nothing but an impartial tribunal to investigate the Government case, and the Congress case against the Government, will bring out the truth.
('84', 12, 4, 16, 23894) 4. The speeches recently made on behalf of the Governm ent in the Assembly on the release motion, 4 and on the gagging
('84', 12, 5, 17, 24013) 1Vide “Letter to Secretary, Home Department, Government of India”, 24 1 1944 and “Letter to Secretary, Home Department, Government of India”, 7 2 1944. 2 ibid 3 In letters to Additional Secretary, Home Department, Government of India; vide “Letter to Secretary, Home Department, Government of India”, 15 7 1943 4 On February 8, the Central Legislative Assembly rejected Lalchand Navalrai’s resolution for releasing political prisoners.
('84', 12, 5, 18, 24449) In his speech, Sir Reginald Maxwell, Home Member, had said that “if Government were asked to release the Congress leaders, they must be assured that the results would be beneficial to India
('84', 13, 0, 1, 24639) 14 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 13, 1, 2, 24680) order 1 on Shri Sarojini Devi, I consider to be playing with fire.
('84', 13, 1, 3, 24747) I distinguishbetween defeat of Japanese arms and Allied victory.
('84', 13, 1, 4, 24812) The latter must carry with it the deliverance of India from the foreign yoke.
('84', 13, 1, 5, 24890) The spirit; of India demands complete freedom from all foreign dominance and would, therefore, resist Japanese yoke equally with British or any other.
('84', 13, 1, 6, 25041) The Congress represents that spirit in full measure.
('84', 13, 1, 7, 25094) It has grown to be an institution whose roots have gone deep down into the Indian soil.
('84', 13, 1, 8, 25182) I was, therefore, staggered to read that Government were satisfied with things as they were going.
('84', 13, 1, 9, 25281) Had they not got from among the Indian people the men and money they wanted?
('84', 13, 1, 10, 25358) Was not the Government machinery running smooth?
('84', 13, 1, 11, 25407) This self satisfaction bodes ill for Britain, India and the world, if it does not quickly give place to a searching of hearts in British high places.
('84', 13, 1, 12, 25557) 5. Promises for the future are valueless in the face of the world struggle in which the fortune of all nations and therefore of the whole of humanity is involved.
('84', 13, 1, 13, 25720) Present performance is the peremptory need of the moment, if the war is to end in world peace and not be a preparation for another war bloodier than the present, if indeed there can be a bloodier.
('84', 13, 1, 14, 25917) Therefore real war effort must mean satisfaction of India’s demand.
('84', 13, 1, 15, 25985) “Quit India” only gives vivid expression to that demand and has not the sinister and poisonous meaning attributed to it without warrant by the Government of India.
('84', 13, 1, 16, 26149) The expression is charged with the friendliest feeling for Britain in terms of the whole of humanity.
('84', 13, 1, 17, 26251) 6. I have done.
('84', 13, 1, 18, 26267) I thought that, if I claim to be a friend of the British, as I do, nothing should deter me from sharing my deepest thoughts with you.
('84', 13, 1, 19, 26401) It is no pleasure for me to be in this camp, where all my creature comforts are supplied without any effort on my part, when I know that millions outside are starving for want of food.
('84', 13, 2, 20, 26586) and to war effort” (The Indian Annual Register, 1944, Vol. I, p.

('84', 16, 1, 2, 30548) 17. REQUEST TO GOVERNMENT ON KASTURBA’S FUNERAL 1
('84', 16, 2, 3, 30598) [February 22, 1944] 2
('84', 16, 3, 4, 30620) 1. Body should be handed over to my sons and relatives which would mean a public funeral without interference from Government.
('84', 16, 3, 5, 30747) 2. If that is not possible, funeral should take place as in the case of Mahadev Desai 3; and if the Government will allow relatives only to be present at the funeral, I shall not be able to accept the privilege unless all friends who are as good as relatives to me are also allowed to be present.
('84', 16, 3, 6, 31044) 3. If this also is not acceptable to the Government, then those who have been allowed to visit her will be sent away by me and only those who are in the camp (detenus) will attend the funeral.
('84', 16, 3, 7, 31237) It has been, as you will be able to bear witness, my great anxiety not to make any political capital out of this most trying illness of my life companion.
('84', 16, 3, 8, 31392) But I have always wanted whatever the Government did, to be done with good grace which, I am afraid, has been hitherto lacking.
('84', 16, 3, 9, 31520) It is not too much to expect that now that the patient is no more, whatever the Government decide about the funeral will be done with good grace.

('84', 17, 2, 3, 32307) DETENTION CAMP, February 26, 1944
('84', 17, 3, 4, 32341) THE ADDITIONAL SECRETARY HOME DEPARTMENT
('84', 17, 4, 5, 32382) SIR, I have read the speech of the Hon’ble the Home Member in the Assembly on the debate 1 arising out of the ban on Shrimati Sarojini Devi.
('84', 17, 4, 6, 32523) The speech has reference, among other things, to the correspondence between Shrimati Mirabai and myself and the Government’s refusal to publish that correspondence.
('84', 17, 4, 7, 32688) The following is the relevant portion of the speech:
('84', 17, 5, 8, 32741) She (Shrimati Sarojini Devi) refers, and the point has been raised in this debate, to a letter said to have been written 2 by Miss Slade to Mr. Gandhi and Mr. Gandhi’s reply 3 and I have been asked why no publicity was given to that letter.
('84', 17, 5, 9, 32982) That letter was written and answered long before the Congress leaders were placed in detention.
('84', 17, 5, 10, 33078) If Mr. Gandhi had wished to give publicity to that letter, he was perfectly free to do it himself.
('84', 17, 5, 11, 33177) But it was a confidential communication addressed to him, and I do not see any reason why Government should disclose a communication of that nature.
('84', 17, 5, 12, 33326) I might say that it would not help the Congress case, if it were disclosed.
('84', 17, 6, 13, 33402) Then it has been said that Mrs. Naidu wishes to defend the Congress from the implication of being pro Japanese.
('84', 17, 6, 14, 33514) Government have never at any time, either here or at home, charged the Congress with being pro Japanese.
('84', 17, 6, 15, 33619) Well, the allusion to that in the booklet called Congress Responsibility refers to a statement quoted from Pandit Nehru himself.
('84', 17, 6, 16, 33748) I have not the time to quote it at length but if Hon’ble Members will refer to the quotation given in the Congress Responsibility pamphlet, they will easily find the passage in question.
('84', 17, 6, 17, 33935) Assuming that the report is correct, it makes strange reading.
('84', 17, 6, 18, 33998) Firstly, as to the non publication by me of this correspondence
('84', 17, 7, 19, 34062) 1 Vide 5th footnote of “Letter to Lord Wavell”, 17 2 1944. 2Vide “Letter to Additional Secretary, Home Department, Government of India” sub title [I} and [J], 5 7 1943. 3 ibid
('84', 18, 0, 1, 34238) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 19
('84', 18, 1, 2, 34284) between Shrimati Mirabai and myself, surely the publication wasunnecessary until the charge of my being pro Japanese was spread abroad.
('84', 18, 1, 3, 34420) Secondly, why do the Government feel squeamish about publishing “confidential” correspondence when both the correspondents have specially invited publication?
('84', 18, 2, 4, 34579) Thirdly, I do not understand the reluctance of the Government to publish the correspondence when, according to the Hon’ble the Home Member, the correspondence will not serve the Congress case.
('84', 18, 2, 5, 34772) Fourthly, the Government seem intentionally or unintentionally to have suppressed the very relevant fact that Shrimati Mirabai wrote to Lord Linlithgow drawing attention to the libellous propaganda in the London Press at the time, containing allegations that I was pro Japanese, which allegations she invited him to repudiate.
('84', 18, 2, 6, 35099) Her letter 1 to Lord Linlithgow enclosed copies of the correspondence referred to and asked for its publication.
('84', 18, 2, 7, 35212) It was written on December 24, long before the Government publication entitled Congress Responsibility which bears the date February 13, 1943, appeared.
('84', 18, 2, 8, 35365) Fifthly, as to Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru’s alleged statement before the Working Committee, I have already made it clear in my reply 2 to the Government pamphlet that it was wholly wrong on their part to make use of the unauthorized notes of the discussions at the Allahabad meeting of the Working Committee, after Pandit Nehru’s emphatic repudiation 3 published in the daily Press.
('84', 18, 2, 9, 35745) It is difficult for me to understand the Hon’ble the Home Member’s speech and the Government’s persistence in making charges and innuendoes against Congress people whom they have put in custody and thus effectively prevented from answering those charges.
('84', 18, 2, 10, 36000) I hope, therefore, that the Government will at the very least see their way to publish the correspondence referred to, namely,

('84', 20, 2, 3, 38576) AGA KHAN PALACE, February 27, 1944 I feel much worried about you.
('84', 20, 2, 4, 38642) You are a class by yourself.

('84', 20, 4, 24, 39812) 21. LETTER TO ADDITIONAL SECRETARY, HOME DEPARTMENT, GOVERNMENT OF INDIA
('84', 20, 5, 25, 39885) DETENTION CAMP, March 4, 1944 THE ADDITIONAL SECRETARY TO THE GOVERNMENT OF INDIA (HOME DEPARTMENT), NEW DELHI
('84', 20, 6, 26, 39996) SIR, In reply to a question in the Assembly, the Hon’ble the Home Member is reported to have said: 2
('84', 20, 7, 27, 40097) 1 Gurudayal Malik 2 Reginald Maxwell was answering K. C. Neyogi in the Central Legislative Assembly on March 2.
('84', 21, 0, 1, 40209) 22 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 21, 1, 2, 40250) The provision for the expenses of Mr. Gandhi and those detained with him in the Aga Khan’s Palace amounted to about Rs. 550 a month.
('84', 21, 1, 3, 40383) In my letter 1 to you dated 26th October last I remarked as follows:
('84', 21, 2, 4, 40452) The huge place in which I am being detained with a big 2 guard around me, I hold to be waste of public funds.
('84', 21, 2, 5, 40562) I should be quite content to pass my days in any prison.
('84', 21, 2, 6, 40619) The Hon’ble the Home Member’s reply quoted above is a sharp reminder to me that I should have followed up the remark just referred to by me.
('84', 21, 2, 7, 40760) But it is never too late to mend.
('84', 21, 2, 8, 40794) I, therefore, take up the question now.
('84', 21, 2, 9, 40834) The expenses on behalf of my companions and me are not merely Rs. 550 per month.
('84', 21, 2, 10, 40915) The rent of this huge place (of which only a portion is open to us) and the expense of maintaining the big outer guard and an inner staff consisting of Superintendent, jamadar and sepoys have got to be added.
('84', 21, 2, 11, 41124) And to this a large squad of convicts from Yeravda to serve the inmates and to look after the garden.
('84', 21, 2, 12, 41226) Virtually the whole of this expense is, from my point of view, wholly unnecessary; and when people are dying of starvation, it is almost a crime against Indian humanity.
('84', 21, 2, 13, 41396) I ask that my companions and I be removed to any regular prison Government may choose.
('84', 21, 2, 14, 41483) In conclusion, I cannot conceal from myself the sad thought that the whole expense of thiscomes from taxes collected from the dumb millions of India.
('84', 21, 3, 15, 41633) I am, etc., M. K. GANDHI Gandhiji’s Correspondence with the Government, pp.

('84', 21, 6, 19, 41969) But truth demands this letter.

('84', 22, 1, 2, 42186) According to the newspapers, Mr. Butler 1 is reported to have said in the House of Commons on 2nd March, 1944:

('84', 22, 3, 4, 42715) the prison authorities that, if I could not procure for the patient the help that she wanted or I thought necessary, I should be separated from her, I ought not to be made a helpless witness of the agonies she was passing through.

('84', 24, 2, 3, 46673) DETENTION CAMP, March 7, 1944
('84', 24, 3, 4, 46703) DEAR GENERAL CANDY 1, Pray accept my deep sympathy in your bereavement.
('84', 24, 3, 5, 46775) I know from my own recent experience what the death of a life long partner must mean to the survivor.

('84', 24, 6, 8, 46936) 24. LETTER.
('84', 24, 6, 9, 46948) TO LORD WAVELL
('84', 24, 7, 10, 46963) March 9, 1944
('84', 24, 8, 11, 46977) DEAR FRIEND, I must thank you for your prompt reply 2 to my letter of 17th February.
('84', 24, 8, 12, 47062) At the outset, I send you and Lady Wavell my thanks for your kind condolences on the death of my wife.
('84', 24, 8, 13, 47165) Though for her sake I have welcomed her death as bringing freedom from living agony, I feel the loss more than I had thought I should.
('84', 24, 8, 14, 47300) We were a couple outside the ordinary.
('84', 24, 8, 15, 47339) It was in 1906 that after mutual consent and after unconscious trials we definitely adopted self restraint as a rule of life.
('84', 24, 8, 16, 47465) To my great joy this knit us together as never before.
('84', 24, 8, 17, 47520) We ceased to be two different entities.
('84', 24, 8, 18, 47560) Without my wishing it, she chose to lose herself in me.
('84', 24, 8, 19, 47616) The result was she became truly my better half.
('84', 24, 8, 20, 47664) She was a woman always of very strong will which, in our early days, I used to mistake for obstinacy.
('84', 24, 8, 21, 47766) But that strong will enabled her to become quite unwittingly my teacher in the art and practice of non violent non co operation.
('84', 24, 8, 22, 47895) The practice began with my own family.
('84', 24, 8, 23, 47934) When I introduced it in 1906, in the political field, it came to be known by the more comprehensive and specially coined name of satyagraha.
('84', 24, 8, 24, 48075) Whenthe course of Indian imprisonment commenced in South Africa, Shri Kasturba was among the civil resisters.
('84', 24, 8, 25, 48185) She went through greater physical trials than I. Although she had gone through several
('84', 24, 9, 26, 48272) 1 Surgeon General, Government of Bombay 2 Vide footnote 1 of “Letter to Lord Wavell”, 17 2 1944.
('84', 25, 0, 1, 48369) 26 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 25, 1, 2, 48410) imprisonments, she did not take kindly to the present incarceration during which all creature comforts were at her disposal.
('84', 25, 1, 3, 48535) My arrest simultaneously with that of many others, and her own immediately following, gave her a great shock and embittered her.
('84', 25, 1, 4, 48664) She was wholly unprepared for my arrest.
('84', 25, 1, 5, 48705) I had assured her that the Government trusted my non violence, and would not arrest me unless I courted arrest myself.
('84', 25, 1, 6, 48824) Indeed the nervous shock was so great that after her arrest she developed violent diarrhoea and, but for the attention that Dr. Sushila Nayyar, who was arrested at the same time as the deceased, was able to give her, she might have died before joining me in this detention camp.
('84', 25, 1, 7, 49103) My presence soothed her, and the diarrhoea stopped without any further medicament.
('84', 25, 1, 8, 49186) Not so the bitterness.
('84', 25, 1, 9, 49209) It led to fretfulness ending in painfully slow dissolution of the body.
('84', 25, 1, 10, 49281) 2. In the light of the foregoing, you will perhaps understand the pain I felt when I read in the papers the statement made on behalf of the Government, which I hold was an unfortunate departure from truth regarding her who was precious to me beyond measure.
('84', 25, 1, 11, 49539) I ask you please to send for and read the complaint 1 in the matter which I have forwarded to the Additional Secretary to the Government of India (Home Department).
('84', 25, 1, 12, 49704) Truth is said to be the first and the heaviest casualty in war.
('84', 25, 1, 13, 49768) How I wish in this war it could be otherwise in the case of the Allied powers!
('84', 25, 1, 14, 49847) 3. I now come to your address which you delivered before the Legislature and of which you kindly sent me copy.
('84', 25, 1, 15, 49958) When the newspapers containing the address were received, I was by the bedside of the deceased.
('84', 25, 1, 16, 50054) Shri Mirabai read to me the Associated Press report.
('84', 25, 1, 17, 50107) But my mind was elsewhere.
('84', 25, 1, 18, 50134) Therefore the receipt of your speech in a handy form was most welcome.
('84', 25, 1, 19, 50205) I have now read it with all the attention it deserves.
('84', 25, 1, 20, 50260) Having gone through it, I feel drawn to offer a few remarks, all the more so, as you have observed that the views expressed by you “need not be regarded as final”.
('84', 25, 1, 21, 50424) May this letter lead to a re shaping of some of them!
('84', 25, 1, 22, 50478) 4. In the middle of page two, you speak of the welfare of the“Indian peoples”.
('84', 25, 1, 23, 50557) I have seen in some Viceregal pronouncements the inhabitants of India being referred to as the people of India.
('84', 25, 1, 24, 50669) Are the two expressions synonymous?
('84', 25, 2, 25, 50705) 1Vide “Letter to Additional Secretary, Home Department, Government of India”, 4 3 1944
('84', 26, 0, 1, 50792) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 27
('84', 26, 1, 2, 50838) 5. At page thirteen, referring to the attainment of self government by India, you say:
('84', 26, 2, 3, 50925) I am absolutely convinced not only that the above represents the genuine desire of the British people, but that they wish to see an early realization of it.
('84', 26, 2, 4, 51082) It is qualified only at present by an absolute determination to let nothing stand in the way of the earliest possible defeat of Germany and Japan; and by a resolve to see that in the solution of the constitutional problem full account is taken of the interests of those who have loyally supported us in this war and at all other times—the soldiers who have served the common cause; the people who have worked with us; the Rulers and populations of the States to whom we are pledged; the minorities who have trusted us to see that they get a fair deal.
('84', 26, 2, 5, 51634) but until the two main Indian parties at least can come to terms, I do not see any immediate hope of progress.
('84', 26, 2, 6, 51745) Without reasoning out I venture to give my paraphrase of your pronouncement.
('84', 26, 2, 7, 51822) ‘We, the British, shall stand by the Indian soldier whom we have brought into being and trained for consolidating our rule and position in India, and who, by experience, we have found can effectively help us in our wars against other nations.
('84', 26, 2, 8, 52065) We shall also stand by the Rulers of the Indian States, many of whom are our creation, and all of whom owe their present position to us, even when these Rulers curb or actually crush the spirit of the people whom they rule.
('84', 26, 2, 9, 52289) Similarly shall we stand by the minorities whom too we have encouraged and used against the vast majority when the latter have at all attempted to resist our rule.
('84', 26, 2, 10, 52453) It makes no difference that they (the majority) seek to replace it by a rule of the will of people of India taken as a whole.
('84', 26, 2, 11, 52579) And in no case will we transfer power unless Hindus and Muslims come to us with an agreement among themselves.’ The position taken up in the paragraph quoted and interpreted by me is no new thing.
('84', 26, 2, 12, 52776) I regard the situation thus envisaged as hopeless, and I claim in this to represent the thought of the man in the street.
('84', 26, 2, 13, 52898) Out of the contemplation of this hopelessness was born the anguished cry of “Quit India”.
('84', 26, 2, 14, 52988) What I see happening in this country day after day provides a complete vindication of the “Quit India” formula as defined by me in my considered writings.
('84', 26, 2, 15, 53143) 6. I note, as I read your speech, that you do not regard the sponsors of the formula of “Quit India” as outcastes to be shunned by society.
('84', 26, 2, 16, 53283) You believe them to be high minded persons.
('84', 26, 2, 17, 53327) Then treatthem as such and trust their interpretation of their own formula
('84', 27, 0, 1, 53402) 28 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 27, 1, 2, 53443) and you cannot go wrong.
('84', 27, 1, 3, 53468) 7. After developing the Cripps offer you have said at page sixteen in the middle of the paragraph:
('84', 27, 2, 4, 53567) the demand for release of those leaders who are in detention is an utterly barren one until there is some sign on their part of willingness to co operate.
('84', 27, 2, 5, 53722) It needs no consultation with anyone or anything but his own conscience for anyone of those under detention to decide whether he will withdraw from the Quit India resolution and the policy which had such tragic consequences, and will co operate in the great tasks ahead.
('84', 27, 2, 6, 53993) Then again, reverting to the same subject you say on pages nineteen and twenty:
('84', 27, 3, 7, 54073) There is an important element which stands aloof, I recognize how much ability and high mindedness it contains; but I deplore its present policy and methods as barren and unpractical.
('84', 27, 3, 8, 54257) I should like to have the co operation of this element in solving the present and the future problems of India.
('84', 27, 3, 9, 54369) If its leaders feel that they cannot consent to take part in the present Government of India, they may still be able to assist in considering future problems.
('84', 27, 3, 10, 54528) But I see no reason to release those responsible for the declaration of August 8, 1942, until I am convinced that the policy of non co operation and even of obstructions has been withdrawn—not in sack cloth and ashes that helps no one, but in the recognition of a mistaken and unprofitable policy.
('84', 27, 3, 11, 54826) 8. I am surprised that you, an eminent soldier and man of affairs, should hold such an opinion.
('84', 27, 3, 12, 54922) How can the withdrawal of a resolution, arrived at jointly by hundreds of men and women after much debating and careful consideration, be a matter of individual conscience?
('84', 27, 3, 13, 55095) A resolution jointly undertaken can be honourably, conscientiously and properly withdrawn only after joint discussion and deliberation.
('84', 27, 3, 14, 55231) Individual conscience may come into play after this necessary step, not before.
('84', 27, 3, 15, 55311) Is a prisoner ever free to exercise his conscience?
('84', 27, 3, 16, 55363) Is it just and proper to expect him to do so?
('84', 27, 3, 17, 55409) 9. Again, you recognize “much ability and high mindedness” in those who represent the Congress organization and then deplore their present policy and methods as “barren and unpractical”.
('84', 27, 3, 18, 55596) Does not the second statement cancel the first?
('84', 27, 3, 19, 55644) Able and high minded men may come to erroneous decisions, but I have not before heard such people’s policy and methods being described as “barren and unpractical”.
('84', 27, 3, 20, 55808) Is it not up to you to discuss the pros and cons of their policy with them before pronouncing judgment, especially when they are also admittedly representatives of millions of their people?
('84', 27, 3, 21, 55998) Does it
('84', 28, 0, 1, 56006) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 29
('84', 28, 1, 2, 56052) become an all powerful Government to be afraid of the consequences of releasing unarmed men and women with a backing only of men and women equally unarmed and even pledged to non violence?
('84', 28, 1, 3, 56241) Moreover why should you hesitate to know their minds and reactions?
('84', 28, 1, 4, 56309) 10. Then you have talked of the “tragic consequences” of the “Quit India” resolution.
('84', 28, 1, 5, 56395) I have said enough in my reply 1 to the Government pamphlet Congress Responsibility, etc., combating the charge that the Congress was responsible for those consequences.
('84', 28, 1, 6, 56565) I commend the pamphlet and my reply to your attention, if you have not already seen them.
('84', 28, 1, 7, 56655) Here I would just like to emphasize what I have already said.
('84', 28, 1, 8, 56717) Had Government stayed action till they had studied my speeches and those of the members of the Working Committee, history would have been written differently.
('84', 28, 1, 9, 56876) 11. You have made much of the fact that your Executive Council is predominantly Indian.
('84', 28, 1, 10, 56964) Surely their being Indians no more makes them representatives of India than non Indians.
('84', 28, 1, 11, 57053) Conversely it is quite conceivable that a non Indian may be a true representative of India, if he is elected by the vote of the Indian people.
('84', 28, 1, 12, 57196) It would give no satisfaction even if the head of the Indian Government was a distinguished Indian not chosen by the free vote of the people.
('84', 28, 1, 13, 57338) 12. Even you, I am sorry, have fallen into the common error of describing the Indian forces as having been recruited by “voluntary enlistment”.
('84', 28, 1, 14, 57482) A person who takes to soldiering as a profession will enlist himself wherever he gets his market wage.
('84', 28, 1, 15, 57585) Voluntary enlistment has come to bear by association a meaning much higher than that which attaches to an enlistment like that of the Indian soldier.
('84', 28, 1, 16, 57735) Were those who carried out the orders at the Jallianwala massacre volunteers?
('84', 28, 1, 17, 57813) The very Indian soldiers who have been taken out of India and are showing unexampled bravery will be ready to point their rifles unerringly at their own countrymen at the orders of the British Government, their employers.
('84', 28, 1, 18, 58035) Will they deserve the honourable name of volunteers?
('84', 28, 1, 19, 58088) 13. You are flying all over India.
('84', 28, 1, 20, 58123) You have not hesitated to go among the skeletons 2 of Bengal.
('84', 28, 1, 21, 58185) May I suggest an interruptionin your scheduled flights and a descent upon Ahmednagar and the Aga Khan’s Palace in order to probe the hearts of your captives?
('84', 28, 2, 22, 58343) 1 Vide “Letter to Additional Secretary, Home Department, Government of India”, 5 7 1943. 2 The reference is to the Bengal famine.
('84', 29, 0, 1, 58473) 30 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 29, 1, 2, 58514) all friends of the British, however much we may criticize the British Government and system in India.
('84', 29, 1, 3, 58616) If you can but trust, you will find us to be the greatest helpers in the fight against Nazism, Fascism, Japanism and the like.
('84', 29, 1, 4, 58743) 14. Now I revert to your letter of the 25th February.
('84', 29, 1, 5, 58797) Shri Mirabai and I have received replies to our representations.
('84', 29, 1, 6, 58862) The remaining inmates have received their notices.
('84', 29, 1, 7, 58913) The reply received by me I regard as a mockery; the one received by Shri Mirabai is an insult.
('84', 29, 1, 8, 59008) According to the report of the Home Member’s answer to a question in the Central Assembly, the replies received by us seem to be no replies.
('84', 29, 1, 9, 59149) He is reported to have said that the stage “for the review of the cases had not yet arrived.
('84', 29, 1, 10, 59242) Government at present were only receiving representations from prisoners.” If the representations in reply to the Government notices are to be considered merely by the executive that imprisoned them without trial, it will amount to a farce and an eye wash, meant perhaps for foreign consumption, but not as an indication of a desire to do justice.

('84', 29, 1, 16, 59911) Her parents, recognizing her urge to come to me, gave her their full blessings.
('84', 29, 1, 17, 59991) She spends her time in the service of the masses.
('84', 29, 1, 18, 60041) She went to Orissa at my request to understand the plight of the people of that benighted land.
('84', 29, 1, 19, 60137) That Government was hourly expecting Japanese invasion.
('84', 29, 1, 20, 60193) Papers were to be removed or burnt, and withdrawal of the civil authority from the coast was being contemplated.

('84', 29, 1, 23, 60616) It, therefore, baffles me to understand her incarceration.The only reason for burying her alive, so far as I can see, is that she has committed the crime of associating herself with me.

('84', 31, 4, 9, 63571) 26. LETTER TO ADDITIONAL SECRETARY, HOME DEPARTMENT, GOVERNMENT OF INDIA
('84', 31, 5, 10, 63644) DETENTION CAMP, March 20, 1944
('84', 31, 6, 11, 63675) THE ADDITIONAL SECRETARY GOVERNMENT OF INDIA (H.D.) NEW DELHI
('84', 31, 7, 12, 63737) SIR, I have read with painful interest the answer given on behalf of the Government in the Central Assembly about the facilities, medical and otherwise, given to my deceased wife.
('84', 31, 7, 13, 63917) I had hoped for a better response to my letter 1 of 4th March, 1944, assuming that it was in Government’s hands when the answer was given.
('84', 31, 7, 14, 64056) Beyond the admission 2 that the deceased was never offered release, the statement makes no amends for the misrepresentations pointed out in that letter.
('84', 31, 7, 15, 64209) On the contrary, it adds one more by stating that “trained nurses were made available.
('84', 31, 7, 16, 64296) .” No trained nurse was asked for or supplied.

('84', 32, 1, 2, 64744) a week because she found herself ill fitted for the work entrusted to her.
('84', 32, 1, 3, 64819) Only then, and after some further delay and repeated requests about Shri Kanu Gandhi, were the two allowed to come.
('84', 32, 1, 4, 64935) The facilities have been recited as if they had been granted promptly and willingly.
('84', 32, 1, 5, 65020) The fact is that most of them, when not refused, were granted as if grudgingly and when it was almost too late.

('84', 34, 1, 5, 69522) Thus there was an interval of more than eight weeks between the first request for non allopathic aid and of actual bringing in of that aid.Before Vaidyaraj Sharma came, I had been asked to give a written undertaking 2 (which I gladly did) that I absolved the Government of all responsibility about the result of his treatment (Appendix H).
('84', 34, 1, 6, 69862) The Vaidyaraj was thus in sole charge of the case for the time being.
('84', 34, 1, 7, 69932) One would have thought that a physician in sole charge of a patient would have all such facilities of visiting and watching the patient as he considered necessary.
('84', 34, 1, 8, 70096) And yet there was no end to the difficulties in getting these facilities for him.
('84', 34, 1, 9, 70178) These have been alluded to in the enclosure 3 to my letter 4 of March 4, 1944, and in Appendix G 5. .
('84', 34, 1, 10, 70280) All this time the patient was passing through great sufferings and her condition was deteriorating so rapidly that every delay weighed against chances of her recovery.
('84', 34, 1, 11, 70448) Whether the delays and difficulties experienced by the patient and me were caused by one department of the Government or another, or even by the Government doctors, the responsibility surely rests with the Central Government.
('84', 34, 1, 12, 70674) I note that the Government have maintained complete silence over the written request (which was reinforced by subsequent verbal reminders) of Drs.
('84', 34, 1, 13, 70821) Nayyar and Gilder to call Dr. B. C. Roy in consultation, and have not even condescended to give their reasons for not granting the request.

('84', 35, 1, 2, 71431) pointed out by me in my letter 1 dated March 20, 1944, in the Hon.
('84', 35, 1, 3, 71498) the Home Member’s statement in the Assembly that trained nurses were in attendance.
('84', 35, 1, 4, 71582) The fact is that they never were.

('84', 35, 1, 6, 71756) I hope, after a calm perusal of this bare recital of facts and of the relevant copies of correspondence attached hereto, it will be conceded that the claim of the Government of India that “they did everything possible” to ensure that the deceased received all the treatment that I wished during her illness is not justified.Much less can Mr. Butler’s claim be justified.
('84', 35, 1, 7, 72127) For, he went further when he said, “she was receiving all possible medical care and attention, not only from her regular attendents, but from those desired by her family.” Does not the statement of the Government of Bombay (Appendix D), “Government have decided that no outside doctors should be allowed unless the Government Medical Officer considers that it is absolutely necessary for medical reasons” contradict the above claims?
('84', 35, 1, 8, 72561) On the question of release, and the report received by the Government of India of a “private conversation” my son had with his mother in this connection, a prisoner can have no “private” conversation with anybody from outside.
('84', 35, 1, 9, 72788) Therefore, so far as I am concerned, the Government are free to make use of the conversation after verification (usual and obligatory in such cases) by my son.
('84', 35, 1, 10, 72948) In any case the Government would have been absolved from all blame, if they had made an offer of release and laid on me the burden of deciding what was “best and kindest” for her.
('84', 35, 1, 11, 73128) As to the arrangement for the funeral, my letter to the Government dated March 4, 1944, embodying my actual request, which the Inspector General of Prisons took down in writing from dictation, speaks for itself.
('84', 35, 1, 12, 73340) It, therefore, astonishes me that on “enquiries” made by the Government, they were “informed” that I had “no special preference between the first two alternatives” mentioned in my letter.
('84', 35, 1, 13, 73528) The information given to the Government is wholly wrong.
('84', 35, 1, 14, 73585) It is inconceivable that, given the freedom of choice, I could ever be reconciled to the cremation of a dear one being performed in a jail compound (which this camp is today) instead of the consecrated cremation ground.
('84', 35, 1, 15, 73805) It is not pleasant or easy for me to write about such personal matters to the Government.
('84', 35, 1, 16, 73895) But I do so in this case for the sake of the memory of one who was my faithful partner for over sixty two years.

('84', 38, 1, 2, 77480) 30. LETTER TO LORD WAVELL
('84', 38, 2, 3, 77506) April 9, 1944
('84', 38, 3, 4, 77520) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter 1 of 28th March received by me on the 3rd instant.
('84', 38, 3, 5, 77603) Please accept my thanks for it.
('84', 38, 3, 6, 77635) I take up the general matter first.
('84', 38, 3, 7, 77671) You have sent me a frank reply.
('84', 38, 3, 8, 77703) I propose to reciprocate your courtesy by being perfectly frank.
('84', 38, 3, 9, 77768) Friendship to be true demands frankness even though it may some time appear unpleasant.
('84', 38, 3, 10, 77856) If anything I say offends you, please accept my apology in advance.
('84', 38, 4, 11, 77924) It is a pity that you have refused to deal with important points raised in my letter.
('84', 38, 4, 12, 78010) Your letter is a plea for co operation by the Congress in the present administration, and failing that, in planning for the future.
('84', 38, 4, 13, 78142) In my opinion, this requires equality between the parties and mutual trust.
('84', 38, 4, 14, 78218) But equality is absent and Government distrust of the Congress can be seen at every turn.
('84', 38, 4, 15, 78308) The result is that suspicion of Government is universal.
('84', 38, 4, 16, 78365) Add to this the fact that Congressmen have no faith in the competence of the Government to ensure India’s future good.
('84', 38, 4, 17, 78484) This want of faith is based upon bitter experience of the past and present conduct of the British administration of India.
('84', 38, 4, 18, 78607) Is it not high time that you co operate with the people of India through their elected representatives instead of expecting co operation from them?
('84', 38, 4, 19, 78755) All this was implied in the August resolution.
('84', 38, 4, 20, 78802) The sanction behind the demand in the resolution was not violence, but self suffering.
('84', 38, 4, 21, 78889) Anyone, be he Congressman or other, who acted against this rule of conduct had no authority to use the Congress name for his action.
('84', 38, 4, 22, 79022) But I see that this resolution repels you as it did Lord Linlithgow.
('84', 38, 4, 23, 79091) You know that I have joined issue on the point.
('84', 38, 4, 24, 79139) I have seen nothing since to alter my view.
('84', 38, 4, 25, 79183) You have been good enough to credit me with “intelligence”, “experience”, and “acumen”.
('84', 38, 4, 26, 79271) Let me say that all these three have failed to make me realize that the effect of
('84', 38, 5, 27, 79353) 1 Vide Appendix “Letter from Lord Wavell”, 28 3 1944. 2 According to The Transfer of Power, Vol. IV, p.
('84', 38, 5, 28, 79457) 898, in his report to the Secretary of State for India, the addressee said: “Gandhi has sent me an ill tempered letter in reply to mine.
('84', 38, 5, 29, 79594) I am sending you a copy and am not continuing the correspondence.”
('84', 39, 0, 1, 79661) 40 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 39, 1, 2, 79702) the Congress resolution “must be to hamper the prosecution of the war”.
('84', 39, 1, 3, 79774) The responsibility for what followed the hasty arrests of Congressmen must rest solely on the Government.
('84', 39, 1, 4, 79880) For, they invited the crisis, not the authors of the resolution.
('84', 39, 1, 5, 79945) You remind me that you were Commander in Chief at the time.
('84', 39, 1, 6, 80005) How much better it would have been for all concerned if confidence in the immeasurable strength of arms had ruled your action instead of fear of a rebellion!
('84', 39, 1, 7, 80163) Had the Government stayed their hand at thetime, surely all the bloodshed of those months would have been avoided.
('84', 39, 1, 8, 80278) And it is highly likely that the Japanese menace would have become a thing of the past.
('84', 39, 1, 9, 80366) Unfortunately it was not to be.
('84', 39, 1, 10, 80398) And so the menace is still with us, and what is more, the Government are pursuing a policy of suppression of liberty and truth.
('84', 39, 1, 11, 80526) I have studied the latest ordinance about the detenus, and I recall the Rowlatt Act of 1919. It was properly called the Black Act.
('84', 39, 1, 12, 80657) As you know, it gave rise to an unprecedented agitation.
('84', 39, 1, 13, 80714) That Act pales into insignificance before the series of ordinances that are being showered from the Viceregal throne.
('84', 39, 1, 14, 80832) Martial Law in effect governs not one Province as in 1919, but the whole of India.
('84', 39, 1, 15, 80915) Things are moving from bad to worse.
('84', 39, 1, 16, 80952) You say, “it is clear to me that you had lost confidence in our ability to defend India and were prepared to take advantage of our supposed military straits to gain political advantage.” I must deny both the charges.
('84', 39, 1, 17, 81169) I venture to suggest that you should follow the golden rule, and withdraw your statement and suspend judgment till you have submitted the evidence in your possession to an impartial tribunal and obtained its verdict.
('84', 39, 1, 18, 81386) I confess that I do not make the request with much confidence.
('84', 39, 1, 19, 81449) For, in dealing with Congressmen and others, Government have combined the prosecutor, judge and jailor in the same person and thus made proper defence impossible on the part of the accused.
('84', 39, 1, 20, 81639) Judgments of courts are being rendered nugatory by fresh ordinances.
('84', 39, 1, 21, 81708) No man’s freedom can be said to be safe in this extraordinary situation.
('84', 39, 1, 22, 81781) You will probably retort that it is an exigency of the war.
('84', 39, 1, 23, 81841) I wonder !
('84', 39, 1, 24, 81852) As I visualize India today, it is one vast prison containing four hundred million souls.
('84', 39, 1, 25, 81941) You are its sole custodian.
('84', 39, 1, 26, 81969) The Government prisons are prisons within this prison.
('84', 39, 1, 27, 82024) I agree with you that whilst you hold the views expressed in your letter under reply, the proper place for one like me is a Government prison.
('84', 39, 1, 28, 82167) And unless there is a change of heart, view and policy on the part of the Government, I am quite
('84', 40, 0, 1, 82264) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 41
('84', 40, 1, 2, 82310) content to remain your prisoner.
('84', 40, 1, 3, 82343) Only I hope you will listen to the request made by me through the proper channels to remove me and my fellow prisoners to some other prison where the cost of our detention need not be even one tenth of what it is today.
('84', 40, 1, 4, 82563) As to my complaint 1 about Mr. Butler’s statement and later the Home Secretary’s, I have received two letters from the HomeDepartment in reply.
('84', 40, 1, 5, 82707) I am sorry to say, they have appeared to me highly unsatisfactory.
('84', 40, 1, 6, 82774) They ignore patent facts, and betray an obstinate refusal to face truth even on a wholly non political issue.

('84', 43, 9, 14, 87464) I wish to put on record the fact that by reason of the cremation of the corpses of Shri Mahadev Desai and then my wife, the place of cremation which has been fenced off becomes consecrated ground.

('84', 43, 10, 17, 87806) 1 From February 10 to March 3, 1943 2 According to The Transfer of Power, Vol. IV, pp.
('84', 43, 10, 18, 87893) 948 9, in a cable dated May 4, 1944, to the Secretary of State for India, the Viceroy reported: “Latest reports show progressive deterioration in Gandhi’s anaemia, blood pressure and kidney functions, all of which in opinion of Dr. B. C. Roy shared by Surgeon General Candy, have tendency to produce coronary or cerebral thrombosis.
('84', 43, 10, 19, 88226) This is a case in which I consider we must be guided by medical opinion.
('84', 43, 10, 20, 88299) Deterioration in Gandhi’s health appears such that his further participation in active politics is improbable and I have no doubt that death in custody would intensify feeling against Government.
('84', 43, 10, 21, 88495) I am accordingly instructing Bombay Government to release Gandhi unconditionally at 8 a.m.
('84', 43, 10, 22, 88586) On Saturday, 6th May, with announcement that release is entirely on medical grounds and am informing all Governors accordingly.” For the British Premier Winston Churchill’s displeasure at Viceroy’s decision, vide footnote 1 of “Letter from Lord Wavell”, 15 8 1944.

('84', 46, 1, 2, 91613) 39. FRAGMENT OF A LETTER
('84', 46, 2, 3, 91638) [After May 6, 1944] 1
('84', 46, 3, 4, 91660) I had condemned it in my letter to Linlithgow without waiting for evidence.
('84', 46, 3, 5, 91736) Did you not see it ?
('84', 46, 3, 6, 91757) In my very first letter 2
('84', 46, 4, 7, 91783) written in August the day before Mahadev passed away, I had condemned all violence, including the violence that had taken place.
('84', 46, 4, 8, 91912) It had been the Government’s design to get me to admit responsibility for the violence which would justify their repression, and show them to be innocent before the world.
('84', 46, 4, 9, 92084) I did not oblige.
('84', 46, 4, 10, 92102) Nothing would make me do so.
('84', 46, 4, 11, 92131) Being in jail how could I be expected to know about it ?
('84', 46, 4, 12, 92188) So when I heard about Kishorelal, I immediately lodged a protest.
('84', 46, 4, 13, 92254) You must try to understand this.
('84', 46, 4, 14, 92287) Think over it.
('84', 46, 4, 15, 92302) I have not been guilty of the slightest error.
('84', 46, 4, 16, 92349) None but the Government says that I committed an error.
('84', 46, 4, 17, 92405) That was a false charge.
('84', 46, 4, 18, 92430) I had condemned all acts of violence.
('84', 46, 4, 19, 92468) They wanted me to accept the Government’s version and condemn popular violence and condemn it from the jail.
('84', 46, 4, 20, 92577) I refused to do that.
('84', 46, 4, 21, 92599) There is no difference between what I am saying now and what I said in 1942. On the basis of the evidence available today, I have condemned certain acts of violence.
('84', 46, 4, 22, 92765) When that information was given to me without any evidence, I promptly and unequivocally protested.
('84', 46, 4, 23, 92865) Did you not read my reply to the Government ?
('84', 46, 4, 24, 92911) I have not gone back upon it.
('84', 46, 4, 25, 92941) I believe that all type of killing and burning is bad.
('84', 46, 4, 26, 92996) So, it taught a lesson at least to those who killed and burnt, did it not ?
('84', 46, 4, 27, 93072) The fact is that my correspondence was released only after the fast.
('84', 46, 4, 28, 93141) You should read those letters.
('84', 46, 4, 29, 93172) I have certainly condemned the violence.
('84', 46, 4, 30, 93213) But how can I admit without any direct evidence that people resorted to such and such acts ?
('84', 46, 4, 31, 93306) [From Gujarati]
('84', 46, 5, 32, 93322) Manavtana Prahari Pannalal Jhaveri, p.
('84', 46, 6, 33, 93361) 1 The letter appears to have been written following Gandhiji’s release from jail on May 6, 1944, when certain instances of mass action during the Quit India Movement were judged in retrospect in terms of violence and non violence; vide also “Discussion with a Friend”, after 6 5 1944; “Letter to Annada Babu Chowdhary”, 9 6 1944. 2Vide “Letter to Lord Linlithgow”, 14 8 1942.
('84', 47, 0, 1, 93737) 48 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 47, 1, 2, 93778) 40. DISCUSSION WITH A FRIEND 1
('84', 47, 2, 3, 93809) [After May 6, 1944] 2
('84', 47, 3, 4, 93831) Gandhiji questioned the statement that sabotage could be part of the non violent programme or that it was derivable from the principle of ahimsa as he understood it.
('84', 47, 3, 5, 93997) The friend, however, persisted that sabotage had come to stay whether one liked it or not.
('84', 47, 4, 6, 94088) GANDHIJI: Irresponsible prophesying leads to nowhere.
('84', 47, 4, 7, 94142) The real question is where we stand, what our attitude towards it is going to be.
('84', 47, 5, 8, 94224) FRIEND: Was destruction of Government property violence?
('84', 47, 5, 9, 94281) You say that nobody has a right to destroy any property not his own.
('84', 47, 5, 10, 94350) If so, is not Government’s property mine?
('84', 47, 5, 11, 94392) I hold it is mine and I may destroy it.
('84', 47, 5, 12, 94432) There is a double fallacy involved in your argument.
('84', 47, 5, 13, 94485) In the first place, conceding that Government property is national property— which today it is not—I may not destroy it because I am dissatisfied with the Government.
('84', 47, 5, 14, 94652) But even a national government will be unable to carry on for a day if everybody claimed the right to destroy bridges, communications, roads, etc., because he disapproved of some of its activities.
('84', 47, 5, 15, 94850) Moreover the evil resides not in bridges, roads, etc., which are inanimate objects but in men.
('84', 47, 5, 16, 94945) It is the latter who need to be tackled.
('84', 47, 5, 17, 94986) The destruction of bridges, roads, etc., by means of explosives does not touch this evil but only provokes a worse evil in the place of the one it seeks to end.
('84', 47, 5, 18, 95147) 3 To sterilize it needs not destruction but self immolation of the purest type, which would demonstrate that the authorities might break but would not be able to bend a will that has
('84', 47, 6, 19, 95330) 1 The discussion appeared under the title “A Pointer for the Future” by Pyarelal who explains that “a friend” had asked Gandhiji “How is the cutting of telegraph wires contrary to the principle of ahimsa?” And another who met him some time after he left the Aga Khan Palace had posed the problem thus: “There are two schools of thought amongst our youth today.
('84', 47, 6, 20, 95691) One school holds, and openly says, that as a programme of action ahimsa is played out.
('84', 47, 6, 21, 95778) It has done its work, which was to awaken the masses, and has set the stage for the final struggle for independence.
('84', 47, 6, 22, 95895) In this struggle, force of arms cannot be excluded.
('84', 47, 6, 23, 95947) The other school, while professing belief in ahimsa, says that there is room for modification and further elaboration in its technique.
('84', 47, 6, 24, 96083) They aver that the next phase of our struggle would be characterized by organized sabotage on an extensive scale.” 2 ibid 3 The rest of the paragraph is from Mahatma Gandhi—The Last Phase, Vol. I, Book One, p.
('84', 48, 0, 1, 96293) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 49
('84', 48, 1, 2, 96339) resigned itself to the God of truth.
('84', 48, 2, 3, 96376) I agree that the evil is within ourselves, not in the bridge which can be used for a good purpose as well as an evil one.
('84', 48, 2, 4, 96498) I also agree that its blowing up provokes counter violence of a worse type.
('84', 48, 2, 5, 96574) But it may be necessary from a strategic point of view for the success of the movement and in order to prevent demoralization.
('84', 48, 2, 6, 96701) It is an old argument.
('84', 48, 2, 7, 96724) One used to hear it in old days in defence of terrorism.
('84', 48, 2, 8, 96781) Sabotage is a form of violence.
('84', 48, 2, 9, 96813) People have realized the futility of physical violence, but some people apparently think that it may be successfully practised in its modified form as sabotage.
('84', 48, 2, 10, 96974) 1 It lacked the quality of non violence and could not take the place of full fledged armed conflict.
('84', 48, 2, 11, 97075) We have to deal with a power which takes pride in not recognizing defeat.
('84', 48, 2, 12, 97149) In the early part of the British rule there were powerful risings.
('84', 48, 2, 13, 97216) In several places the British were actually beaten.
('84', 48, 2, 14, 97268) But they won in the end.
('84', 48, 2, 15, 97293) A British statesman used to say, “I do not believe in wooden guns.” National struggles could not be won by “wooden guns”.
('84', 48, 2, 16, 97415) It is my conviction that the whole mass of people would not have risen to the height of courage and fearlessness that they have, but for the working of full non violence.
('84', 48, 2, 17, 97586) How it works we do not yet fully know.
('84', 48, 2, 18, 97625) But the fact remains that under non violence we have progressed from strength to strength even through our apparent failures and set backs.
('84', 48, 2, 19, 97765) On the other hand, terrorism resulted in demoralization.
('84', 48, 2, 20, 97822) Haste leads to waste.
('84', 48, 3, 21, 97844) You characterized the “Quit India” movement as a non violent rebellion.
('84', 48, 3, 22, 97916) Is not non violent rebellion a programme of seizure of power?
('84', 48, 3, 23, 97978) A non violent rebellion is not a programme of seizure of power.
('84', 48, 3, 24, 98042) It is a programme of transformation of relationship ending in a peaceful transfer of power.
('84', 48, 3, 25, 98134) It will never use coercion.
('84', 48, 3, 26, 98162) Even those who hold contrary views will receive full protection under it.
('84', 48, 4, 27, 98236) We have found that a person who has had a schooling in violent activity comes nearer to true non violence than one who has had no such experience.
('84', 48, 4, 28, 98383) That can be true only in the sense that having tried violence again and again he has realized its futility.
('84', 48, 4, 29, 98491) That is all.
('84', 48, 4, 30, 98504) Would you maintain also that a person who has had a taste of vice is nearer to virtue than the one who had none?
('84', 48, 4, 31, 98617) For, that is what your argument amounts to.
('84', 48, 5, 32, 98661) 1 The rest of the paragraph is from Mahatma Gandhi—The Last Phase, Vol. I, Book One, p.
('84', 48, 5, 33, 98749) 38 2 These two paragraphs are reproduced from Mahatma Gandhi—The Last Phase, Vol. I, Book One, pp.
('84', 48, 5, 34, 98848) 38 9. 3 ibid
('84', 49, 0, 1, 98861) 50 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 49, 1, 2, 98902) It is no secrecy, if the person concerned is boldly prepared to face the consequences of his action.
('84', 49, 1, 3, 99003) He resorts to secrecy in order to achieve his object.
('84', 49, 1, 4, 99057) He can refuse to take any part in subsequent interrogations during his trial.
('84', 49, 1, 5, 99135) He need not make a false statement.
('84', 49, 1, 6, 99171) No secret organization, however big, could do any good.
('84', 49, 1, 7, 99227) Secrecy aims at building a wall of protection round you.
('84', 49, 1, 8, 99284) Ahimsa disdains all such protection.
('84', 49, 1, 9, 99321) It functions in the open and in the face of odds, the heaviest conceivable.
('84', 49, 1, 10, 99397) We have to organize for action a vast people that have been crushed under the heel of unspeakable tyranny for centuries.
('84', 49, 1, 11, 99518) They cannot be organized by any other than open, truthful means.
('84', 49, 1, 12, 99583) I have grown up from youth to 76 years in abhorrence of secrecy.
('84', 49, 1, 13, 99648) There must be no watering down of the ideal.
('84', 49, 1, 14, 99693) Unless we cling to the formula in its fulness, we shall not make any headway.
('84', 49, 1, 15, 99771) I know we have not always lived up to our ideals.
('84', 49, 1, 16, 99821) There have been grave lapses.
('84', 49, 1, 17, 99851) Had our instruments been less imperfect, we would have been nearer our goal.
('84', 49, 1, 18, 99928) But in spite of our temporizing with our ideal, non violence has worked like a silent leaven among the dumb millions.
('84', 49, 1, 19, 100046) That does not mean that we can afford to go on like this for ever.
('84', 49, 1, 20, 100113) We cannot remain static.
('84', 49, 1, 21, 100138) We must move forward or we shall slide back.
('84', 49, 2, 22, 100183) Are you of opinion then, that the August resolution caused a set back in the struggle for independence; that all the heroism and courage which our people showed in the course of it was useless?
('84', 49, 2, 23, 100377) No, I do not say that.
('84', 49, 2, 24, 100400) In the historical process, the country will be found to have advanced towards freedom through every form of struggle, even through the August upheaval.
('84', 49, 2, 25, 100552) All that I have said is that the progress would have been much greater, if we had shown the non violent bravery of my conception.
('84', 49, 2, 26, 100682) In this sense the sabotage activity has retarded the country’s freedom.
('84', 49, 2, 27, 100754) I have the highest admiration for the courage, patriotism and spirit of self sacrifice of people, say, like Jayaprakash Narayan.
('84', 49, 2, 28, 100883) But Jayaprakash cannot be my ideal.
('84', 49, 2, 29, 100919) If I had to give a medal for heroism, it would go not to him but to his wife who, though simple and unlearned in politics, typifies in her person the power of satyagraha in its purest form before which even Jayaprakash has to bow.
('84', 49, 2, 30, 101150) What I have said about the August upheaval is not by way of judgment upon the past—I have consistently refused to condemn it—but as a guidance for the future.
('84', 49, 3, 31, 101309) Our people have faith in non violence but they do not know how to make it
('84', 50, 0, 1, 101383) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 51
('84', 50, 1, 2, 101429) dynamic.
('84', 50, 1, 3, 101438) What is the reason for this failure?
('84', 50, 1, 4, 101475) By hammering away at it through painful years, people have begun to see that there is a potency in non violence, but they have not seen it in all its fulness and beauty.
('84', 50, 1, 5, 101645) If they had responded to all the steps that had to be taken for the effective organization of non violence and carried out in their fulness the various items of the eighteen fold constructive programme, our movement would have taken us to our goal.
('84', 50, 1, 6, 101894) But today our minds are confused because our faith in constructive work is so weak.
('84', 50, 1, 7, 101978) I know, one must push forth undaunted by difficulties.
('84', 50, 2, 8, 102033) Harijan, 10 2 1946

('84', 53, 1, 2, 104517) 48. LETTER TO POTHAN JOSEPH
('84', 53, 2, 3, 104545) PALM BUN, JUHU, May 13, 1944
('84', 53, 3, 4, 104574) DEAR POTHAN JOSEPH,
('84', 53, 4, 5, 104594) As you probably know Gandhiji asked the Government to provide him with Dawn while he was in detention.
('84', 53, 4, 6, 104697) And whenever it came–which was fairly regularly–he perused it carefully.
('84', 53, 4, 7, 104770) Since our coming here, however, he has been missing it.
('84', 53, 4, 8, 104826) For, naturally, the Government copy has ceased to come.
('84', 53, 4, 9, 104882) He has, therefore, asked me to request you to send him a copy of the Dawn regularly.
('84', 53, 4, 10, 104967) In case it is not the practice of your management to send it free to anybody, he says the subscription should be paid by you out of your capacious pocket.
('84', 53, 4, 11, 105122) You know well enough that Gandhiji has no money to buy newspapers with.
('84', 53, 5, 12, 105194) Please send the back numbers too as from the 1st of May, 1944. The address should be as above until further notice.
('84', 53, 6, 13, 105310) With regards.
('84', 53, 7, 14, 105324) Yours sincerely,
('84', 53, 8, 15, 105341) PYARELAL
('84', 53, 9, 16, 105350) POTHAN JOSEPH, ESQ.
