('84', 55, 8, 9, 108002) 53. SILENCE DAY NOTE TO DOCTORS 5
('84', 55, 9, 10, 108036) May 15, 1944] 6
('84', 55, 10, 11, 108052) The oppression was the fancied or real control of the doctors rather than the mind.
('84', 55, 10, 12, 108136) I believe I have freed myself from the doctors’ control.
('84', 55, 10, 13, 108193) It does not matter if the freedom is imaginary or imagined.
('84', 55, 10, 14, 108253) The effect on me is the same.
('84', 55, 10, 15, 108283) Whatever I may now do will be due either to my weakness or strength.
('84', 55, 10, 16, 108352) Next fortnight will show us all what is in store for me and us.
('84', 55, 10, 17, 108416) I am approaching the thing with a detached mind.
('84', 55, 10, 18, 108465) The difference is this.
('84', 55, 10, 19, 108489) If I have the strength of mind, what I announced yesterday will abide.
('84', 55, 10, 20, 108560) If the mind has become weak I do not know to what extent I shall go.
('84', 55, 10, 21, 108629) If the medicine is the least thing, you are safe and I am safe.
('84', 55, 10, 22, 108693) About visitors I shall be stricter than the doctors have [advised].
('84', 55, 11, 23, 108761) From a facsimile: Mahatma Gandhi—The Last Phase, Vol. I, Book One, between pp.

('84', 57, 10, 15, 111094) Therefore, you should do only what appeals to your heart and head.

('84', 61, 7, 12, 117245) 64. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('84', 61, 8, 13, 117275) JUHU, May 20, 1944
('84', 61, 9, 14, 117294) NARANDAS, I went carefully through your Annual Report.
('84', 61, 9, 15, 117349) I have not yet started writing anything.
('84', 61, 9, 16, 117390) I have written only three letters to invalids.
('84', 61, 9, 17, 117437) But Daridranarayana is the greatest invalid in the world.
('84', 61, 9, 18, 117495) You are one of His matchless devotees dedicated exclusively to His service.
('84', 61, 9, 19, 117571) You celebrate the Rentia Baras 2 on the occasion of my birthday and every year you make your plan of service more rigorous.
('84', 61, 9, 20, 117695) This year the test will be the hardest so far.
('84', 61, 9, 21, 117742) May you succeed in it.
('84', 61, 9, 22, 117765) This time, while in jail, I read about Marx and whatever literature I could get about the great experiment in Russia.
('84', 61, 9, 23, 117883) What a great difference between that experiment and our spinning wheel?
('84', 61, 9, 24, 117955) There also, as in India, the whole nation is invited to join in the yajna.
('84', 61, 9, 25, 118030) But the experiments there and here are as different from each other as East from West or North from South.
('84', 61, 10, 26, 118137) 1 Wife of Mahadev Desai 2 Sacrificial spinning initiated by the addressee in honour of Gandhiji’s birthday; this was also called Rentia Yajna meaning non stop spinning beginning on Bhadarva Vad 12, Gandhiji’s date of birth according to Vikram era, usually falling in the second half of September, to October 2. Vide also “Notes”, 12 7 1939.
('84', 62, 0, 1, 118478) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 63
('84', 62, 1, 2, 118524) What a difference between our spinning wheel and their machines driven by steam or electricity?
('84', 62, 1, 3, 118620) But all the same I prefer the snail like speed of the spinning wheel.
('84', 62, 1, 4, 118690) The spinning wheel is a symbol of ahimsa, and ultimately it is ahimsa that will triumph.
('84', 62, 1, 5, 118779) If, however, we who claim to be its votaries are weak, we shall dishonour ourselves and discredit ahimsa.
('84', 62, 1, 6, 118885) Your activity is excellent indeed.
('84', 62, 1, 7, 118920) But you should now introduce some new changes in it.
('84', 62, 1, 8, 118973) There is a science of the spinning wheel, as there is one of machines.
('84', 62, 1, 9, 119044) We have still not fully evolved the “technique” of the spinning wheel.
('84', 62, 1, 10, 119115) It requires deep study.
('84', 62, 1, 11, 119139) Just as knowledge without faith is useless, even so faith without knowledge is blind.

('84', 62, 5, 15, 119327) 65. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('84', 62, 6, 16, 119357) JUHU, May 20, 1944
('84', 62, 7, 17, 119376) NARANDAS, I drafted an article for you while lying in bed.
('84', 62, 7, 18, 119435) I was afraid that it would have too many corrections, but that did not happen.
('84', 62, 7, 19, 119514) I didn’t feel like making a fair copy with ink.
('84', 62, 7, 20, 119562) If you want any changes to be made in the draft, send it back to me.
('84', 62, 7, 21, 119631) I will think over your revisions and will make a fair draft and send it over to you.
('84', 62, 7, 22, 119716) We have enough time still.
('84', 62, 7, 23, 119743) Secondly, you know Manu (Jaisukhlal’s); she has created a very good impression on me.
('84', 62, 7, 24, 119829) I have not seen any other girl in our family with the same spontaneous spirit of service that she has.
('84', 62, 7, 25, 119932) The devotion with which she looked after Ba has captured my heart.
('84', 62, 7, 26, 119999) She would like to remain with me, but I do not wish it.
('84', 62, 7, 27, 120055) I am a broken reed just now and, therefore, can give her nothing.
('84', 62, 7, 28, 120121) The others are busy with their work.
('84', 62, 7, 29, 120158) And what can they give her now?
('84', 62, 7, 30, 120190) Her education must go on regularly.
('84', 62, 7, 31, 120226) That can be done only if she is with you.
('84', 62, 7, 32, 120268) She is not the type of girl whose presence will irritate you.
('84', 62, 7, 33, 120330) She is simple hearted.
('84', 62, 7, 34, 120353) She is dull in her studies, has a good voice, and her health is fairly good.

('84', 79, 1, 2, 140778) 99. A LETTER
('84', 79, 2, 3, 140791) JUHU, May 27, 1944 I myself have not seen the papers, but Sushila told me that you obtained Nathubhai’s signature on your bulletin.
('84', 79, 2, 4, 140923) Nathubhai was the last to come into my life, through Mahadev.
('84', 79, 2, 5, 140985) But Jivraj and Purushottam Patel had come into it even before you did.
('84', 79, 2, 6, 141056) They were followed by Deshmukh and then Nerulkar.
('84', 79, 2, 7, 141106) Dalal is dead.
('84', 79, 2, 8, 141121) I sent a gentle note of reproach to Nathubhai and asked him why he had not called.
('84', 79, 2, 9, 141204) If, now, Nathubhai signs as a doctor, you should rope in Deshmukh and Nerulkar too.
('84', 79, 2, 10, 141288) I know that you were prevailed upon by Dr. Gilder.
('84', 79, 2, 11, 141339) This protest, therefore, is not addressed to you.
('84', 79, 2, 12, 141389) It is against that Mayor.
('84', 79, 2, 13, 141415) The bulletin, of course, is not to be issued.
('84', 79, 2, 14, 141461) But this is one reason for my blood pressure.
('84', 79, 2, 15, 141507) There are other reasons, too, but I will not bother you with them.
('84', 79, 2, 16, 141574) The pressure, of course, will come down, and then a day will come when I also will go the way Dalal has gone.
('84', 79, 2, 17, 141684) Despite the different therapies, I and all others will have to go one day under some pretext or other.
('84', 79, 2, 18, 141787) That is why I tell you that you are welcome to go on torturing me till you have conquered death.
('84', 79, 3, 19, 141884) From a photostat of the Gujarati: C.W. 2719. Courtesy: Nathubhai Patel

('84', 92, 1, 2, 157054) 126. SPEECH AT JUHU
('84', 92, 2, 3, 157074) June 8, 1944 I thought you were all good men and that you had faith in prayer.
('84', 92, 2, 4, 157153) But if the report that has reached me is correct, I do not think that you answer to that description.
('84', 92, 2, 5, 157255) If I am mistaken, you can correct me.
('84', 92, 2, 6, 157293) You have gate crashed and broken in.
('84', 92, 2, 7, 157330) If that is so, I do not wish to have your darshan 1, neither do I wish to give you my darshan.
('84', 92, 2, 8, 157425) When it rained, I came out and begged to be excused.
('84', 92, 2, 9, 157478) I thought that none of you were left out.
('84', 92, 2, 10, 157520) But you were late, though you had come in time for the usual prayers.
('84', 92, 2, 11, 157590) 2 So I was helpless.
('84', 92, 2, 12, 157611) I thought that if Sarojini Devi had allowed you and if you had come quietly, I would have had no objection.
('84', 92, 2, 13, 157719) Instead you howled and broke open the gate.
('84', 92, 2, 14, 157763) I am pleased to see you.
('84', 92, 2, 15, 157788) But the way you have come here has pained me greatly.
('84', 92, 2, 16, 157842) I hope you will not repeat this.
('84', 92, 2, 17, 157875) I do not wish to say any more.
('84', 92, 2, 18, 157906) I shall be obliged, if you disperse quietly.
('84', 92, 2, 19, 157951) Even this much speaking is beyond my strength and against the orders of my doctors.
('84', 92, 2, 20, 158035) But I have spoken because I felt that, unless I gave expression to my anguish, I would not be able to sleep peacefully.
('84', 92, 2, 21, 158155) You gate crashed and it hurts me.
('84', 92, 2, 22, 158189) If you disperse peacefully, my anguish will be lightened.
('84', 92, 2, 23, 158247) But if you do not remain peaceful and disperse in an orderly manner, I shall have to come back.
('84', 92, 2, 24, 158343) Those of you who wish to contribute to the Harijan Fund may do so.
('84', 92, 2, 25, 158410) But you will not expect me to keep standing here.
('84', 92, 2, 26, 158460) That is beyond my strength.
('84', 92, 3, 27, 158488) The Bombay Chronicle, 9 6 1944
('84', 92, 4, 28, 158519) 1 Sight of a person, place or thing considered holy 2 The report said: “Due to the inclement weather Gandhiji went to the usual prayer ground facing the sea, a little earlier than usual, and begged to be excused.
('84', 92, 4, 29, 158732) It was decided to hold the prayers inside the compound.
('84', 92, 4, 30, 158788) .” The report in The Hindu, 10 6 1944, said: “After waiting for more than an hour, they were told that they could proceed to Mr. Gandhi in batches.
('84', 92, 4, 31, 158936) But the crowd rushed in.
('84', 92, 4, 32, 158961) .” 3 The report concluded: “After Gandhiji turned back some people made their contributions to the Fund and all of them walked out of the grounds peacefully.”

('84', 94, 0, 1, 160545) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 95
('84', 94, 1, 2, 160591) 129. LETTER TO ANNADA BABU CHOWDHARY
('84', 94, 2, 3, 160628) June 9, 1944 Secrecy, in my opinion, is a sin and symptom of violence, therefore, to be definitely avoided, especially if the freedom of the dumb millions is the goal.
('84', 94, 2, 4, 160796) Hence all underground activity, in my opinion, is taboo.
('84', 94, 2, 5, 160853) What I, however, say is that even the content of violence and non violence, whether as policy, or creed, should be judged by every individual worker according to the dictates of his head and heart.
('84', 94, 2, 6, 161051) And when there is a conflict between the head and the heart, the heart wins.
('84', 94, 2, 7, 161128) I am not saying anything as the leader of the movement, I must be regarded still as a prisoner with freedom to give opinions, not to issue instructions.
('84', 94, 3, 8, 161281) Glimpses of Gandhiji, pp.

('84', 94, 8, 14, 161557) 131. DRAFT LETTER TO THE VICEROY 2
('84', 94, 9, 15, 161592) JUHU, June 10, 1944 The Committee of the Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce and Industry congratulate His Excellency the Viceroy on the step taken by him in releasing Mahatma Gandhi.
('84', 94, 9, 16, 161782) Although it is stated that the action has been taken on medical grounds, the
('84', 94, 10, 17, 161859) 1 This was written as postscript to Pyarelal’s reply to the addressee who was not keeping well.
('84', 94, 10, 18, 161955) 2 The draft carries heavy revisions in Gandhiji’s hand.
('84', 95, 0, 1, 162011) 96 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 95, 1, 2, 162052) Committee feel that to ignore the political potentialities of Gandhiji’s release would be a great mistake on the part of the Government.
('84', 95, 1, 3, 162189) The Committee firmly believe that the situation in 1942 was thoroughly mishandled by the Government of India leading to the arrest of Gandhiji and other leaders and other responsible Congressmen throughout the country.
('84', 95, 1, 4, 162408) The disturbances were the natural consequence which the Government should have foreseen.
('84', 95, 1, 5, 162497) The Committee is convinced that had the Government waited and responded to the way of negotiation which was clearly contemplated as can be proved from Gandhiji’s and Maulana Abul Kalam Azad’s and Panditji’s speeches and statements made at the time and not exhibited a panicky mood showed by the arrests, the history of India would be much different today from what it is.
('84', 95, 1, 6, 162869) While deploring the past mistakes, the Committee feel that these could be rectified by reviewing the position afresh and making a firm attempt to solve the political deadlock.
('84', 95, 1, 7, 163045) The Committee is convinced that Mahatmaji is a man of peace and goodwill and that his method is not one of giving advantage to the enemy.
('84', 95, 1, 8, 163183) The Committee, therefore, feel that a solution is not impossible if the Government were to reciprocate the friendliness of Gandhiji.
('84', 95, 1, 9, 163316) The Com[mittee] feel that in order to enable the Mahatma to render effective help in the war effort, the first natural action should be the release of the members of the Working Committee and all others who have been interned.
('84', 95, 1, 10, 163543) It is clear to the Committee [that] Gandhiji is powerless without the backing of the Working Committee.
('84', 95, 1, 11, 163647) We believe that even the economic development, for which His Excellency the Viceroy has expressed such great sympathy, is impossible unless there is at the centre a Government which can inspire confidence and enthusiasm among the people.
('84', 95, 1, 12, 163885) Only a National Government could fulfil the above condition.
('84', 95, 1, 13, 163946) The Com[mittee], therefore, strongly appeal to His Excellency the Viceroy that in the interest of winning the war, the future Indo British relations and the improvement of the economic condition of India, it is imperative that the Government should take immediate steps to achieve conditions for the establishment of a truly National Government.
('84', 95, 1, 14, 164292) The Committee also appeal to Mahatma Gandhi and Mr. Jinnah to make fresh efforts to solve the communal deadlock for the purpose of creating an atmosphere for establishment of a National Government.
('84', 95, 2, 15, 164490) From a original : Pyarelal Papers.
('84', 95, 2, 16, 164525) Nehru Memorial Museum and Library.
('84', 95, 2, 17, 164560) Courtesy : Beladevi Nayyar and Dr. Sushila Nayyar

('84', 96, 2, 3, 164684) SUNDER BUN, JUHU, June 10, 1944
('84', 96, 3, 4, 164716) DEAR FRIEND, I send you herewith in two volumes copies of correspondence between the Government of India or the Bombay Government and myself during my incarceration in the palace of H. H. the Aga Khan in Yeravda.
('84', 96, 3, 5, 164929) The second volume is a copy of my reply 2 to the Government of India pamphlet entitled Congress Responsibility for the Disturbances, 1942 43. The first contains copies of correspondence arising out of the above mentioned reply and on miscellaneous matters of public importance.
('84', 96, 3, 6, 165207) I had the copies cyclostyled with the help of kind friends.
('84', 96, 3, 7, 165267) For fear of censorship difficulties I did not try to have the copies printed at any printing press.
('84', 96, 3, 8, 165367) But lest the Government of India may think that there is anything in the correspondence objectionable from military standpoint, I am circulating for private use only the copies among friends who, I think, should know the nature of the correspondence that took place between the two Governments and me.
('84', 96, 3, 9, 165669) You are free to show your copy to any friends you like, subject to the precaution that applies to you.
('84', 96, 3, 10, 165772) You will confer on me a favour, if you will take the trouble of letting me have your reaction upon the correspondence, especially upon the points arising from my reply to the Government of India pamphlet.
('84', 96, 3, 11, 165977) I have endeavoured to answer every item of importance in the Government indictment.
('84', 96, 3, 12, 166061) I should like to know the points, if any, which require elucidation.
('84', 96, 4, 13, 166130) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI From the original: H. P. Mody Papers.

('84', 99, 3, 6, 170256) Does it mean war on behalf of India’s millions, or the Negroes in East, South or West Africa, or the Negroes of America, or all of them?
('84', 99, 3, 7, 170393) Are the Allies engaged in such a war?

('84', 99, 3, 9, 170520) If they are, may I see them?
('84', 99, 3, 10, 170549) 3. It is stated that the Communist Party has actively helped the authorities to arrest leaders and organizers of labour strikes during the last two years.
('84', 99, 3, 11, 170704) 4. The Communist Party is said to have adopted the policy of infiltrating the Congress oranization with a hostile intent.
('84', 99, 3, 12, 170826) 5. Is not the policy of the Communist Party dictated from outside?
('84', 99, 4, 13, 170893) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('84', 104, 1, 2, 178376) 142. SILENCE DAY INTERVIEW TO JOURNALISTS 1
('84', 104, 2, 3, 178420) BOMBAY, June 12, 1944 Amen.
('84', 104, 2, 4, 178448) So help us God.
('84', 104, 2, 5, 178464) The contract is that there should be silence on both sides.
('84', 104, 2, 6, 178524) You may read what you can from the silence.
('84', 104, 3, 7, 178568) Another spell of a few minutes’ silence followed and Mahatma Gandhi was asked, how long they could stay there.
('84', 104, 3, 8, 178679) By a sign of his finger he replied that the interview would last ten minutes.
('84', 104, 3, 9, 178757) The journalists replied that they had been waiting at Juhu practically all the days since his arrival, and therefore the time of the “silent interview” should be extended.
('84', 104, 3, 10, 178929) Mahatma Gandhi wrote in reply: If there is a good singer amongst you, you can take extra time; otherwise what is the use of your wasting time?
('84', 104, 3, 11, 179072) There is no such thing as silence in journalists.
('84', 104, 4, 12, 179122) The reporters were taken aback at the request, but one journalist came to the rescue of the party, and he sang a song, which seemed to have pleased Mahatma Gandhi.
('84', 104, 4, 13, 179286) Another gentleman, to everybody’s surprise, volunteered to follow up and Mahatma Gandhi wrote: I would gladly listen to more, but ill though I am, the time is all pledged to the nation 2.
('84', 104, 5, 14, 179474) The Hindu, 14 6 1944
('84', 104, 6, 15, 179495) 1 The report said: “Mahatma Gandhi .
('84', 104, 6, 16, 179532) received some thirty journalists at his shack at Juhu this evening.
('84', 104, 6, 17, 179600) Today was his day of weekly silence and since he was leaving the city for Poona on Thursday, he agreed to ‘see’ Pressmen today.
('84', 104, 6, 18, 179728) He was seen in his characteristic pose, squatting crosslegged on a mattress, busy writing something.
('84', 104, 6, 19, 179829) The Pressmen crowded around him and someone passed on a chit to him, stating that the Press was not satisfied with ‘this silent interview’ and that they were eagerly looking forward to the day when he would be completely restored to health and would speak to them again as before.
('84', 104, 6, 20, 180110) Mahatma Gandhi wrote back on the same chit.
('84', 104, 6, 21, 180154) 2 The report concluded: “The journalists then pooled some money for Harijan Fund, gave it to Mahatma Gandhi and left the shack.”

('84', 105, 4, 5, 180404) I promised 2 to give you a written reply to your very kind letter of 9th instant.
('84', 105, 4, 6, 180486) Here is my reply.
('84', 105, 4, 7, 180504) The conferences that are meeting to consider the future, I regard as one of the methods of diverting public attention from the grim realities of the war.
('84', 105, 4, 8, 180658) 3 The future will be decided not by conferences but by the way in which the principal actors behave now.
('84', 105, 4, 9, 180763) We should, therefore, control the present so that the future may correspond to the present.
('84', 105, 4, 10, 180855) We shall reap as we sow.
('84', 105, 4, 11, 180880) The realities are that we allow ourselves to be exploited with our eyes shut and/or open.
('84', 105, 4, 12, 180970) I feel that I know the way out but I am helpless not merely because I am ill, but principally because the censorship tightens round me like the coil of a snake.
('84', 105, 4, 13, 181131) I am taxing God to show me how to disengage myself from the coil.
('84', 105, 4, 14, 181197) I shall take no hasty step.
('84', 105, 4, 15, 181225) Before I take any step, I shall certainly correspond with H. E. the Viceroy.
('84', 105, 4, 16, 181302) As to communal unity, I am wedded to it.
('84', 105, 4, 17, 181343) All I can say is that I shall leave no stone unturned to make my contribution towards a just solution.
('84', 105, 5, 18, 181446) There is a ring of despair running through your letter.
('84', 105, 5, 19, 181502) I wish I

('84', 110, 7, 14, 188427) POONA, June 16, 1944
('84', 110, 8, 15, 188448) On being requested as to how Mr. Mavalankar should act with reference to the work of the Fund 1 in Ahmedabad, Gandhiji said : You can as well represent the capitalists as I do, effectively influencing their contributions.
('84', 110, 8, 16, 188670) You will not be able at the same time to appeal to the masses.
('84', 110, 8, 17, 188733) The whole conception seems to me to be that the few rich should ensure the declared amount.
('84', 110, 8, 18, 188825) Only a popular body can collect from the masses.

('84', 111, 2, 3, 189265) NATURE CURE CLINIC, 6 TODDIWALA ROAD, POONA, June 17, 1944
('84', 111, 3, 4, 189324) DEAR FRIEND, But for the fact that this letter is along the lines of your pre occupation, I should not have troubled you with any letter from me.
('84', 111, 3, 5, 189470) Though there is little cause for it, the whole country and even many from outside expect me to make some decisive contribution to the general good.
('84', 111, 3, 6, 189618) I am sorry to say, my convalescence threatens to be fairly long.
('84', 111, 3, 7, 189683) Even if I was quite well, I could do little or nothing, unless I knew the mind of the Working Committee of the Congress.
('84', 111, 3, 8, 189804) I pleaded 1 as a prisoner for permission to see them.
('84', 111, 3, 9, 189858) I plead now as a free man for such permission.
('84', 111, 3, 10, 189905) If you will see me before deciding, I shall gladly go wherever you want me to, as soon as I am allowed by my medical advisers to undertake long distance travelling.
('84', 111, 3, 11, 190070) I have circulated among friends for private use, copies of the correspondence that passed between the authorities and me during detention.
('84', 111, 3, 12, 190209) I do feel, however, that in fairness to me Government should permit its publication in the Press.
('84', 111, 4, 13, 190307) My address will be as above till 30th instant.
('84', 111, 6, 14, 190354) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI The Bombay Chronicle, 2 7 1944

('84', 114, 4, 15, 195580) POONA, June 18, 1944
('84', 114, 5, 16, 195601) BALKRISHNA, Krishnachandra writes and tells me that just because a man deceived you, you have given up milk at one meal and that you castigated yourself too.
('84', 114, 5, 17, 195759) Both these things can be done on the right occasion but was it the right occasion in your case?
('84', 114, 5, 18, 195855) During the last imprisonment I learnt one thing, namely, that one must never be hasty in judging the actions of one’s co workers, one should put before the person concerned the other side for consideration and then let him judge himself.

('84', 126, 1, 2, 211342) 179. LETTER TO PRITHVI SINGH
('84', 126, 2, 3, 211371) POONA, June 23, 1944
('84', 126, 3, 4, 211392) BHAI PRITHVI SINGH, I should be betraying you if I did not convey to you something more I have heard about you.
('84', 126, 4, 5, 211504) It appears that you had spread your net beforehand, got Nanabhai to side with you and through him influenced me.
('84', 126, 4, 6, 211617) When the time came you cast me aside.
('84', 126, 4, 7, 211655) That is to say, you cast aside non violence.
('84', 126, 4, 8, 211700) You clung to Mirabehn and tried to win me back through her.
('84', 126, 4, 9, 211760) You cast lustful eyes on two girls but neither of them fell into your hands.
('84', 126, 4, 10, 211837) The woman whom you have married was to marry her benefactor.

('84', 130, 7, 8, 217185) June 26, 1944

('84', 130, 8, 11, 217315) The result is: This institution should remain as it is, with some modifications, because it is your creation.
('84', 130, 8, 12, 217425) Do not enlarge its sphere of work.
('84', 130, 8, 13, 217460) Buy about a thousand acres of land near a village under your supervision.
('84', 130, 8, 14, 217534) There should be enough space for patients and also provision for the healthy ones to remain so.
('84', 130, 8, 15, 217630) The rich and the poor should stay in the same way, and food for them should be produced there itself.
('84', 130, 8, 16, 217732) Almost all the things should be grown there.
('84', 130, 8, 17, 217777) Treatment through earth, water, light, air and ether should be given.
('84', 130, 8, 18, 217847) Manage everything in such a way that the poor can get what they require.
('84', 130, 8, 19, 217920) Such new institutions should come up as you get more workers.
('84', 130, 8, 20, 217982) The management should be such that the institution is able to meet its expenses.
('84', 130, 8, 21, 218063) Do not take Government aid so long as power is not in the people’s hands.
('84', 130, 8, 22, 218137) Convene a meeting of naturopaths and discuss the issue.
('84', 130, 8, 23, 218193) Take workers from among them.
('84', 130, 8, 24, 218223) There should be a trust for this and the new institution which will come into being.
('84', 130, 8, 25, 218308) At least you, Ghanshyamdas and myself should

('84', 133, 1, 2, 221766) 191. SPEECH TO CONGERSSMEN, POONA 1
('84', 133, 2, 3, 221802) June 29, 1944
('84', 133, 3, 4, 221816) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, When some of you came to Juhu, doctors forbade me to speak a word to you.
('84', 133, 3, 5, 221912) And I felt very unhappy.
('84', 133, 3, 6, 221937) When I came over to Poona I thought I would be able to meet you.
('84', 133, 3, 7, 222002) Even now I am unwell, but still I meet many people and am able to talk to them.
('84', 133, 3, 8, 222082) Why not with you then?
('84', 133, 3, 9, 222105) I had hoped to spend some more time with you, but the doctors have permitted only half an hour.
('84', 133, 3, 10, 222201) I have promised not to take more than the allotted thirty minutes.
('84', 133, 3, 11, 222268) Hence I omit all preliminaries.
('84', 133, 3, 12, 222300) At my request 2, the Secretary kindly sent me a report of the happenings in Maharashtra since August 9, 1942. Besides the names of those assembled here, he has sent some questions.
('84', 133, 3, 13, 222481) I have read all these papers carefully.
('84', 133, 3, 14, 222521) I do not propose to reply to all the questions.
('84', 133, 3, 15, 222569) This will not be possible within half an hour.
('84', 133, 3, 16, 222616) You will, therefore, excuse me for confining my remarks only to the main issues.
('84', 133, 3, 17, 222697) Today I do not meet you in any representative capacity.
('84', 133, 3, 18, 222753) In terms (the language) of satyagraha, the moment I was imprisoned I ceased to wield the authority reposed in me by the Congress.
('84', 133, 3, 19, 222883) And if I am now out of prison, it is not because of my strength or yours, but because of my illness.
('84', 133, 3, 20, 222984) In a satyagrahi, illness is a thing to be ashamed of.
('84', 133, 3, 21, 223038) This fortuitous release does not restore to me the authority that lapsed with my imprisonment.
('84', 133, 3, 22, 223133) I discussed my position with some lawyer friends 3 in terms of the law prevalent in the land, and they are of the opinion that what I hold to be true in terms of satyagraha happens to be true legally too.
('84', 133, 3, 23, 223338) What then is my status today?
('84', 133, 3, 24, 223368) You who have gathered here occupy certain positions of authority in the Congress.
('84', 133, 3, 25, 223450) I do not hold any such position.
('84', 133, 3, 26, 223483) I am not even a four anna member of the Congress.
('84', 133, 3, 27, 223533) Iresigned from the Congress some years ago to try out the subtler laws of satyagraha.
('84', 133, 3, 28, 223619) Nevertheless, I know that I hold a big place in your
('84', 133, 4, 29, 223672) 1 About 50 representative Congressmen of Maharashtra met Gandhiji at the Nature cure Clinic of Dr. Dinshaw Mehta.
('84', 133, 4, 30, 223786) Gandhiji spoke in Hindustani.

('84', 134, 0, 1, 224075) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 135
('84', 134, 1, 2, 224122) hearts, and you would give weight to whatever I might say.
('84', 134, 1, 3, 224181) What I may say is to be regarded merely as an individual opinion, to be accepted or rejected by you at will.
('84', 134, 1, 4, 224290) It could have been otherwise, if I were speaking in a representative capacity.
('84', 134, 1, 5, 224369) Then I would have expected you as disciplined soldiers to carry out my instructions.
('84', 134, 1, 6, 224454) I thought of many things after reading the documents sent by you.
('84', 134, 1, 7, 224520) But instead of discussing past happenings, I shall speak only of our present duties.
('84', 134, 1, 8, 224605) What work I have done and am still doing in India or abroad is rooted in truth and non violence.
('84', 134, 1, 9, 224702) I have been experimenting all along with the introduction of truth and non violence in day to day life.
('84', 134, 1, 10, 224806) Some people believe that truth and non violence have no place in the practice of politics and public affairs.
('84', 134, 1, 11, 224916) I do not agree.
('84', 134, 1, 12, 224932) I have always believed that these weapons are entirely useless, if they are meant only for personal salvation.
('84', 134, 1, 13, 225043) I would not like to have even beatitude for myself alone.
('84', 134, 1, 14, 225101) I am no slave of any rigid school.
('84', 134, 1, 15, 225136) I have no guru.
('84', 134, 1, 16, 225152) If I discover a guru, I shall bow before him.
('84', 134, 1, 17, 225198) My religion teaches me the need for a guru and how to honour one.
('84', 134, 1, 18, 225264) But today my heart is my only guru.
('84', 134, 1, 19, 225300) I do not propose to give you a religious discourse today.
('84', 134, 1, 20, 225358) I must say that if you have lost faith in the efficacy of truth and non violence, I have no remedy for your despondency.
('84', 134, 1, 21, 225479) Inside the prison I used to read the newspapers and now, when I am out, I hear from people that a sense of frustration has overpowered the country.
('84', 134, 1, 22, 225627) But I felt no frustration in my heart in the prison and I feel none outside.
('84', 134, 1, 23, 225704) If Congressmen feel frustrated, it is because they lack faith in truth and non violence.
('84', 134, 1, 24, 225793) Examine your hearts.
('84', 134, 1, 25, 225814) Has your faith dwindled?
('84', 134, 1, 26, 225839) You are good for nothing, if you are still in the Congress but have no faith in truth and nonviolence.
('84', 134, 1, 27, 225942) Your being in the Congress would then be a sign of your ignorance.
('84', 134, 1, 28, 226009) Who are Congressmen?
('84', 134, 1, 29, 226030) Only those whose names are in its register?
('84', 134, 1, 30, 226074) The Congress should be a poor organization, if it depended for its strength on the few lakhs of members whose names appeared on Congress rolls.
('84', 134, 1, 31, 226218) At the Faizpur Congress 1, Deo and Dastane used to stress the point that the work done on behalf of the Congress was beyond description.
('84', 134, 1, 32, 226355) Huge crowds gathered at Faizpur.
('84', 134, 1, 33, 226388) But a very small proportion of them was on the Congress rolls.
('84', 134, 1, 34, 226451) I noticed atFaizpur that not even untouchability had disappeared from the place.
('84', 134, 1, 35, 226532) A cow could drink water at a well, but not an untouchable.
('84', 134, 1, 36, 226591) Deo and Dastane did not notice this, but it did not escape my eyes.
('84', 134, 2, 37, 226659) 1 In December 1936
('84', 135, 0, 1, 226678) 136 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 135, 1, 2, 226720) been my endeavour from childhood to identify myself with the masses.
('84', 135, 1, 3, 226789) I am one of them and not separate or different.
('84', 135, 1, 4, 226837) That has enabled me to enter their hearts and to understand them.
('84', 135, 1, 5, 226903) At the Round Table Conference I claimed that I represented the whole of India, those who supported the Congress and also those who had nothing to do with it.
('84', 135, 1, 6, 227061) Since the Congress claims to serve all, it represents them all.
('84', 135, 1, 7, 227125) Congress represents to a greater extent the poor, hungry and helpless millions.
('84', 135, 1, 8, 227205) I shall not discuss today why they lost the lustre in their eyes.
('84', 135, 1, 9, 227271) I will merely affirm that you represent Congress, and you cannot represent it without subscribing to truth and non violence.
('84', 135, 1, 10, 227396) Experience has led me to the firm conviction that our success has been mathematically proportionate to the extent to which we have adhered to truth and non violence.
('84', 135, 1, 11, 227562) The phenomenal awakening in the masses during the last 25 years has been entirely due to the purity of our means.
('84', 135, 1, 12, 227676) And to the extent untruth and violence have crept in, they have hindered our progress.
('84', 135, 1, 13, 227763) Whatever harm has come our way, it is due to our lack of faith in truth and non violence.
('84', 135, 1, 14, 227853) Today I do not wish to sit in judgment upon your actions.
('84', 135, 1, 15, 227911) I only wish to place my convictions before you.
('84', 135, 1, 16, 227959) Your faith in me overwhelms me.
('84', 135, 1, 17, 227991) My fortuitous release has given rise to great expectations.
('84', 135, 1, 18, 228051) I am doubtful whether I deserve all this confidence.
('84', 135, 1, 19, 228104) But this much I know that whatever strength I may have is entirely due to my being a votary of truth and non violence.
('84', 135, 1, 20, 228223) If I make any suggestions, they are based on my faith in these fundamentals.
('84', 135, 1, 21, 228300) You want to follow a man like me.
('84', 135, 1, 22, 228334) You raise minor doubts which trouble me.
('84', 135, 1, 23, 228375) If you feel frustrated, ask yourself whether your faith in truth and non violence has ebbed away.
('84', 135, 1, 24, 228473) If so, you should strengthen it.

('84', 141, 1, 2, 239633) 197. SPEECH AT POONA 1
('84', 141, 2, 3, 239656) July 1, 1944
('84', 141, 3, 4, 239669) Gandhiji said that when he saw in the papers in the detention camp that he was appointed Chairman of the Trust he was surprised, but he reconciled himself to the position by the thought that the conception behind the proposal to make him Chairman was that he should, on his release, guide the trustees in determining the object of the Fund and regulating its application from time to time.
('84', 141, 3, 5, 240059) The belief was reinforced by the fact that the chief originator of the idea was Shri Narandas Gandhi who had set up the practice of presenting him with a purse collected chiefly in Kathiawar for the purpose of helping the spread of the hand spinning movement and allied activities in Kathiawar.
('84', 141, 3, 6, 240354) Gandhiji, however, could not shoulder the burden of attending meetings of the Trust regularly and guiding its day to day work.
('84', 141, 3, 7, 240481) The real Chairman was Sir Purushottamdas Thakurdas, the Vice Chairman.
('84', 141, 4, 8, 240552) While the Fund was taking shape, the tragic death of Kasturba came.
('84', 141, 4, 9, 240620) The idea of a National Memorial possessed the public, and the originator responded by combining the purse with the Memorial and merging the former in the latter.
('84', 141, 4, 10, 240782) Thus the present Trust was formed.
('84', 141, 4, 11, 240817) Kasturba was a simple woman devoted to village life, actually living and serving among villages.
('84', 141, 4, 12, 240914) The object of the Fund was very properly the welfare of village women and children.
('84', 141, 4, 13, 240998) It was well that the trustees and the donors should know the whole of his mind on the question of the welfare of women and children in the numerous villages of India.
('84', 141, 4, 14, 241165) The welfare of his conception encompassed the whole life of the women and children in the villages.
('84', 141, 4, 15, 241265) It, therefore, included maternity, hygiene and the treatment of diseases, and education.
('84', 141, 4, 16, 241354) Education meant the basic education of the Hindustani Talimi Sangh.
('84', 141, 4, 17, 241422) The scope of the Fund, therefore, excludes its use in towns and cities or in education abroad or even in the Universities of India.
('84', 141, 4, 18, 241554) He said that it would be readily conceded that while the sum of rupees 75 lakhs appeared to be big for the purpose of a Memorial, it was ridiculously small for the scope he had indicated.
('84', 141, 4, 19, 241742) Gandhiji said that he would be a useless Chairman and guide, if the trustees did not share his idea as to the scope of the Fund.
('84', 141, 5, 20, 241871) Proceeding, Gandhiji said that there was talk that he had said that the collection should be confined to capitalists and that the general public need take no part in the collection.
('84', 141, 5, 21, 242053) It was a travesty of truth.
('84', 141, 5, 22, 242081) The principal men who could move in the matter of organizing country side collection were behind prison bars.
('84', 141, 5, 23, 242191) He was himself disabled.
('84', 141, 5, 24, 242216) He, therefore, expected his rich friends to pull their fullest weight.
('84', 141, 5, 25, 242287) He could never be guilty of harbouring even the thought that the Congress and other
('84', 141, 6, 26, 242371) 1 Gandhiji presided over a meeting of trustees of Kasturba Gandhi National Memorial Fund.
('84', 141, 6, 27, 242461) He spoke in Gujarati.
('84', 142, 0, 1, 242483) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 143
('84', 142, 1, 2, 242530) workers should sit supine.
('84', 142, 1, 3, 242557) The Memorial was a National Memorial in which everyone, no matter what his politics, was expected to put in his best effort.
('84', 142, 1, 4, 242682) It would be no Memorial, if the collections were confined to capitalists.
('84', 142, 1, 5, 242756) Indeed Mridulabehn, who was one of the most active of workers, had come to him for guidance in the matter of collections in Gujarat.
('84', 142, 2, 6, 242889) An unwarranted but pardonable suspicion seems to have been created by the currency of the conversation he had with Dadasaheb Mavalankar who had come for discussion.
('84', 142, 2, 7, 243054) Gandhiji had told him that so far as he was concerned his work should be confined to the exercise of his unrivalled influence among the moneyed men.
('84', 142, 2, 8, 243203) “He is, like me, an ailing man,” said Gandhiji.
('84', 142, 2, 9, 243251) He would not like him to risk his health in doing the taxing work of house to house collection.
('84', 142, 2, 10, 243347) That could be easily organized by the workers that are still available.
('84', 142, 3, 11, 243419) It would be a thousand pities, if anyone who had faith in the object of the Memorial avoided paying his quota, or inducing his friends to pay theirs, under the false belief that Gandhiji wishes people other than capitalists to refrain from contributing to the Memorial.
('84', 142, 3, 12, 243689) Indeed he considered it a good sign that so many millionaires of India were not deterred by any real or imaginary fear of harm from identifying themselves with the Memorial of the dead wife of a detenu condemned by the powers that be.
('84', 142, 3, 13, 243924) For him, the Chairman, it was a matter of gratification.
('84', 142, 4, 14, 243981) Gandhiji said that he did count moneyed men among his friends.
('84', 142, 4, 15, 244044) He knew that critics were not wanting who considered his association with moneyed men a sign of weakness unworthy of a votary of truth and non violence.
('84', 142, 4, 16, 244197) The speaker, on the other hand, considered such association as essentially a sign of his non violence.
('84', 142, 4, 17, 244300) His many friends knew well the motive for his association with them.
('84', 142, 4, 18, 244369) He received money from them for many constructive activities, some of which were also supremely humanitarian.
('84', 142, 4, 19, 244479) They allowed him to put his hands into their pockets for the All India Spinners’ and Village Industries’ Associations, and for basic education as defined by the Hindustani Talimi Sangh, and other similar causes.
('84', 142, 4, 20, 244691) So far as he knew, they had nothing to gain by his association with them.
('84', 142, 4, 21, 244765) His contact with them took place after they had proved their success as businessmen.
('84', 142, 4, 22, 244850) His mission was to convert capitalists not into mere friends and patrons of the millions of unemployed, but willing sharers of their goods with them.
('84', 142, 5, 23, 245000) Further he had observed that some had doubted whether the Funds collected would not be used for political ends.
('84', 142, 5, 24, 245112) He had no hesitation whatsoever in giving the assurance that he had no such idea in view.
('84', 142, 5, 25, 245202) The All India Spinners’ Association and the other bodies just referred to by him, even though initiated by the Congress, had no political character about them.
('84', 142, 6, 26, 245362) This Memorial movement, Mr. Gandhi added, had been initiated not by the Congress or Congressmen, but by non Congressmen and for a purely humanitarian
('84', 143, 0, 1, 245512) 144 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 143, 1, 2, 245554) purpose.
('84', 143, 1, 3, 245563) In a higher sense, no great act done by an Indian, whether politician or no, could be without political significance.
('84', 143, 1, 4, 245681) He had in mind the activities of Indians in the field of literature and science and philosophy.

('84', 144, 3, 15, 247905) I cannot give up the desire to get perfectly well.

('84', 144, 3, 17, 247978) I have nothing which I may call my own.

('84', 144, 3, 23, 248253) I am always surrounded by a crowd.

('84', 146, 1, 2, 251620) seeing the members of the Working Committee for I believethat my authority under the August resolution ended with my imprisonment.

('84', 146, 2, 5, 251881) I interrupted and said: “The Viceroy and everybody else is interested to know your mind because of your hold on the masses of India.” He replied: I am a democrat and I cannot exploit that hold except through the organization in the building of which I had a hand.
('84', 146, 3, 6, 252145) But again I interrupted and said: “Before the Viceroy permits you to see the Committee, he would want to know how you would influence the members.” He said: History does not repeat itself.

('84', 147, 1, 2, 254164) 201. INTERVIEW TO STUART GELDER 1
('84', 147, 2, 3, 254198) July 4[to6] 2 1944
('84', 147, 3, 4, 254217) I saw Mahatma Gandhi on July 4th at Panchgani.
('84', 147, 3, 5, 254264) I told him: “My Editor is anxious to help in solving the political deadlock in India.
('84', 147, 3, 6, 254350) I went to Delhi and I was disappointed.
('84', 147, 3, 7, 254390) I hope you will not disappoint me.” I asked him: “Supposing you saw Lord Wavell how would you begin to talk?
('84', 147, 3, 8, 254499) What would you say to him?”
('84', 147, 4, 9, 254527) He promptly replied that he would tell the Viceroy that he had sought the interview with a view to help and not to hinder the Allies, and it was to this end he had asked for permission to see the members of the Congress Working Committee.
('84', 147, 4, 10, 254766) He said, he had no authority to act in the name of the Congress.
('84', 147, 4, 11, 254831) According to the canons of satyagraha, when a civil resister was imprisoned, the authority vested in him automatically came to an end.
('84', 147, 4, 12, 254966) Hence the need for him to see the members of the Working Committee.
('84', 147, 5, 13, 255034) I said: “The Viceroy might feel, as you swear by the August resolution and by the weapon of civil disobedience, your meeting the Working Committee members may only result in their re investing you with authority to carry on civil disobedience in the name of the Congress, and the result will be that when you come out of the interview you will hold the pistol on the Viceroy’s head and say: ‘Do this or I start civil disobedience.’ That would make things worse than they are today.” Gandhi replied: At the back of that is total distrust of my profession that I am, and have always been, a friend of the British.
('84', 147, 5, 14, 255646) Therefore I can never use the weapon of civil disobedience during the war, unless there was a very grave reason as, for instance, the thwarting of India’s natural rights to freedom.
('84', 147, 6, 15, 255828) My next question was: “Supposing the Working Committee was let out of jail tomorrow and the Government refuses to give India what they want, would you start civil disobedience?” Gandhi replied: If the Working Committee came out, they would take stock of the situation and discuss things among themselves and with me.
('84', 147, 6, 16, 256145) I can tell you this, that I have no intention of offering civil disobedience today.
('84', 147, 6, 17, 256229) I cannot take the country back to 1942. History can never berepeated.
('84', 147, 6, 18, 256299) Even without the authority of the Congress, if I wanted to
('84', 147, 7, 19, 256358) 1 In the source, the interview appeared as “Second Statement” and followed Gandhiji’s version, vide the preceding item.
('84', 148, 0, 1, 256478) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 149
('84', 148, 1, 2, 256525) do it, I could start civil disobedience today on the strength of my supposed influence with the masses.
('84', 148, 1, 3, 256629) But I would be doing so merely to embarrass the British Government.
('84', 148, 1, 4, 256697) This cannot be my object.
('84', 148, 1, 5, 256723) But the Working Committee would not sit still while people are suffering.
('84', 148, 1, 6, 256797) It is my conviction that we cannot meet fully the situation and alleviate the sufferings of the people, unless power and responsibility are transferred from British into Indian hands.
('84', 148, 1, 7, 256981) Without such transfer, the attempts of Congressmen and others to alleviate the people’s sufferings are most likely to lead to conflict with the Government.
('84', 148, 2, 8, 257137) I interrupted and said: “When things are as they are, I cannot believe that they will transfer authority now; that is, Government will not concede the demand for independence while the war is on.”
('84', 148, 3, 9, 257334) Gandhi replied that there was a difference between what he would ask today and what was asked in 1942. Today he would be satisfied with a national government in full control of civil administration.
('84', 148, 3, 10, 257533) It was not so in 1942. Such a government would be composed of persons chosen by the elected members of the Central Assembly.
('84', 148, 3, 11, 257658) “This would mean declaration of independence of India, qualified as above, during the war.”
('84', 148, 4, 12, 257750) I thought it was a great improvement on the 1942 position.
('84', 148, 4, 13, 257809) I asked him if the military would control railways and the ports, etc.
('84', 148, 5, 14, 257880) Gandhi replied that the national government would let the military have all the facilities that it might require.
('84', 148, 5, 15, 257994) But the control would be that of the national government.
('84', 148, 5, 16, 258052) Ordinance rule would give place to normal administration by the national government.
('84', 148, 6, 17, 258137) “Will the Viceroy be there?”, I asked.
('84', 148, 6, 18, 258176) [Gandhiji replied:] Yes, but he will be like the King of England guided by responsible Ministers.
('84', 148, 6, 19, 258274) Popular government will be automatically restored in all the provinces so that both the provincial and the central government will be responsible to the people of India.
('84', 148, 6, 20, 258444) So far as military operations are concerned, the Viceroy and the Commander in Chief will have complete control.
('84', 148, 6, 21, 258556) But it must be possible for the national government to offer advice and criticisms even in military matters.
('84', 148, 6, 22, 258665) Thus the portfolio of Defence would be in the hands of the national government which would be genuinely interested in the defence of the country and may render great assistance in the shaping of policies.
('84', 149, 0, 1, 258870) 150 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 149, 1, 2, 258912) The Allied forces would be allowed to carry on their operations on Indian soil; I realize that they cannot defeat Japan without that.
('84', 149, 2, 3, 259046) Gandhi made it clear that the expenses of the Allied operations on the Indian soil should not be borne by India.
('84', 149, 2, 4, 259159) I asked: “If a national government is formed, would you advise the Congress to participate in it?”
('84', 149, 3, 5, 259258) Gandhi replied in the affirmative.
('84', 149, 3, 6, 259293) I asked: “So it means that if a national government is formed, the Congress will join and help the war effort.
('84', 149, 3, 7, 259404) What would be your position?” [Gandhiji replied:] I am a lover of peace through and through.
('84', 149, 3, 8, 259497) After independence was assured I would probably cease to funtion as adviser to the Congress and, as an all war resister, I would have to stand aside; but I shall not offer any resistance against the national government or the Congress.
('84', 149, 3, 9, 259733) My co operation will be abstention from interfering with the even tenor of life in India.
('84', 149, 3, 10, 259823) I shall work with the hope that my influence will always be felt to keep India peace minded and brotherhood among all without the distinction of race and colour.
('84', 149, 4, 11, 259985) I next asked: “Supposing there is a conflict between the civil and military authorities, how would the dispute be settled?
('84', 149, 4, 12, 260108) If, for example, civil authorities want to use the railway to carry two thousand tons of food, and the military authorities wanted it for carrying munitions, what would you advise?” Gandhi replied: As I said before, I would not have to advise on such matters.
('84', 149, 4, 13, 260368) But supposing I had, I can conceive of the necessity of allowing precedence to the military.
('84', 149, 4, 14, 260461) But supposing the military wanted to blow off places or practice manoeuvres in disregard of the life of the people, I would say: ‘Hands off.’ The thing is that with mutual trust such difficulties would not arise and if they did, they would be easily adjusted.
('84', 149, 4, 15, 260721) If there is no trust, I cannot work.
('84', 149, 4, 16, 260758) I cannot work for Allied victory without trust.
('84', 149, 4, 17, 260806) If they trusted, a settlement would be easy to achieve.
('84', 149, 4, 18, 260862) Freedom for India will bring hope to Asiatics and other exploited nations.
('84', 149, 4, 19, 260937) Today there is no hope for the Negroes, but Indian freedom will fill them with hope.
('84', 149, 5, 20, 261022) Finally I asked: “What about the Hindu Muslim differences?” Gandhi replied: If the British meant well, there would be no difficulties.
('84', 149, 6, 21, 261157) Gandhi said in conclusion: Most of us believe that whatever the Viceroy may wish personally, he has not the authority in the political sphere.
('84', 149, 6, 22, 261300) Mr. Churchill does not want a settlement.
('84', 149, 6, 23, 261342) He wants to crush me, if he has
('84', 150, 0, 1, 261374) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 151
('84', 150, 1, 2, 261421) been correctly reported 1. He has never denied the report.
('84', 150, 1, 3, 261480) The beauty of it, for me, and the pity of it, for him, is that no one can crush a satyagrahi; for, he offers his body as a willing sacrifice and thus makes the spirit free.
('84', 150, 2, 4, 261653) In the course of his explanatory statement, Mahatma Gandhi said that throughout his talks with the British journalist he had emphasized the fact that he was speaking for himself and in no sense involving the Congress in what he said.
('84', 150, 2, 5, 261887) He added: I do not know how far today I represent the views of the members of the Working Committee.
('84', 150, 2, 6, 261988) And about Hindu Muslim formula which has nothing to do with these two statements, I have not spoken as a Hindu.
('84', 150, 2, 7, 262100) I have spoken as an Indian first and an Indian last.
('84', 150, 2, 8, 262153) My Hinduism is my own—I personally think it embraces all faiths.
('84', 150, 2, 9, 262218) Therefore I have no authority to speak as a representative of the Hindus.
('84', 150, 2, 10, 262292) That I respond to mass mind and the masses know me instinctively is a fact which cannot be gainsaid but I have not built my case upon it.

('84', 151, 6, 7, 263707) 204. DRAFT LETTER TO THACKER & CO.
('84', 151, 6, 8, 263742) AND OXFORD UNIVERSITY PRESS 2
('84', 151, 7, 9, 263772) July 5, 1944 It was after much thought that I declared a trust in connection with my writings.
('84', 151, 7, 10, 263867) I had observed misuse of Tolstoy’s writings for want of a trust.
('84', 151, 7, 11, 263932) By curing the defect, I preserved fully the idea lying behind dislike for copyright, i.e., for personal gain for one’s writings.
('84', 151, 7, 12, 264061) The idea also was to prevent profiteering by publishers or distortion or misrepresentation, wilful or unintentional.
('84', 151, 7, 13, 264178) I have requested the Navajivan Trust to permit you to publish Shri Prabhu’s compilation with the right for you to multiply editions as long as there is demand for it, provided that the price will be reduced to the minimum, leaving to you a profit of not more than five per cent—one half of which shall be paid to Shri Prabhu as honorarium for his labours.
('84', 151, 7, 14, 264534) One hundred copies of each edition should be given free of cost to the Navajivan Trust.
('84', 151, 7, 15, 264622) The Navajivan Trust should have the right to publish a cheaper edition (in English or in any Indian languages) for sale in India including Burma and Ceylon.
('84', 151, 7, 16, 264779) If, per chance, any profit accrues, it will be equally divided among your firm, Shri Prabhu and the Navajivan Trust.

('84', 152, 7, 24, 266384) AS AT SEVAGRAM, via WARDHA, 3
('84', 152, 8, 25, 266414) July 6, 1944
('84', 152, 9, 26, 266427) DEAR FRIEND, I was much touched by your letter of 10th May last.

('84', 157, 4, 6, 271217) 214. LETTER TO CHHOTUBHAI
('84', 157, 5, 7, 271243) PANCHGANI, July 7, 1944
('84', 157, 6, 8, 271267) BHAI CHHOTUBHAI, I like your letter very much because it is so candid.
('84', 157, 6, 9, 271338) But you have raised questions one would not expect from a man of your intelligence.
('84', 157, 6, 10, 271422) There are other co workers like you and I sometimes wonder if my company is stifling their intelligence.
('84', 157, 6, 11, 271527) All the same, I answer the questions.
('84', 157, 6, 12, 271565) 1. I have not the least doubt of Russia’s bravery.
('84', 157, 6, 13, 271616) But I would not weigh it on the scales of non violence.
('84', 157, 6, 14, 271672) 2. It does not appear to me that anything that is happening today can be likened to the Dharasana episode.
('84', 157, 6, 15, 271779) I can understand the hardship resulting from the refusal of the farmers to sell the stocks of grains lying with them to the Government at rates lower than they can afford.
('84', 157, 6, 16, 271951) But the looting of Government grain stocks cannot be called non violent whether it is done after serving prior notice or not.
('84', 157, 6, 17, 272077) I have always considered and still consider salt public property like water and air.
('84', 157, 6, 18, 272162) I cannot include acts like sabotage of railways, etc., in non violence.
('84', 157, 6, 19, 272234) 3. It is of course not easy to decide on a programme for someone who is bent upon facing bullets in a non violent way, but it is not impossible.
('84', 157, 6, 20, 272379) One is not duty bound to give one’s name.
('84', 157, 6, 21, 272421) Informing about the action contemplated would suffice.
('84', 157, 6, 22, 272476) If at the time fixed one finds that no one has come to the spot because the notice, being anonymous, had been thrown away, another notice can be sent.
('84', 157, 6, 23, 272627) If this is done again and again, one day the tiger is sure to come.
('84', 157, 6, 24, 272695) However, do not conclude from this that I consider the programme mentioned in the second question non violent even if carried out after giving
('84', 158, 0, 1, 272838) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 159
('84', 158, 1, 2, 272885) prior information.
('84', 158, 1, 3, 272904) My answer is intended only to clear the difficulty about the third question.
('84', 158, 1, 4, 272981) 4. The information contained in the cutting is more or less correct.
('84', 158, 1, 5, 273050) My advice to Raojibhai was not in exercise of a right.
('84', 158, 1, 6, 273105) One does not advise as a matter of right.
('84', 158, 1, 7, 273147) One commands.
('84', 158, 1, 8, 273161) Is that not so ?
('84', 158, 1, 9, 273178) I lost the right to command from the moment of my incarceration.
('84', 158, 1, 10, 273243) 5. Post Offices, courts, and so on, today do not belong to the people.
('84', 158, 1, 11, 273314) Even when they come to belong to the people, they will not be personal property.
('84', 158, 1, 12, 273395) Even personal property will be property belonging to the people.
('84', 158, 1, 13, 273460) Out of that, only what the nation has given unto itself or kept for itself would belong to it.
('84', 158, 1, 14, 273555) I hope this provides you all the explanations you seek.
('84', 158, 1, 15, 273611) I have not revised the above.
('84', 158, 2, 16, 273641) Blessings from BAPU

('84', 160, 5, 8, 276243) DEAR JATINDERNATH, I have gone through your letter.
('84', 160, 5, 9, 276295) It makes me sad.
('84', 160, 5, 10, 276312) Ill as I am, I am powerless to help much.
('84', 160, 5, 11, 276354) But taking the recital as true, the question is why did not the two men who were so brutally assaulted resist unto death.

('84', 160, 5, 13, 276552) I know this is more easily said than done.
('84', 160, 5, 14, 276595) But if we are to learn the art of non violence, we must refuse to be living witnesses of our own degradation.

('84', 162, 6, 11, 278997) 223. A LETTER
('84', 162, 7, 12, 279011) PANCHGANI, July 10, 1944 As for Bapa’s reference 2 of July 6, I see no discrepancy in my opinion regarding Nanjibhai’s 3 proposed donation and the previous opinion quoted by Bapa.
('84', 162, 7, 13, 279191) My point is that no donor should arbitrarily keep part or whole of the donation with himself.
('84', 162, 7, 14, 279285) He may send recommendation about ear marking.
('84', 162, 7, 15, 279331) If it satisfies our conditions, the ear marking may be allowed.
('84', 162, 7, 16, 279395) If my opinion is held good, the fourth condition is superfluous.
('84', 162, 7, 17, 279460) Thus while I see no discrepancy in my present opinion and the past, my emphasis has changed.
('84', 162, 7, 18, 279553) In my weakness, I was anxious to make up the total of 75 lacs somehow.
('84', 162, 7, 19, 279624) Now I am strong enough to resist that temptation.
('84', 162, 7, 20, 279674) We shall better serve the object of the Memorial by securing what we can by October 2 next, than by letting donors to
('84', 162, 8, 21, 279792) 1 Vide also “Letter to Gajanan N. Kanitkar”, 28 61944. 2 As Secretary, Kasturba Gandhi National Memorial Fund Trust 3 Nanji Kalidas; vide also “Letter to Nanji Kalidas”, 20 9 1944.
('84', 163, 0, 1, 279973) 164 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 163, 1, 2, 280015) fritter away the sum by local earmarkings and keeping the bulk with themselves.
('84', 163, 1, 3, 280095) In the States, generally, we are likely to experience difficulty in spending money in the villages.
('84', 163, 1, 4, 280195) I prefer the use of the word ‘villages’ to that of the expression ‘rural areas’.
('84', 163, 1, 5, 280276) There may be rural area of Calcutta but it may not be composed of villages properly so called.
('84', 163, 1, 6, 280371) Santa Cruz is a suburban area but not a village.
('84', 163, 1, 7, 280420) I hope the distinction I have made is capable of being easily understood.
('84', 163, 1, 8, 280494) Again our large donors will be townsmen.
('84', 163, 1, 9, 280535) Their natural wish will be to spend their donation in their own way and in their own place.
('84', 163, 1, 10, 280627) This may defeat the purpose of this Memorial.
('84', 163, 1, 11, 280673) I see the prospect of such questions arising frequently.
('84', 163, 1, 12, 280730) They will be largely of interpretation.

('84', 169, 1, 2, 288654) 233. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('84', 169, 2, 3, 288682) [July 12, 1944] 1
('84', 169, 3, 4, 288700) I had not authorized publication of the interview or even the substance.
('84', 169, 3, 5, 288773) I had said that it should not be published, unless I authorized its publication, and in no case had I ever dremt that the interview would be published, with exclusive rights to any one paper.
('84', 169, 3, 6, 288965) If it was to be published, it should have been broadcast throughout India.
('84', 169, 3, 7, 289040) Therefore I had to offer that apology 2 publicly in order to soothe myself and also to show to the Press my appreciation that they have respected my desire to be left alone, and also not to report anything which I had not authorized.
('84', 169, 3, 8, 289274) I know that some things have appeared in the Press without authority but, generally speaking, I must confess the Press has obliged me by refraining from reporting things that are not authorized.
('84', 169, 3, 9, 289469) My object in seeing the Press people is purely to advance the cause for which I am living, namely, the freedom of India through truth and non violence.
('84', 169, 3, 10, 289621) I do not seek publicity for the sake of it and just now I feel I would serve the cause better by remaining in obscurity, if such things were possible.
('84', 169, 3, 11, 289772) Therefore I had warned Gelder that he was not to publish anything from me unless I authorized it.
('84', 169, 3, 12, 289870) He has published 3
('84', 169, 4, 13, 289889) what he has, I have no doubt, with the best of intentions, but somehow or other I feel he has not served the cause as well as he might have.
('84', 169, 4, 14, 290030) I passed nearly three hours with him distributed over three days in order that he might know the whole of my mind.
('84', 169, 4, 15, 290145) I believed him, and still believe him, to be a well wisher of India as he is a lover of his own country, and I accepted his word entirely when he told me that he approached me not as a journalist principally but as one desiring to see that the political deadlock was resolved.
('84', 169, 4, 16, 290422) Whilst I declared my views with absolute freedom, I told him that his first business should be to go to Delhi and, if I could reach the

('84', 170, 1, 2, 290923) Viceregal throne, he should see the Viceroy 1 and give him what impressions he had gathered.
('84', 170, 1, 3, 291016) Having myself failed to get an interview with the Viceroy, I felt that Gelder being reporter of a prominent English daily might be able to serve the cause.
('84', 170, 1, 4, 291172) Even in South Africa, where I was working in a hostile atmosphere, I was fortunate enough to get journalists and editors to help me when they became impressed by my earnestness and the justice of my cause.
('84', 170, 1, 5, 291378) I was handling the disabilities of Indians in South Africa.
('84', 170, 1, 6, 291438) The publication, therefore, at this stage, of an abstract [by Gelder] of two interviews seems to me to be misfired.
('84', 170, 1, 7, 291554) I, therefore, propose to give you two notes prepared after discussion with Gelder one of which, namely, the shorter one, after his pilgrimage to Delhi he was free to send to his paper, and the other he could discuss privately with anybody who cared to understand me or who Gelder thought, should know how my mind was working You will see after you have read the two notes that he has compressed the two in the report published by him.
('84', 170, 1, 8, 291989) You will notice also that there are some glaring inaccuracies in the report as published.
('84', 170, 1, 9, 292079) I want to guard myself against being undrestood as accusing Gelder of wilful distortion.
('84', 170, 1, 10, 292168) But I have found it times without number during my public life, covering a period of over 50 years, that my statements do not admit of being easily abridged or paraphrased.
('84', 170, 1, 11, 292341) In 1897, I very nearly lost my life when Reuter sent an abridged summary of a pamphlet 2 I had written and distributed in India in 1896. The summary was, I have no doubt, an unconscious distortion of what I had written.
('84', 170, 1, 12, 292561) Fortunately my life was spared when I was lynched, and I was able to show that the case based against me on the strength of the summary was utterly wrong.
('84', 170, 1, 13, 292716) Here the abridgement has no such mischievous consequences.
('84', 170, 1, 14, 292775) I recall the South African incident in order to emphasize my point.
('84', 170, 1, 15, 292843) All my life I have handled what seemed to be forlorn causes.
('84', 170, 1, 16, 292904) I have been also a fairly successful journalist, but I did not embark upon that calling for a living.
('84', 170, 1, 17, 293006) It was a venture in order to advertise the cause I was handling, and I gave this long preface before handing the two statements to fellow journalists in the hope that they would respondto
('84', 170, 2, 18, 293194) 1 Who, however, declined to see him 2 The “Green Pamphlet”.

('84', 171, 1, 2, 293296) my earnest wish that they would co operate with me in dealing with the situation which, if properly handled, may yield promising results for mankind.
('84', 171, 1, 3, 293446) I was ill prepared for this ordeal that is in front of me.

('84', 171, 1, 20, 295208) I claim no further authority for my views.
('84', 171, 1, 21, 295251) I stand by every word that appeared in the two statements I have given to you, but I speak on behalf of no one else than myself.

('84', 172, 1, 2, 295560) 234. LETTER TO HORACE G. ALEXANDER
('84', 172, 2, 3, 295595) [July] 1 12, 1944
('84', 172, 3, 4, 295613) MY DEAR HORACE, I have your long letter—long for the time and the way in which it had to be sent, not for the subject matter.
('84', 172, 3, 5, 295739) Some of what you tell me I had known already after coming out, and some of it is startling.
('84', 172, 3, 6, 295831) All of it is good as coming from you, even the part that I know to be wrong.
('84', 172, 3, 7, 295908) But that which is wrong does not diminish the importance of what you have said.
('84', 172, 3, 8, 295988) The defects of your narrative arise from your good nature.
('84', 172, 3, 9, 296047) I would rather have the latter than have the defects removed at the sacrifice of it.
('84', 172, 3, 10, 296132) I need not thus have qualified my appreciation of your letter but for the fear of misleading you into the belief that I accept the whole of your version without any deduction.
('84', 172, 3, 11, 296308) To discuss the deduction is not germane to what I want to say.
('84', 172, 3, 12, 296371) You know the other side of the picture.
('84', 172, 3, 13, 296411) The popular fury was pardonable; the vindictive and inhuman retribution wholly indefensible.
('84', 172, 3, 14, 296504) But I will not take your time over this.
('84', 172, 3, 15, 296545) Your anxiety that I should offer co operation at least for the alleviation of hunger, I fully understand.
('84', 172, 3, 16, 296651) My difficulty is that I cannot, for the very valid reason that the alleviation is only apparent.
('84', 172, 3, 17, 296748) The Viceroy’s good intentions in the matter are not to be doubted.
('84', 172, 3, 18, 296815) His promptness in rushing to Bengal on arrival was worthy of the soldier that he is.
('84', 172, 3, 19, 296900) The agency through which he had and has to work is not designed to carry out the work of alleviation.
('84', 172, 3, 20, 297002) You are entitled to put your noble work and experience against what I am saying.
('84', 172, 3, 21, 297083) That only shows that evil by itself and in itself has no life.
('84', 172, 3, 22, 297146) It requires the prop of good for its sustenance.
('84', 172, 3, 23, 297195) Hospitals, roads, railways are probably good in themselves but when they are instruments of evil they are to be shunned.
('84', 172, 3, 24, 297316) They become snares.
('84', 172, 3, 25, 297336) You will now realize somewhat my meaning.
('84', 172, 3, 26, 297378) Sufficient to say that at no time has India been so bound down as now.
('84', 172, 3, 27, 297449) The remedy is liberty consistent with the movements of Allied troops.
('84', 172, 3, 28, 297519) But there is deep mutual

('84', 174, 1, 2, 299311) 236. LETTER TO SHAMALDAS GANDHI
('84', 174, 2, 3, 299343) [After July 12, 1944] 1
('84', 174, 3, 4, 299367) SHAMALDAS, I do not remember whether I have said anything to you about Bhai Munshi.
('84', 174, 3, 5, 299451) I had a long talk with him.

('84', 179, 1, 2, 309143) 241. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS
('84', 179, 2, 3, 309171) PANCHGANI, July 13, 1944 Some have said that I have admitted that the August resolution has lapsed.
('84', 179, 2, 4, 309271) Not only have I never said it, on the contrary, at the Maharashtra Workers’ meeting 1, I made it clear to the friends who had gathered around me at Poona that no comma of that resolution could be altered by anybody except those who passed it, namely, the Working Committee and finally the A.I.C.C. What I have said and what I reaffirm is that my authority under the resolution had undoubtedly lapsed according to my view of the working of satyagraha.
('84', 179, 2, 5, 309722) The premature publication 2 of the interview to Mr. Gelder has led to some confusion in the minds of Congressmen.
('84', 179, 2, 6, 309836) Let me make it clear that the lapsing of my authority has nothing to do with the normal activities of the Congress.
('84', 179, 2, 7, 309952) What no one can do in the name of the Congress is mass civil disobedience which was never started and which, as I have said, I cannot at the present moment, even in my personal capacity, start.
('84', 179, 2, 8, 310146) The “Quit India” resolution I hold to be absolutely innocuous.
('84', 179, 2, 9, 310209) The Gelder interview notes 3 now published are in no way in conflict with the “Quit India” resolution as I have interpreted it and, as the joint author of it, I have every right to interpret it.
('84', 179, 2, 10, 310404) The question before me and before the All India [Congress Committee] is how to implement the resolution at the present time, i.e., nearly two years after the passing of the resolution.
('84', 179, 2, 11, 310589) The Gelder interview notes show the way how it can be done in a perfectly honourable manner.
('84', 179, 2, 12, 310682) Those who approve of the stand I have taken up will naturally support it.
('84', 179, 2, 13, 310756) People having difficulty are free to refer to me but their approval of the stand taken by me must not be interpreted to mean suspension of the normal activities of the Congress and, if the Government interfere with those activities, the inherent right of individual civil disobedience is in no way suspended
('84', 179, 3, 14, 311064) 1 Vide “Speech to Cngressmen, Poona”, 29 6 1944. 2 Vide Appendix “Stuart Gelder’s Cable to News Chronicle” , 12 7 1944. 3 Vide “Interview to Stuart Gelder”, 4 7 1944 and “Interview to Stuart Gelder”, 4 7 1944.
('84', 180, 0, 1, 311274) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 181
('84', 180, 1, 2, 311321) under the statement referred to by me.
('84', 180, 1, 3, 311360) The statements constitute my individualpersonal effort to end the political deadlock.
('84', 180, 1, 4, 311446) They are more addressed to the powers that be than to the people.
('84', 180, 1, 5, 311512) If there is a hearty response, there will be no occasion for civil disobedience, individually or not.
('84', 180, 2, 6, 311614) Answering a question put by a reporter whether the Cripps proposals could be compared with his recent statements, Mahatma Gandhi said: My proposal is wholly different.
('84', 180, 2, 7, 311782) The Cripps proposals were unacceptable to me for the simple reason that they contemplated almost perpetual vivisection of India and would have created an effective barrier against Indian independence.
('84', 180, 2, 8, 311983) I want to say this without the slightest disrespect to Sir Stafford Cripps.
('84', 180, 2, 9, 312059) 1 He still remains to me the same friend that he claimed to be when he was here.
('84', 180, 2, 10, 312140) For me friendships abide in spite of political differences.
('84', 180, 2, 11, 312200) One fundamental element in my attitude is that I shall never be a party to the sale of the rights of the people of the States for the sake of freedom of the people of British India.
('84', 180, 2, 12, 312382) At the same time I am no enemy of the Princes.
('84', 180, 2, 13, 312429) I consider myself to be their friend and, if anybody cares to understand, I am quite prepared to suggest a solution at once honourable to them and to the people.
('84', 180, 2, 14, 312591) I live for a cause and, if I perish, it is for the cause.
('84', 180, 3, 15, 312649) A reporter suggested that it might be that His Majesty’s Government do not, for the duration of the war, entertain any idea for the transference of power, and it was feared that Mr. Jinnah would not be agreeable to accept Mahatma Gandhi’s suggestion because a national government might, in his opinion, consolidate the position of the Hindus in the centre.
('84', 180, 3, 16, 313006) Mahatma Gandhi explained: If Mr. Jinnah does not accept my suggestion or if the powers that be do not, I would consider it most unfortunate.
('84', 180, 3, 17, 313147) That would show that neither of them wants India to be really free at this juncture and give India a full share in winning the war for freedom and democracy.
('84', 180, 3, 18, 313305) I myself feel firmly that Mr. Jinnah does not block the way, but the British Government do not want a just settlement of the Indian claim for independence which is overdue, and they are using Mr. Jinnah as a cloak for denying freedom to India.
('84', 180, 3, 19, 313549) I have uttered my warning in the talk I gave to Mr. Stuart Gelder.
('84', 180, 4, 20, 313616) Mahatma Gandhi said that it must be the duty of all fair minded people to break what he called “the diabolical conspiracy to stifle India’s aspiration”.
('84', 180, 4, 21, 313769) He declared:
('84', 180, 5, 22, 313782) 1Vide also “Answers to Questions”, 15 7 1944.
