('84', 186, 1, 2, 321949) 249. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS
('84', 186, 2, 3, 321977) PANCHGANI, July 14, 1944 I have been receiving letters from several provinces complaining of the ill treatment of detenus.
('84', 186, 2, 4, 322100) I cannot vouch for their accuracy.
('84', 186, 2, 5, 322135) I have no means of verifying the accounts.
('84', 186, 2, 6, 322178) But correspondents who have written are most of them known personally to me and they are not likely to exaggerate.
('84', 186, 2, 7, 322293) One instance came to my notice only yesterday.
('84', 186, 2, 8, 322340) It is from Ajmer.
('84', 186, 2, 9, 322358) The prisoner was fasting.
('84', 186, 2, 10, 322384) His wife wrote several letters to me asking me to advise her husband to give up the fast.
('84', 186, 2, 11, 322474) As it was, the prisoner was willing.
('84', 186, 2, 12, 322511) I telegraphed 1 to the Superintendent conveying my advice to the prisoner to desist from fasting.
('84', 186, 2, 13, 322609) He accepted it and gave up his fast.
('84', 186, 2, 14, 322646) I now learn that the prisoner was being prosecuted under some jail regulations for having committed the crime of fasting.
('84', 186, 2, 15, 322768) I know when I was a prisoner in Yeravda that there was some such regulation and I thought that when a prisoner gave up his fast, he would not be prosecuted.
('84', 186, 2, 16, 322925) I also fasted, and I could also be punished, but I escaped punishment, I suppose, because I was regarded as a celebrity.
('84', 186, 2, 17, 323046) Assuming that I have been correctly informed, I would plead with the authorities that they should ignore such cases.
('84', 186, 2, 18, 323163) There would be nothing wrong if they allowed prisoners to fast at will.
('84', 186, 2, 19, 323235) The most reasonable thing would be to investigate the complaints for which they were fasting and promptly give redress, if the complaints were found justified.
('84', 186, 2, 20, 323395) These things have been done before.
('84', 186, 2, 21, 323431) There is no reason why that admirable practice should not be followed now.
('84', 186, 2, 22, 323506) I plead for humane treatment to prisoners, more especially when they are in detention on mere suspicion or found guilty of crimes created by special ordinances and not under the ordinary law.
('84', 186, 2, 23, 323698) Other cases that have come to my notice are not of fasting but of alleged ill treatment in order to break the spirit of prisoners.
('84', 186, 2, 24, 323829) I dealt with such cases when I edited the Young India and later the Harijan, and in many cases the authorities gave redress.
('84', 186, 2, 25, 323954) I happen to know that such cases sometimes do not reach the higher authorities.
('84', 186, 2, 26, 324034) My purpose in bringing this to public notice is to
('84', 186, 3, 27, 324085) 1 Vide “Telegram to Superintendent, Central Prison, Ajmer”, 17 5 1944.
('84', 187, 0, 1, 324156) 188 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 187, 1, 2, 324198) seek redress.
('84', 187, 1, 3, 324212) It is well known that in most provinces prisoners are suffering hardships which are perfectly avoidable.
('84', 187, 1, 4, 324317) All those who are at all ill or are losing weight should at once be discharged.
('84', 187, 1, 5, 324397) This will surely not prejudice the war effort or endanger the peace of the country.
('84', 187, 2, 6, 324481) I have received bitter criticism of my views 2 expressed in the Gelder interview.
('84', 187, 2, 7, 324563) Some of my correspondents say that under the influence of Moderates and moneyed men, I have betrayed the cause of the country.
('84', 187, 2, 8, 324690) If for nothing else, for dealing with such criticism, I am glad of the premature publication 3 of the interview.
('84', 187, 2, 9, 324803) I do not want to sail under false colours.
('84', 187, 2, 10, 324846) The country as well as the Government should know me exactly as I am.
('84', 187, 2, 11, 324916) I have never concealed the fact that I am a friend of everybody, Moderates, moneyed men, Englishmen, Americans or any other, irrespective of caste, colour or persuasion.
('84', 187, 2, 12, 325086) My belief and practice are directly derived from my non violence.
('84', 187, 2, 13, 325152) My non co operation is non co operation with evil, not with the evil doer.
('84', 187, 2, 14, 325227) Underneath my non co operation is my earnest desire to wean the evil doer from the evil or harm he is doing, so that I can give him hearty co operation.
('84', 187, 2, 15, 325380) Again if I associate with the so called Moderates or with moneyed men, I do so to seek their co operation in the cause I am handling.
('84', 187, 2, 16, 325514) But I approach them with an open mind, so that I correct myself where I find myself in the wrong.
('84', 187, 2, 17, 325612) I have known of no cause that I have espoused that has suffered because of such association.
('84', 187, 2, 18, 325705) Some critics have suggested that by my present attitude I am lending moral weight to the Allied cause.
('84', 187, 2, 19, 325808) They forget that my offer, such as it is, is conditioned upon the Allies, in this case the British Government, recognizing full independence, qualified during the pendency of the war.
('84', 187, 2, 20, 325992) I see, therefore, no conflict between the principles enunciated in August resolution and what I have now suggested.
('84', 187, 2, 21, 326108) May I suggest to critics that they should wait till the British Government have spoken?
('84', 187, 2, 22, 326196) The statements made by me were meant in the first instance for the Government.
('84', 187, 2, 23, 326275) Mr. Gelder sprang a surprise.
('84', 187, 3, 24, 326305) 1 What follows appeared independently in The Bombay Chronicle.
('84', 187, 3, 25, 326368) 2 Vide “Interview to Stuart Gelder”, 4 7 1944. 3 Vide Appendix “Stuart Gelder’s Cable to News Chronicle” , 12 7 1944.
('84', 188, 0, 1, 326486) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 189
('84', 188, 1, 2, 326533) He has done so with the best of motives.
('84', 188, 1, 3, 326574) After all, there is a higher Power ruling all the actions of human beings.

('84', 191, 1, 2, 330885) 254. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS 1
('84', 191, 2, 3, 330913) PANCHGANI, July 15, 1944
('84', 191, 3, 4, 330938) QUESTION: Will you kindly explain the exact difference between the Cripps Plan and your own as revealed in the Gelder interview?
('84', 191, 4, 5, 331067) ANSWER: My plan contemplates an immediate recognition of full independence for India as a whole, subject to limitations for the duration of the war to meet the requirements of the Allied operations.
('84', 191, 4, 6, 331266) The Cripps Plan, as I understood it, dealt more with the future than with the immediate arrangements.
('84', 191, 4, 7, 331368) Moreover, in my opinion, the Cripps Plan meant dismemberment of India, the Indian States being set up as an all extensive disintegrating factor.
('84', 191, 4, 8, 331513) But if my plan is considered by British statesmen to be not very different from the Cripps Plan, it should be all the easier for them to accept it.
('84', 191, 5, 9, 331661) What if Mr. Jinnah sticks to a plebiscite of Muslims only in the districts or provinces where the Muslims are in majority?
('84', 191, 5, 10, 331784) Neither Qaid e Azam Jinnah nor the Muslim League have pronounced their opinion on Rajaji’s Formula 3. I would deprecate anticipating them.
('84', 191, 5, 11, 331923) Rajaji is with me.
('84', 191, 5, 12, 331942) We have agreed for the sake of conserving my limited energy that he should deal with the questions arising from the Formula.
('84', 191, 5, 13, 332067) For my part I would appeal to the questioners, foreign or Indian, not to forestall the Muslim League.
('84', 191, 6, 14, 332169) How do you propose to fix the ratio of the League and Congress in the national government?
('84', 191, 6, 15, 332260) I must not be drawn into details.
('84', 191, 6, 16, 332294) If the indication of my mind affords any satisfaction to the authorities, they should open the gates of the prison, and let those who can speak with authority pronounce upon my proposal or at least let me confer with them.
('84', 191, 6, 17, 332517) As it is, I do not know that I have not embarrassed them by my sharing my personal opinion with the public before first sharing it with them.
('84', 191, 6, 18, 332659) The publication 4 is premature and not of my seeking.
('84', 191, 7, 19, 332713) 1 Sent by the London office of the United Press of India 2 Vide also “Interview to the Press”, 13 7 1944. 3 Vide “ C. Rajagopalchari’s Formula”, before 5 8 1942 4 By Stuart Gelder of News Chronicle, vide Appendix “Stuart Gelder’s Cable to News Chronicle” , 12 7 1944.
('84', 192, 0, 1, 332981) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 193
('84', 192, 1, 2, 333028) Will you meet Mr. Jinnah personally?
('84', 192, 1, 3, 333065) The question arises from ignorance of facts.
('84', 192, 1, 4, 333110) I am always willing to meet Qaid e Azam Jinnah.
('84', 192, 2, 5, 333158) What are your views on the Bombay Plan 1?
('84', 192, 2, 6, 333200) Do you think crisis like the one which overtook Bengal could be permanently avoided by acceptance of such a plan?
('84', 192, 2, 7, 333314) The Bombay Plan is a post war plan.
('84', 192, 2, 8, 333350) Anyway, the question should be addressed to the authors 2.

('84', 193, 8, 21, 335689) 258. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('84', 193, 9, 22, 335717) PANCHGANI, July 16, 1944 A correspondent asks me what those who, on being discharged, have been served with restriction orders confining them within certain areas or requiring them to report themselves periodically at police thanas, should do.
('84', 193, 9, 23, 335961) I regard all such restrictions as degrading and could not myself submit to them.
('84', 193, 9, 24, 336042) However I know men who, being unable any longer to bear the jail hardships, have preferred the restricted freedom.
('84', 193, 9, 25, 336157) I must refuse to judge their conduct.
('84', 193, 9, 26, 336195) Everyone suffers according to his capacity.
('84', 193, 9, 27, 336239) But it is a serious question for the Government to consider whether it is a necessary part of war effort to wound the spirit of young men and women, whose only fault is that they love their country’s independence before everything else.
('84', 193, 10, 28, 336476) The Hindu, 17 7 1944; also The Bombay Chronicle, 16 7 1944
('84', 193, 11, 29, 336535) 1 From the postmark 2 In the source, the letter is placed after the letters of July 15, 1944. 3 Son and daughter of Vrajlal A. Gandhi, brother of Jaisukhlal Gandhi

('84', 194, 8, 21, 337668) 260. LETTER TO MATHURADAS TRIKUMJI

('84', 194, 10, 23, 337728) MATHURADAS,

('84', 207, 2, 3, 356509) ‘DILKHUSHA’, PANCHGANI, July 18, 1944 Your wire of 11th instant was received here on 14th, but due to pressure of work on the staff that is here, it was given to me onlytoday.

('84', 207, 2, 5, 356759) Evidently I forgot all about the letter I had promised.

('84', 207, 2, 7, 356873) This is the treatment I am having: massage for about an hour all over the body and a hot water bath, lying in a full length tub for about 20 minutes.
('84', 207, 2, 8, 357023) This is all very soothing for me.
('84', 207, 2, 9, 357057) Often before entering the tub I have hot and cold hip baths for five minutes each.
('84', 207, 2, 10, 357140) My food, you know, milk, vegetables, fruit and gur.
('84', 207, 2, 11, 357192) Between three and four, I have an earth bandage—this too, I think, you know.
('84', 207, 2, 12, 357269) Clean earth is mixed with water and made into a dough.
('84', 207, 2, 13, 357324) I take a similar bandage before retiring.
('84', 207, 2, 14, 357366) Horrible medicine I have is bhilama.
('84', 207, 2, 15, 357403) Boiled in water, strained, mixed with milk, I had it for seven days.
('84', 207, 2, 16, 357472) There has been an interval of more than seven days.
('84', 207, 2, 17, 357524) I propose to take it from tomorrow again for seven days.
('84', 207, 2, 18, 357581) In Poona, I had what is supposed to be a specific against hook worm.
('84', 207, 2, 19, 357650) It is called Carbon Tetrachlor Ethylene.
('84', 207, 2, 20, 357691) I am on the onward march.
('84', 207, 2, 21, 357717) Dr. Jivraj Mehta is in Panchgani looking after me.
('84', 207, 2, 22, 357768) Sushila whom you know was with me even in jail.
('84', 207, 2, 23, 357816) I have sent her to Delhi.

('84', 207, 2, 25, 357993) I expect to go to Sevagram, Deo volente, in the early part of August.
('84', 207, 2, 26, 358063) I am here at least till the end of the month.

('84', 210, 4, 7, 361798) 284. A LETTER
('84', 210, 5, 8, 361812) “DILKHUSHA”, PANCHGANI, July 19, 1944
('84', 210, 6, 9, 361850) DEAR FRIEND, I appreciate your very frank letter.
('84', 210, 6, 10, 361900) I shall return the courtesy by being equally frank.
('84', 210, 6, 11, 361952) The difference between now and August, 1942 is that at that time I had no knowledge of the response the people both pro Congress and anti Congress would make.
('84', 210, 6, 12, 362111) Now I know the kind of response they made.
('84', 210, 6, 13, 362154) The heroism, the suffering and the self sacrifice of those who took part in the struggle are beyond praise; but weighed in the scales of Truth and Non violence there were glaring defects in the demonstration and I can only say that India failed to reach her natural goal because of those defects.
('84', 210, 6, 14, 362451) Whatever may be true of other nations I have no doubt that India can come to her own fully only by truthful and non violent means.
('84', 210, 6, 15, 362582) In the face of sabotage and the like the rulers as usual lost their heads and resorted to reprisals unheard of before.
('84', 210, 6, 16, 362701) I write under correction.
('84', 210, 6, 17, 362727) I have asked for an impartial tribunal for investigation of the charges against the Congress and counter charges against the Government.
('84', 210, 6, 18, 362864) Unless I am convinced to the contrary, I shall continue to believe that the mole hill of popular violence has been shown on behalf of the Government to have been a mountain and the Himalayan violence of the authorities has been generally defended as no more than necessary for the occasion.
('84', 210, 6, 19, 363155) I must, therefore, refuse to judge popular action by the footrule of Truth and Non violence unless I can apply the same measure for the

('84', 211, 1, 2, 363691) Governmental action.
('84', 211, 1, 3, 363712) This is one difference.
('84', 211, 1, 4, 363736) The second difference is the terrible and progressive starvation of the people.
('84', 211, 1, 5, 363816) Whether it is due to the wrath of God or the incompetence of the rulers or the universal pressure of the War is not relevant to the elucidation of my reply.
('84', 211, 1, 6, 363973) I hold that these two causes mark a decisive difference between now and 1942. I would be unworthy of my creed if I failed to make use of all the resources of head and heart that God has vouchsafed to me for discovering a solution of the deadlock.
('84', 211, 1, 7, 364220) What is that solution submitted by me ?

('84', 211, 1, 9, 364389) This limitation you know.

('84', 211, 1, 11, 364522) If my proposal reaches full fruition, what is today a war of brute strength against brute strength would be turned into a war for the liberation of the exploited people of the world.
('84', 211, 1, 12, 364705) Then it would be a war between predominantly moral strength plus minimum of brute strength matched against pure brute strength which is being used for the exploitation of China and the weaker states of Europe.

('84', 213, 4, 7, 367662) 288. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS 1
('84', 213, 5, 8, 367692) PANCHGANI, July 19, 1944 I am glad you have put the question exactly as you have seen it in the critical Press.
('84', 213, 5, 9, 367804) I confess that I am not able to go through all Press criticisms and, therefore, I find myself at a disadvantage.
('84', 213, 5, 10, 367917) Your question, therefore, is doubly helpful to me.
('84', 213, 5, 11, 367968) Let me remind critics at the outset that publicity of the interview 2 (to Mr. Stuart Gelder of the News Chronicle) was not of my seeking.
('84', 213, 5, 12, 368106) As I have already remarked 3, it was meant for the powers that be.
('84', 213, 5, 13, 368173) I ask for a dispassionate examination of my proposals on their merits.
('84', 213, 5, 14, 368244) I should not mind a climb down, if it resulted in the attainment of Indian independence.
('84', 213, 5, 15, 368333) I may say that the favourable war situation had nothing to do with my proposal, if only for the simple reason that in the flush of approaching victory, my proposal was not likely even to receive a hearing.
('84', 213, 5, 16, 368539) But as a lover of peace, not merely in India, but peace among all mankind, I could not but make a proposal for what it is worth.
('84', 213, 5, 17, 368668) After all, there is such a thing as world opinion, apart from the opinion of authorities.
('84', 213, 5, 18, 368758) A united, enlightened, powerful opinion of the world is bound to affect those who are today wielding what appears to be absolute power in waging the war, and experience has taught me that one should not be afraid of being misunderstood or of rejection of one’s
('84', 213, 6, 19, 369019) 1 The report said: “A journalist suggested to Gandhiji that it had been said by a large section of the overseas Press that he (Gandhiji) had revised his attitude because of the favourable war situation and also because the Congress suffered ‘a heavy defeat’ and that his latest stand was considered as ‘a climb down’.” 2 Vide “Interview to Stuart Gelder”, 4 7 1944 and 4/6 7 1944. 3Vide “Statement to the Press”, 12 7 1944 and “Interview to the Press”, 13 7 1944.
('84', 214, 0, 1, 369483) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 215
('84', 214, 1, 2, 369530) proposal, if it is sound in itself.
('84', 214, 1, 3, 369566) The heavy defeat of the Congress I do not feel at all.
('84', 214, 1, 4, 369621) I have not a shadow of doubt that this passage through fire and suffering by thousands of Congressmen and Congress sympathizers has raised the status of India and the strength of the people.
('84', 214, 1, 5, 369812) Throughout all my long public life I have not experienced a sense of defeat, heavy or otherwise.
('84', 214, 1, 6, 369909) I know many Congressmen are labouring under a sense of frustration.
('84', 214, 1, 7, 369977) Poor men, they do not know the value of self suffering.
('84', 214, 1, 8, 370033) But even that frustration is only momentary.
('84', 214, 1, 9, 370078) Victory, that is, independence of India as a whole, is a certainty.
('84', 214, 1, 10, 370146) That it may not come in my lifetime is a matter of indifference to me.
('84', 214, 1, 11, 370217) I can but work for it till the end of my life.
('84', 214, 1, 12, 370264) Victory will come when God wills it.
('84', 214, 1, 13, 370301) Only today I wrote to a friend who wanted to know the difference between now and August 1942. From it I quote relevant sentences.
('84', 214, 1, 14, 370431) I have said the difference between now and August 1942 is that at that time I had no knowledge of the response the people, both pro Congress and anti Congress, would make.
('84', 214, 1, 15, 370603) Now I know the kind of response they made.
('84', 214, 1, 16, 370646) The heroism, suffering and self sacrifice of those who took part in this struggle are beyond praise, but weighed in the scale of truth and non violence there are glaring defects in the popular demonstration.
('84', 214, 1, 17, 370854) And I can only say that India failed to reachher natural goal at the time because of these defects.
('84', 214, 1, 18, 370954) Whatever may be true of other nations, I have no doubt that India can come to her own fully by truth and non violent means.
('84', 214, 1, 19, 371078) In the face of sabotage and the like, rulers have as usual lost their heads and resorted to reprisals unheard of before.
('84', 214, 1, 20, 371199) I write this under correction.
('84', 214, 1, 21, 371230) I have asked 1 for an impartial tribunal for the investigation of charges against the Congress and my counter charges against the Government.
('84', 214, 1, 22, 371372) Unless I am convinced to the contrary, I shall continue to believe that the molehill of popular violence has been shown on behalf of Government to have been a mountain and the Himalayan violence of the authorities has been generally defended as no more than necessary for the occasion.
('84', 214, 1, 23, 371658) I must, therefore, refuse to judge popular action by the footrule of truth and non violence unless I can apply the same measure for Government action.
('84', 214, 1, 24, 371809) This is one difference.
('84', 214, 1, 25, 371833) The second difference is the terrible progressive starvation of the people.
('84', 214, 1, 26, 371909) Whether it is due to wrath of God or incompetence of the rulers or universal
('84', 214, 2, 27, 371986) 1Vide “Letter to Additional Secretary, Home Department, Government of India”, 15 7 1943 and 26 10 1943.

('84', 215, 1, 2, 372132) pressure of war, is not relevant to the elucidation of my reply.
('84', 215, 1, 3, 372197) I hold that these two causes mark decisive differences between now and August 1942. I would be unworthy of my creed, if I failed to make use of all the resources of head and heart that God has vouchsafed to me for discovering a solution of the deadlock.
('84', 215, 1, 4, 372451) What that solution is, is submitted 1 by me.
('84', 215, 1, 5, 372496) It is nothing less than the present declaration of freedom of India, limited during the war period by the exigencies of the war.
('84', 215, 1, 6, 372625) This limitation you know.
('84', 215, 1, 7, 372651) If the offer is accepted, then I would be criminally guilty if I did not advise the Congress to accept it.
('84', 215, 1, 8, 372758) If my proposal reaches full fruition, what is today a war of brute strength would be turned into a war for the liberation of the exploited peoples of the world.
('84', 215, 1, 9, 372919) Then it would be a war between predominantly moral strength plus the minimum of brute strength matched against pure brute strength which is being used for the exploitation of China and the weaker States of Europe.
('84', 215, 1, 10, 373133) Rajaji’s offer 2 has seen the light of day only now, but I had personally subscribed to it when I was fasting in prison camp.
('84', 215, 1, 11, 373259) It is now sixteen months old.
('84', 215, 1, 12, 373289) For the rest of the offer, I must carry out the contract between Rajaji and myself.
('84', 215, 1, 13, 373373) He is to bear the brunt of all criticism that might be made about that offer.
('84', 215, 1, 14, 373451) Finally I would say to my critics to enter with me into the sufferings not only of the people of India but of those, whetherengaged in the war or not of the whole world.
('84', 215, 1, 15, 373621) I cannot look at this butchery going on in the world with indifference.
('84', 215, 1, 16, 373693) I have an unchangeable faith that it is beneath the dignity of men to resort to mutual slaughter.
('84', 215, 1, 17, 373791) I have no doubt that there is a way out.
('84', 215, 1, 18, 373832) I am vain enough to think that my malaria was a godsend, and He used Government as His instrument for discharging me.
('84', 215, 1, 19, 373950) I should be never reconciled to myself if, for fear of hostile criticism or wrath of impatient Congressmen or even possible displeasure of members of the Working Committee, I did not express personal opinion, the acceptance of which, I hold, must result in bringing peace to the world, even out of the present turmoil.

('84', 220, 1, 2, 381486) 295. ANSWER S TO QUESTIONS 1
('84', 220, 2, 3, 381515) PANCHGANI, July 20, 1944
('84', 220, 3, 4, 381540) QUESTION:
('84', 220, 4, 5, 381550) 1. Do you agree with inferences being drawn in London following the publication of your interview 2 that you favour full entry of free Indian government into war against Japan?
('84', 220, 5, 6, 381727) ANSWER: Yes.
('84', 220, 6, 7, 381740) 2. Regarding Pakistan there is a tendency here to interpret your last contact with Mr. Jinnah as indicating your acceptance of Pakistan.
('84', 220, 6, 8, 381877) Is this so?
('84', 220, 6, 9, 381889) Mr. Rajagopalachari’s Formula 3 indicates my way of meeting the communal difficulty.
('84', 220, 6, 10, 381974) I am indifferent whether it is called Pakistan or not.
('84', 220, 7, 11, 382029) 3. In the event of free Indian government taking control of finance, what policy will you advise regarding Anglo American capital interest in India?
('84', 220, 7, 12, 382178) My advice would be to respect Anglo American capital interest, which, in the absence of agreement, is not considered by an impartial tribunal inconsistent with Indian national interests.
('84', 220, 8, 13, 382365) 4. Will you outline your conception of the role of a free India in the post war world with special relationship to the peoples of the British Commonwealth and the United States of America?
('84', 220, 8, 14, 382554) If I have any say in post war policy, the free national government of India will promote a Commonwealth of all world States naturally including British Commonwealth and America and also, if possible, belligerent States so as to reduce to the minimum the possibility of armed conflict between different States.
('84', 220, 8, 15, 382864) The Bombay Chronicle, 22 7 1944
('84', 220, 9, 16, 382896) 1 The report said that the questions were cabled to Gandhiji from London, on July 18, by Cavalcade, a British news magazine, which claimed that it had “consistently supported the cause of Indian freedom, and added that it was advised by Mr. Pulin Seal, Chairman of the Executive Committee of Indian Congressmen in London, to ask if Gandhiji would give for publication his answers to four questions”.

('84', 221, 1, 2, 383624) 296. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('84', 221, 2, 3, 383652) PANCHGANI, July 21, 1944 1 have answered the question 1 as a confirmed war resister; and if I became a party to the August resolution and I now suggest what I consider to be a perfectly honourable solution, it is because thereby I expect to promote the war resistance effort.
('84', 221, 2, 4, 383928) I dream of a world where there will be no strife between nations and nations.
('84', 221, 2, 5, 384006) It is possible only if Great Britain, America and Russia contemplate such world peace.
('84', 221, 2, 6, 384093) I deliberately omit China for, unfortunately China is not able like Russia, Britain or America to stand alone, though much bigger than all these three powerful nations and more ancient.
('84', 221, 2, 7, 384279) China is still menaced by Japan and needs all the assistance that she can get before she can rise to her full height.
('84', 221, 2, 8, 384397) I see no chance for the groaning world, unless the three States now demonstrate to the world that they have one mind, that they are not putting forth the effort they are doing for any selfish design, butthat they are truly fighting for all democracies on the face of the earth.
('84', 221, 2, 9, 384675) My proposal is an acid test, and I have no shadow of doubt that its hearty acceptance by Britain will immediately turn the scales and ensure the defeat of the belligerent powers and fill exploited nations of the earth with hope.
('84', 221, 2, 10, 384904) You see that I am, therefore, fighting for no small stake.
('84', 221, 3, 11, 384963) The Bombay Chronicle, 22 7 1944
('84', 221, 4, 12, 384995) 1 The reference is to the fourth question of the preceding item.
('84', 221, 4, 13, 385060) 2 The report concluded: “Gandhiji invited questions and the Pressmen fired out a few questions and when they stumbled and seemed to get stuck up, Gandhiji smiled and said that he would lead them on.
('84', 221, 4, 14, 385259) He could put even mischievous questions, he said, but thought that was not the proper time for it.”

('84', 222, 5, 12, 386074) 298. INTERVIEW TO THE UNITED PRESS OF INDIA 1
('84', 222, 6, 13, 386120) PANCHGANI, July 22, 1944 I am not afraid of the word ‘diarchy’.
('84', 222, 6, 14, 386184) 2 The arrangement proposed seems to me to be as natural as the present is unnatural.
('84', 222, 6, 15, 386269) If Allied operations have to continue with India as the base, as they must, my proposal is that they are only feasible and consistent with immediate declaration of India’s independence.
('84', 222, 6, 16, 386455) But I heartily agree that there must be mutual trust.
('84', 222, 6, 17, 386509) If it cannot be established, my proposal is valueless.
('84', 222, 6, 18, 386564) The winter of mutual distrust among the Boers and Britons was overnight turned into a summer of mutual trust after the sanguinary Boer War.
('84', 222, 6, 19, 386704) In our case, when the victory becomes a mutual interest, mutual trust follows as a matter of course.
('84', 222, 6, 20, 386805) The Bombay Chronicle, 23 7 1944
('84', 222, 7, 21, 386837) 1 The report said that a special representative of the United Press of India “sought elucidation from Gandhiji on the points raised by the British Press, specially the Delhi correspondent of the London Times, on Gandhiji’s proposals that military control shall be in the hands of the Viceroy and the Commander in Chief”.
('84', 222, 7, 22, 387158) 2 The Times correspondent had remarked: “What is proposed in fact is a kind of diarchy in the military field which would be practicable only on the assumption that there is complete identity of aims and; mutual trust, and past events have done nothing to create these.”

('84', 226, 1, 2, 391646) 304. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS
('84', 226, 2, 3, 391674) PANCHGANI, July 23, 1944 The Sind Home Minister 1, in defending the forcible prevention of a member of the Sind Legislative Assembly from exercising his right of attending the Assembly meeting, is reported to have said: “Our information is that, since the release of Mahatma Gandhi, the subversive movement had been restarted throughout India and that leading personalities behind that movement were again trying to direct it.” He referred in this connection to the escape from Karachi jail of three under trial prisoners concerned in the Marriot Road dacoity case and said, “this is all in pursuance of the policy of reviving the movement.” All the information that I have gathered since my discharge is absolutely contrary to the statement alleged to have been made by the Sind Home Minister.
('84', 226, 2, 4, 392469) May it be that he is badly served by his informants?
('84', 226, 2, 5, 392522) Is it not his duty to supply the public with details of the information in his possession?
('84', 226, 2, 6, 392613) Who are the leading personalities, and what is the subversive movement?
('84', 226, 2, 7, 392685) If there is any connection between the escape from Karachi jail of the under trial prisoners and the supposed revival of the so called subversive movement, the least that is necessary is to mention these names and show the connection.
('84', 226, 2, 8, 392920) I would not have taken notice of the Sind Home Minister’s statement but for the fact that it is likely to be used by enemies of India’s freedom to frustrate the efforts that I am making for the cause of independence.
('84', 226, 2, 9, 393137) I am sure the Sind Home Minister is as anxious as I am for India’s freedom, attained through peaceful means.
('84', 226, 2, 10, 393246) I may add, too, that throughout this anxious period my attempt has been, through the Press and in my talks with Congressmen and others, to show that I am opposed unequivocally to sabotage and the like.
('84', 226, 2, 11, 393448) I have also stated in explicit terms that I never have had an opportunity of starting civil disobedience and that the authority vested in me by the A.I.C.C. expired on my imprisonment, and could not automatically be revived by my discharge on grounds of ill health.
('84', 226, 3, 12, 393714) 1 Haji Muhammad Hashim Gazdar
('84', 227, 0, 1, 393744) 228 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 227, 1, 2, 393786) Therefore assuming that civil disobedience is described as subversive movement, which I deny, even that cannot be offered by anybody on behalf of Congress.
('84', 227, 1, 3, 393942) But I have said at the same time that normal Congress activities of a purely peaceful nature must be carried on even if restrictions are imposed upon them.
('84', 227, 1, 4, 394098) It is up to the authorities, therefore, if they are at all inclined to respond to my advice, not to interfere with such activities as were permissible, say, before August 1942, such as, for instance, monthly flag demonstration, public meetings and the like.
('84', 227, 1, 5, 394356) The Bombay Chronicle, 24 7 1944
('84', 227, 2, 6, 394388) 305. INTRODUCTION TO “DRAFT INSTRUCTION FOR CIVIL RESISTERS”
('84', 227, 3, 7, 394449) PANCHGANI, July 24, 1944 The following is the literal translation of draft instructions 1 for the guidance of civil resisters.
('84', 227, 3, 8, 394576) The draft was in Hindustani and copies were prepared in both Devanagari and Persian scripts.
('84', 227, 3, 9, 394669) It was prepared on 7th August, 1942, and was placed before the Working Committee and discussed on the 8th of August.
('84', 227, 3, 10, 394786) The Working Committee was again to have met on the morning of the 9th August.
('84', 227, 3, 11, 394864) But that was not to be.
('84', 227, 3, 12, 394888) I was to put before the Working Committee my view of the negotiations which I was to carry on with the Government.
('84', 227, 3, 13, 395003) They were to cover a period of at least three weeks.
('84', 227, 3, 14, 395056) The instructions were to see the light of day only on failure of the contemplated negotiations.
('84', 227, 3, 15, 395152) The object of publishing the draft at present is twofold.
('84', 227, 3, 16, 395210) It shows how my mind was running at the time.
('84', 227, 3, 17, 395256) The draft is an additional answer to the adverse suggestions made in the Government indictment about my non violence.
('84', 227, 3, 18, 395374) The second and more relevant object is to let Congress workers know how I would have acted at the time.
('84', 227, 3, 19, 395478) I have come to know that my name was freely used to justify acts of sabotage and the like.
('84', 227, 3, 20, 395569) I would like every Congressman and for that matter every Indian to feel that on him and her lies the responsibility of freeing India from the incubus of foreign rule.Non violent suffering is the only way.
('84', 227, 3, 21, 395774) Freedom of India means
('84', 227, 4, 22, 395797) 1 Vide “Draft Instructions for Civil Resisters”, 4 8 1942.
('84', 228, 0, 1, 395856) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 229
('84', 228, 1, 2, 395903) everything for us but it means also much for the world.
('84', 228, 1, 3, 395959) For, freedom won through non violence will mean the inauguration of a new order in the world.
('84', 228, 1, 4, 396053) There is no hope for mankind in any other way.
('84', 228, 2, 5, 396100) M. K. GANDHI
('84', 228, 3, 6, 396113) Gandhiji’s Correspondence with the Government, pp.

('84', 230, 6, 10, 398115) 311. LETTER TO C. RAJAGOPALACHARI
('84', 230, 7, 11, 398149) PANCHGANI, July 25, 1944
('84', 230, 8, 12, 398174) MY DEAR C. R., It is early morning.
('84', 230, 8, 13, 398210) I feel your absence.
('84', 230, 8, 14, 398231) Questions regarding Pakistan crop up.
('84', 230, 8, 15, 398269) Papers are being sent to you.
('84', 230, 8, 16, 398299) But that is not enough.
('84', 230, 8, 17, 398323) Some questions I must answer myself.
('84', 230, 8, 18, 398360) It is not right that I shouldanswer them without you.
('84', 230, 8, 19, 398414) I won’t drag you to Panchgani.
('84', 230, 8, 20, 398445) But I do want you to be in Sevagram when I reach there.
('84', 230, 8, 21, 398501) I hope to be there on 3rd August.
('84', 230, 8, 22, 398535) Try to reach there that day and come with the intention of settling down there till my fate is decided one way or the other.
('84', 230, 8, 23, 398660) Every decision of my fate must necessarily be final just for the time being.
('84', 230, 8, 24, 398737) It is as wet as when you left.
('84', 230, 8, 25, 398768) But I am flourishing.
('84', 230, 8, 26, 398790) And I see that I can like this place if there is a refuge for poor people.
('84', 230, 8, 27, 398865) It has been built for the rich or the upper middle class.
('84', 230, 10, 28, 398923) From a photostat: G.N. 2095
('84', 230, 11, 29, 398951) 1 The telegram is extracted from Pyarelal’s letter dated July 25 to the addressee, which, inter alia, read: “Gandhiji has decided to leave for Sevagram.
('84', 230, 11, 30, 399104) The stay here had done him good and from the point of view of his health a further stay for a fortnight would have been eminently desirable.
('84', 230, 11, 31, 399245) But his soul yearned for Sevagram and the doctors saw no good in thwarting his innate nature.
('84', 230, 11, 32, 399339) Gandhiji has just sent you the following wire.” 2 ibid

('84', 234, 2, 3, 403581) PANCHGANI, July 26, 1944
('84', 234, 3, 4, 403606) MY DEAR CLEMENT 1, I had your sweet letter whilst I was a prisoner.
('84', 234, 3, 5, 403674) From there I wrote no letters.
('84', 234, 3, 6, 403705) Ba is ever with me though her body has been consigned to the flames.
('84', 234, 3, 7, 403774) Though I see this truth through the reason and the heart, world wide sympathy I have prized.
('84', 234, 3, 8, 403867) It has made me realize the goodness of God as never before.
('84', 234, 3, 9, 403927) I was glad to have some account of you from Manilal.
('84', 234, 3, 10, 403980) He was able to tell me that you had kept up the old tradition.
('84', 234, 3, 11, 404043) Do tell me all about the whole family—how and what they are doing.
('84', 234, 3, 12, 404110) As I write this, all the old associations revive and make me glad.
('84', 234, 3, 13, 404177) With love to you all,
('84', 234, 4, 14, 404199) Yours, M. K. GANDHI

('84', 240, 2, 3, 413210) PANCHGANI, July 27, 1944
('84', 240, 3, 4, 413235) Mahatma Gandhi said that he had been greatly benefited by his stay in Panchgani and his health had considerably improved.
('84', 240, 4, 5, 413357) The Nawab of Wai who introduced the citizens to Mahatma Gandhi expressed the hope that he would visit the place annually.
('84', 240, 5, 6, 413479) Mahatma Gandhi talked to the gathering quite informally, and replying to the Vice Principal of a local European school who said, he had seen Mahatma Gandhi in Charlestown while he was a young boy nearly forty years ago in South Africa, Mahatma Gandhi said, “Oh yes.
('84', 240, 5, 7, 413745) I remember Charlestown well.
('84', 240, 5, 8, 413774) Don’t I know Charlestown where I got a good hiding?” 2 and burst into laughter.
('84', 240, 6, 9, 413854) Mahatma Gandhi said that he liked Panchgani better than other hill stations he had visited in India, but referred to the lack of accommodation and said that wealthy people should construct quarters so that the poor could also take advantage of the climate for recuperating their health.
('84', 240, 6, 10, 414141) The Bombay Chronicle, 28 7 1944

('84', 242, 7, 14, 416145) 333. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('84', 242, 8, 15, 416173) PANCHGANI, July 28, 1944 The question most discussed with me by visitors is whether I approve of underground activities.
('84', 242, 8, 16, 416294) These include sabotage, the publication of unauthorized sheets, etc.
('84', 242, 8, 17, 416363) It has been suggested to me that without some workers going underground they could have done nothing.
('84', 242, 8, 18, 416465) Some have contended that destruction of property, including dislocation of communication, provided that safety of human life could be ensured, should surely be counted as non violence.
('84', 242, 8, 19, 416650) Examples of other nations as having not hesitated to do all these things and much worse have been cited.
('84', 242, 8, 20, 416755) My reply is that no nation has, so far as I know, deliberately used truth and non violence as exclusive means for the attainment of freedom.
('84', 242, 8, 21, 416896) Judged by that standard, I say unhesitatingly, that underground activities, even though utterly innocent in themselves, should have no place in the technique of non violence.
('84', 242, 8, 22, 417071) Sabotage and all it means, including destruction of property, is in itself violence.
('84', 242, 8, 23, 417156) Though these activities may be shown to have touched the imagination and enthusiasm, I have no doubt that they have harmed the movement as a whole.
('84', 242, 8, 24, 417304) I swear by the Constructive Programme.
('84', 242, 8, 25, 417343) Let me recount the
('84', 243, 0, 1, 417362) 244 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 243, 1, 2, 417404) items of that programme: 1. Communal unity 2. Removal of untouchability 3. Prohibition 4. Khadi 5. Other village industries 6. Village sanitation 7. New or basic education 8. Adult education 9. Uplift of women 10. Service of the so called aboriginals 11. Education in health and hygiene 12. Propaganda of rashtra bhasha 13. Love of one’s own language 14. Working for economic equality.
('84', 243, 1, 3, 417790) Unfortunately the workers have not developed in that programme the living faith which I have.
('84', 243, 1, 4, 417884) I can but re emphasize the importance of that programme.
('84', 243, 1, 5, 417941) And, if the whole of India could be converted to take to that programme, we should reach our goal in the quickest manner possible.
('84', 243, 1, 6, 418072) To the workers who are still underground, I advise: If you share my conviction that underground activity is not conducive to the growth of the spirit of active non violence, you will discover yourselves and take the risk of being imprisoned, believing that imprisonment, thus undergone, itself helps the freedom movement.
('84', 243, 2, 7, 418394) The Bombay Chronicle, 29 7 1944
('84', 243, 3, 8, 418426) 1Vide also Appendices “Discussion on Underground Activities”, after 31 3 1944 and “Discussion with Underground Workers”, after 31 3 1944.
('84', 244, 0, 1, 418564) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 245

('84', 246, 1, 2, 421238) 338. TALK TO BOMBAY CONGRESS LEADERS 1
('84', 246, 2, 3, 421277) PANCHGANI, [July] 2 29/30, 1944 Ninth August is a great day and it is the duty of all to observe it.
('84', 246, 2, 4, 421378) But that part of the resolution which speaks of mass civil disobedience cannot be brought into force because the authority to put it into force was vested solely in me.
('84', 246, 2, 5, 421547) Today I see no possibility of mass civil disobedience either according to that authority or according to circumstances.
('84', 246, 2, 6, 421667) Mass civil disobedience is one thing and the exercise of citizen’s right and civil disobedience in pursuance of it is different.
('84', 246, 2, 7, 421796) The people have been exercising the right of defensive individual civil disobedience since 1920. People in general may not understand the difference between mass civil disobedience and civil disobedience for the defence of individual citizen’s rights.
('84', 246, 2, 8, 422048) But it is necessary to know the differences.
('84', 246, 2, 9, 422093) On such occasions as 9th August, people have to understand the difference, and exercise this right of individual civil disobedience for the defence of civil rights.
('84', 246, 2, 10, 422258) In such places where it is necessary to take the permission of police for meetings, processions and such common civil rights, permission from the police should be asked for.
('84', 246, 2, 11, 422432) But, if such permission is not granted, people should exercise their civil right in spite of the refusal.
('84', 246, 3, 12, 422538) Chief Commissioner’s Office, Bombay, File No.
('84', 246, 3, 13, 422584) 3001/HP.

('84', 247, 1, 2, 423083) 339. LETTER TO P. C. JOSHI
('84', 247, 2, 3, 423110) AS AT SEVAGRAM,
('84', 247, 3, 4, 423126) CAMP PANCHGANI, July 30, 1944
('84', 247, 4, 5, 423156) DEAR FRIEND, I had duly received your letter 1 of 14th June and also your letter of 26th of July sent with Shri Kumaramangalam.
('84', 247, 4, 6, 423284) Your answer to my first question provokes further question for your reply.
('84', 247, 4, 7, 423359) I understand that although the chief actors among the Allied powers are by no means inclined towards real democracy, you think that by the time the war ends, their designs will be confounded and that the people all the world over will suddenly find self expression and overthrow the present leaders.
('84', 247, 4, 8, 423659) In the peoples, according to answer, I am entitled to include us, other Asiatics and Negroes, for that matter perhaps, also the proletariat of Japan and Germany.
('84', 247, 4, 9, 423821) If such is your belief, I must confess that I do not share it but I keep myself open to conviction.
('84', 247, 4, 10, 423921) Meanwhile I suggest that the title ‘people’s war’ is highly misleading.
('84', 247, 4, 11, 423993) It enables the Government in India to claim that at least one popular party considers this as people’s war.
('84', 247, 4, 12, 424101) I suggest, too, that Russia’s limited alliance with the Allied powers cannot by any stretch of imagination convert what was before an imperialistic war against that Nazi combine, into a people’s war.
('84', 247, 4, 13, 424301) Holding the view I do, it is superfluous for me now to answer your argument that “this war has split the world into two camps”.
('84', 247, 4, 14, 424429) Between Scylla and Charybdis, if I sail in either direction, I suffer shipwreck.
('84', 247, 4, 15, 424510) Therefore I have to be in the midst of the storm.
('84', 247, 4, 16, 424560) I suggested a way out.
('84', 247, 4, 17, 424583) Naturally it has been rejected because the powers that be do not want to relax their grip on India.
('84', 247, 4, 18, 424683) As I am composing this letter to you, I have read and re read your argument.
('84', 247, 4, 19, 424760) Every paragraph offends; for, to me, it lacks reality.
('84', 247, 4, 20, 424815) Please believe me that my prejudice against your party has nothing to do with my examination of your answer to the first question.
('84', 247, 5, 21, 424946) Q. 2. Your answer, as far as it goes, I hold to be completely satisfactory.
('84', 247, 5, 22, 425022) I will not ask you for further proof about your finances.
('84', 247, 5, 23, 425080) After I have dealt with your answers, I will put my difficulties before
('84', 247, 6, 24, 425152) 1 Vide Appendix “Letter from P. C. Joshi”, 14 6 1944.
('84', 248, 0, 1, 425206) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 249
('84', 248, 1, 2, 425253) Your answers to the other questions do not admit of a categorical reply.
('84', 248, 1, 3, 425326) I understand your answers and appreciate them too.
('84', 248, 1, 4, 425377) If I was free from prejudices, I would have no hesitation in accepting your answers.
('84', 248, 1, 5, 425462) 1 But my difficulty is real and I ask for your sympathy.
('84', 248, 1, 6, 425519) When I make the admission that I have prejudices, it is an appeal to you to have patience with me and to disarm my prejudices in the best manner you can.
('84', 248, 1, 7, 425673) I can only give you my assurance that I am ready to see anybody you want me to see, to read anything you want me to read and to examine every argument or fact produced by you as dispassionately as I can.
('84', 248, 1, 8, 425877) I give you this further assurance that I have not acted upon my prejudice, nor shall I do so, unless the prejudices harden into a confirmed belief that your party represents a force of evil and is really an obstacle in the way of the fight for freedom.
('84', 248, 1, 9, 426130) I am not likely to have that belief easily and, if I have it, you shall have ample notice so as to enable you to wean me from it.
('84', 248, 1, 10, 426260) I know your worth.
('84', 248, 1, 11, 426279) You have very able young men and women, as selfless as I would claim to be.
('84', 248, 1, 12, 426355) You are all hard working and possess great energy and you impose strict discipline on your workers.
('84', 248, 1, 13, 426455) All this I prize and admire.
('84', 248, 1, 14, 426484) I would not easily lose such a force because of any preconceived notions of mine.
('84', 248, 1, 15, 426566) If I have been inordinately long in dealing with your answers which you sent me so promptly, it was because, as you are aware, I was preoccupied and also because I was examining the evidence that was pouring in upon me unsolicited against your party.
('84', 248, 1, 16, 426817) 2 I asked them to let me use their names and they have given me the permission.

('84', 248, 1, 18, 426955) I did not even know that he was coming and when he did ask for an appointment 3, it was in connection with my acceptance of the Rajaji Formula 4. Butreally he took the greater part of my time to tell me that the communists had done great injury to the national cause.
('84', 248, 1, 19, 427223) I am using a milder term than

('84', 251, 2, 6, 433780) 341. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS
('84', 251, 3, 7, 433808) PANCHGANI, July 30, 1944 I have noticed this.
('84', 251, 3, 8, 433854) 2 It has caused me pain as also amazement that the representatives of the British nation, who have a long and distinguished record of heroic fight for political freedom, should divorce the economic development of India from political subjection and give the former preference over the latter.
('84', 251, 3, 9, 434147) To me it looks like putting the cart before the horse, and I have not yet seen any horse performing the trick of pushing the cart with its nose.
('84', 251, 3, 10, 434292) It was, therefore, a pleasure to find two noted industrialists, Mr. J. R. D. Tata and Sir Homi Mody, summarily rejecting the idea put forth in the House of Commons and holding out, I suppose, from bitter experience, that the economic development of India was dependent upon the solution of the political deadlock, in other words a proper national government functioning at the Centre.
('84', 251, 3, 11, 434677) I suppose they had in mind the gigantic concessions that have been made during recent years to British monopolists.
('84', 251, 3, 12, 434793) They must have had in mind also the strangling of Indian enterprise.
('84', 251, 3, 13, 434862) What can, therefore, happen without a national government is not the economic development of India, but its exploitation and degradation.
('84', 251, 4, 14, 435000) 1Vide also the following item.
('84', 251, 4, 15, 435031) 2 According to the report, Gandhiji was alluding to “the House of Commons debate with particular reference to the consensus of opinion .
('84', 251, 4, 16, 435168) that the economic development of India was of greater importance than the solution of the political deadlock”.
('84', 251, 4, 17, 435279) Vide also the preceding item.
('84', 252, 0, 1, 435309) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 253
('84', 252, 1, 2, 435356) Members of the House of Commons, not knowing the realities in India, may philosophize and talk of the immediate importance of economic development.
('84', 252, 1, 3, 435504) I wish they can see what is going on today inIndia.
('84', 252, 1, 4, 435556) I have no shadow of doubt in my mind that the Bengal famine, as also famines in other parts of India, were man made and not God made.
('84', 252, 1, 5, 435690) I need not impugn the honesty of the rulers who have been sent out to India from Britain.
('84', 252, 1, 6, 435780) I hold that in spite of all the honesty that the British rulers can summon to their assistance, it is impossible for them to get behind the Indian skin and know the real disease.
('84', 252, 1, 7, 435959) The consensus of opinion in the House of Commons, therefore, is for me a terrible pointer.
('84', 252, 1, 8, 436050) It confirms me in my opinion that the “Quit India” resolution was no hasty cry conceived in anger.
('84', 252, 1, 9, 436149) To put the same in parliamentary language, it demands that India must be now governed by Indians chosen by her own people—not a coterie but the whole mass of the people without distinction of race, creed or colour.
('84', 252, 1, 10, 436364) It is unfortunate that the House of Commons has once more missed the opportunity of making the issue between the Allied powers and the Axis powers a real issue of democracy versus autocracy, or the exploitation of classes or nations by a class or a nation armed to the teeth.
('84', 252, 1, 11, 436640) My offer presented that issue in the clearest possible language that I could command.
('84', 252, 1, 12, 436726) It was presented on behalf of all the exploited nations and races of the earth.
('84', 252, 1, 13, 436806) It is a great pity that the Lords and the Commons have turned down my offer.
('84', 252, 1, 14, 436883) The Allies will have their victory, but the exploited races will not feel the glow of it.
('84', 252, 1, 15, 436973) They will know that the seeds of another and deadlier war will be sown by that very victor.
('84', 252, 1, 16, 437065) I ask myself the question: ‘Must rivers of blood flow for such an empty victory?’
('84', 252, 2, 17, 437147) Asked when he expected to meet Mr. Jinnah, Mahatma Gandhi said: I expect to meet the Qaid e Azam as soon as he wants me, of course, health permitting.
('84', 252, 2, 18, 437298) The publication of the Formula 1 is in pursuit of negotiations for a communal settlement.
('84', 252, 2, 19, 437388) It is not an idle effort.
('84', 252, 2, 20, 437414) It is conceived in all sincerity.
('84', 252, 2, 21, 437448) It is unfortunate that the criticism that has been levelled against it, so far as I can see, has been conceived out of prejudice or careless study of the Formula.
('84', 252, 2, 22, 437611) Nor is it an offer on the part of any party.
('84', 252, 2, 23, 437656) It is a contribution from two life servants of the nation towards the solution of the communal tangle, which has hitherto defied solution.
('84', 252, 2, 24, 437795) It is in open invitation to all
('84', 252, 3, 25, 437827) 1 Rajaji Formula; vide Appendix “C. Rajagopalachari’s Formula”, after 5 8 1942.
('84', 253, 0, 1, 437907) 254 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 253, 1, 2, 437949) parties to apply their minds to the solution.
('84', 253, 1, 3, 437995) The Rajaji Formula is intended as a help to all lovers of the country.
('84', 253, 1, 4, 438066) It is the best we could conceive, but it is open to amendment, as it is open to rejection or acceptance.
('84', 253, 2, 5, 438171) Gandhiji told that British Government’s rejection of the offer does not affect the Rajaji Formula in anyway whatsoever.
('84', 253, 2, 6, 438291) As far as he remembered, Gelder did notthe proposal, and, if he did, he must have got it from Rajaji and not from him.
('84', 253, 3, 7, 438410) In a way the rejection of my offer for the resolution of the political deadlock enables all parties to concentrate their attention on communal settlement.
('84', 253, 3, 8, 438565) Whilst I had said and repeat that the presence of a third party effectively prevents a solution, it was never meant to convey that I would make no attempt at an honourable solution, even while the third party continued to dominate this land of ours.
('84', 253, 3, 9, 438815) No one will be more pleased than I, if we can pull through a solution which satisfied all parties.
('84', 253, 4, 10, 438914) To a reporter who asked if Mahatma Gandhi would advocate Congressmen going back to jail in view of the British Government’s rejection of his proposals, Mahatma Gandhi said: Have you ever known any sane person without any cause going to jail, or after discharge going back to jail?
('84', 253, 4, 11, 439195) But a person who holds his self respect or his country’s liberty dearer than life itself invites suffering even unto death in defending either and, in that process, if jail comes his way, he welcomes it.
('84', 253, 4, 12, 439399) The question, therefore, should be addressed to the Government: ‘When do you propose to take back to jail those whom you have released?’ I know that Government are not going to oblige you by answering your question.
('84', 253, 4, 13, 439615) The Hindu, 1 8 1944

('84', 255, 4, 7, 441527) 345. LETTER TO A. V. THAKKAR
('84', 255, 5, 8, 441556) July 31, 1944
('84', 255, 6, 9, 441570) BAPA, This is just to make you laugh, if I can.
('84', 255, 6, 10, 441618) When there is a clash of temperaments, father son, husband wife, friend friend, do not break off their relationship but live separately.
('84', 255, 6, 11, 441755) Compared to you, Swami is as meek as a woman.
('84', 255, 6, 12, 441801) We have among us men who have more than one wife.
('84', 255, 6, 13, 441851) You have a right to have many wives like Swami.
('84', 255, 6, 14, 441899) All these days you put up with him.
('84', 255, 6, 15, 441935) Pull on for a few more years.
('84', 255, 6, 16, 441965) Little more of life remains.
('84', 255, 6, 17, 441994) And I have explained how to carry on.
('84', 255, 6, 18, 442032) You are working with all your strength.

('84', 258, 0, 1, 446510) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 259
('84', 258, 1, 2, 446557) 351. INTERVIEW TO “DAILY WORKER”
('84', 258, 2, 3, 446590) BOMBAY, August 2, 1944
('84', 258, 3, 4, 446613) Q. You promise all aid to the Allied war effort.
('84', 258, 3, 5, 446662) 1 How concretely will the character and quantity of the war effort in India and other countries be changed through the establishment of a national government in India?
('84', 258, 4, 6, 446830) Mahatma Gandhi replied that the question required a detailed answer, whereas the basis of his offer was to give moral weight to the Allied cause.
('84', 258, 4, 7, 446976) This the cause lacked at present.
('84', 258, 5, 8, 447010) Asked to explain what he meant by “adding moral weight to the Allied cause”, Mahatma Gandhi said: The Allies are today making brave declarations about democracy and liberty which to me, or, to put it plainly, to the exploited nations, mean nothing.
('84', 258, 5, 9, 447259) Mere declarations, pleasing to the ear, can give no satisfaction to the sufferers.
('84', 258, 5, 10, 447342) By “the exploited nations” I mean the Asiatics and Africans.
('84', 258, 5, 11, 447403) If the Allies are fighting for democracy, their democracy should include all the exploited races of the earth.
('84', 258, 5, 12, 447514) Facts, as I see them, prove the contrary.
('84', 258, 5, 13, 447556) Almost all, if not all, parties agree that India was never so much under foreign domination as it is today.
('84', 258, 5, 14, 447664) A clear acceptance of the Indian demand for independence and the consequent establishment of a national responsible government, subject to the limitations I have mentioned, would immediately change the character of the Allied cause.
('84', 258, 5, 15, 447897) It will be immediately differentiated from the cause of the Axis Powers, if the latter’s fight can be described as a cause.
('84', 258, 6, 16, 448021) What material gain will accrue to the Allies from the recognition of India as an independent country, subject to the provision accepted by you?
('84', 258, 6, 17, 448165) I must refuse to descend from the platform I occupy.
('84', 258, 6, 18, 448218) Surely, if the character of the Allied cause is so radically altered, as I claim it must be by the acceptance of my offer, all else must follow as a matter of course.
('84', 258, 6, 19, 448385) But whether it does or not, I want the acceptance of my offer to be on the unadulterated moral basis.
('84', 258, 6, 20, 448487) It should be enough for the Allies to have the guarantee that their military operations will not, in any way, be adversely affected by India being counted as an
('84', 258, 7, 21, 448648) 1 Vide “Interview to Stuart Gelder”, 4 7 1944.
('84', 259, 0, 1, 448695) 260 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 259, 1, 2, 448737) independent nation, not merely in word but in fact.
('84', 259, 1, 3, 448789) I hold that the effect of the declaration of India’s independence, accompanied by simultaneous sincere action, should, by itself, take the wind out of the sails of the Axis Powers.
('84', 259, 1, 4, 448970) And I should be surprised if they do not capitulate almost immediately on the declaration.
('84', 259, 1, 5, 449061) Suppose England was under foreign rule today, like India, and the ruling power was engaged in a war with some other nation or nations, and involved England willy nilly in the war.
('84', 259, 1, 6, 449241) Suppose further that the foreign power suddenly declared England independent without the latter having put up an armed fight for freedom, would not every Englishman enthusiastically support the erstwhile foreign ruler, now turned a friendly power?
('84', 259, 1, 7, 449489) You can now understand what will happen to India if, when Britain is in sight of victory, she were to declare the independence of India.
('84', 259, 1, 8, 449626) Having said all this to elucidate my answer, I wish to suggest that my offer furnishes a basis for honourable negotiation and release of the members of the Congress Working Committee.
('84', 259, 1, 9, 449810) A discussion of details and filling in the gaps, deliberately left in my offer, must follow as a matter of course.
('84', 259, 2, 10, 449925) The correspondent then told him that the Tory Press in Britain confuses the people by stating that “Gandhi still adheres to the ‘Quit India’ resolution 1.’’ They exploit the fact that the British people are unaware of the burning anti Fascist and patriotic content of the resolution.
('84', 259, 2, 11, 450209) The correspondent asked him to clarify his statement that the resolution was “innocuous 2”.
('84', 259, 2, 12, 450301) The whole of the resolution is a noble document.
('84', 259, 2, 13, 450350) The ‘Quit India’ slogan is an innocuous and natural cry.
('84', 259, 2, 14, 450407) The sting was in the sanction clause of the resolution authorizing me to offer mass civil disobedience in the event of the rejection of the national demand.
('84', 259, 2, 15, 450564) As I have said, my authority has lapsed, and even if it has not, I cannot organize mass civil disobedience at the present moment.
('84', 259, 2, 16, 450694) Therefore, the resolution should be read without the sanction clause, and I challenge anybody to take exception to a single word in that resolution.
('84', 259, 2, 17, 450843) ‘Quit India’, read together with the Congress offer that the Allied operations on the Indian soil might continue, means nothing more and nothing less than that the British rule should end in its
('84', 259, 3, 18, 451038) 1Vide Appendix “Resolution Passed by All India Congress Committee”, 8 8 1942. 2 Vide “Interview to the Press”, 13 7 1944.
('84', 260, 0, 1, 451160) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 261
('84', 260, 1, 2, 451207) entirety, even while the war is going on—if the war is merely for the deliverance of the exploited nations of the earth.
('84', 260, 2, 3, 451328) The correspondent next reminded him of his statement that the Cripps offer 1
('84', 260, 3, 4, 451405) contemplated almost perpetual vivisection of India and asked him what it meant.
('84', 260, 3, 5, 451485) Mahatma Gandhi smiled and said: Surely it can mean only one thing.
('84', 260, 3, 6, 451552) The Cripps offer divided India into Princely India and democratic India.
('84', 260, 3, 7, 451625) Is not that vivisection?
('84', 260, 4, 8, 451650) The correspondent told him that a lot of propaganda was being made in reactionary circles in England, particularly by the Tory Press, to the effect that if Gandhiji’s demand was granted, the minorities would suffer.
('84', 260, 4, 9, 451866) Mahatma Gandhi replied: That is a function belonging to the Rajaji Formula 2. I can only say that the Formula contemplates the fullest protection to the smallest minority.
('84', 260, 4, 10, 452038) If there are any gaps left in it, they will be filled in at the time of mutual discussion that must precede a final settlement.
('84', 260, 4, 11, 452166) The Bombay Chronicle, 3 8 1944

('84', 262, 1, 2, 455086) 355. LETTER TO GOPINATH BARDOLOI
('84', 262, 2, 3, 455119) August 3, 1944
('84', 262, 3, 4, 455134) MY DEAR BARDOLOI, I have your letter.
('84', 262, 3, 5, 455172) I have read the papers and I have had long chats with the friends.
('84', 262, 3, 6, 455239) I will not, because I cannot, give specific instructions.
('84', 262, 3, 7, 455297) But I would lay down general principles to guide you.
('84', 262, 3, 8, 455351) There should never be the slightest departure from truth and non violence.
('84', 262, 3, 9, 455426) There should be perfect fearlessness.
('84', 262, 3, 10, 455464) There should be no secrecy, and there should be complete non co operation with evil.
('84', 262, 3, 11, 455549) Thus under the lure of saving starving people I may not co operate with evil even as I may not pour milk in a poison bowl in the hope of feeding the poor.
('84', 262, 3, 12, 455704) The Bihar example will mislead if not properly understood.
('84', 262, 3, 13, 455763) I co operated and spent the money that was collected.
('84', 262, 3, 14, 455817) There were two parallel collections.
('84', 262, 3, 15, 455854) Ours was the biggest and best spent.
('84', 262, 3, 16, 455891) Today there is no such scope.
('84', 262, 3, 17, 455921) Do not think of the past except to learn lessons from it.
('84', 262, 4, 18, 455979) From a copy: Pyarelal Papers.
('84', 262, 4, 19, 456009) Courtesy: Pyarelal

('84', 263, 1, 2, 456070) 356. LETTER TO K. SRINIVASAN
('84', 263, 2, 3, 456099) August 3, 1944
('84', 263, 3, 4, 456114) DEAR SRINIVASAN 1, Khurshedbehn who is with me just tells me that you have lost your dear daughter.
('84', 263, 3, 5, 456214) I am lying down, so she takes this to my dictation.It was like news to me, when she mentioned the tragedy and yet as I think of it I have a fear that I saw the news somewhere and might also have thought of writing to you, and then [some]thing intervened between the thought and the execution of it.
('84', 263, 3, 6, 456513) Very often such things have happened in my life.
('84', 263, 3, 7, 456562) Whether I have written to you or spoken to you about the tragedy, my writing to you now need not be superfluous.
('84', 263, 3, 8, 456675) Having suffered myself in the same manner I can appreciate all the more your grief.
('84', 263, 3, 9, 456759) Accept therefore the sympathy of a fellow sufferer in life’s march.
('84', 263, 3, 10, 456827) Did you ever know that in Sevagram Mahadev was a regular reader of The Hindu and in the detention camp first Pyarelal and then I took Mahadev’s place and often found things in The Hindu which we did not find in the other papers?

('84', 264, 0, 1, 457629) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 265
('84', 264, 1, 2, 457676) 358. DISCUSSION WITH D. RAMASWAMI 1
('84', 264, 2, 3, 457712) SEVAGRAM, [On or after August 3, 1944] 2
('84', 264, 3, 4, 457753) Re organization of the villages is a very intricate problem, but if we can find even half a dozen workers of the right type, we can solve it in due time.
('84', 264, 3, 5, 457907) The time factor is important, but given the right start the thing will grow like a snowball.
('84', 264, 3, 6, 458000) You have heard of Booker T. Washington.
('84', 264, 3, 7, 458040) We have to produce better workers than even him in order to achieve our object.
('84', 264, 3, 8, 458120) As for you, your ambition will be fulfilled if, besides your ability and enthusiasm, you introduce something else in your life, i.e., a living faith in God.
('84', 264, 3, 9, 458277) Then all insipidity will vanish.
('84', 264, 3, 10, 458310) A cosmopolitan 3
('84', 264, 4, 11, 458327) outlook is a necessity but it can never be a substitute for God.
('84', 264, 4, 12, 458392) God is there, but our conception of God is limited by our mental horizon and by our physical environment.
('84', 264, 4, 13, 458498) For instance, when you read the Bible, you find that the God of the Hebrews was quite different from the God of Jesus Christ.
('84', 264, 4, 14, 458624) You are dissatisfied with the prevalent idea about God for the simple reason that those who profess belief in God do not present a living God in their own lives.
('84', 264, 4, 15, 458786) Unless you have a living faith in God to sustain you, when failure stares you in the face, there is disappointment for you.
('84', 264, 4, 16, 458910) You may develop a revulsion for the work that you have taken up.
('84', 264, 4, 17, 458975) You may begin to feel that after all what Dr. Ambedkar said was the right thing and you made a mistake in rejecting the high posts which you had been offered.
('84', 264, 4, 18, 459134) My advice to you is that you should not leave this Ashram till you have found God.
('84', 264, 4, 19, 459217) In spite of my limitless failings I am a seeker after Truth and so are my companions in this place.
('84', 264, 4, 20, 459317) The Ashram, apart from its inhabitants, the sum total of energy that it represents, the principles for which it stands, may enable you to know God to the extent that you may be able to say ‘God is’, just as you can say ‘Truth is’.
('84', 264, 5, 21, 459548) RAMASWAMI: I can say that in the sense that Truth is the antithesis of
('84', 264, 6, 22, 459619) 1 A young Harijan graduate who gave Gandhiji a report of his work in the villages and sought his help and guidance.
('84', 264, 6, 23, 459735) Gandhiji was pleased with his report.
('84', 264, 6, 24, 459773) 2 The discussion took place at Sevagram Ashram.
('84', 264, 6, 25, 459821) After his release Gandhiji reached there on August 3, 1944. 3 Mahatma Gandhi—The Last Phase here has “humanitarian”.
('84', 265, 0, 1, 459938) 266 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 265, 1, 2, 459980) falsehood.
('84', 265, 2, 3, 459991) GANDHIJI: That is good enough.
('84', 265, 2, 4, 460022) The seers have described God as “ Neti, neti” (‘Not this, not this’).
('84', 265, 2, 5, 460092) Truth will elude you.
('84', 265, 2, 6, 460114) The sum total of all that is true is Truth.
('84', 265, 2, 7, 460158) But you can’t sum up all that is true.
('84', 265, 2, 8, 460197) Like most of those who have had Western education, you have got an analytical mind.
('84', 265, 2, 9, 460281) But there are things that can’t be analysed.
('84', 265, 2, 10, 460326) God who can be analysed by my poor intellect won’t satisfy me.
('84', 265, 2, 11, 460389) Therefore I do not try to analyse Him.
('84', 265, 2, 12, 460428) I go behind the relative to the absolute and I get my peace of mind.
('84', 265, 3, 13, 460497) R. I have carefully gone through your writings in the Harijan and Young India .
('84', 265, 3, 14, 460577) Your way of life appeals to me very much.
('84', 265, 3, 15, 460619) It offers scope for the exercise of individual will.
('84', 265, 3, 16, 460672) The idea of God introduces a determinism and that limits man.
('84', 265, 3, 17, 460734) It interferes with his free will.
('84', 265, 4, 18, 460768) G. Is there such a thing as free will?
('84', 265, 4, 19, 460807) Where is it?
('84', 265, 4, 20, 460820) We are mere playthings in the hands of Providence.
('84', 265, 5, 21, 460871) R. What is the relationship between God and man, between Truth and God?
('84', 265, 6, 22, 460943) G. I used to say ‘God is Truth’.

('84', 266, 3, 7, 462744) 359. DISCUSSION WITH A FRIEND 3
('84', 266, 4, 8, 462776) [On or after August 3, 1944] 4
('84', 266, 5, 9, 462807) FRIEND: If you pray to God, can He intervene and set aside the law for your sake?
('84', 266, 6, 10, 462889) GANDHIJI: God’s law remains unaltered but since that very law says that every action has a result, if a person prays, his prayer is bound to produce an unforeseeable result in terms of His law.
('84', 266, 7, 11, 463083) But do you know the God to whom you pray?
('84', 266, 7, 12, 463125) No, I don’t.
('84', 266, 8, 13, 463138) To whom shall we pray then?
('84', 266, 8, 14, 463166) To the God whom we do not know—we do not always know the person to whom we pray.
('84', 266, 9, 15, 463247) Maybe, but the person to whom we pray is knowable.
('84', 266, 9, 16, 463298) So is God; and since He is knowable, we search.
('84', 266, 9, 17, 463346) It may take a billion years before we find Him.
('84', 266, 9, 18, 463394) What does it matter?
('84', 266, 9, 19, 463415) So, I say, even if you do not believe, you must continue to pray, i.e., search.
('84', 266, 9, 20, 463495) “Help thou my unbelief” is a verse from the Bible to be remembered.

('84', 266, 9, 22, 463606) You must have infinite patience, and inward longing.
('84', 266, 9, 23, 463659) Inward longing obviates all such questions.
('84', 266, 9, 24, 463703) “Have faith and you will be whole” is another tip from the Bible.

('84', 267, 11, 21, 464969) 362. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('84', 267, 12, 22, 464997) SEVAGRAM, August 5, 1944 Many Congressmen ask me how to celebrate the forthcoming 9th of August.
('84', 267, 12, 23, 465094) That date was a turning point in India’s fight for freedom.
('84', 267, 12, 24, 465154) I had intended to spend 9th August, 1942 in peaceful introspection and to inaugurate negotiations for a settlement.
('84', 267, 12, 25, 465270) But the Government or Fate had decided otherwise.
('84', 267, 12, 26, 465320) The Government went mad, and so did some people.
('84', 267, 12, 27, 465369) Sabotage and the like were resorted to
('84', 267, 13, 28, 465408) 1 From the contents; vide the preceding item.
('84', 267, 13, 29, 465454) 2 This was read out at a public meeting held in Hyderabad on August 4 under the Presidentship of Hasan Yar Jung Bahadur.
('84', 268, 0, 1, 465575) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 269
('84', 268, 1, 2, 465622) and many things were done in the Congress name or in my name.
('84', 268, 1, 3, 465684) I am aware that I do not represent the Congress mind always.
('84', 268, 1, 4, 465745) Many Congressmen repudiate my non violence.
('84', 268, 1, 5, 465789) The Working Committee is the only body which can legitimately and truly represent the Congress.
('84', 268, 1, 6, 465885) As an old servant of the country, however, I can advise, and Congressmen are at liberty to treat my advice as instructions.
('84', 268, 1, 7, 466009) I have already said 1 that mass civil disobedience cannot be offered now; but mass civil disobedience is one thing and individual action in defence of self respect and liberty is wholly another.
('84', 268, 1, 8, 466204) It is a universal duty for all time, the discharge of which requires no sanction save that of one’s own conscience.
('84', 268, 1, 9, 466320) In a previous note, I have pointed out when and where the duty arises.
('84', 268, 1, 10, 466391) But the forthcoming 9th is a special occasion.
('84', 268, 1, 11, 466438) There has arisen much misunderstanding about the Congress purpose and mind.
('84', 268, 1, 12, 466514) I must avoid all avoidable risks.
('84', 268, 1, 13, 466548) Therefore, in all places except in Bombay, my advice is not to disregard special police prohibitions for that day.
('84', 268, 1, 14, 466663) For Bombay, I have already given advice through the Mayor of Bombay.
('84', 268, 1, 15, 466732) I need not reiterate the advice here.
('84', 268, 1, 16, 466770) I have selected Bombay as the most suitable place for the simple reason that it is most easily accessible to me and is the place where the historic meeting of August 1942 was held.
('84', 268, 1, 17, 466951) Whatever it is to be, it will be a symbolic act.
('84', 268, 1, 18, 467000) Curiosity is natural and pardonable, but I plead for restraint.
('84', 268, 1, 19, 467064) The self imposed curb will be finished if I succeed in carrying conviction to the human family, that every man or woman, however weak in body, is the guardian of his or her self respect and liberty.
('84', 268, 1, 20, 467263) This defence avails, though the whole world may be against the individual resister.
('84', 268, 1, 21, 467347) I have suggested the present symbolic procedure to see whether those who organize the demonstration have co operation from the local public.
('84', 268, 1, 22, 467488) Freedom of 400 million people through purely non violent effort is not to be gained without learning the virtue of iron discipline, not imposed from without, but sprung naturally from within.
('84', 268, 1, 23, 467680) Without the requisite discipline non violence can only be a veneer.
('84', 268, 1, 24, 467748) The second thing that I should like done on the forthcoming 9th August is for those who have gone underground to discover themselves.
('84', 268, 1, 25, 467882) They can do so by informing the authorities of their
('84', 268, 2, 26, 467935) 1 Vide “Talk to Bombay Congress Leaders”, 29/30 7 1944.
('84', 269, 0, 1, 467991) 270 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 269, 1, 2, 468033) movements and whereabouts or by simply and naturally doing their work in the open without any attempt to evade or elude the police.
('84', 269, 1, 3, 468165) To go underground is to elude the police.
('84', 269, 1, 4, 468207) Therefore, real discovery is to discover oneself to the party eluded.
('84', 269, 1, 5, 468277) Nothing should be done unless the conviction has gone home that a particular action is essential for the cause.
('84', 269, 1, 6, 468389) In the absence of such a conviction, those who see this note may ignore it and should follow what they consider best for the country.
('84', 269, 1, 7, 468523) What everyone should do on the 9th, whether they have the conviction as to nonviolence or not, or whether they are Congressmen or not, is to carry out on the 9th the whole or any part of the fourteenfold programme reiterated in my recent note 1. Just for example, everyone should spin.
('84', 269, 1, 8, 468809) Communities should find ways of giving expression to mutual understanding and brotherhood.
('84', 269, 1, 9, 468900) Hindus and Muslims may organize joint programmes of prayers—God may bless the Quaid e Azam and me with wisdom to reach a common understanding in the interest of India.
('84', 269, 1, 10, 469068) Hindus should visit Harijans and render them the service they may need.
('84', 269, 1, 11, 469140) The spirit of service and helpfulness should pervade the atmosphere everywhere.
('84', 269, 1, 12, 469220) I have experienced friendliness from Englishmen and Americans wherever I have met them, whether officials or laymen.
('84', 269, 1, 13, 469337) I invite their co operation especially on the 9th.
('84', 269, 1, 14, 469388) Let them realize that the August resolution was not conceived in hatred.
('84', 269, 1, 15, 469461) It was an unvarnished statement of the natural right of the people of this land.
('84', 269, 1, 16, 469542) To those who share my faith I would advise fasting and prayers on the auspicious day.
('84', 269, 1, 17, 469628) This must not be a mechanical act.
('84', 269, 1, 18, 469663) It must be done without ostentation, for self purification and penance.
('84', 269, 1, 19, 469735) Its uplifting power is capable of being tested by every individual for himself.
('84', 269, 1, 20, 469815) If the demonstration is carried out in the spirit in which I have conceived it, I have no doubt that it will lead to an early end of the misery of the masses.
('84', 269, 1, 21, 469974) The Hindu, 7 8 1944
