('84', 271, 3, 7, 472998) 365. LETTER TO B. R. AMBEDKAR
('84', 271, 4, 8, 473028) SEVAGRAM, August 6, 1944 Thank you for yours 2 of July 31 received yesterday.
('84', 271, 4, 9, 473106) The Hindu Muslim question is for me a lifelong question.
('84', 271, 4, 10, 473163) There was a time when I used to think that when that question was solved India’s political troubles would be over.
('84', 271, 4, 11, 473278) Experience has taught me that it was only partly true.
('84', 271, 4, 12, 473333) Untouchability I began to abhor when I was in my teens, But it was a question with me of religious and social reform.
('84', 271, 4, 13, 473451) And though it has attained a great political importance its religious and social value is for me much greater.
('84', 271, 4, 14, 473562) But I know to my cost that you and I hold different views on this very important question.
('84', 271, 4, 15, 473653) And I know, too, that on broad politics of the country we see things from different angles.
('84', 271, 4, 16, 473745) I would love to find a meeting ground between us on both the questions.
('84', 271, 4, 17, 473817) I know your great ability and I would love to own you as a colleague and co worker.
('84', 271, 4, 18, 473901) But I must admit my failure to come nearer to you.
('84', 271, 4, 19, 473952) If you can show me a way to a common meeting ground between us I would like to see it.
('84', 271, 4, 20, 474039) Meanwhile, I must reconcile myself to the present unfortunate difference.
('84', 271, 4, 21, 474113) The Bombay Chronicle, 3 1 1945
('84', 271, 5, 22, 474144) 1 Vide Appendix “A Resolution”, before 9 8 1944. 2 Which inter alia read: “ .
('84', 271, 5, 23, 474222) the Hindu Muslim problem is not the only communal problem that has to be settled.
('84', 271, 5, 24, 474304) there is a communal problem between the Hindus and the untouchables, which is also awaiting solution.
('84', 271, 5, 25, 474406) An all round settlement between the Hindus and other minorities, I am sure, will become necessary if India’s political goal is to be achieved.
('84', 271, 5, 26, 474549) But, if you are anxious to solve the Hindu untouchable problem as you are to solve the Hindu Muslim problem, I shall be glad to formulate points on which a settlement is necessary.

('84', 275, 3, 4, 478929) QUESTION: You said in Panchgani: “All my recent declarations are quite consistent with all my previous declarations on the communal problem.” But in the past you had said: “Partition means a patent untruth.
('84', 275, 3, 5, 479136) My whole soul rebels against the idea .
('84', 275, 3, 6, 479176) To assent to such a doctrine is for me denial of God (Harijan, 13 4 1940).
('84', 275, 4, 7, 479251) The partition proposal has altered the face of the Hindu Muslim problem.
('84', 275, 4, 8, 479324) I have called it an untruth.
('84', 275, 4, 9, 479353) There can be no compromise with it.
('84', 275, 4, 10, 479389) It cannot come by honourable agreement (Harijan, 4 5 1940).
('84', 275, 4, 11, 479449) 2 I consider vivisection of India to be a sin.
('84', 275, 4, 12, 479496) (Harijan, 24 5 1942) .” 3 Would you kindly enlighten me how they are consistent?
('84', 275, 4, 13, 479577) The Mahasabhaites seem to argue in the above style and hence clarification is sought.
('84', 275, 5, 14, 479663) ANSWER: Though I would avoid answering all questions on the subject before the forthcoming meeting between Quaid e Azam and me, I must not postpone answering yours.
('84', 275, 5, 15, 479828) I know my present attitude has puzzled and pained many people.
('84', 275, 5, 16, 479891) I have not revised the opinion quoted by you.
('84', 275, 5, 17, 479937) At the same time that I made the statement you refer to, I was also a party to the self determination resolution of the A. I. C. C. I hold that the Rajaji Formula gives effect to that resolution.
('84', 275, 5, 18, 480133) I would however urge critics not to mind my inconsistencies, so called or real.
('84', 275, 5, 19, 480213) Let them examine the question on merits and bless the effort if they can.
('84', 275, 6, 20, 480287) Q. What is your reaction to Mr. Jinnah’s speech 4?
('84', 275, 6, 21, 480338) If Mr. Jinnah does not accept your proposal or your talks with him end in failure, will you withdraw your support to Rajaji’s proposals or will the proposals stand?
('84', 275, 7, 22, 480503) A. I do not believe in dying before my death.
('84', 275, 7, 23, 480549) I do not approach the forthcoming visit with the expectation of failure.
('84', 275, 7, 24, 480622) I always hope for the best and prepare for the worst.
('84', 275, 7, 25, 480676) I would therefore ask you not to anticipate failure.
('84', 275, 7, 26, 480729) Ask me when failure stares you and me in the face.

A. Jinnah spoke at length criticizing Rajagopalachari’s Formula and Gandhiji’s association with it.

('84', 277, 4, 12, 483370) 375. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('84', 277, 5, 13, 483398) August 8, 1944 The question asked is whether my statement contemplates civil disobedience or its avoidance.
('84', 277, 5, 14, 483506) It asserts a universal right which becomes a duty when there is an attack upon its ordinary exercise.
('84', 277, 5, 15, 483608) It therefore contemplates civil disobedience if Government wants it.
('84', 277, 5, 16, 483677) Twenty five citizens of Bombay sent notices on the 3rd instant to the Police Commissioner of their intention to march in batches of five and offer silent prayers and sing Jhandavandan and Vandemataram at a common gathering place and asked for permission to perform the act.
('84', 277, 5, 17, 483951) 1 If permission is not granted, there will certainly be disobedience.
('84', 277, 5, 18, 484021) In order that the public may not know the time or place, the Police Commissioner has been fully informed, while the public has not been.
('84', 277, 5, 19, 484158) If this extraordinary forbearance is not appreciated and the authorities withhold permission and interfere with the simple symbolic exercise of a public right, the fault would be that of the authorities.
('84', 277, 5, 20, 484362) The Press and the public have to judge whether, under circumstances such as these, civil disobedience does not become a duty.
('84', 277, 5, 21, 484488) The Hindu, 10 8 1944
('84', 277, 6, 22, 484509) 1 Vide Appendix “Draft Letter to the Commissioner of Police, Bombay”, after 19 8 1944.

('84', 278, 1, 2, 484643) 376. LETTER TO RAJA GOVINDALAL SHIVLAL
('84', 278, 2, 3, 484682) ASHRAM, SEVAGRAM, August 8, 1944
('84', 278, 3, 4, 484715) DEAR RAJA SAHEB,
('84', 278, 4, 5, 484732) Gandhiji has your letter of 16th inst.
('84', 278, 5, 6, 484771) Your argument is built partly on fallacy and partly on disregard of facts.
('84', 278, 5, 7, 484846) Acceptance of the C.R. formula by Gandhiji concedes nothing but the insistent demand of the minorities for self determination.
('84', 278, 5, 8, 484973) It carries no other implication.
('84', 278, 5, 9, 485006) Far from absolving the seceding units from ‘moral obligation’ to give their support to [the] freedom movement, it lays down that the separation can only come after attainment of complete independence with [the] co operation of those who claim the right to secede.
('84', 278, 5, 10, 485270) Further, it stipulates the creation of a special machinery for the joint administration of matters of common concern to the two sovereign states such as defence, foreign affairs, railways, currency, economic planning, etc.
('84', 278, 5, 11, 485493) The provision embodying this arrangement will be an integral part of the charter for separation.
('84', 278, 6, 12, 485590) Nationalist Muslims are not let down by the formula, since they were parties to the self determination resolution of the Working Committee that met at Delhi in April, 1942.
('84', 278, 7, 13, 485763) The need for them to stand by their principles will be even greater under independence.
('84', 278, 7, 14, 485851) That will be the real testing time for them.
('84', 278, 8, 15, 485896) Yours sincerely,
('84', 278, 9, 16, 485913) RAJA GOVINDALAL SHIVLAL SHRI SADAN 15 NARAYAN DABHAOLKAR ROAD MALABAR HILL BOMBAY 6

('84', 280, 1, 2, 487392) 379. LETTER TO GENERAL MANAGER, OXFORD UNIVERSITY PRESS
('84', 280, 2, 3, 487448) SEVAGRAM, August 9, 1944
('84', 280, 3, 4, 487473) DEAR SIR, With reference to your letter of 2nd inst., since the Oxford University Press is not conducted for profit, I should think that a net profit being stipulated for, there should be no objection to a minimum profit.
('84', 280, 3, 5, 487695) The only inducement to the Navajivan Trust, and for that matter also for me, to have a well known concern like yours publishing Shri R. K. Prabhu’s compilation can be to acquire the widest publicity possible outside India for it.
('84', 280, 3, 6, 487925) The Navajivan Press exists only for printing writings like Shri Prabhu’s compilation as cheaply as possible for Indian readers.
('84', 280, 3, 7, 488053) The object therefore undoubtedly is to publish an edition as cheap as possible and certainly cheaper than yours.
('84', 280, 3, 8, 488166) Therefore it would be improper to hold over publication of such an Indian edition till your stock is exhausted.
('84', 280, 3, 9, 488278) If you rely chiefly on Indian sales, I think the contemplated publication by you might be dropped.
('84', 280, 3, 10, 488377) Labours of the authors will not go unrewarded in any case.
('84', 280, 3, 11, 488436) I will ask the Navajivan Trust to cover them and publish their compilation whenever they are in a position to do so.
('84', 280, 4, 12, 488553) Yours sincerely,
('84', 280, 5, 13, 488570) THE GENERAL MANAGER OXFORD UNIVERSITY PRESS POST BOX 31 BOMBAY

('84', 282, 1, 2, 490200) 382. TRIBUTE TO MAHADEV DESAI 1
('84', 282, 2, 3, 490232) WARDHAGANJ, August 10, 1944 August l5 is the second anniversary of Mahadev Desai’s death.
('84', 282, 2, 4, 490322) Two or three correspondents have administered a gentle rebuke.
('84', 282, 2, 5, 490385) The following is my paraphrase of the first of their remarks: You have become President of the Kasturba Memorial Fund Trust.
('84', 282, 2, 6, 490510) Mahadev renounced everything for your sake and even laid down his life for you.
('84', 282, 2, 7, 490590) He died at a much younger age than Kasturba and yet how much he achieved in that relatively short space of time!
('84', 282, 2, 8, 490703) Kasturba was verily a sati, but while India has produced many satis, all will admit that it has produced only one Mahadev.
('84', 282, 2, 9, 490826) If he had not chosen to throw in his lot with you, he might have been living today.
('84', 282, 2, 10, 490910) His talents would have enabled him to achieve front rank distinction as a savant and man of letters.
('84', 282, 2, 11, 491011) He might have even been rich, brought up his family in all material comfort and provided his son with the highest education.
('84', 282, 2, 12, 491136) Instead, he chose to merge himself in you.
('84', 282, 2, 13, 491179) You regarded him as your son.
('84', 282, 2, 14, 491209) May I ask what you have done for him?
('84', 282, 2, 15, 491247) These sentiments seem to me to be natural.
('84', 282, 2, 16, 491290) The contrast between the two is too striking to be missed.
('84', 282, 2, 17, 491349) The one was ready to drop off like a fully ripe fruit.
('84', 282, 2, 18, 491404) The other had yet to ripen and mature.
('84', 282, 2, 19, 491443) Life still lay before Mahadev as ordinary standards go.
('84', 282, 2, 20, 491499) He had aimed at living up to a hundred years.
('84', 282, 2, 21, 491545) The amount of material that he had piled up in his voluminous note books called for years of patient labour to work up and he had hoped to do all that.
('84', 282, 2, 22, 491697) In his trunk was found a memo of my talks taken down on the day previous to his final end.
('84', 282, 2, 23, 491788) Probably, none besides myself can today make them out, and even I don’t know to what use he would have put them.
('84', 282, 2, 24, 491901) He was a living example of “the wise, who live and work as if they were born to immortality and everlasting youth”.
('84', 282, 2, 25, 492017) 2 But, if all our dreams could be realized, life would become a phantasmagoria, and there would be utter chaos on
('84', 282, 3, 26, 492131) 1 The Gujarati original appeared in Gujarat Samachar, 13 8 1944. This is an “authoritative translation” by Pyarelal.
('84', 282, 3, 27, 492248) 2 "The wise should devote themselves to learning and worldly welfare as if they were immortal and would never grow old, and follow the path of dharma as if Death had seized them by the hair.”

('84', 283, 1, 2, 492482) God in His mercy, therefore, has ordained that His will alone should prevail on earth.
('84', 283, 1, 3, 492569) Mahadev, though an idealist and a dreamer, never allowed his feet to be taken off the firm earth.
('84', 283, 1, 4, 492667) He, therefore, adorned everything that he attempted.
('84', 283, 1, 5, 492720) To Mahadev’s admirers, I can only offer this consolation, that he lost nothing by his association with me.
('84', 283, 1, 6, 492827) His dreams rose above scholarship or learning.
('84', 283, 1, 7, 492874) Riches had no attraction for him.
('84', 283, 1, 8, 492908) God had blessed him with high intellect and versatile tastes but what his soul thirsted for was the devotional spirit.
('84', 283, 1, 9, 493027) Even before he came to me, he had assiduously sought and cultivated the company of devotees and men of God after his heart.
('84', 283, 1, 10, 493151) One may say that it was in furtherance of this quest that he came to me and, not obtaining full satisfaction even with me, (shall I say) he turned his back upon me in the fullness of youth, leaving behind him his weeping relations and friends, and set forth to seek realization of his quest in the bosom of his Maker.
('84', 283, 1, 11, 493469) The only fitting service that I can render his memory is to complete the work which he has left behind him unfinished, and to make myself worthy of his devotion—obviously a more difficult task than merely raising a fund for his memorial.
('84', 283, 1, 12, 493707) It can be fulfilled only through Divine grace.
('84', 283, 1, 13, 493754) Mahadev’s external goal was the attainment of swaraj; the inner, to fully realize in his own person his ideal of devotion, and if possible to share the same with others.
('84', 283, 2, 14, 493924) The raising of a material memorial to the deceased’s memory is outside my scope.
('84', 283, 2, 15, 494005) That is a task for his friends and admirers to take up.
('84', 283, 2, 16, 494061) Does a father initiate a memorial for his son?
('84', 283, 2, 17, 494108) I was not responsible for the Kasturba Memorial.
('84', 283, 2, 18, 494157) In my previous statement 2 I have explained its origin.
('84', 283, 2, 19, 494213) I have become the President of the Committee only in order to ensure the use of the fund in accordance with its object.
('84', 283, 2, 20, 494333) If friends and admirers of Mahadev similarly set up a committee to raise a memorial fund and invite me to become its president and give guidance for its proper use, I shall gladly accept it.
('84', 283, 3, 21, 494524) A word to litterateurs.
('84', 283, 3, 22, 494548) They know or should know that he put the charkha above literature.
('84', 283, 3, 23, 494615) He took delight in spinning for hours.
('84', 283, 3, 24, 494654) It was a daily duty.
('84', 283, 3, 25, 494675) He would encroach upon his sleeping hours to finish

('84', 284, 3, 15, 495823) WARDHA, August 11, 1944 I am writing to you in my mother tongue 1 which I believe you will tolerate.
('84', 284, 3, 16, 495924) The Congress policy has been definite and determined.
('84', 284, 3, 17, 495978) With this nothing can be mixed.
('84', 284, 3, 18, 496010) An independent India cannot entertain any other stranger in its midst.
('84', 284, 3, 19, 496081) The consent which I have given to a particular scheme depends upon the fact that it is based on a cardinal principle of the Congress.
('84', 284, 3, 20, 496215) 2 I command an influence over the masses and therefore I cannot hide that which I consider against the good of my country.
('84', 284, 3, 21, 496338) An advantage would be taken of this situation by my opponents and this was not outside the pale of my thoughts.
('84', 284, 3, 22, 496450) But this fear comes out of the weakness of our forces.
('84', 284, 3, 23, 496505) To remove this fear, the way lies in freely but respectfully expressing our opinion and only in this way can we conquer and win; this is my respectful opinion.
('84', 284, 3, 24, 496665) Permit me to tell you that no particular work of mine has resulted in any loss to my country.
('84', 284, 3, 25, 496759) At least I have never heard that it has.

('84', 294, 0, 1, 513990) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 295
('84', 294, 1, 2, 514037) 395. NOTE TO K. M. MUNSHI 1
('84', 294, 2, 3, 514065) [After August 14, 1944] 2
('84', 294, 3, 4, 514091) My reluctance to comment on the Rajaji Formula has led to my attitude being misunderstood by many friends all over the country.
('84', 294, 3, 5, 514219) On the whole it is my advice that you should maintain peace till the conference to be held between us is over.
('84', 294, 5, 6, 514330) I cannot approve of the Rajaji Formula.
('84', 294, 5, 7, 514370) The division of a Hindu and a Muslim area is conditional in the Formula.
('84', 294, 5, 8, 514443) A partition, on the other hand, will enable the Hindus and Muslims in those provinces to settle down in their respective areas.
('84', 294, 5, 9, 514571) The second argument does not seem to support the first One.
('84', 294, 6, 10, 514631) My objections to the Rajaji Formula, however, go deeper.
('84', 294, 6, 11, 514688) The force behind disruptionism is the urge to convert Islam in India into a religio political party and to dominate the country by overawing the Nationalists into submission.
('84', 294, 6, 12, 514863) Mr. Jinnah’s recent utterances are too fresh to be forgotten easily.
('84', 294, 6, 13, 514932) He will accept no alliance on a conditional acceptance of Pakistan as in the Formula, and if any is made it will not last a day after the principle of Pakistan is accepted by the Nationalists.
('84', 294, 6, 14, 515125) These objections are not deeply rooted.
('84', 294, 6, 15, 515165) If you have no better argument, nothing will be lost by remaining silent.
('84', 294, 7, 16, 515239) Pilgrimage to Freedom, pp.

('84', 295, 3, 6, 515829) It was received here on the 10th.
('84', 295, 3, 7, 515863) The post has become very heavy.
('84', 295, 3, 8, 515895) Even important letters such as yours do not come into my hands immediately they are received.
('84', 295, 3, 9, 515989) I have not so recovered as to permit my working all hours of the day.
('84', 295, 3, 10, 516059) This preface is merely to show you the importance I attach to your letter.
('84', 295, 3, 11, 516134) But nothing is lost by the delay.
('84', 295, 3, 12, 516168) We shall come to no final terms.
('84', 295, 3, 13, 516201) The smallest interest will have the same weight as the largest.
('84', 295, 3, 14, 516265) That is the requirement of my creed.
('84', 295, 3, 15, 516302) It is a lapse if I do not live up to it.
('84', 295, 3, 16, 516343) With this assurance, I would leave you for the time being.
('84', 295, 3, 17, 516402) Pray that both of us may have the strength to do what is wholly right and not to tone down the right for the sake of expedience.

('84', 298, 1, 2, 519569) 402. INTERVIEW TO DUTY SOCIETY DEPUTATION 1
('84', 298, 2, 3, 519613) SEVAGRAM, August 15, 1944
('84', 298, 3, 4, 519639) Mahatma Gandhi was in a cheerful mood talking to the deputationists and was smiling throughout.
('84', 298, 3, 5, 519735) When asked by the Mahatma, Mr. Ibadat Yar Khan explained to him about the development that has taken place during the last 20 years, specially the establishment of an engineering college and the foundation of a medical college during the term of Dr. Sir Ziauddin Ahmed, the Vice Chancellor of the University .
('84', 298, 4, 6, 520045) The deputation also discussed the present political situation with the Mahatma and urged for an honourable settlement between the League and the Congress in the forthcoming meeting of the two great leaders of the Hindus and the Muslims.
('84', 298, 4, 7, 520282) Mr. Gandhi showed his willingness to concede every reasonable demand of the Mussalmans and said: I want that myself and the Quaid e Azam should be locked up and should not be allowed to come out till we come to some decision to remove this deadlock.
('84', 298, 5, 8, 520532) The members of the deputation again requested him to end the deadlock and see India governed by Indians themselves for which he had been trying for such a long time.
('84', 298, 5, 9, 520698) Gandhiji replied: I wish to see a free India in my lifetime, for God knows what will happen when I am no more.
('84', 298, 5, 10, 520809) The Bombay Chronicle, 20 8 1944

('84', 299, 3, 6, 521926) 405. LETTER TO SATIS CHANDRA DAS GUPTA
('84', 299, 4, 7, 521965) SEVAGRAM, August 16, 1944
('84', 299, 5, 8, 521991) BHAI SATIS BABU, Received your letter.
('84', 299, 5, 9, 522030) Balvantsinha has well apprised me of your work.
('84', 299, 5, 10, 522078) I am amazed at your tireless efforts.
('84', 299, 5, 11, 522116) Isn’t it your discovery that cow’s milk is available in so much quantity in Bengal?
('84', 299, 5, 12, 522200) And that the milkmen are all Muslims!
('84', 299, 5, 13, 522238) Balvantsinha has become your devotee.
('84', 299, 5, 14, 522276) I like it.
('84', 299, 5, 15, 522287) He himself is a goseva enthusiast.
('84', 299, 5, 16, 522322) He works hard.
('84', 299, 5, 17, 522337) I have found his knowledge to be haphazard and his outlook is not scientific.
('84', 299, 5, 18, 522415) He therefore needs guidance.
('84', 299, 5, 19, 522444) He has strongly refuted this opinion and believes—or had been believing—that I have, maybe unknowingly, done him an injustice.
('84', 299, 5, 20, 522571) There always has been antagonism between Parnerkar 1 and Balvantsinha and it has always caused me trouble.
('84', 299, 5, 21, 522678) I was not able to take from them as much work as I wanted to because of this antagonism.
('84', 299, 5, 22, 522767) Now Parnerkar is also there and he has got the work of his liking.
('84', 299, 5, 23, 522834) He also loves to serve the cow.
('84', 299, 5, 24, 522866) I happily watch from this distance this confluence of the three and also hope that its outcome will be good.
('84', 299, 5, 25, 522975) I have a few minutes during which I am dictating this letter.
('84', 299, 5, 26, 523037) You must have understood the reason for my giving a little background.
('84', 299, 5, 27, 523108) I shall be satisfied if both of them remain there and you can take full work from them although both are required here.
('84', 299, 5, 28, 523228) The work of the goshala here goes on but perhaps it is not satisfactory.
('84', 299, 5, 29, 523301) I do not at all want either of them to leave your work to come here.
('84', 299, 5, 30, 523370) Nor do I want both of them to come here.
('84', 299, 5, 31, 523411) I can have no definite programme.
('84', 299, 5, 32, 523445) God only knows what will happen.
('84', 299, 5, 33, 523478) I am reaching Bombay on the 19th.
('84', 299, 6, 34, 523512) 1 Yashwant M. Parnerkar

('84', 300, 3, 9, 523810) 406. LETTER TO MAHAVIR PRASAD PODDAR
('84', 300, 4, 10, 523847) August 17, 1944
('84', 300, 5, 11, 523863) MAHAVIR PRASAD, I do not know whether Ghanshyamdas has told you about my scheme for nature cure.
('84', 300, 5, 12, 523960) If my ideas can be implemented, I would have used, to the best of my ability, all my God given talents.
('84', 300, 5, 13, 524064) These ideas came to me while I was at Dinshaw’s Arogya Bhavan 3. I shall not give a full account of their evolution.
('84', 300, 5, 14, 524181) Here I am giving you in short the ideas in their final form.
('84', 300, 5, 15, 524242) Select a plot of a thousand acres near any village.
('84', 300, 5, 16, 524294) It will be better if the land is situated in a salubrious region.
('84', 300, 5, 17, 524360) It does not matter if the village is far away from a town or the railway station.
('84', 300, 5, 18, 524442) Select two such plots or at least one.
('84', 300, 5, 19, 524481) Get a layout of the land made right now— even before purchasing the land.
('84', 300, 5, 20, 524555) Keep in view the following points while making the plan.
('84', 300, 5, 21, 524612) Have the roads marked out in the plan.
('84', 300, 5, 22, 524651) One road shall be broad but right now it will not be made motorable, only bullock carts or horse driven carriages will ply on it.
('84', 300, 5, 23, 524781) The plot must be provided with fresh water.
('84', 300, 5, 24, 524825) There should be a nice swimming pool, a gymnasium or two to provide facilities for physical exercise.
('84', 300, 5, 25, 524927) Arrangement should be made to grow fruits, trees, vegetables and foodgrains.
('84', 300, 5, 26, 525004) There shall be facilities on this land to treat patients by nature cure methods.
('84', 300, 5, 27, 525085) Nature cure will include the various methods of mud pack, treatment with water, such as hip bath, friction bath, steam bath, etc., treatment with light, such as sun bath, suryanamaskara 4, moon bath, watching the stars, utilizing all the lights of the rainbow through the medium of cloth, water, glass bottle, etc., treatment with air such as pranayama 5, subsisting on air, etc.
('84', 300, 6, 28, 525465) 1 Addressee’s wife 2 Addressee’s son 3 At Poona 4, Name of an exercise; literally, ‘worship of the Sun’ 5 Breathing exercises
('84', 301, 0, 1, 525591) 302 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 301, 1, 2, 525633) initial stage, use of modern devices like electricity, etc., will be avoided.
('84', 301, 1, 3, 525711) This is with a view to initially using mechanical aids to the minimum and developing such devices as the villagers can use easily as also exploring their usefulness.
('84', 301, 1, 4, 525877) Not only will sick persons be treated in this institution, but even normal persons likely to benefit from nature cure will be admitted to it.
('84', 301, 1, 5, 526019) We should try to give vigour and vitality to the weak.
('84', 301, 1, 6, 526074) Children will be admitted to the institution with this view, and efforts will be made to build their health according to the laws of nature.
('84', 301, 1, 7, 526215) Health will be our prime concern.
('84', 301, 1, 8, 526249) Special emphasis will be placed on preservation and improvement of health.
('84', 301, 1, 9, 526324) Thus the aim of this institution will be self reliance in all respects and its message will be universal.
('84', 301, 1, 10, 526430) It will tend to become an ideal village with facilities for basic education and village industries like khadi, etc.
('84', 301, 1, 11, 526546) Initially it will certainly require a lot of money but I cannot think of a better use of money than this.
('84', 301, 1, 12, 526652) A trust should be constituted for this purpose.
('84', 301, 1, 13, 526700) I had thought of Dinshaw Mehta, Ghanshyamdas, and myself as trustees; Ghanshyamdas added two more—Devdas and you.
('84', 301, 1, 14, 526814) I had of course thought of you but I had no idea how far you could go with this.
('84', 301, 1, 15, 526895) If I accept your name you should free yourself from all other work and devote yourself to this work.
('84', 301, 1, 16, 526996) Ghanshyamdas believes in nature cure and he can either attract donations or give one himself.
('84', 301, 1, 17, 527090) Devdas will fulfil this function by becoming Ghanshyamdas’s representative.
('84', 301, 1, 18, 527166) I will be the guide—since the whole idea is mine.
('84', 301, 1, 19, 527216) It can be said that I am a devotee of nature cure for the last fifty years.
('84', 301, 1, 20, 527292) This venture was conceived with the expectation that Dinshaw could be put in charge of fully implementing the ideas.
('84', 301, 1, 21, 527409) And I shall like very much your joining this provided you can devote the rest of your life entirely to this work.
('84', 301, 1, 22, 527523) Meet me at the earliest if you find these ideas good enough.
('84', 301, 2, 23, 527584) From a copy of the Hindi: Pyarelal Papers.
('84', 301, 2, 24, 527627) Courtesy: Pyarelal
('84', 302, 0, 1, 527646) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 303
('84', 302, 1, 2, 527693) 407. INTERVIEW TO PEGGY DURDIN 1
('84', 302, 2, 3, 527726) [After August 17, 1944] 2
('84', 302, 3, 4, 527752) Q. Does the Viceroy’s rejection 3 of your offer in any way lessen the desirability of or urgency for a communal settlement now?
('84', 302, 4, 5, 527880) A. Not in the least.
('84', 302, 4, 6, 527901) As I have already said in several interviews the simultaneous publication of my offer to the Viceroy and the Rajaji Formula established a wholly unintended connection between the two.
('84', 302, 4, 7, 528085) The rejection makes the urgency doubly urgent.
('84', 302, 4, 8, 528132) This I say although I believe that past experience shows that so long as there is a third party dividing communities and interests there is no adjustment possible.
('84', 302, 4, 9, 528296) This has never meant for me that I should not strive for a settlement even before independence.
('84', 302, 5, 10, 528392) Q. From the point of view of non violence, is it not preferable for a national government to take office after, rather than during, the present war?
('84', 302, 6, 11, 528541) A. Not if a national government comes into being even during the war by the spontaneous act of Great Britain or the Allies.
('84', 302, 6, 12, 528665) For then the war itself will have changed its course and the peace to come will be wholly honourable and calculated to promote non violence.
('84', 302, 7, 13, 528806) Q. Would not a strong group of nationalist ministers, Hindu and Muslim, responsible under the present constitution to the Viceroy rather than to the Legislature in point of fact, nullify the Viceregal veto?
('84', 302, 7, 14, 529013) Would not a common front presented by strong nationalist leaders make acceptance of their programme and plans inevitable?
('84', 302, 8, 15, 529135) A. No such manipulation can possibly electrify the whole nation.
('84', 302, 8, 16, 529200) Such an experiment is doomed to failure ab initio.
('84', 302, 8, 17, 529251) It would lack trust on the part of the British Government in the people of India.
('84', 302, 9, 18, 529333) Q. I am not clear on your attitude toward mass civil disobedience.
('84', 302, 9, 19, 529400) Am I right in thinking that you would consider its use justified if your appeal to the Viceroy and the talks with Mr. Jinnah fail?
('84', 302, 10, 20, 529531) A. Mass civil disobedience can only take place if other efforts to
('84', 302, 11, 21, 529598) 1 Correspondent of Time and Life.
('84', 302, 11, 22, 529632) The source had reproduced the interview from The Free Press Journal.
('84', 302, 11, 23, 529701) 2 The correspondent met Gandhiji in August shortly after the Viceroy’s rejection of Gandhiji’s proposals.
('84', 302, 11, 24, 529807) Gandhiji’s correspondence with the Viceroy was released to the Press on August 17, 1944. 3 Vide Appendix “Letter from Lord Wavell”, 15 8 1944.
('84', 303, 0, 1, 529950) 304 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 303, 1, 2, 529992) achieve the object aimed at fail.
('84', 303, 1, 3, 530026) Here the object is independence.
('84', 303, 1, 4, 530059) Appeal to the Viceroy was for a settlement.
('84', 303, 1, 5, 530103) The appeal having failed the case for civil disobedience is complete.
('84', 303, 1, 6, 530173) Successful negotiations with the Quaid e Azam need not affect the case for civil disobedience.
('84', 303, 1, 7, 530268) But as I have said—for reasons I need not enter into here but which I have already publicly stated—I may not offer civil disobedience at the present moment.
('84', 303, 1, 8, 530425) Mass civil disobedience is conceived as an entirely effective substitute for a bloody war and is any day far superior to it.
('84', 303, 1, 9, 530550) But just as wars do not take place just for the sake of war, but only for a cause just or unjust, mass civil disobedience can take place only for a cause wholly just.
('84', 303, 1, 10, 530717) If I have understood your question correctly, this answer ought to set at rest all your doubts.
('84', 303, 2, 11, 530813) Q. By American management of a section of the Burma Assam Railway and part of the port of Calcutta I think we can say that the war in Burma is being shortened.
('84', 303, 2, 12, 530973) Would a national government permit such American controls?
('84', 303, 3, 13, 531032) A. I have already answered the question in my previous public statements.
('84', 303, 3, 14, 531106) Permission for all such controls is clearly indicated under my offer.
('84', 303, 3, 15, 531176) Of course, it is only for the purpose of the war.
('84', 303, 4, 16, 531226) Q. Would you consider courting rearrest if your proposals or those of yourself and Mr. Jinnah are not accepted?
('84', 303, 5, 17, 531338) A. I really do not know future plans.
('84', 303, 5, 18, 531376) You will believe me when I say that they are in God’s hands.
('84', 303, 6, 19, 531437) Q. Non violence may be relative, not absolute.
('84', 303, 6, 20, 531484) Some participation in the already existing violence, participation for the purpose of producing real and lasting peace, may be unavoidable and even desirable.
('84', 303, 6, 21, 531643) Is this a fair statement of the position?
('84', 303, 7, 22, 531685) A. It is a fair statement.
('84', 303, 7, 23, 531712) I cannot challenge it merely because it is likely to lead to dangerous abuse from the non violent standpoint.
('84', 303, 7, 24, 531822) Pure unmixed non violence is impossible as Euclid’s line.
('84', 303, 8, 25, 531880) Q. I understand your answer to mean that mass civil disobedience presents no solution of the present deadlock.
('84', 303, 9, 26, 531991) A. You are right.
('84', 303, 10, 27, 532009) Q. May I quote you as saying that the national government you conceive of would do nothing which, as far as the war in the Far East is concerned, would jeopardize one additional American life or which would lengthen the war for an American soldier—that such a government would on the contrary make every effort to hasten the conclusion of the war against Japan?
('84', 303, 11, 28, 532371) A. You will be safe in using the language as if it was mine.
('84', 303, 11, 29, 532432) The Hindu, 4 10 1944

('84', 306, 4, 10, 535313) 412. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS OF INDIA
('84', 306, 5, 11, 535357) SEVAGRAM, (WARDHA), August 18, 1944 The published correspondence 1 shows that I left no stone unturned to conform to the Viceregal requirements.
('84', 306, 5, 12, 535502) The final Government reply is positive proof that the British Government have no intention of winning public support.
('84', 306, 5, 13, 535620) I do not confine myself to the Congress, since its main demand has been backed by almost all political parties.
('84', 306, 5, 14, 535732) So far as the technical winning of the war is concerned, they have evidently no need for such support.
('84', 306, 5, 15, 535835) Moral support they seem to despise.
('84', 306, 5, 16, 535871) Boiled down, the Viceroy’s proposition means that unless all the main parties agree as to the constitution of the future and there is agreement between the British Government and the main parties, there is to be no change in the constitutional position, and the Government of India as at present is to be carried on.
('84', 306, 5, 17, 536188) The names of the parties given in the Government reply are illustrative only.
('84', 306, 5, 18, 536266) I have no doubt that on due occasions more will be exhibited as from a conjurer’s bag and who knows how and when the British Government will agree to surrender control?
('84', 306, 5, 19, 536435) It is as clear as crystal that the British Government do not propose to give up the power they possess over four hundred millions, unless the latter develop strength enough to wrest it from them.
('84', 306, 5, 20, 536631) I shall never lose hope that India will do so by purely moral means.
('84', 306, 5, 21, 536700) The problem of food, meanwhile, remains unsolved.
('84', 306, 6, 22, 536750) 1 Vide “Letter to Lord Wavell”, 15 7 1944 and 26/27 7 1944.
('84', 307, 0, 1, 536810) 308 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 307, 1, 2, 536852) national Government envisaged by me can provide a genuine solution.
('84', 307, 1, 3, 536920) Any other will be a mirage.
('84', 307, 1, 4, 536948) It is most unfortunate that at this critical juncture the Quaid e Azam has fallen ill and under medical advice cannot see me till he is free from his illness.
('84', 307, 1, 5, 537107) A proper heart agreement between us can induce a revision of the firm refusal of the British Government as conveyed through His Excellency’s letter.
('84', 307, 1, 6, 537256) Let us all pray that the Quaid e Azam may be soon restored enough to see me and that God may so dominate our hearts as to lead us to a right solution.
('84', 307, 1, 7, 537407) I would like to assure all parties to be affected by our solution that we will not come to any terms which will compromise or ignore a single interest.
('84', 307, 1, 8, 537559) The Rajaji Formula is capable of being amended if it is found to contain flaws as many Hindu and Sikh friends have suggested it does.
('84', 307, 1, 9, 537693) No solution is likely to last unless, on the face of it, it is right and is acceptable to the people of India as a whole.
('84', 307, 1, 10, 537815) The Bombay Chronicle, 19 8 1944

('84', 311, 8, 17, 543116) I do not endorse any Pakistan but I do endorse Rajaji’s scheme even if it be called Pakistan.
('84', 311, 8, 18, 543210) It is a concrete form of the Congress resolution.
('84', 311, 8, 19, 543260) The Rajaji Formula merely furnishes a basis for discussion.
('84', 311, 8, 20, 543320) It opens a way to the solution of the communal tangle.
('84', 311, 8, 21, 543375) Everybody who does not like it is free to oppose it.
('84', 311, 8, 22, 543428) If you think that it will harm the country you are bound to oppose it.
('84', 311, 8, 23, 543499) If Muslim opinion dislikes it, it must go.
('84', 311, 8, 24, 543542) It will go also if Hindus and others oppose it.
('84', 311, 8, 25, 543590) The Rajaji Formula furnishes a scheme for voluntary acceptance.
('84', 311, 8, 26, 543654) There is no room for discussion, if it is to be imposed by force.
('84', 311, 8, 27, 543720) I could be no party to a forcible imposition of a thing even if of my own coining.
('84', 311, 8, 28, 543803) Here therefore there is no question of ignoring or disregarding nationalist Muslims of any other section.
('84', 311, 8, 29, 543909) Quaid e Azam represents the League.
('84', 311, 8, 30, 543945) I represent nobody but myself.
('84', 311, 8, 31, 543976) I did read your contribution to Bharat Jyoti.
('84', 311, 8, 32, 544022) Your book, I am sorry, I have not been able to touch.
('84', 311, 8, 33, 544076) You should know that we (Rajaji and I) have reserved the right to oppose even the modified scheme of partition, if it ever goes to the

('84', 317, 0, 1, 551390) 318 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 317, 1, 2, 551432) 429. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS 1
('84', 317, 2, 3, 551460) August 23, 1944
('84', 317, 3, 4, 551476) QUESTION : Mahatmaji, you have been during your whole political career a strong supporter of the integrity of India and an opponent of vivisection.
('84', 317, 3, 5, 551624) How do you reconcile your present position in giving support to Rajaji’s proposals ?
('84', 317, 4, 6, 551709) ANSWER : There is no change in my views.
('84', 317, 4, 7, 551750) I am even today as much against vivisection of India as ever before.
('84', 317, 4, 8, 551819) Rajaji’s formula concedes right of self determination, but it does not concede Pakistan—an indefinite and undefined expression.
('84', 317, 4, 9, 551947) As a believer in non violence I cannot use force in keeping people of a particular area inside India if they want to separate.
('84', 317, 4, 10, 552074) All I can do is to persuade them.
('84', 317, 5, 11, 552108) Q. Whatever be the result of your negotiations with Mr. Jinnah, don’t you think that the British statesmen taking advantage of Rajaji’s offer, which has your support, will divide India into two parts and establish two rival federations instead of one and thereby find an additional reason for the continuance of British control ?
('84', 317, 5, 12, 552438) A. I do not think the British statesmen will do it, unless they want it themselves and have independently so decided.
('84', 317, 5, 13, 552556) They know that forty crores of people cannot be kept under permanent bondage.
('84', 317, 5, 14, 552634) The world forces are moving so fast that whether the British Government will or not India must be free at no distant date.
('84', 317, 5, 15, 552757) Furthermore, Rajaji’s formula definitely lays down that the exercise of the right of self determination can only accrue after independence.
('84', 317, 6, 16, 552897) Q. The non Muslims of the Punjab and of Bengal feel panicky about Rajaji’s formula because they are afraid that under this formula the non Muslims in the separated areas will be thrown into Pakistan.
('84', 317, 7, 17, 553097) A. From the reports that I receive it is evident that so far as the Punjab is concerned there is already Pakistan in action.
('84', 317, 7, 18, 553222) The religious and cultural rights of the non Muslims they say are denied to them.
('84', 317, 7, 19, 553304) My informants say that undue restrictions are placed on non Muslim leaders and their womenfolk cannot even move about freely for fear of molestation.
('84', 317, 7, 20, 553454) If this is a true picture I don’t think the position will be in any way worse in “Pakistan” if ever it is established.
('84', 317, 7, 21, 553573) The people of the Punjab and Bengal need entertain no false fears, as I am not going to sell them off.
('84', 317, 7, 22, 553676) I have no right to do so.
('84', 317, 7, 23, 553702) No individual can barter away rights of brave people endowed with self 
('84', 317, 8, 24, 553774) 1 The questions were asked by Lala Brijlal.
('84', 318, 0, 1, 553818) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 319
('84', 318, 1, 2, 553865) confidence.
('84', 318, 1, 3, 553877) Today I enjoy the confidence of the people because they believe that their interests are safe in my hands and I cannot betray them.
('84', 318, 1, 4, 554009) If tomorrow I act against their wishes and interests I shall be stoned by these very people who now trust me.
('84', 318, 1, 5, 554119) I am rather pained at the nervousness exhibited by the Sikhs who are a brave community.
('84', 318, 1, 6, 554207) Unless they have lost the chivalrous spirit and bravery which the Gurus infused in them, they need entertain no fear about my coming talks with Mr. Jinnah.
('84', 318, 1, 7, 554363) I have already explained in my Press statement and I repeat again that nothing will be done by me or us to the prejudice of any section of the Indian population and whatever proposals are agreed to between Quaid e Azam Jinnah and myself will be open to confirmation, amendment and rejection by the representatives of various communities and interests.
('84', 318, 1, 8, 554715) There is no idea of forcing anything on anybody against his will.
('84', 318, 2, 9, 554781) Q. If Pakistan ever comes into existence don’t you think, Mahatmaji, the existence of a rival independent state in the north west will be a constant danger to the independence of India ?
('84', 318, 3, 10, 554968) A. Thirty crores and over of inhabitants living in India have nothing to fear from two crores of Muslims living in the north west.
('84', 318, 3, 11, 555099) If the former are so weak as not to be able to defend themselves against two crores in the north west, then they have no right to ask for independence.
('84', 318, 3, 12, 555251) I have no doubt in my mind that if India becomes independent, Indians will be able to defend themselves against any outside aggres sion with the resources at their disposal.
('84', 318, 4, 13, 555425) Q. Mahatmaji, all your attempts during the last twenty years or over for bringing about Hindu Muslim unity have gone in vain and Hindu Muslim relations today are as much strained as ever before.
('84', 318, 4, 14, 555620) Don’t you think that India has been put on the wrong track and communal electorates are the bane of the Indian constitution?
('84', 318, 4, 15, 555745) The Muslim demand for Pakistan and Mr. Jinnah’s propounding of the two nation theory are the natural sequences of separate electorates and communal reservations and so long as the principle of separate electorates on religious basis continues to disfigure the constitution of our country, there is no chance of the Hindus and Muslims living at peace as members of the great Indian nations ?
('84', 318, 4, 16, 556136) If you agree with the above contention why don’t you give a right lead to the country by pressing for joint electorates as the basis of political rights ?
('84', 318, 4, 17, 556291) A. I do believe that separate electorates have done more harm than good.
('84', 318, 5, 18, 556364) From a copy : Pyarelal Papers.
('84', 318, 5, 19, 556395) Nehru Memorial Museum and Library.

('84', 319, 7, 16, 557235) August 23, 1944 1. In the social order of my conception, as much production as possible would be located in the villages, and that too through the power of people’s hands and feet.
('84', 319, 7, 17, 557416) But this ideal cannot always be realized.
('84', 319, 7, 18, 557458) We have to accept compromise at some point.
('84', 319, 7, 19, 557502) Experience alone can decide the limits of such compromise.
('84', 319, 7, 20, 557561) Every worker can decide the limit for himself; but when he works as a member of some institution he has to submit to the limit accepted by the institution.
('84', 319, 7, 21, 557717) He helps the institution and accelerates its progress towards its goal if he further narrows the limit accepted by it, as Vinoba has done.
('84', 319, 7, 22, 557856) 1 I cannot go further than this in my reply.
('84', 319, 7, 23, 557901) But you will perhaps be able, on the basis of this, to formulate in fewer words a policy befitting or supporting my conception.
('84', 319, 7, 24, 558029) Try to do it and if you frame any such formula, please show it to me.
('84', 319, 7, 25, 558099) 2. For me, India begins and ends in the villages; that is, what I

('84', 320, 1, 3, 558385) If I think, and can persuade the institutions concerned to think, about paper making from this point of view, we might find it easier to reach our goal.
('84', 320, 1, 4, 558538) If the people of a village can produce energy from some source in the village itself so that they can invent a device whereby, instead of every person making paper, a few hands are able to produce all the paper needed, I would welcome such an invention.
('84', 320, 1, 5, 558792) If the attempt to produce everything through the power of man’s hands and feet puts such constraints on him that further development of this triple faculties would be completely arrested, I would regard such an arrangement as faulty.

('84', 322, 2, 3, 562042) SEVAGRAM, August 24, 1944
('84', 322, 3, 4, 562068) BHAI JIVANJI, Mridulabehn 1 has a good many complaints against Navajivan Karyalaya and the [Gujarat] Vidyapith.
('84', 322, 3, 5, 562180) She says that when one seeks your help for my work, one always gets a negative reply.
('84', 322, 3, 6, 562266) The result is, you do not profit from the ideas that occur to workers like her.
('84', 322, 3, 7, 562346) You attach no value to the help offered by these workers.
('84', 322, 3, 8, 562404) You behave with absolute confidence in yourself as if whatever you do is beyond criticism or improvement.
('84', 322, 3, 9, 562510) Since you are involved in these complaints, and since you are one of the founders of these institutions, people generally believe that what the Gandhians do can hardly warrant any criticism.
('84', 322, 3, 10, 562701) And the Gandhians, on their part, boastfully say to workers like her: ‘Look at our work and our skill in keeping our balance.
('84', 322, 3, 11, 562827) We are supplying cheap and ennobling literature to the people; and we never sit idle.
('84', 322, 3, 12, 562913) We have acquired the secret of unremitting work.
('84', 322, 3, 13, 562962) Now, we do not understand what you critics want to say.
('84', 322, 3, 14, 563018) You cannot find fault with the work we are doing.
('84', 322, 3, 15, 563068) We do not work the way you do.
('84', 322, 3, 16, 563099) It does not suit us.
('84', 322, 3, 17, 563120) The field for service is very wide.
('84', 322, 3, 18, 563156) You can do as you please and let us do what we like.
('84', 322, 3, 19, 563209) So our plea is that we should bear with each other and carry on our work.
('84', 322, 3, 20, 563283) Moreover, we are always ready to carry out Gandhiji’s wishes.’ Mridulabehn depicts this picture of Navajivan Karyalaya and the Vidyapith and allied institutions.
('84', 322, 3, 21, 563445) The language is not hers but mine.
('84', 322, 3, 22, 563480) I have used garish words.
('84', 322, 3, 23, 563506) Without them I cannot make you see Mridulabehn’s meaning as I understand it.
('84', 322, 3, 24, 563583) She is sarcastic but not virulent.
('84', 322, 3, 25, 563618) I have regarded her criticism as friendly.
('84', 322, 3, 26, 563661) You also should take it in the same spirit and give her whatever help she needs and you can give.
('84', 322, 3, 27, 563759) She has cited two instances.
('84', 322, 3, 28, 563788) The reply 2

('84', 334, 4, 7, 578646) 458. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('84', 334, 5, 8, 578674) August 31, 1944 I have seen an Orient Press report to the effect that I have consented to receive the salute of Khaksars on my arrival in Bombay.
('84', 334, 5, 9, 578820) I may say that I have given no such consent.
('84', 334, 5, 10, 578865) I am going to Bombay as an individual.
('84', 334, 5, 11, 578904) I can, therefore, receive no salute.
('84', 334, 5, 12, 578941) I invite individuals and organizations to devote themselves to silently praying that we may both be wisely guided by the Almighty.
('84', 334, 5, 13, 579072) I would ask then to avoid all demonstrations.
('84', 334, 5, 14, 579118) Let the leaders of all communities devise ways and means of cultivating friendly relations with one another.
('84', 334, 5, 15, 579227) The Hitavada, 1 9 1944

('84', 336, 3, 4, 581254) NARANDAS, A fund of Rs. 75 lakhs is being collected 1. Let its fate be what it will.
('84', 336, 3, 5, 581339) I do not know how much from it will be made available to you.
('84', 336, 3, 6, 581401) You who are at the root of this collection should however carry on with your work in your own manner.
('84', 336, 3, 7, 581503) This means that you should be able to collect money according to your plan.
('84', 336, 3, 8, 581579) Those who have been always helping you for the Rentia Baras 2 purse should understand this.
('84', 336, 3, 9, 581671) And if they do, they should send you their contributions this time also as they have been doing in the past.
('84', 336, 3, 10, 581780) Whenever you feel that such donors require a word from me, you may use this letter.
('84', 336, 3, 11, 581864) It would certainly pain me if the purpose of the Kasturba Fund is misunderstood and in consequence further expansion of your work is obstructed.
('84', 336, 3, 12, 582009) I will regard the Fund as having been put to good use only if its work, like your work, spreads throughout the country.
('84', 336, 4, 13, 582129) Blessings from BAPU

('84', 339, 1, 2, 585500) 468. LETTER TO B. G. KHER
('84', 339, 2, 3, 585526) September 1, 1944
('84', 339, 3, 4, 585544) BHAI BALASAHEB 1, Bhai Lalubhai had brought the resolution drafted by students for the students’ conference.
('84', 339, 3, 5, 585653) His sincere entreaty created a good impression on me.
('84', 339, 3, 6, 585707) He pressed me hard and somehow exacted a message 2 also.
('84', 339, 3, 7, 585764) That message is not a message but an invitation to bind the students.
('84', 339, 3, 8, 585834) I was not very willing to do even that much, nor did I have the time.
('84', 339, 3, 9, 585904) I did not like the resolution.
('84', 339, 3, 10, 585935) Pyarelal offered and tried to shorten it.
('84', 339, 3, 11, 585977) His draft was fairly good but I was not satisfied.
('84', 339, 3, 12, 586028) He does not get a minute to spare.
('84', 339, 3, 13, 586063) After the arrival of the Bishop of Rangoon his work has increased a lot.
('84', 339, 3, 14, 586136) I, therefore, took up the drafting of the resolution in my own hand.
('84', 339, 3, 15, 586205) I did this on the spur of the moment, but the work was too much.
('84', 339, 3, 16, 586270) Whatever I have done is enclosed herewith.
('84', 339, 3, 17, 586313) 3 It seems to me that I have compressed a great deal in a short space, multum in parvo.
('84', 339, 3, 18, 586401) But persons with superficial knowledge of a subject sometimes suffer from such a delusion and are pleased with themselves.
('84', 339, 3, 19, 586524) I would not be surprised if that is what has happened in the case of this draft, for I have finished it somehow in intervals snatched from a busy schedule.
('84', 339, 3, 20, 586680) You may, therefore, add anything to or remove anything from the draft.
('84', 339, 3, 21, 586751) You need not fear that I would feel offended.
('84', 339, 3, 22, 586797) He is a true co worker who finds out the shortcomings of his colleague and helps him to correct them in a friendly spirit.
('84', 339, 3, 23, 586920) The interview with the Bishop shaped very well.
('84', 339, 3, 24, 586968) The result lies in the hands of God.
('84', 339, 3, 25, 587005) I hope your study of Urdu is going on.
('84', 339, 3, 26, 587044) If it was discontinued owing to pressure of work, please resume it.
('84', 339, 3, 27, 587112) Drop by drop fills the ocean.
('84', 339, 3, 28, 587142) I am reaching Bombay on the 9th to meet the Quaid e Azam.
('84', 339, 3, 29, 587200) I hope you will have no difficulty in reading and understanding this letter.
('84', 339, 4, 30, 587277) Blessings from BAPU From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 2772

('84', 340, 6, 13, 588101) 470. SPEECH AT A. I. S. A. MEETING I
('84', 340, 7, 14, 588138) SEVAGRAM, September 1, 1944 More than two years have passed since we last met.
('84', 340, 7, 15, 588217) I have come to know a little, that is to say, not the whole of what happened outside [the jail] during these two years.
('84', 340, 7, 16, 588337) It seemed as though one age had succeeded another, bringing in the process trouble for the whole of India.
('84', 340, 7, 17, 588444) How could the Charkha Sangh have escaped it?
('84', 340, 7, 18, 588489) Today, we have once again come together under these circumstances but whatever little work we might yet be able to do would not be enough for us.
('84', 340, 7, 19, 588635) A large amount of the Charkha Sangh property has either been destroyed or is in Government custody.
('84', 340, 7, 20, 588735) Besides, many of our colleagues could not be among us today.
('84', 340, 7, 21, 588796) Here, I am not talking of Congressmen but of those who were especially helpful in the Sangh work and are its trustees.
('84', 340, 7, 22, 588915) But I have realized that even with these few we can carry on the Sangh work.
('84', 340, 7, 23, 588992) We are sure of
('84', 340, 8, 24, 589007) 1 President, Legislative Council, Bombay, 1937 47
('84', 341, 0, 1, 589057) 342 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 341, 1, 2, 589099) their ability to do it.
('84', 341, 1, 3, 589123) I have thought a great deal over the subject of khadi during my detention.
('84', 341, 1, 4, 589198) I shall briefly state the conclusions I have arrived at.
('84', 341, 1, 5, 589255) The most important discovery I made was that the foundation of the A.I.S.A. was so weak that the Association could be easily wiped out of existence.
('84', 341, 1, 6, 589404) It had not taken root in the life of the people.
('84', 341, 1, 7, 589453) The Government could destroy it by imprisoning its leaders.
('84', 341, 1, 8, 589513) Though some of its activities continued, I saw clearly that the Government could exterminate it at its pleasure.
('84', 341, 1, 9, 589626) That is to say, my belief that the movement for the revival of the spinning wheel was indestructible, whatever the circumstances, had been dashed to the ground.
('84', 341, 1, 10, 589787) The work had not been organized on an imperishable basis.
('84', 341, 1, 11, 589845) I am not a man to accept defeat easily but it was in the jail that I discovered that we live at Government’s mercy and it hurts me.
('84', 341, 1, 12, 589977) If it were in my power I would choose to live at no one’s mercy except God’s.
('84', 341, 1, 13, 590055) True, it is Divine dispensation that no man may live without the goodwill of his fellow beings but I am not talking of such help.
('84', 341, 1, 14, 590185) My activities are founded on my own thinking.
('84', 341, 1, 15, 590231) The Charkha Sangh was also founded on the same principles.
('84', 341, 1, 16, 590290) In South Africa, I discovered that if India was to survive and progress non violently, it could only be through the charkha—the charkha alone can be a symbol of non violence.
('84', 341, 1, 17, 590465) We may draw strength from other symbols as well but such strength may not lead to the world’s well being.
('84', 341, 1, 18, 590571) I realized in jail that there was something wrong in our method of khadi work, which must needs be amended.
('84', 341, 1, 19, 590679) I had asked India to carry on spinning.
('84', 341, 1, 20, 590719) I knew how this spinning work was to be carried on.
('84', 341, 1, 21, 590771) But I did not lay the necessary stress on the requisite outlook and the spirit which was to underlie it.
('84', 341, 1, 22, 590876) I looked at it from its immediate practical aspect.
('84', 341, 1, 23, 590928) All my co workers also laid stress on this practical side.
('84', 341, 1, 24, 590987) So I suffered it, and also lent my helping hand to it.
('84', 341, 1, 25, 591042) We have gone far in that direction.
('84', 341, 1, 26, 591078) But today I cannot continue to ask people to spin in that manner.
('84', 341, 1, 27, 591144) I contemplated how to work in the future.
('84', 341, 1, 28, 591186) I even thought of disbanding the Sangh on my own and distributing its property and funds among the people.
('84', 341, 1, 29, 591293) I saw that our work would be incomplete, so long as we did not carry the message of the charkha to every home.
('84', 341, 1, 30, 591404) That, I thought, accounted for our being far from our ideal.
('84', 341, 1, 31, 591465) There are seven lakh villages in India.
('84', 341, 1, 32, 591505) Thousands of them do not even know what the charkha is.
('84', 341, 1, 33, 591561) This is our fault and it is because of this fault that
('84', 342, 0, 1, 591616) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 343
('84', 342, 1, 2, 591663) we have failed to put khadi work on a sound basis.
('84', 342, 1, 3, 591714) You must ponder over it.
('84', 342, 1, 4, 591739) All the thought and study I have been giving to this subject lately make me feel that the work would have to be decentralized if it is to spread far and wide and take permanent root.
('84', 342, 1, 5, 591922) The above line of thought led to the idea of decentralization and I thought it would be very good indeed if its worth could be proved.
('84', 342, 1, 6, 592057) I realize that the difficulties in my way are many but then hardly anyone has devoted as much thought and effort to the charkha as I have.
('84', 342, 1, 7, 592196) This is a rather tall claim and it also smacks of pride, but not to mention it on the right occasion would be false modesty.
('84', 342, 1, 8, 592321) In the jail too I had no other thought but the charkha.
('84', 342, 1, 9, 592377) The strength behind all my activities including civil disobedience is derived wholly from the charkha to which I have devoted most of my energy and funds.
('84', 342, 1, 10, 592532) Most of the ten million rupees of the Tilak Swaraj Fund was also used up for the spinning activity.
('84', 342, 1, 11, 592632) This brought about a spate of charges against me but I regard them as so many bouquets.
('84', 342, 1, 12, 592720) For whatever I did, I did after due deliberation and with full knowledge of its consequences.
('84', 342, 1, 13, 592814) I did not deceive anyone.
('84', 342, 1, 14, 592840) Nothing was spent on the charkha without convincing the public about it.
('84', 342, 1, 15, 592913) That is how this institution came into being.
('84', 342, 1, 16, 592959) After much reflection and study I have arrived at the definite conclusion that, however intense, my sadhana 1 of the charkha has remained imperfect and I must admit that my study too has not been as thorough as it ought to have been.
('84', 342, 1, 17, 593193) Today, my words have a greater force because I can see these things more clearly.
('84', 342, 1, 18, 593275) Besides the Charkha Sangh members, as well as sympathizers and those who share my feelings, today’s gathering includes some representatives of the public also.
('84', 342, 1, 19, 593435) Had we only directed the strength the country displayed during the movement along the right channels, we could have shown how much public support we had.
('84', 342, 1, 20, 593589) But we failed to do so.
('84', 342, 1, 21, 593613) The fault is not yours but mine and when I say all this, it is not so much to blame you, as to whip up your intelligence and my own.
('84', 342, 1, 22, 593746) We plied the charkha but mechanically, not intelligently.
('84', 342, 1, 23, 593804) Had you yourselves appreciated the full significance of the charkha, you would have given it the same importance as I do.
('84', 342, 1, 24, 593926) It also has political
('84', 342, 2, 25, 593948) 1 Spiritual discipline
('84', 343, 0, 1, 593971) 344 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 343, 1, 2, 594013) significance.
('84', 343, 1, 3, 594027) It has however no place in the dishonest game of politics.
('84', 343, 1, 4, 594086) More than any other thing it is the charkha that stands for clean, noble politics.
('84', 343, 1, 5, 594169) If there is [no] truth in this statement, how can we claim swaraj through the charkha?
('84', 343, 1, 6, 594256) It certainly does not mean that as soon as the yarn snaps swaraj comes to nought.
('84', 343, 1, 7, 594338) It is often alleged that workers of the A.I.S.A. and the A.I.V.I.A., if not Gandhiites in general, are unintelligent and lifeless.
('84', 343, 1, 8, 594469) People repose trust in them.
('84', 343, 1, 9, 594498) But they (the Gandhiites) are not able to tell the people what exactly are the problems facing the country and how our programme is calculated to resolve these problems and take us to our goal.
('84', 343, 1, 10, 594692) On the other hand, Marxian literature is fast increasing in the country and Gandhiites are not able to resist the impact of these external forces.
('84', 343, 1, 11, 594839) We say that we are devoted to non violence.
('84', 343, 1, 12, 594883) If so, we must reveal in our lives the force of non violence.
('84', 343, 1, 13, 594945) Unless we can reveal its force in our own lives, we will not be true Gandhiites.
('84', 343, 1, 14, 595026) In fact, there is no such thing as Gandhism.
('84', 343, 1, 15, 595071) If anything, it is non violence that deserves to be called an ideology.
('84', 343, 1, 16, 595143) Every member of the Charkha Sangh should be a living witness of non violence.
('84', 343, 1, 17, 595221) If he is a devotee of non violence or Gandhism, he must be a live wire.
('84', 343, 1, 18, 595293) Today Gandhism is a word of reproach.
('84', 343, 1, 19, 595331) It no more connotes something virtuous or praiseworthy.
('84', 343, 1, 20, 595387) Let us admit we have failed to make non violence a part of our being.
('84', 343, 1, 21, 595457) Otherwise we would find the charkha established in every village.
('84', 343, 1, 22, 595523) I confess that I have failed.
('84', 343, 1, 23, 595553) Had I been an adept in this art, I would have produced a concrete pattern of reconstructed village life in Sevagram at any rate.
('84', 343, 1, 24, 595682) But today even if I put the charkha in the hands of the people of Sevagram they do not accept it.
('84', 343, 1, 25, 595780) We teach them how to use it, tempt them by providing them with work, pay them more wages and serve them in various ways, yet all to little purpose.
('84', 343, 1, 26, 595928) But my faith in the charkha is unshakable even when I have failed as President of the Sangh.
('84', 343, 1, 27, 596021) That is why I said that we should admit that we have failed to do what we ought to have done.
('84', 343, 1, 28, 596115) It is not due to want of sacrifice in us.
('84', 343, 1, 29, 596157) Amongst us are men and women who have sacrificed much.
('84', 343, 1, 30, 596212) My head bends low before them.
('84', 343, 1, 31, 596243) When I think of each of them my heart is deeply moved.
('84', 343, 1, 32, 596298) My conscience tells me that a country which abounds in persons instilled with such a spirit of sacrifice can never fail.
('84', 343, 1, 33, 596419) Yet in spite of this sacrifice, we have not yet made our country free.
('84', 343, 1, 34, 596490) Freedom is coming, perhaps sooner than we believe.
('84', 343, 1, 35, 596541) But it does

('84', 344, 1, 2, 596600) not satisfy me.
('84', 344, 1, 3, 596616) I even question my own share in it and then console myself with the thought that we have at least tried our best.
('84', 344, 1, 4, 596730) I do not hold anybody guilty.
('84', 344, 1, 5, 596760) I am only pointing to the situation as it is.
('84', 344, 1, 6, 596806) Correct assessment of a situation is also a sign of intelligence.
('84', 344, 1, 7, 596872) We should not feel satisfied with what we have done.
('84', 344, 1, 8, 596925) We have tried our best, no doubt.

('84', 344, 1, 11, 597201) I lay before you a hard prescription.
('84', 344, 1, 12, 597239) If you are prepared for it, well and good.

('84', 344, 1, 14, 597352) You should examine it thoroughly.

('84', 344, 1, 16, 597525) The Sangh need not keep even a pice for future activities.
('84', 344, 1, 17, 597584) All of us should be convinced that the charkha is the symbol of non violent economic self sufficiency.
('84', 344, 1, 18, 597687) If we and the people grasp this significance of the charkha not a pice need be spent on propaganda for the charkha.
('84', 344, 1, 19, 597803) There would then be no reason to fear Government ordinances either.
('84', 344, 1, 20, 597871) Nor need we look to the rich for alms.
('84', 344, 1, 21, 597910) We shall without effort become the centre of hope, and the people will come to us of their own accord.
('84', 344, 1, 22, 598013) They will not go elsewhere to seek work.
('84', 344, 1, 23, 598054) Every village will become the nerve centre of independent India.
('84', 344, 1, 24, 598119) India will then not be known by her cities like Bombay and Calcutta, but by her 400 millions inhabiting the seven lakhs of villages.
('84', 344, 1, 25, 598252) The problems of Hindu Muslim differences, untouchability, conflicts, misunderstan dings and rivalries will all melt away.
('84', 344, 1, 26, 598374) This is the real function of the Sangh.
('84', 344, 1, 27, 598414) We have to live and die for it.
('84', 344, 1, 28, 598446) You will argue it is a very big task requiring much intelligence.
('84', 344, 1, 29, 598512) I tell you that this cannot be acquired by mere study in libraries.
('84', 344, 1, 30, 598580) We have to develop it by the labour of our hands.
('84', 344, 1, 31, 598630) This is the idea underlying the Nayee Talim according to which the intellect is developed by the effort put forth by the hands and feet.
('84', 344, 1, 32, 598767) Books need not be burnt but their importance is only secondary.
('84', 344, 1, 33, 598831) The charkha has to rank first of all.
('84', 344, 1, 34, 598869) In the same manner the pursuit of the charkha must become the mainspring of manifold other activities like village industries, Nayee Talim, etc.
('84', 344, 1, 35, 599014) If we are able to adopt the charkha intelligently we can revive the entire economic life of our villages once more.
('84', 344, 1, 36, 599130) But we can progress only as far as the strength of our
('84', 345, 0, 1, 599185) 346 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 345, 1, 2, 599227) members takes us.
('84', 345, 1, 3, 599245) I do not wish to create a fresh universe, like Vishwamitra, who wanted to take Trishanku to heaven but the poor fellow remained suspended half way.
('84', 345, 1, 4, 599393) Therefore, we have to work within the limits of our strength with our feet on the hard earth.
('84', 345, 1, 5, 599487) If we ourselves disband the Sangh the Government will have little left to attach.
('84', 345, 1, 6, 599569) They could surely not destroy us all, for our strength would have gone up to forty crores.
('84', 345, 1, 7, 599660) If they want to liquidate us we shall submit to it cheerfully.
('84', 345, 1, 8, 599723) And what does it matter if a few million among us are done away with?
('84', 345, 1, 9, 599793) An ocean does not dry up if a few drops evaporate.
('84', 345, 1, 10, 599844) Nothing can diminish its greatness.
('84', 345, 1, 11, 599880) Similarly, the more we are suppressed, the more powerful we shall grow.
('84', 345, 1, 12, 599952) The only condition is that we must recognize the power of non violence.
('84', 345, 1, 13, 600024) We must carry on untiring research on the charkha.
('84', 345, 1, 14, 600075) No doubt we have put in a lot of effort for the charkha and made some improvements in it.

('84', 345, 1, 16, 600309) We should like him to devise such charkhas as can yield more and better quality of yarn.
('84', 345, 1, 17, 600398) But even if we fail to find such an expert, I am not going to accept defeat.
('84', 345, 1, 18, 600475) I will prove my point with the help of reasoning.
('84', 345, 1, 19, 600525) We should have undying faith in the charkha.
('84', 345, 1, 20, 600570) When faith materializes it manifests itself through reason.
('84', 345, 1, 21, 600630) It is not self luminous.
('84', 345, 1, 22, 600655) For when faith transcends its bounds and finds another medium to express itself it shines forth all the more.
('84', 345, 1, 23, 600765) Faith is never lost; in fact it grows and sharpens the intellect.
('84', 345, 1, 24, 600831) And then faith can challenge reason.
('84', 345, 1, 25, 600868) It is no use merely making speeches or giving lectures; we must make scientific experiments and declare from the house tops the results of our experiments.
('84', 345, 1, 26, 601024) We have been suppressed and we have to work our way up.
('84', 345, 1, 27, 601080) Let us therefore do away with mutual recriminations, disabuse our minds of any reservations, iron out all the differences and thus simplify our work.
('84', 345, 1, 28, 601230) We should repose full confidence in our representatives and be frank.
('84', 345, 1, 29, 601300) We are votaries of truth and should, therefore, not be afraid of speaking the whole truth, for the greater the fear in our hearts, the less we shall be able to speak the truth.
('84', 345, 1, 30, 601477) That is why the Gita gives the pride of place to fearlessness.
('84', 345, 1, 31, 601540) I am telling you this on the strength of my inner experience.
('84', 345, 1, 32, 601602) We should be fearless and not hide anything.
('84', 345, 1, 33, 601647) Selfishness has already impeded our progress and unless we get rid of it, we would not be able to organize our strength and would thus prove traitors to Mother India.

('84', 346, 1, 2, 601909) 471. SPEECH AT A.I.S.A. MEETING II
('84', 346, 2, 3, 601944) SEVAGRAM, September 2, 1944 Yesterday, I was a little hasty while talking to you.
('84', 346, 2, 4, 602026) Some work was indeed done but later I kept thinking over it.
('84', 346, 2, 5, 602087) I had undertaken the stupendous task of preparing a draft for you.
('84', 346, 2, 6, 602154) I even entered silence for the purpose.
('84', 346, 2, 7, 602194) After much reflection last night and this morning I have prepared a draft which I shall now read out for your consideration.
('84', 346, 2, 8, 602319) 1. The village is the centre for the charkha, and the Charkha Sangh can realize its highest ambitions only when its work is decentralized in the villages.
('84', 346, 2, 9, 602474) Keeping this in view, this meeting of the A. I. S. A. resolves that the following changes be implemented in its present methods of work: (a) The largest number of workers whose one passion is the charkha and whom the A. I. S. A. approves should go to the villages.
('84', 346, 2, 10, 602739) (b) The present sales depots and production centres should be curtailed.
('84', 346, 2, 11, 602812) (c) Training institutions should be developed and teaching courses enlarged.
('84', 346, 2, 12, 602889) (d) The Sangh should permit any province or district which wants to be independent and self sufficient to become so.
('84', 346, 2, 13, 603006) 2. A Standing Committee composed of the members of the A.I.S.A., A.I.V.I.A. and the Hindustani Talimi Sangh should be formed in order to issue necessary directions in the light of the new ideology.
('84', 346, 2, 14, 603204) The three institutions must realize that their task is to achieve perfect non violence.
('84', 346, 2, 15, 603292) Complete swaraj will follow in its wake.
('84', 346, 2, 16, 603333) The three institutions must be so equipped that the entire government machinery should depend upon them and not vice versa.
('84', 346, 2, 17, 603457) This means the workers of these three bodies should attain in some measure the quality of a sthitaprajna 1. They must be men of secure understan ding.
('84', 346, 2, 18, 603608) If this is not possible we should stop making tall claims for the charkha.

('84', 351, 9, 11, 612896) 475. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('84', 351, 10, 12, 612924) September 3, 1944 Reference has been made to me from Gujarat 1 as to the association by Congressmen with the authorities in relieving distress which has overtaken areas through devastating floods.
('84', 351, 10, 13, 613121) The Congress, as an organization, is not functioning.
('84', 351, 10, 14, 613175) The general rule is non co operation, while the Government is warring against the Congress.
('84', 351, 10, 15, 613267) There should be no hesitation about individuals associating, if effective relief can thereby be given to the distressed people.
('84', 351, 10, 16, 613395) Every case should be judged on its own merits.
('84', 351, 10, 17, 613442) The test should be, is any initiative and responsibility left with the individuals?
('84', 351, 10, 18, 613526) The golden rule is to follow fearlessly one’s own judgment even at the risk of its proving erroneous.
('84', 351, 10, 19, 613628) The Hindu, 5 9 1944
('84', 351, 11, 20, 613648) 1 According to The Bombay Chronicle, 7 9 1944, Kanaiyalal Desai, President, Surat District Congress Committee, and President, Gujarat Central Congress Workers’ Committee, had “three hours’ discussion with Gandhiji on the present political situation and relief work in Gujarat.
('84', 351, 11, 21, 613925) Gandhiji had also made it clear that Congressmen in no circumstances should resort to mass civil disobedience.”
