('84', 353, 1, 2, 615183) 478. SPEECH AT A. I. S. A. MEETING—III
('84', 353, 2, 3, 615222) SEVAGRAM, September 3, 1944 Today, I will try to explain my thoughts to you more clearly and present them to you in a different frame from what I have said during the last two days.
('84', 353, 2, 4, 615404) Our work had a very humble beginning.
('84', 353, 2, 5, 615442) When I started khadi I had with me, apart from Maganlalbhai 1 and others who had elected to live and die with me, Vithaldasbhai 2 and a few sisters.
('84', 353, 2, 6, 615591) Vithaldas was, at that time, fighting for the labourers, but [at my call] he gave up his shop and joined me in this unremunerative work.
('84', 353, 2, 7, 615728) We had then not the faintest idea as to what the future had in store for us.
('84', 353, 2, 8, 615805) We have travelled a long way since then and today about two crores of people have come under the influence of the charkha.
('84', 353, 2, 9, 615928) So far, we have maintained that the charkha has the power to bring us freedom.
('84', 353, 2, 10, 616007) With its help we have been able to provide the village people with a large amount of money.
('84', 353, 2, 11, 616099) But can we still hold, as we have always maintained, that swaraj is impossible without the charkha?
('84', 353, 2, 12, 616199) So long as we do not substantiate this claim the charkha is really no more than a measure of relief, to which we turn because we can do nothing else about it.
('84', 353, 2, 13, 616358) It would not then be the means of our salvation.
('84', 353, 2, 14, 616407) Secondly, we have failed to carry our message to the crores of our people.
('84', 353, 2, 15, 616482) They have neither any knowledge of what the charkha can do for them nor even the necessary curiosity for it.
('84', 353, 2, 16, 616591) The Congress did accept the charkha.
('84', 353, 2, 17, 616628) But did it do so willingly?
('84', 353, 2, 18, 616656) No, it tolerates the charkha simply for my sake.
('84', 353, 2, 19, 616705) The Socialists ridicule it outright.
('84', 353, 2, 20, 616742) They have spoken and written much against it.
('84', 353, 2, 21, 616788) We have no clear or convincing reply to offer to them.
('84', 353, 2, 22, 616843) How I wish I could convince them that the charkha is the key to swaraj!
('84', 353, 2, 23, 616915) I have not been able to justify the claim all these years.
('84', 353, 2, 24, 616974) Now for my third point: non violence is not something of the other world.
('84', 353, 2, 25, 617048) If it is, I have no use for it.
('84', 353, 2, 26, 617080) I am of the earth and if non violence is something really worth while I want to realize it here on this earth while I am still alive.
('84', 353, 2, 27, 617214) The non violence I want is one which the masses can follow in practice.
('84', 353, 2, 28, 617286) And how else can it be
('84', 353, 3, 29, 617309) 1 Maganlal Gandhi 2 Vithaldas Jerajani
('84', 354, 0, 1, 617348) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 355
('84', 354, 1, 2, 617395) realized except in a society which has compassion and other similar virtues as its characteristics?
('84', 354, 1, 3, 617495) If you go to the house of one who has use for violence you will find his drawing room decorated with tigers’ skins, deers’ horns, swords, guns and such like.
('84', 354, 1, 4, 617653) I have been to the Viceregal Lodge, I also saw Mussolini.
('84', 354, 1, 5, 617711) In the houses of both I found arms hanging on the walls.
('84', 354, 1, 6, 617768) I was given a salute with arms, a symbol of violence.
('84', 354, 1, 7, 617822) Just as arms symbolize violence the charkha symbolizes non violence, in the sense that we can most directly realize non violence through it.
('84', 354, 1, 8, 617963) But it cannot symbolize non violence so long as we do not work in accordance with its spirit.
('84', 354, 1, 9, 618057) The sword in Mussolini’s hall seemed to say ‘Touch me and I will cut you.’ It gave a vivid picture of violence.
('84', 354, 1, 10, 618169) It seemed to ask you to touch it and realize its power.
('84', 354, 1, 11, 618225) So also we must illustrate the power of the charkha so that a mere look at it may speak to us about non violence.
('84', 354, 1, 12, 618339) .But we are bankrupt today.
('84', 354, 1, 13, 618367) What is our answer to the Socialists?
('84', 354, 1, 14, 618405) They complain that we have been harping on the charkha for years and yet we have achieved nothing.
('84', 354, 1, 15, 618504) The charkha was there during Muslim rule also.
('84', 354, 1, 16, 618551) Dacca was famous for its muslin.
('84', 354, 1, 17, 618584) The charkha then was a symbol of poverty and not of non violence.
('84', 354, 1, 18, 618650) The kings took forced labour from women and depressed classes.
('84', 354, 1, 19, 618713) The same was later repeated by the East India Company.
('84', 354, 1, 20, 618768) Kautilya 1 mentions in his Arthashastra the existence of such forced labour.
('84', 354, 1, 21, 618845) For ages the charkha was thus a symbol of violence and the use of force and compulsion.
('84', 354, 1, 22, 618933) The spinner got but a handful of grain or two small coins, while ladies of the court went about luxuriously clad in the finest of muslins, the product of exploited labour.
('84', 354, 1, 23, 619105) As against this, I have presented the charkha to you as a symbol of non violence.
('84', 354, 1, 24, 619187) If I did not make it clear to you so far, it was my mistake.
('84', 354, 1, 25, 619248) You know I am among the maimed and can move but slowly.
('84', 354, 1, 26, 619304) Yet I do believe that the work done so far has not been a waste.
('84', 354, 1, 27, 619369) I shall now pass to my fourth point.
('84', 354, 1, 28, 619406) We have not yet proved that there can be no swaraj without the charkha.
('84', 354, 1, 29, 619478) It cannot be proved so long as you do not explain it to Congressmen.
('84', 354, 1, 30, 619547) The charkha and the Congress should become synonyms.
('84', 354, 1, 31, 619600) The task of proving the superiority of non violence is a difficult one.
('84', 354, 1, 32, 619672) We have to fathom its depths if we are to realize its truth.
('84', 354, 2, 33, 619733) 1 Chanakya, the celebrated writer on statecraft
('84', 355, 0, 1, 619781) 356 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 355, 1, 2, 619823) always supported all that I have said so far.
('84', 355, 1, 3, 619869) The world is going to put me to the test.
('84', 355, 1, 4, 619911) It may declare me a fool for my tall talk about the charkha.
('84', 355, 1, 5, 619972) The task of making the charkha, which for centuries had been a symbol of poverty, helplessness, injustice and forced labour, the symbol now of mighty non violent strength, of the new social order and of the new economy, has fallen on our shoulders.

('84', 355, 1, 30, 621632) Ours is not a self sufficiency of that pattern.

('84', 365, 6, 8, 636280) 496. A CIRCULAR LETTER
('84', 365, 7, 9, 636303) SEVAGRAM, September 8, 1944
('84', 365, 8, 10, 636331) BHAI, Day before yesterday, that is, on the night of the 6th, Shri Deshpandeji told me that Jajuji is not fit for the post of Secretary as he does not have administrative, that is, management talent although he is a saintly man.
('84', 365, 8, 11, 636560) He can hold the highest position in a society of saints.
('84', 365, 8, 12, 636617) In support of his opinion he told me that the Provincial Secretaries or Agents of the A.I.S.A., who have returned from here, have all gone back disappointed and helpless.
('84', 365, 8, 13, 636788) Therefore, hefears that the A.I.S.A. is going to die under its own weight.
('84', 365, 8, 14, 636863) If this is true, as head of the A.I.S.A., I have to give it a second thought because my experience is completely contrary to Deshpandeji’s opinion.
('84', 365, 8, 15, 637011) My experience tells me that true saintliness implies efficiency, and Jajuji is a living embodiment of this truth.
('84', 365, 8, 16, 637125) I have, therefore, decided to have Jajuji’s administrative talents verified.
('84', 365, 8, 17, 637202) I have already talked to Jajuji and he also agrees to this.
('84', 365, 8, 18, 637262) If you have accepted Jajuji as Secretary out of despair and only to please me, you have not been truly faithful to the A.I.S.A. and if Deshpande’s prophecy comes true and the A.I.S.A. comes to nought, in my opinion, it will not be on account of Jajuji but due to your own weakness.
('84', 365, 8, 19, 637544) How can any secretary, however able, attain success without the whole hearted co operation of his subordinates?
('84', 365, 8, 20, 637656) The A.I.S.A. has no power to compel any one.
('84', 365, 8, 21, 637701) Its strength lies in the whole hearted co operation among all its office 
('84', 365, 9, 22, 637775) 1Vide the preceding item.
('84', 366, 0, 1, 637801) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 367
('84', 366, 1, 2, 637848) bearers, i.e., their mutual love and fellow feeling.
('84', 366, 1, 3, 637901) If this is lacking nothing avails.
('84', 366, 1, 4, 637936) Please, therefore, let me have your true opinion whether Jajuji is unfit for the secretaryship, whether he lacks administrative talents, whether you have reluctantly accepted his candidature.
('84', 366, 1, 5, 638128) If your answer is in support of Deshpandeji’s statement, please write to me substantiating your objections with concrete instances so that I can decide the course of my duty.
('84', 366, 1, 6, 638303) Kindly send an early reply.

('84', 368, 1, 2, 640095) 501. TALK WITH M. A. JINNAH 1
('84', 368, 2, 3, 640125) BOMBAY, September 9, 1944 It was a test of my patience.
('84', 368, 2, 4, 640181) I am amazed at my own patience.
('84', 368, 2, 5, 640213) However, it was a friendly talk.
('84', 368, 2, 6, 640246) His (Jinnah’s) contempt for your Formula (Rajaji Formula) and his eontempt for you is staggering.
('84', 368, 2, 7, 640344) You rose in my estimation that you could have talked to him for all those hours and that you should have taken the trouble to draw up that formula.
('84', 368, 2, 8, 640492) He says you have accepted his demand and so should I. I said, “I endorse Rajaji’s Formula and you can call it Pakistan if you like.” He talked of the Lahore Resolution 2. I said, “I have not studied it and I do not want to talk about it.
('84', 368, 2, 9, 640730) Let us talk about Rajaji’s Formula and you can point out any flaws that you find there.” In the middle of the talk he came back to the old ghost: “I thought you had come here as a Hindu, as a representative of the Hindu Congress.” I said, “No, I have come here neither as a Hindu nor as a representative of the Congress.
('84', 368, 2, 10, 641051) I have come here as an individual.
('84', 368, 2, 11, 641086) You can talk to me as an individual or as the President of the League, whichever way you prefer.
('84', 368, 2, 12, 641183) If you had agreed with Rajaji and accepted his Formula, you and he would have gone before your respective organizations and pleaded with them to accept it.
('84', 368, 2, 13, 641339) That is why Rajaji came to you.
('84', 368, 2, 14, 641371) You would then have placed it before other parties, too, in the same way.
('84', 368, 2, 15, 641445) Now you and I have to do it.” He said he was the President of the League.
('84', 368, 2, 16, 641519) Where was the basis for a talk if I was there representing nobody except myself?
('84', 368, 2, 17, 641600) Who was to deliver the goods?
('84', 368, 2, 18, 641630) I was the same man as he had found me in 1939. There was no change in me.
('84', 368, 2, 19, 641704) I almost felt like saying, “Yes, I am the same man and since you think it is no use talking to me, I will go away.” But I resisted the temptation.
('84', 368, 2, 20, 641851) I told him, “Is it not worth your while to convert an individual?
('84', 368, 2, 21, 641917) I am the same man no doubt.
('84', 368, 2, 22, 641945) You can change my views if you can and I will support you whole heartedly.” “Yes, I
('84', 368, 3, 23, 642029) 1 The meeting lasted three and a quarter hours.
('84', 368, 3, 24, 642077) Gandhiji reported the talk to C. Rajagopalachari.
('84', 368, 3, 25, 642127) 2 Of March 23, 1940; vide Appendix “Resolution Passed by All India Muslim League”, 23 3 1940.

('84', 369, 2, 4, 642399) He would go to jail, he would even face bullets.
('84', 369, 2, 5, 642448) I said, “I will stand by your side to face them.” “You may not,” he said.
('84', 369, 2, 6, 642522) “Try me,” I replied.

('84', 369, 2, 8, 642572) He wants Pakistan now, not after independence.
('84', 369, 2, 9, 642619) “We will have independence for Pakistan and Hindustan,” he said.
('84', 369, 2, 10, 642684) “We should come to an agreement and then go to the Government and ask them to accept it, force them to accept our solution.” I said I could never be a party to that.
('84', 369, 2, 11, 642850) I could never ask the Britishers to impose partition on India.
('84', 369, 2, 12, 642913) “If you all want to separate, I can’t stop you.
('84', 369, 2, 13, 642961) I have not got the power to compel you and I would not use it if I had.” He said, “The Muslims want Pakistan.
('84', 369, 2, 14, 643071) The League represents the Muslims and it wants separation.” I said, “I agree the League is the most powerful Muslim organization.
('84', 369, 2, 15, 643201) I might even concede that you as its President represent the Muslims of India, but that does not mean that all Muslims want Pakistan.
('84', 369, 2, 16, 643335) Put it to the vote of all the inhabitants of the area and see.” He said, “Why should you ask non Muslims?” I said, “You cannot possibly deprive a section of the population of its vote.
('84', 369, 2, 17, 643520) You must carry them with you, and if you are in the majority why should you be afraid?” I told him of what Kiron Shankar Roy had said to me “If the worst comes to the worst, we in Bengal will all go in Pakistan, but for goodness sake do not partition Bengal.
('84', 369, 2, 18, 643779) Do not vivisect it.” “If you are in majority,” I said, “you will have your choice.
('84', 369, 2, 19, 643862) I know it is a bad thing for you, but if you want it all the same you will have it.
('84', 369, 2, 20, 643946) But that will be an adjustment between you and me.
('84', 369, 2, 21, 643997) It cannot occur while the Britishers are here.” He began to cross examine me on the various clauses of the Formula.
('84', 369, 2, 22, 644113) I said to him, “If you want clarification of those things, is it not better to have it from the author of the Formula?” “Oh, no”, he did not want that.
('84', 369, 2, 23, 644265) I said, “What is the use of your cross examining me?” He recollected himself.
('84', 369, 2, 24, 644343) “Oh, no.
('84', 369, 2, 25, 644352) I am not cross examining you”, and then added: “I have been a lawyer all my life and my

('84', 372, 7, 9, 647810) 506. LETTER TO M. A. JINNAH
('84', 372, 8, 10, 647838) September 11, 1944
('84', 372, 9, 11, 647857) DEAR QUAID E AZAM, I received your letter 2 yesterday at 3.30 p.m.
('84', 372, 9, 12, 647924) I was in the midst of appointments.
('84', 372, 9, 13, 647960) I hasten to reply at the earliest opportunity.
('84', 372, 9, 14, 648007) I have said in my letter to you, it is implied in the Rajaji Formula and I have stated publicly that I have approached you as an individual.
('84', 372, 9, 15, 648148) My life mission has been Hindu Muslim unity, which I want for its own sake, but which is not to be achieved without the foreign ruling power being ousted.
('84', 372, 9, 16, 648303) Hence the first condition of the exercise of the right of self determination is achieving independence by the joint action of all the parties and groups composing India.
('84', 372, 9, 17, 648473) If such joint action is unfortunately impossible, then too.
('84', 372, 9, 18, 648533) I must fight with the assistance of such elements as can be brought together.
('84', 372, 9, 19, 648611) I am glad, therefore, that you did not break off our talks when I refused to assume or accept a representative capacity.
('84', 372, 9, 20, 648732) Of course I am pledged to use all the influence I may have with the Congress to ratify my agreement with you.
('84', 372, 9, 21, 648842) May I remind you that the Rajaji Formula was designed in the first instance for your acceptance, and submission thereafter to the League?
('84', 372, 9, 22, 648980) It is true that I said an ocean separated you and me in outlook.
('84', 372, 10, 23, 649045) 1 Vide also telegram and letters to the addressee, “Telegram to Narandas Gandhi”, 5 9 1944; “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 6 9 1944 and 10/12 9 1944. 2 Dated September 10; vide Appendix “Letter from M. A. Jinnah”, 10 9 1944.
('84', 373, 0, 1, 649268) 374 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 373, 1, 2, 649310) But that had no reference to the Lahore Resolution of the League.
('84', 373, 1, 3, 649376) The Lahore Resolution is indefinite.
('84', 373, 1, 4, 649413) Rajaji has taken from it the substance and given it a shape.
('84', 373, 1, 5, 649474) Now for the points raised by you: 1. I have already answered this in the foregoing.
('84', 373, 1, 6, 649558) 2. The constitution will be framed by the Provisional Government contemplated in the Formula or an authority specially set up by it after the British power is withdrawn.
('84', 373, 1, 7, 649728) The independence contemplated is of the whole of India as it stands.
('84', 373, 1, 8, 649797) The basis for the formation of Provisional Interim Government will have to be agreed to between the League and the Congress.
('84', 373, 1, 9, 649922) 3. The Commission will be appointed by the Provisional Government.
('84', 373, 1, 10, 649989) “Absolute majority” means a clear majority over non Muslim elements as in Sind, Baluchistan or the Frontier Province.
('84', 373, 1, 11, 650107) The form of plebiscite and the franchise must be a matter for discussion.
('84', 373, 1, 12, 650181) 4. “All parties” means, the parties interested.
('84', 373, 1, 13, 650229) 5. “Mutual agreement” means agreement between contracting parties.
('84', 373, 1, 14, 650296) “Safeguarding defence, etc.,” means for me a central or joint board of control.
('84', 373, 1, 15, 650376) Safeguarding means safeguarding against all who may put the common interests in jeopardy.
('84', 373, 1, 16, 650466) 6. The power is to be transferred to the nation, that is, to the Provisional Government.
('84', 373, 1, 17, 650555) The Formula contemplates peaceful transfer by the British Government.
('84', 373, 1, 18, 650625) So far as I am concerned I would like the transfer to take place as early as possible.

('84', 376, 4, 9, 656080) 509. TALK WITH M. A. JINNAH 1
('84', 376, 5, 10, 656110) September 12, 1944
('84', 376, 6, 11, 656129) GANDHIJI: He drew a very alluring picture of the Government of Pakistan.
('84', 376, 6, 12, 656202) It would be a perfect democracy.
('84', 376, 6, 13, 656235) I asked him if he had not told me that democracy did not suit Indian conditions.
('84', 376, 6, 14, 656316) He did not remember it.
('84', 376, 6, 15, 656340) He asked me to tell him what he had said.
('84', 376, 6, 16, 656382) So I told him all that and said that I might have misunderstood him.
('84', 376, 6, 17, 656451) In that case he should correct me.
('84', 376, 6, 18, 656486) But when I repeated in detail what he had said, he could not say no.
('84', 376, 6, 19, 656555) He said, yes, he had said that, but that was with regard to imposed democracy.
('84', 376, 6, 20, 656634) Then he said, “Do you think it is a question of religious minority with us?” I said, “Yes.” If not, he should tell me what it was.
('84', 376, 6, 21, 656765) He harangued.
('84', 376, 6, 22, 656779) I won’t repeat all that here.
('84', 376, 6, 23, 656809) I asked him what would happen to the other minorities in Pakistan: Sikhs, Christians, Depressed Classes, etc.
('84', 376, 6, 24, 656919) He said they would be part of Pakistan.
('84', 376, 6, 25, 656959) I asked him if he meant joint electorates.
('84', 376, 6, 26, 657002) He knew I was coming to it.
('84', 376, 6, 27, 657030) He said, yes, he would like them to be a part of the whole.
('84', 376, 6, 28, 657090) He would explain the advantages of joint electorates, but if they wanted separate electorates they would have it.
('84', 376, 6, 29, 657204) Sikhs would have Gurumukhi if they wanted and the Pakistan Government would give them financial aid.
('84', 376, 6, 30, 657305) I asked, “What about Jats?” At first he pooh poohed the idea.
('84', 376, 6, 31, 657367) Then he said, “If they want it, they will also have it.
('84', 376, 6, 32, 657423) They will have separate existence if they want it.” I said, “What about Christians?
('84', 376, 6, 33, 657507) They also want some place where they are in a majority and where they can rule, as for instance in Travancore?” He said that was a problem for the Hindus.
('84', 376, 6, 34, 657662) I said supposing Travancore was in Pakistan?
('84', 376, 6, 35, 657707) He said he would give it to them.
('84', 376, 6, 36, 657741) He cited the instance of Newfoundland.
('84', 376, 6, 37, 657780) The rest of the talk was nothing.
('84', 376, 6, 38, 657814) I am to continue exploring his mind.

('84', 378, 2, 3, 659488) September 13, 1944
('84', 378, 3, 4, 659507) After the morning session of the talks, as Jinnah and Gandhiji emerged .
('84', 378, 3, 5, 659580) the waiting group of reporters asked the usual question: “Anything for us?” The leaders halted and .
('84', 378, 3, 6, 659681) Gandhiji spoke: I have nothing, but I will go for you.
('84', 378, 3, 7, 659736) Yesterday you read something in our faces.
('84', 378, 3, 8, 659779) Here are we both.
('84', 378, 3, 9, 659797) I would like you not to read anything in our faces except hope and nothing but hope.
('84', 378, 4, 10, 659882) At this stage Gandhiji turned to Mr. Jinnah and asked: Am I right?

('84', 378, 5, 13, 660023) They have written so much terrible.

('84', 378, 7, 19, 660447) 514. LETTER TO M. A. JINNAH
('84', 378, 8, 20, 660475) September 14, 1944
('84', 378, 9, 21, 660494) DEAR QUAID E AZAM, I have your letter of the 13th instant.
('84', 378, 9, 22, 660553) 1 I understood from our talks that you were in no hurry for my answer I was, therefore, taking the matter in a leisurely fashion, even hoping that as our talks proceeded and as cordiality increased, mutual clarification would come of itself and that we would only have to record our final agreement.
('84', 378, 9, 23, 660853) But I understand and appreciate the other viewpoint.
('84', 378, 9, 24, 660906) We should take nothing for granted.
('84', 378, 9, 25, 660942) I should clarify your difficulties in understanding the Rajaji Formula and you should do likewise regarding yours, i.e., the Muslim League Lahore Resolution of 1940.
('84', 378, 10, 26, 661108) 1 In his letter the addressee had complained that he had not received Gandhiji’s reply to his letter of September 11.
('84', 379, 0, 1, 661226) 380 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 379, 1, 2, 661268) With reference to the Lahore Resolution, as agreed between us I shall deal with it in a separate letter.
('84', 379, 1, 3, 661373) Perhaps at the end of our discussion, we shall discover that Rajaji not only has not put the Lahore Resolution out of shape and mutilated it but has given it substance and form.
('84', 379, 1, 4, 661551) Indeed, in view of your dislike of the Rajaji Formula, I have, at any rate for the moment, put it out of my mind and I am concentrating on the Lahore Resolution in the hope of finding a ground for mutual agreement.
('84', 379, 1, 5, 661766) So much for the first paragraph of your letter.
('84', 379, 1, 6, 661814) As to the second, I do hold that unless we oust the third party we shall not be able to live at peace with one another.
('84', 379, 1, 7, 661934) That does not mean that I may not make an effort to find ways and means of establishing a living peace between us.
('84', 379, 1, 8, 662049) You ask for my conception of the basis for a provisional interim government.
('84', 379, 1, 9, 662126) I would have told you if I had any scheme in mind.
('84', 379, 1, 10, 662177) I imagine that if we two can agree it would be for us to consult the other parties.
('84', 379, 1, 11, 662261) I can say this, that any provisional government to inspire confidence at the present moment must represent all parties.
('84', 379, 1, 12, 662381) When that moment arrives, I shall have been replaced by some authoritative person, though you will have me always at your beck and call when you have converted me or I you, or by mutual conversion we have become one mind functioning through two bodies.
('84', 379, 1, 13, 662634) As to the third point, the provisional government, being the appointing authority, will give effect to the findings of the Commission.
('84', 379, 1, 14, 662769) This I thought was implied in my previous answer.
('84', 379, 1, 15, 662819) Rajaji tells me that ‘absolute majority’ is used in his Formula in the same sense as it is used in ordinary legal parlance wherever more than two groups are dealt with.
('84', 379, 1, 16, 662988) I cling to my own answer.
('84', 379, 1, 17, 663014) But you will perhaps suggest a third meaning and persuade me to accept it.
('84', 379, 1, 18, 663089) The form of the plebiscite and franchise must be left to be decided by the provisional interim government unless we decide it now.
('84', 379, 1, 19, 663220) I should say it should be by adult suffrage of all the inhabitants of the Pakistan area.
('84', 379, 1, 20, 663309) As to the fourth, ‘all parties’ means you and I and everyone else holding views on the question at issue will and should seek by peaceful persuasion to influence public opinion as is done where democracy functions wholly or in part.
('84', 380, 0, 1, 663542) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 381
('84', 380, 1, 2, 663589) As to the fifth, supposing that the result of the plebiscite is in favour of partition, the provisional government will draft the treaty and agreements as regards the administration of matters of common interest, but the same has to be confirmed and ratified by the governments of the two States.
('84', 380, 1, 3, 663886) The machinery required for the settlement and administration of matters of common interest will, in the first instance, be planned by the interim government, but subsequ ently will be matter for settlement between the two governments acting through the agencies appointed by each for that purpose.
('84', 380, 1, 4, 664184) As to the sixth, I hope the foregoing makes superfluous any further reply.
('84', 380, 2, 5, 664259) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI The Hindu, 29 9 1944
('84', 380, 3, 6, 664310) 515. LETTER TO M. A. JINNAH
('84', 380, 4, 7, 664338) September 15, 1944
('84', 380, 5, 8, 664357) DEAR QUAID E AZAM, This is in terms of our talks of Wednesday the 13th instant.
('84', 380, 5, 9, 664437) For the moment I have shunted the Rajaji Formula and with your assistance am applying my mind very seriously to the famous Lahore Resolution of the Muslim League.
('84', 380, 5, 10, 664600) You must admit that the Resolution itself makes no reference to the two nations theory.
('84', 380, 5, 11, 664688) In the course of our discussions, you have passionately pleaded that India contains two nations, i.e., Hindus and Muslims, and that the latter have their homelands in India as the former have theirs.
('84', 380, 5, 12, 664888) The more our argument progresses, the more alarming your picture appears to me.
('84', 380, 5, 13, 664968) It would be alluring if it was true.
('84', 380, 5, 14, 665005) But my fear is growing that it is wholly unreal.
('84', 380, 5, 15, 665054) I find no parallel in history for a body of converts and their descendants claiming to be a nation apart from the parent stock.
('84', 380, 5, 16, 665182) If India was one nation before the advent of Islam, it must remain one in spite of the change of faith of a very large body of her children.
('84', 380, 5, 17, 665323) You do not claim to be a separate nation by right of conquest, but by reason of acceptance of Islam.
('84', 380, 5, 18, 665424) Will the two nations become
('84', 380, 6, 19, 665452) 1 For the addressee’s reply, vide Appendix “Letter from M. A. Jinnah”, 14 9 1944.
('84', 381, 0, 1, 665534) 382 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 381, 1, 2, 665576) one if the whole of India accepted Islam?
('84', 381, 1, 3, 665618) Will Bengalis, Oriyas, Andhras, Tamilians, Maharashtrians, Gujaratis, etc., cease to have their special characteristics if all of them become converts to Islam?
('84', 381, 1, 4, 665779) These have all become one politically because they are subject to oneforeign control.
('84', 381, 1, 5, 665865) They are trying today to throw off that subjection.
('84', 381, 1, 6, 665917) You seem to have introduced a new test of nationhood.
('84', 381, 1, 7, 665971) If I accept it, I would have to subscribe to many more claims and face an insoluble problem.
('84', 381, 1, 8, 666064) The only real, though awful, test of our nationhood arises out of our common political subjection.
('84', 381, 1, 9, 666163) If you and I throw off this subjection by our combined effort, we shall be born a politically free nation out of our travail.
('84', 381, 1, 10, 666289) If by then we have not learnt to prize our freedom, we may quarrel among ourselves and, for want of a common master holding us together in his iron grip, seek to split up into small groups or nationalities.
('84', 381, 1, 11, 666496) There will be nothing to prevent us from descending to that level and we shall not have to go in search of a master.
('84', 381, 1, 12, 666613) There are many claimants to the throne that never remains vacant.
('84', 381, 1, 13, 666679) With this background, I shall present you with my difficulty in accepting your Resolution.
('84', 381, 1, 14, 666770) I. Pakistan is not in the Resolution.
('84', 381, 1, 15, 666808) Does it bear the original meaning Punjab, Afghanistan, Kashmir, Sind and Baluchistan, out of which the name was mnemonically formed?
('84', 381, 1, 16, 666941) If not what is it?
('84', 381, 1, 17, 666960) 2. Is the goal of Pakistan pan Islam?
('84', 381, 1, 18, 666998) 3. What is it that distinguishes an Indian Muslim from every other Indian, if not his religion?
('84', 381, 1, 19, 667094) Is he different from a Turk or an Arab?
('84', 381, 1, 20, 667134) 4. What is the Connotation of the word “Muslims” in the Resolution under discussion?
('84', 381, 1, 21, 667219) Does it mean the Muslims of India of geography or of the Pakistan to be?
('84', 381, 1, 22, 667292) 5. Is the Resolution addressed to the Muslims by way of education, or to the inhabitants of the whole of India by way of appeal, or to the foreign ruler as an ultimatum?
('84', 381, 1, 23, 667462) 6. Are the constituents in the two zones to constitute “Independent States”, an undefined number in each zone?
('84', 381, 1, 24, 667573) 7. Is the demarcation to take place during the pendency of British Rule?
('84', 381, 1, 25, 667646) 8. If the answer to the last question is in the affirmative, the proposal must be accepted first by Britain and then imposed upon
('84', 382, 0, 1, 667776) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 383
('84', 382, 1, 2, 667823) India, not evolved from within by the free will of the people of India.
('84', 382, 1, 3, 667895) 9. Have you examined the position and satisfied yourself that these “Independent States” will be materially and otherwise benefited by being split up into fragments?
('84', 382, 1, 4, 668061) 10. Please satisfy me that these Independent Sovereign States will not become a collection of poor States, a menace to themselves and to the rest of India.
('84', 382, 1, 5, 668217) 11. Pray show me by facts and figures or otherwise how the independence and welfare of India as a whole can be brought about by the acceptance of the Resolution?
('84', 382, 1, 6, 668379) 12. How are the Muslims under the Princes to be disposed of as a result of this scheme?
('84', 382, 1, 7, 668467) 13. What is your definition of “minorities”?
('84', 382, 1, 8, 668512) 14. Will you please define the “adequate, effective and mandatory safeguards” for minorities referred to in the second part of the Resolution?
('84', 382, 1, 9, 668655) 15. Do you not see that the Lahore Resolution contains only a bare statement of the objective and does not give any idea as to the means to be adopted for the execution of the idea and the concrete corollaries thereof?
('84', 382, 1, 10, 668874) For instance: (a) Are the people in the regions falling under the plan to have any voice in the matter of separation and, if so, how is it to be ascertained?
('84', 382, 1, 11, 669032) (b) What is the provision for Defence and similar matters of common concern contemplated in the Lahore Resolution?
('84', 382, 1, 12, 669147) (c) There are many groups of Muslims who have continuously expressed dissent from the policy of the League.
('84', 382, 1, 13, 669255) While I am prepared to accept the preponderating influence and position of the League and have approached you for that very reason, is it not our joint duty to remove their doubts and carry them with us by making them feel that they and their supporters have not been practically disfranchised?
('84', 382, 1, 14, 669550) (d) Does this not lead again to placing the Resolution of the League before the people of the zones concerned as a whole for acceptance?
('84', 382, 1, 15, 669687) As I write this letter and imagine the working of the Resolution in practice, I see nothing but ruin for the whole of India.
('84', 382, 1, 16, 669812) Believe me, I approach you as a seeker.
('84', 382, 1, 17, 669852) Though I represent nobody but myself, I aspire to represent all the inhabitants of India, for I realize in my own person their misery and degradation, which is their common lot, irrespective of class, caste or creed.
('84', 382, 1, 18, 670069) I know that you have acquired a
('84', 383, 0, 1, 670101) 384 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 383, 1, 2, 670143) unique hold on the Muslim masses.
('84', 383, 1, 3, 670177) I want you to use your influence for their total welfare, which must include the rest.
('84', 383, 1, 4, 670264) In this hastily written letter, I have only given an inkling of my difficulty.
('84', 383, 2, 5, 670343) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI The Hindu, 29 9 1944
('84', 383, 3, 6, 670394) 516. LETTER TO M. A. JINNAH

('84', 383, 5, 8, 670441) DEAR QUAID E AZAM, I have yours of the 14th instant, 1 received at 9.40 a.m.
('84', 383, 5, 9, 670518) I woke up at 3 a.m.
('84', 383, 5, 10, 670538) today to finish my promised letter 2 on the Lahore Resolution.
('84', 383, 5, 11, 670601) There is no mistake about the date, for I wrote in answer to your reminder of the 13th instant.
('84', 383, 5, 12, 670697) Independence does mean as envisaged in the A.I.C.C. Resolution of 1942. But it cannot be on the basis of a united India.
('84', 383, 5, 13, 670818) If we come to a settlement, it would be on the basis of the settlement, assuming, of course, that it accrues general acceptance in the country.
('84', 383, 5, 14, 670962) The process will be somewhat like this.
('84', 383, 5, 15, 671002) We reach by joint effort independence for India as it stands.
('84', 383, 5, 16, 671064) India becoming free will proceed to demarcation, plebiscite and partition if the people concerned vote for partition.
('84', 383, 5, 17, 671182) All this is implied in the Rajaji Formula.
('84', 383, 5, 18, 671225) As to the provisional interim government, I am afraid I cannot carry my answer any further than I have done.
('84', 383, 5, 19, 671334) Though I have no scheme for the provisional government, if you have one in connection with the Lahore Resolution, which also, I presume, requires an interim government, we can discuss it.
('84', 383, 5, 20, 671522) The Formula was framed by Rajaji in good faith.
('84', 383, 5, 21, 671570) I accepted it in equal good faith.
('84', 383, 5, 22, 671605) The hope was that you would look at it with favour.
('84', 383, 5, 23, 671657) We still think it to be the best in the circumstances.
('84', 383, 5, 24, 671712) You and I have to put flesh on it, if we can.
('84', 383, 5, 25, 671758) I have explained the process we have to go through.
('84', 383, 5, 26, 671810) You have no objection to it.
('84', 383, 5, 27, 671839) Perhaps, you want to know how I would form the provisional government if I was invited thereto.
('84', 383, 6, 28, 671935) 1 Vide Appendix “Letter from M. A. Jinnah”, 14 9 1944. 2 Vide the preceding item.
('84', 384, 0, 1, 672017) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 385
('84', 384, 1, 2, 672064) was in that unenviable position, I would see all the claimants and endeavour to satisfy them.
('84', 384, 1, 3, 672158) My co operation will be available in that task.
('84', 384, 1, 4, 672206) I can give you full satisfaction about your inquiry, “What I would like to know would be, what will be the powers of such a provisional interim government, how it will be formed, to whom it will be responsible.” The provisional interim government will be responsible to the elected members of the present Assembly or a newly elected one.
('84', 384, 1, 5, 672544) It will have all the powers less that of the Commander in Chief’during the war and full powers thereafter.
('84', 384, 1, 6, 672651) It will be the authority to give effect to the agreement that may be arrived at between the League and the Congress and ratified by the other parties.
('84', 384, 1, 7, 672802) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI The Hindu, 29 9 1944

('84', 387, 6, 9, 677268) 523. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('84', 387, 7, 10, 677298) September 16, 1944
('84', 387, 8, 11, 677317) Gandhiji said that at prayer time there was usually great rush.
('84', 387, 8, 12, 677381) People came to him to give money for the Harijan Fund and to take autographs.
('84', 387, 8, 13, 677459) Due to this, children and weak persons experienced considerable difficulty every day.
('84', 387, 8, 14, 677545) Gandhiji, therefore, said that only those who wanted autographs or who wanted to give him money should stay behind while the rest should leave the prayer ground immediately the prayers were over.
('84', 387, 9, 15, 677741) Secondly he said that the moment he started moving, everybody rushed after him.
('84', 387, 9, 16, 677821) This caused trouble.
('84', 387, 9, 17, 677842) Women and children were put to inconvenience.
('84', 387, 9, 18, 677888) At Juhu there was a lot of space.
('84', 387, 9, 19, 677922) Though there was not as much space here, there was enough.
('84', 387, 9, 20, 677981) There was no need to crowd.
('84', 387, 9, 21, 678009) If nobody crowded and followed him, people would be able to go away from the prayer ground soon.
('84', 387, 9, 22, 678106) They would be happy and he would be comfortable.
('84', 387, 9, 23, 678155) He would also be able to collect money and give autographs at leisure.
('84', 387, 10, 24, 678226) Thirdly Gandhiji said that the prayers began with a Buddhist invocation followed by two minutes’ silence.
('84', 387, 10, 25, 678332) The silence was an integral part of the prayer.
('84', 387, 10, 26, 678380) He found people talking during the silence.
('84', 387, 10, 27, 678424) When silence was a part of prayer they should close their eyes and contemplate.
('84', 387, 10, 28, 678504) Nobody should talk.
('84', 387, 10, 29, 678524) This was the proper behaviour and correct discipline.
('84', 387, 10, 30, 678578) Everyone should observe this discipline.
('84', 387, 10, 31, 678619) The Bombay Chronicle, 17 9 1944
('84', 388, 0, 1, 678651) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 389

('84', 393, 6, 11, 686765) 2 God only knows what the result will be.
('84', 393, 6, 12, 686807) I had your wires.

('84', 393, 6, 16, 686984) Though I know he wants me to fix up the Phﬁnix Trust, he never mentions it.
('84', 393, 6, 17, 687060) But I have it constantly in mind.
('84', 393, 6, 18, 687094) Sita 4 is in Sevagram.

('84', 395, 1, 2, 689325) 536. LETTER TO SUSHILA GANDHI
('84', 395, 2, 3, 689355) September 18, 1944
('84', 395, 3, 4, 689374) SUSHILA, I got your two letters.
('84', 395, 3, 5, 689407) The country’s condition is exactly as you describe it to be.
('84', 395, 3, 6, 689468) But surely God’s hand must be behind this.
('84', 395, 3, 7, 689511) We shall have performed our dharma if we acquit ourselves creditably in our own field and shed lustre on it.
('84', 395, 3, 8, 689620) Manilal has devoted himself completely to my service, and is thus paying his filial debt.
('84', 395, 3, 9, 689710) Do not worry about him.
('84', 395, 3, 10, 689734) Sita 1 has taken her place in the Nayee Talim school at Sevagram.
('84', 395, 3, 11, 689800) Sumi 2 is with her, as also the daughter of a Bihari gentleman named Lakshmi Babu.
('84', 395, 3, 12, 689883) The fourth is Ashadevi’s own daughter.
('84', 395, 3, 13, 689922) There are thus four girls in all.
('84', 395, 3, 14, 689956) Ashadevi has become their mother.
('84', 395, 3, 15, 689990) She is a learned woman.
('84', 395, 3, 16, 690014) According to me this type of education is the best.
('84', 395, 3, 17, 690066) All these four girls learn with the other children at Sevagram, and also teach them a few things.
('84', 395, 3, 18, 690164) Do not get frightened at this news.
('84', 395, 3, 19, 690200) Sita herself voluntarily decided to join this school.
('84', 395, 3, 20, 690254) But of course it was I who was responsible for putting the idea in Manilal’s and Sita’s minds and luring them on.
('84', 395, 3, 21, 690368) I would have tried to lure you too, if you had been here.
('84', 395, 3, 22, 690426) God alone knows, of course, whether you would have yielded or not.
('84', 395, 3, 23, 690493) Now that you have learnt to drive a car, how can I keep pace with you?
('84', 395, 3, 24, 690564) By all means go ahead.
('84', 395, 3, 25, 690587) I have talks with Jinnah Saheb practically daily.
('84', 395, 3, 26, 690637) Before you get this letter you will have known the result.
('84', 395, 4, 27, 690696) Blessings from BAPU

('84', 397, 1, 2, 692292) 539. LETTER TO M. A. JINNAH
('84', 397, 2, 3, 692320) September 19, 1944
('84', 397, 3, 4, 692339) DEAR QUAID E AZAM, Many thanks for yours 1 of the 17th instant.
('84', 397, 3, 5, 692403) I am sorry to have to say that your answers omitting 1, 2 and 6 do not give satisfaction.
('84', 397, 3, 6, 692493) It may be that all my questions do not arise from the view of mere clarification of the Lahore Resolution.
('84', 397, 3, 7, 692600) But I contend that they are very relevant from the standpoint of a seeker that I am.
('84', 397, 3, 8, 692685) You cannot expect anyone to agree to or shoulder the burden of the claim contained in the Lahore Resolution without, for instance, answering my questions 15 (a) and 15 (b) 2 which you brush aside as not arising by way of clarification.
('84', 397, 3, 9, 692921) Dr. Ambedkar’s thesis, while it is ably written, has carried no conviction to me.
('84', 397, 3, 10, 693003) The other book mentioned by you, I am sorry to say, I have not seen.
('84', 397, 3, 11, 693072) Why can you not accept my statement that I aspire to represent all the sections that compose the people of India?
('84', 397, 3, 12, 693186) Do you not aspire?
('84', 397, 3, 13, 693205) Should not every Indian?
('84', 397, 3, 14, 693230) That the aspiration may never be realized is beside the point.
('84', 397, 3, 15, 693293) I am beholden to you, in spite of your opinion about me, for having patience with me.
('84', 397, 3, 16, 693379) I hope you will never lose it, but will persevere in your effort to convert me.
('84', 397, 3, 17, 693459) I ask you to take me with my strong views and even prejudices, if I am guilty of any.
('84', 397, 3, 18, 693545) As to your verdict on my policy and programme, we must agree to differ.
('84', 397, 3, 19, 693617) For, I am wholly unrepentant.
('84', 397, 3, 20, 693647) My purpose is as a lover of communal unity to place my services at your disposal.
('84', 397, 3, 21, 693729) I hope you do not expect me to accept the Lahore Resolution without understanding its implications.
('84', 397, 3, 22, 693829) If your letter is the final word, there is little hope.
('84', 397, 3, 23, 693885) Can we not agree to differ on the question of “two nation” and yet solve the problem on the basis of self determination?
('84', 397, 3, 24, 694006) It is this basis that has brought me to you.
('84', 397, 3, 25, 694051) If the regions holding Muslim majorities have to be separated according to the Lahore
('84', 397, 4, 26, 694137) 1 Vide Appendix “Letter from M. A. Jinnah”, 17 9 1944. 2 Vide “Letter to M. A. Jinnah”, 15 9 1944.
('84', 398, 0, 1, 694236) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 399
('84', 398, 1, 2, 694283) Resolution, the grave step of separation should be specifically placed before and approved by the people in that area.
('84', 398, 2, 3, 694402) Yours sincerely,
('84', 398, 3, 4, 694419) M. K. GANDHI The Hindu, 29 9 1944
('84', 398, 4, 5, 694453) 540. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('84', 398, 5, 6, 694483) BOMBAY, September 19, 1944
('84', 398, 6, 7, 694510) In the course of his speech at the prayer meeting, Gandhiji said that he did not know how many Muslim brothers and sisters were there in the audience but there was at least one, namely, Raihanabehn Tyabjee.
('84', 398, 6, 8, 694717) That was enough for his present purpose.
('84', 398, 6, 9, 694758) His earnest prayer to all present was that if they had the good of the country at heart and wanted India to be free and independent at the earliest moment they should establish the closest bonds of friendship between Hindus and Mussalmans and members of all other communities.
('84', 398, 6, 10, 695035) That was the least that every one of them was expected to do and could do.
('84', 398, 6, 11, 695110) Was there anyone among them who doubted that if they could become one at heart the coming of independence would be accelerated?
('84', 398, 6, 12, 695238) Ever since his return to India he had been proclaiming that truth from house tops.
('84', 398, 6, 13, 695321) That did not mean that they could afford to rest in idleness and freedom would by itself drop into their lap.
('84', 398, 6, 14, 695431) If that was realized many other things would follow as a matter of course.
('84', 398, 7, 15, 695506) Referring to his talks with Mr. Jinnah he said that he considered it to be their great good fortune that they—two brothers—were having their friendly talks.
('84', 398, 7, 16, 695663) He was not at liberty to divulge the nature of their talks.
('84', 398, 7, 17, 695723) But they could rest satisfied that they were not talking without hope.
('84', 398, 7, 18, 695794) The day he felt that there was no more hope, he would not hesitate to say so.
('84', 398, 7, 19, 695872) He wanted them all to fraternize with one another on the Id Day and pray that God may guide them aright.
('84', 398, 8, 20, 695977) Concluding, he warned the people against putting faith in speculations in which both the foreign and the Indian Press were indulging.
('84', 398, 9, 21, 696111) Sometimes they found all kinds of prophecies.
('84', 398, 9, 22, 696157) God was with them.
('84', 398, 9, 23, 696176) They were not being led by prophecies, but by the spirit of God.
('84', 398, 9, 24, 696241) The papers published all kinds of guesses and messages were also sent abroad.
('84', 398, 9, 25, 696319) It would not benefit the people to depend on these reports.
('84', 398, 9, 26, 696379) It would, in fact, be wrong to believe in them.
('84', 398, 9, 27, 696427) The Bombay Chronicle, 20 9 1944
('84', 398, 10, 28, 696459) 1 For the addressee’s reply, vide Appendix “Letter from M. A. Jinnah”, 21 9 1944

('84', 401, 1, 2, 699153) 545. A CIRCULAR LETTER
('84', 401, 2, 3, 699176) BOMBAY, September 21, 1944
('84', 401, 3, 4, 699203) BHAISHRI, I am writing this circular in Gujarati since all those to whom I intend to send it know the language.
('84', 401, 3, 5, 699315) I send with this a list of ten additional trustees.
('84', 401, 3, 6, 699367) At first I thought I would send the names merely for your information.
('84', 401, 3, 7, 699438) As my duty becomes clearer to me, I realize that I must function as Chairman without insisting on having my own way.
('84', 401, 3, 8, 699555) A list of members of the Executive Committee is also attached.
('84', 401, 3, 9, 699618) I have kept the following considerations in mind in drawing up both these lists.
('84', 401, 3, 10, 699699) We should include those who understand my method of work best and who have had some experience of village work or who share my point of view regarding village work.
('84', 401, 3, 11, 699864) I am painfully aware that I have not been able to include as many women as I should have liked to.
('84', 401, 3, 12, 699963) This Memorial Fund is in memory of an uneducated woman who had been touched by the ideal of service to villages, and it would, therefore, be but fitting that the Board consists wholly of women.
('84', 401, 3, 13, 700157) I would then feel that my efforts in this field have been fully rewarded.
('84', 401, 3, 14, 700231) But the time for this has not yet come.
('84', 401, 3, 15, 700271) Let us all hope that such mature and able women will get trained up for this work.
('84', 401, 3, 16, 700354) You may, without any hesitation whatever, reject any names in the list which you disapprove of.
('84', 401, 3, 17, 700450) If you wish, we may elect the additional members at a meeting of the trustees.
('84', 401, 3, 18, 700529) Kindly send me your opinion at an early date.
('84', 401, 3, 19, 700575) List of additional trustees: 1. Shri Mangaldas Pakvasa 2. Smt.
('84', 401, 3, 20, 700638) Ashadevi Aryanayakum 3. Smt.
('84', 401, 3, 21, 700667) Gosibehn Captain 4. Smt.

('84', 402, 10, 14, 701514) 547. LETTER TO M. A. JINNAH
('84', 402, 11, 15, 701542) September 22, 1944
('84', 402, 12, 16, 701561) DEAR QUAID E AZAM, Your letter of yesterday 2 (21st instant) so disturbed me that I thought I would postpone my reply till after we had met at the usual time.
('84', 402, 12, 17, 701720) Though I made no advance at our meeting, I think I see some what clearly what you are driving at.
('84', 402, 12, 18, 701818) The more I think about the
('84', 402, 13, 19, 701845) 1 The addressee had wished Gandhiji success in his efforts to achieve unity and freedom 2 Vide Appendix “Letter from M. A. Jinnah”, 21 9 1944.
('84', 403, 0, 1, 701988) 404 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 403, 1, 2, 702030) two nation theory the more alarming it appears to be.
('84', 403, 1, 3, 702084) The book recommended by you gives me no help.
('84', 403, 1, 4, 702130) It contains half truths and its conclusions or inferences are unwarranted.
('84', 403, 1, 5, 702205) I am unable to accept the proposition that the Muslims of India are a nation, distinct from the rest of the inhabitants of India.
('84', 403, 1, 6, 702335) Mere assertion is no proof.
('84', 403, 1, 7, 702363) The consequences of accepting such a proposition are dangerous in the extreme.
('84', 403, 1, 8, 702442) Once the principle is admitted there would be no limit to claims for cutting up India into numerous divisions, which would spell India’s ruin.
('84', 403, 1, 9, 702585) I have, therefore, suggested a way out.
('84', 403, 1, 10, 702625) Let it be a partition as between two brothers, if a division there must be.
('84', 403, 1, 11, 702701) You seem to be averse to a plebiscite.
('84', 403, 1, 12, 702740) In spite of the admitted importance of the League, there must be clear proof that the people affected desire partition.
('84', 403, 1, 13, 702860) In my opinion, all the people inhabiting the area ought to express their opinion specifically on this single issue of division.
('84', 403, 1, 14, 702988) Adult suffrage is the best method, but I would accept any other equivalent.
('84', 403, 1, 15, 703064) You summarily reject the idea of common interest between the two arms.
('84', 403, 1, 16, 703135) I can be no willing party to a division which does not provide for the simultaneous safeguarding of common interests, such as Defence, Foreign Affairs and the like.
('84', 403, 1, 17, 703300) There will be no feeling of security by the people of India without a recognition of the nutural and mutual obligations arising out of physical contiguity.
('84', 403, 1, 18, 703456) Your letter shows a wide divergence of opinion and outlook between us.
('84', 403, 1, 19, 703527) Thus you adhere to the opinion often expressed by you that the August 1942 Resolution is “inimical to the ideals and demands of Muslim India”.
('84', 403, 1, 20, 703670) There is no proof for this sweeping statement.
('84', 403, 1, 21, 703717) We seem to be moving in a circle.
('84', 403, 1, 22, 703751) I have made a suggestion.
('84', 403, 1, 23, 703777) If we are bent on agreeing, as I hope we are, let us call in a third party or parties to guide or even arbitrate between us 1.
('84', 403, 2, 24, 703904) Yours sincerely,
('84', 403, 3, 25, 703921) M. K. GANDHI The Hindu, 29 9 1944
('84', 403, 4, 26, 703955) 1 For the addressee’s reply, vide Appendix “Letter from M. A. Jinnah”, 23 9 1944.

('84', 406, 1, 2, 707180) 552. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('84', 406, 2, 3, 707208) BOMBAY, September 24, 1944 Whoever has given currency to the news about the Sevagram Ashram has not served the cause of truth.
('84', 406, 2, 4, 707335) The only truth about the news is that the disbandment and transformation of the Sevagram Ashram is under contemplation.
('84', 406, 2, 5, 707455) No decision has yet been taken.
('84', 406, 2, 6, 707487) But the suggestion that it has anything to do with my supposed dissatisfaction with the conduct of the Ashram during my incarceration is altogether untrue.
('84', 406, 2, 7, 707643) On the contrary I have expressed my unstinted admiration for the single minded devotion with which they carried on the Ashram under those difficult and anxious 21 months.
('84', 406, 2, 8, 707814) If it is ultimately decided to disband the Ashram it would be for the purpose of raising the activities of the members to a higher level than heretofore.
('84', 406, 3, 9, 707968) The Bombay Chronicle, 25 9 1944
('84', 406, 4, 10, 708000) 553. LETTER TO M. A. JINNAH 1
('84', 406, 5, 11, 708030) September 24, 1944
('84', 406, 6, 12, 708049) DEAR QUAID E AZAM, I have your two letters of September 23 2 in reply to my letters of the 22nd and 23rd.
('84', 406, 6, 13, 708155) With your assistance, I am exploring the possibilities of reaching an agreement, so that the claim embodied in the Muslim League Resolution of Lahore may be reasonably satisfied.
('84', 406, 6, 14, 708334) You must, therefore, have no apprehensions that the August Resolution will stand in the way of our reaching an agreement.
('84', 406, 6, 15, 708456) That Resolution dealt with the question of India as against Britain, and it cannot stand in the way of our settlement.
('84', 406, 6, 16, 708575) I proceed on the assumption that India is not to be regarded as two or more nations, but as one family consisting of many members
('84', 406, 7, 17, 708705) 1 Gandhiji’s draft is available under G.N. 2056. 2 Vide last footnote of “Letter to M. A. Jinnah”, 23 9 1944 and Appendix “Letter from M. A. Jinnah”, 23 9 1944.
('84', 407, 0, 1, 708866) 408 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 407, 1, 2, 708908) of whom the Muslims living in the north west zones, i.e., Baluchistan, Sind, North West Frontier Province and that part of the Punjab where they are in absolute majority over all the other elements and in parts of Bengal and Assam where they are in absolute majority, desire to live in separation from the rest of India.
('84', 407, 1, 3, 709229) Differing from you on the general basis, I can yet recommend to the Congress and the country the acceptance of the claim for separation contained in the Muslim League Resolution of Lahore, 1940, on my basis and on the following terms: The areas should be demarcated by a commission, approved by the Congress and the League.
('84', 407, 1, 4, 709553) The wishes of the inhabitants of the area demarcated should be ascertained through the votes of the adult population of the areas or through some equivalent method.
('84', 407, 1, 5, 709718) If the vote is in favour of separation, it shall be agreed that these areas shall form a separate State as soon as possible after India is free from foreign domination and can, therefore, be constituted into two sovereign independent States.
('84', 407, 1, 6, 709960) There shall be a treaty of separation, which should also provide for the efficient and satisfactory administration of Foreign Affairs, Defence, Internal Communications, Customs, Commerce and the like, which must necessarily continue to be matters of common interest between the contracting parties.
('84', 407, 1, 7, 710259) The treaty shall also contain terms for safeguarding the rights of minorities in the two States.
('84', 407, 1, 8, 710356) Immediately on the acceptance of this agreement by the Congress and the League, the two shall decide upon a common course of action for the attainment of the independence of India.
('84', 407, 1, 9, 710537) The League will, however, be free to remain out of any direct action, to which the Congress may resort and in which the League may not be willing to participate.
('84', 407, 1, 10, 710699) If you do not agree to these terms, could you let me know in precise terms what you would have me to accept in terms of the Lahore Resolution and bind myself to recommend to the Congress?
('84', 407, 1, 11, 710887) If you could kindly do this, I shall be able to see, apart from the difference in approach, what definite terms I can agree to.

('84', 411, 1, 2, 716773) 558. LETTER TO M. A. JINNAH
('84', 411, 2, 3, 716801) September 25, 1944
('84', 411, 3, 4, 716820) DEAR QUAID E AZAM, Yesterday’s talk leads me to inflict this letter on you, which I trust you will not mind.
('84', 411, 3, 5, 716929) Our conversations have come about as a result of your correspondence with Rajaji in July last over his Formula and your consultations with the League Working Committee thereon, and my own letter 1 to you suggesting a meeting between you and me.
('84', 411, 3, 6, 717174) My proposal of yesterday is an earnest effort to meet the essential requirements of the Lahore Resolution.
('84', 411, 3, 7, 717281) I would like you, therefore, to think fifty times before throwing away an offer which had been made entirely in the spirit of service in the cause of communal harmony.
('84', 411, 3, 8, 717449) Do not take, I pray, the responsibility of rejecting the offer.
('84', 411, 3, 9, 717513) Throw it on your Council.
('84', 411, 3, 10, 717539) Give me an opportunity of addressing them.
('84', 411, 3, 11, 717582) If they feel like rejecting it, I would like you to advise the Council to put it before the open session of the League.
('84', 411, 3, 12, 717702) If you will accept my advice and permit me, I would attend the open session and address it.
('84', 411, 3, 13, 717794) You are too technical when you dismiss my proposal for arbitration or outside guidance over points of difference.
('84', 411, 3, 14, 717908) If I have approached you as an individual, and not in any representative capacity, it is because we believe that if I reach an agreement with you, it will be of material use in the process of securing a Congress League settlement and acceptance of it by the country.
('84', 411, 3, 15, 718175) Is it irrelevant or inadmissible to supplement our efforts to convince each other without help, guidance, advice or even arbitration?
('84', 411, 4, 16, 718309) Yours sincerely,
('84', 411, 5, 17, 718326) M. K. GANDHI The Hindu 29 9 1944

('84', 412, 1, 2, 718450) 559. LETTER TO M. A. JINNAH
('84', 412, 2, 3, 718478) September 26, 1944
('84', 412, 3, 4, 718497) DEAR QUAID E AZAM, In view of my letter to you of yesterday, left to myself, I would have refrained from dealing with your letter 1 before our meeting today.
('84', 412, 3, 5, 718655) But I have deferred to Rajaji’s advice to finish the chain of correspondence.
('84', 412, 3, 6, 718733) I confess I am unable to understand your persistent refusal to appreciate the fact that the Formula presented to you by me in my letter of the 24th as well as the Formula presented to you by Rajaji give you virtually what is embodied in the Lahore Resolution, providing at the same time what is absolutely necessary to make the arrangement acceptable to the country.
('84', 412, 3, 7, 719100) You keep on saying that I should accept certain theses, while I have been contending that the best way for us, who differ in our approach to the problem, is to give body to the demand as it stands in the Resolution and work it out to our mutual satisfaction.
('84', 412, 3, 8, 719359) It is on this plan that I understand Rajaji’s Formula is to be conceived, and it is on the same plan that I have tried to work it out in the course of and as a result of our talks.
('84', 412, 3, 9, 719540) I contend that either gives you the substance of the Lahore Resolution.
('84', 412, 3, 10, 719612) Unfortunately, you reject both.
('84', 412, 3, 11, 719644) And I cannot accept the Lahore Resolution as you want me to, especially when you seek to introduce into its interpretation theories and claims which I cannot accept and which I cannot ever hope to induce India to accept.
('84', 412, 3, 12, 719865) Your constant references to my not being clothed with representative authority are really irrelevant.
('84', 412, 3, 13, 719967) I have approached you so that, if you and I can agree upon a common course of action, I may use what influence I possess for its acceptance by the Congress and the country.
('84', 412, 3, 14, 720140) If you break, it cannot be because I have no representative capacity, or because I have been unwilling to give you satisfaction in regard to the claim embodied in the Lahore Resolution.
('84', 412, 4, 15, 720326) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI The Hindu, 29 9 1944

('84', 418, 1, 2, 729214) 568. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS 1
('84', 418, 2, 3, 729244) September 28, 1944 It is a matter of deep regret that we two could not reach an agreement.
('84', 418, 2, 4, 729335) But there is no cause for disappointment.
('84', 418, 2, 5, 729377) The breakdown is only so called.
('84', 418, 2, 6, 729410) It is an adjournment sine die.
('84', 418, 2, 7, 729441) Each one of us must now talk to the public and put our viewpoints before them.
('84', 418, 2, 8, 729520) If we do so dispassionately and if the public cooperate, we may reach a solution of the seemingly insoluble at an early date.
('84', 418, 2, 9, 729646) My experience of the previous three weeks confirms me in the view that the presence of a third power hinders the solution.
('84', 418, 2, 10, 729769) A mind enslaved cannot act as if it was free.
('84', 418, 2, 11, 729815) I need not impute base motives to the rulers to prove what seems to me to be an axiomatic truth.
('84', 418, 2, 12, 729912) Nevertheless, I am going to continue to work for the solution as I have been during these three weeks.
('84', 418, 2, 13, 730015) The questions for consideration are simple.
('84', 418, 2, 14, 730059) Has the Rajaji Formula or mine made a reasonable approach to the Lahore Resolution?
('84', 418, 2, 15, 730143) If they or either of them is such an approach, all parties, and especially the members of the Muslim League, should ask the Quaid e Azam to revise his opinion.
('84', 418, 2, 16, 730303) If Rajaji and I have stultified the Lahore Resolution we should be educated.
('84', 418, 2, 17, 730380) The chief thing is for the Press and the public to avoid partisanship and bitterness.
('84', 418, 3, 18, 730466) To a question on his future plans, whether he proposed to concentrate on a Hindu Muslim settlement or take up political work, seeking imprisonment if necessary, Mahatma Gandhi replied: I shall act as my inner voice tells me.
('84', 418, 4, 19, 730691) Asked how far the offer he had made had conceded the demand made in the Lahore Resolution of the League, Mahatma Gandhi emphasized that the Rajaji Formula or the formula that he presented conceded the substance of the League demand.
('84', 418, 4, 20, 730924) He said: In my opinion, either formula gives as much as can reasonably be expected with due regard to the interests of the whole of India.
('84', 418, 5, 21, 731063) In answer to a question whether his offer was to be treated now as withdrawn, he said that so far as he was concerned the offer he had made stood.
('84', 418, 5, 22, 731210) It was not made in
('84', 418, 6, 23, 731229) 1 A Press conference of about 40 Indian and foreign journalists was held at Birla House; Sarojini Naidu, C. Rajagopalachari, Bhulabhai Desai, Nagindas Master, M. Y. Nurie, Dr. M. D. D. Gilder and S. K. Patil were among others present.

('84', 419, 1, 2, 731545) any bargaining spirit.
('84', 419, 1, 3, 731568) He said: I think it is a just solution of the problem and it is in the spirit of the policy which the Congress has consistently adopted in connection with the communal question, namely, self determination.
('84', 419, 2, 4, 731774) A number of questions were put on the representative character of the two leaders who conducted the negotiations and why Mahatma Gandhi prolonged the talks when he was apprised of Mr. Jinnah’s views on the first day of the talks.
('84', 419, 2, 5, 732004) Mahatma Gandhi answered: I am a man reputed to have inexhaustible patience and I had no reason to despair of either being converted by the Quaid e Azam or in my turn converting him.
('84', 419, 2, 6, 732186) Therefore, so long as there was the slightest possibility, I clung to the hope that we shall pull through to a solution.
('84', 419, 2, 7, 732307) Haste in such cases is a most dangerous thing.
('84', 419, 2, 8, 732354) You should, therefore, conclude that yesterday was really the moment when the public should have been taken into confidence.
('84', 419, 2, 9, 732479) As for myself, I am entirely satisfied that we have not wasted these three weeks.
('84', 419, 2, 10, 732561) I have no doubt whatsoever that we know now each other better than ever before.
('84', 419, 3, 11, 732641) When you agreed to meet Mr. Jinnah, did you meet him on the basis that he was the sole representative of the Muslims?
('84', 419, 3, 12, 732759) I have never admitted that claim, but I have said throughout that the Muslim League is by far the most representative Muslim organization.
('84', 419, 3, 13, 732898) It would have been folly on my part not to recognize this, but I have always been aware that there is outside the League a large body of Muslims which does not see eye to eye with the League and which does not believe in the two nations theory.
('84', 419, 4, 14, 733143) Mahatma Gandhi asserted that the fight for freedom had not been suspended when he approached the Quaid e Azam.
('84', 419, 4, 15, 733254) He said: My approach to the Quaid e Azam was itself a part of the fight for freedom.
('84', 419, 5, 16, 733339) Asked if there was any possibility of the two leaders meeting again in the near future, Mahatma Gandhi said: I hope so.
('84', 419, 5, 17, 733459) It is for the Press and the public to make it possible and hasten the date.
('84', 419, 5, 18, 733535) I assure you that we have not parted as enemies, but as friends.

('84', 420, 0, 1, 733797) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 421
('84', 420, 1, 2, 733844) correspondence, it shows that it is based on the two nations theory and it has been known as the Pakistan Resolution.
('84', 420, 1, 3, 733962) Further, I had to examine the Resolution in view of the interpretation put upon it by the Quaid e Azam in his numerous speeches and statements in elucidation of the Resolution.
('84', 420, 1, 4, 734139) It is indisputable that the Resolution, while it does not enunciate that theory, is based upon that theory.
('84', 420, 1, 5, 734247) The Quaid e Azam has insisted upon that.
('84', 420, 1, 6, 734288) Therefore, I urge that apart from the two nations theory, if I could accept the principle of division of India in accordance with the demand of the League, he should accept it.
('84', 420, 1, 7, 734465) But unfortunately it was just there we split.
('84', 420, 2, 8, 734511) Asked about Mr. Jinnah’s views regarding a provisional interim government, he said: I am not sure that the Quaid e Azam puts great weight on the interim government.
('84', 420, 2, 9, 734676) I gave all the explanation of my conception of an interim government without any reservation.
('84', 420, 2, 10, 734770) It is quite clear in my letters 1. If I did not go any further, it was because I could not and, even if you cross examine me any further, I would have to say I could not go any further.
('84', 420, 2, 11, 734956) But if, as you suggest, the Quaid e Azam attached greater weight to it, then it was open to him to put it into concrete form.
('84', 420, 2, 12, 735082) I would have then taxed myself and spared no effort to accept the proposition or to make some other suggestions.
('84', 420, 3, 13, 735195) Mahatma Gandhi was told that those Muslims who did not see eye to eye with the League had no real Muslim backing.
('84', 420, 3, 14, 735309) He replied: Therefore, I have said that the League is by far the most representative of Muslim opinion, but I cannot despise the others by simply saying that they have no Muslim backing.
('84', 420, 3, 15, 735496) What does it matter if they have no more Muslim backing if the opinion represented by a single Muslim, or by a body of Muslims whom you can count on your fingers, is intrinsically sound?
('84', 420, 3, 16, 735683) The way of approaching a question is not to examine the numerical strength of those behind the opinion, but to examine the soundness of the opinion on merits, or else we will never reach a solution, and if we reach one, it will be a blind solution simply because it is the wish of the largest body.
('84', 420, 3, 17, 735982) If the largest body goes wrong, it is up to me to say you are wrong and not to submit.
('84', 420, 3, 18, 736069) The rule of majority does not mean that it should suppress the opinion of even an individual, if it is sound.
('84', 420, 3, 19, 736179) An individual’s opinion should have greater weight than the opinion of many, if that
('84', 420, 4, 20, 736264) 1 Vide “Letter to M. A. Jinnah”, 14 9 1944 and 15 9 1944.

('84', 421, 1, 2, 736364) opinion is sound on merits.
('84', 421, 1, 3, 736392) That is my view of real democracy.
('84', 421, 2, 4, 736427) Mahatma Gandhi was asked what he thought of the idea of formation of provinces on linguistic, cultural and communal basis.
('84', 421, 2, 5, 736550) He replied that since 1920 he was for provinces on a linguistic basis.
('84', 421, 2, 6, 736621) As for redistribution on a cultural basis, he did not really know what it meant and he was unable to understand how provinces could be reconstituted on communal lines unless there was a suggestion that there should be inter migration of the various communities to concentrate in particular areas.
('84', 421, 2, 7, 736918) It seemed to him to be fantastic and impossible.
('84', 421, 2, 8, 736967) He said: We are not inhabiting a country full of deserts and wastelands.
('84', 421, 2, 9, 737040) We are a densely populated country and I do not see the slightest chance for such redistribution.
('84', 421, 2, 10, 737138) In that respect the Lahore Resolution is quite sound—where there is an obvious Muslim majority they should be allowed to constitute a separate State by themselves and that has been fully conceded in the Rajaji Formula or my formula.
('84', 421, 2, 11, 737371) There is not much distinction between them.
('84', 421, 2, 12, 737415) That right is conceded without the slightest reservation.
('84', 421, 2, 13, 737473) But if it means utterly independent sovereignty so that there is to be nothing in common between the two, I hold it is an impossible proposition.
('84', 421, 2, 14, 737619) That means war to the knife.
('84', 421, 2, 15, 737648) It is not a proposition that resolves itself into a voluntary or friendly solution.
('84', 421, 2, 16, 737732) Therefore, the Rajaji Formula and my formula have presented certain things to be in common between sovereign States.
('84', 421, 2, 17, 737849) Therefore, there is no question of one party overbearing the other or the Centre having an overbearing Hindu majority.
('84', 421, 2, 18, 737968) I think our formula should be critically and sympathetically examined and it would be found that the formula concedes everything that could reasonably be conceded if we consider ourselves to be one family.
('84', 421, 2, 19, 738174) Children of the same family, dissatisfied with one another by reason of change of religion, if they should separate, then the separation should be within ourselves and not separation in the face of the whole world.
('84', 421, 2, 20, 738389) When two brothers separate, they do not become enemies of one another in the eyes of the world.
('84', 421, 2, 21, 738485) The world will still recognize them as brothers.
('84', 421, 3, 22, 738534) A journalist said that some of the Nationalist Muslims felt that the Congress through Mahatma Gandhi meeting Mr. Jinnah had put them in a false position and that they might have to change their attitude towards Indian nationalism.
('84', 421, 4, 23, 738765) Mahatma Gandhi replied that it was an extraordinary suggestion.
('84', 421, 4, 24, 738829) Nationalist Muslims were nationalists simply because they could not be otherwise.
('84', 421, 4, 25, 738911) He said: I am a nationalist, not in order to please anybody, but because I cannot be otherwise.
('84', 421, 4, 26, 739007) And If I approached the Quaid e Azam, I approached him in the common interests of myself and Nationalist
('84', 422, 0, 1, 739112) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 423
('84', 422, 1, 2, 739159) Muslims and other Nationalists.
('84', 422, 1, 3, 739191) Nationalist Muslims, so far as I know, were delighted when I approached the Quaid e Azam and were looking forward to a proper solution in the confidence that I would not sell the interests represented by them.
('84', 422, 1, 4, 739401) Undoubtedly, a Nationalist Muslim represents the nation, but he represents the Muslims also, who are a part of the nation.
('84', 422, 1, 5, 739524) He would be guilty of disloyalty, if he sacrifices the Muslim interests.
('84', 422, 1, 6, 739597) But my nationalism has taught me that I would be guilty of disloyalty if I sacrifice the interests of a single Indian.
('84', 422, 2, 7, 739716) Asked if there was any difference between his present attitude towards the Muslim League demand and the stand he took in 1942, Mahatma Gandhi said: There is very great difference.
('84', 422, 2, 8, 739896) In 1942, Rajaji had not ‘burst’ on the scene as he did at the Aga Khan Palace with a concrete proposition.
('84', 422, 2, 9, 740003) It reflects very great credit on his persistence.
('84', 422, 2, 10, 740053) He never takes up a standpoint without the fullest consideration and having taken it up, he follows it to the bitterest end.
('84', 422, 2, 11, 740178) He had abundant faith in my loyalty and he never gave me up as I have never given him up.
('84', 422, 2, 12, 740268) When he found me in the Aga Khan Palace and presented the Formula, I did not take even five minutes and I said ‘Yes’ because I saw it in a concrete shape.
('84', 422, 2, 13, 740423) My mind is narrow.
('84', 422, 2, 14, 740442) I have not read much literature.
('84', 422, 2, 15, 740475) I have not seen much of the world.
('84', 422, 2, 16, 740510) I have concentrated upon certain things in life and beyond that I have no other interest.
('84', 422, 2, 17, 740600) Therefore, I could not realize the meaning of Rajaji’s stand and I disliked it.
('84', 422, 2, 18, 740680) But when he came with a concrete formula—I myself a concrete being of flesh and blood—and when he had put something in concrete shape, I felt I could hug it and touch it.
('84', 422, 2, 19, 740851) Therefore, you see the vast difference between 1942 and today.
('84', 422, 2, 20, 740914) However, thereby I have not departed from the Congress standpoint in general terms.
('84', 422, 2, 21, 740998) Congress has accepted self determination and the Rajaji Formula has also accepted the principle of self determination and therefore the Formula had become common ground.
('84', 422, 3, 22, 741168) Proceeding, Mahatma Gandhi explained that he accepted the principle of sovereign States, consistent with friendliness.
('84', 422, 3, 23, 741287) He said: Friendliness suggests that before the whole world we must act as one nation, not united by extraneous circumstances, or united by force of British arms, but united by a greater force, that is, our own determined will.
