('84', 423, 1, 2, 741623) 569. INTERVIEW TO “NEWS CHRONICLE” 1
('84', 423, 2, 3, 741660) BOMBAY, September 29, 2 1944
('84', 423, 3, 4, 741689) Mr. Gandhi told me today why his talks with Mr. Jinnah failed to produce a solution of the Hindu Muslim differences.
('84', 423, 3, 5, 741806) I could not accept the two nations basis.
('84', 423, 3, 6, 741848) This was Mr. Jinnah’s demand.
('84', 423, 3, 7, 741878) He wants immediate recognition of the North West Frontier Province, Sind, the whole of the Punjab, Bengal and Assam as sovereign and completely independent Pakistan.
('84', 423, 4, 8, 742044) He wants Mr. Gandhi to agree to this amputation from the rest of India without consulting the wishes of the inhabitants by plebiscite.
('84', 423, 4, 9, 742179) He has rejected the Rajagopalachari Formula.
('84', 423, 4, 10, 742224) I asked Mr. Gandhi what he was prepared to recognize as Pakistan and on what basis there could be any hope of agreement in future.
('84', 423, 4, 11, 742355) He was frank and precise.
('84', 423, 4, 12, 742381) He replied: I want to make it clear that I believe Mr. Jinnah is sincere, but I think he is suffering from hallucination when he imagines that an unnatural division of India could bring either happiness or prosperity to the people concerned.
('84', 423, 4, 13, 742623) It was my suggestion that provided there was the safeguard of a plebiscite there could he sovereignty for the predominantly Muslim areas, but it should be accompanied by bonds of alliance between Hindustan and Pakistan.
('84', 423, 4, 14, 742843) There should be common policy and working arrangement on foreign affairs, defence, communications and similar matters.
('84', 423, 4, 15, 742962) This is manifestly vital to the welfare of both parts of India.
('84', 423, 5, 16, 743026) This arrangement, Mr. Gandhi said, could not interfere with the internal life of Muslims who would not be subject in any way to Hindu domination.
('84', 423, 5, 17, 743172) Such a division would not create an artificial split between people who whatever their religious faiths are descended from a common stock and are all Indians.
('84', 423, 5, 18, 743331) Unfortunately, Mr. Jinnah would have none of it and asked me to agree to the principle of two nations entirely separate.
('84', 423, 6, 19, 743452) I asked Mr. Gandhi if he had adopted the attitude because he thought he could not ‘sell’ such a division to the country or because he thought it wrong in principle.
('84', 423, 6, 20, 743617) He replied.
('84', 423, 7, 21, 743629) 1 Of London, represented by Stuart Gelder 2 The Hindu, 2 10 1944, however reports this interview under the dateline, September 30.
('84', 424, 0, 1, 743760) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 425
('84', 424, 1, 2, 743807) Because it is fundamentally wrong in principle.
('84', 424, 1, 3, 743855) If I had thought Mr. Jinnah’s view was right, even though the whole world were against me, I would have accepted it personally and given him my unquestioned allegiance.
('84', 424, 2, 4, 744024) If Mr. Jinnah agreed to your view of division, but insisted there should be no plebiscite or a plebiscite in which only Muslims would vote, would you settle on this basis?
('84', 424, 2, 5, 744196) How could I agree in a personal or any other capacity to decide the future of millions of people without their having anything to say about their destiny?
('84', 424, 3, 6, 744351) What was your impression of Mr. Jinnah’s attitude on the question of an interim national government which you outlined 1 to me in July?
('84', 424, 3, 7, 744487) Mr. Jinnah has said that he is deeply interested in independence, but it did not seem to me that he set as great store by it as immediate recognition of the Pakistan he wants.
('84', 424, 3, 8, 744663) Whereas, you see, my view has been all along that we cannot be free among ourselves until we are free from imperial domination.
('84', 424, 3, 9, 744791) We have parted as friends.
('84', 424, 3, 10, 744818) These days have not been wasted.
('84', 424, 3, 11, 744851) I am convinced that Mr. Jinnah is a good man.
('84', 424, 3, 12, 744897) I hope we shall meet again.
('84', 424, 3, 13, 744925) I am a man of prayer and I shall pray for understanding.
('84', 424, 3, 14, 744982) In the mean time, it is the duty of the public to digest the situation and bring the pressure of their opinion upon us.

('84', 431, 10, 10, 752668) HOME DEPARTMENT
('84', 431, 11, 11, 752684) NEW DELHI
('84', 431, 13, 12, 752694) M. K. GANDHI, ESQUIRE
('84', 431, 15, 13, 752716) In reply to your letter of 4th March regarding Mr. Butler’s reply to a question in the House of Commons on the 2nd March, 1944, I am directed to say that the Government of India regret that you should feel that they were unreasonable or obstructive about the calling in of special medical attendants.
('84', 431, 15, 14, 753017) The Government of India were always ready to allow any extra medical aid or consultation which the Government doctors considered necessary, and they do not think that there was any delay in summoning outside aid when the Government doctors decided that it was needed.
('84', 431, 15, 15, 753285) It was on January 28 that they were first informed that Mrs. Gandhi had asked for the services of Dr. Dinshaw Mehta, and it was not until January 31 that they were told that Dr. Gilder had asked for consultation with certain other doctors.
('84', 431, 15, 16, 753525) On February 1, the Bombay Government were explicitly informed that any extra medical aid or consultation might be allowed which the Government doctors considered necessary or useful.
('84', 431, 15, 17, 753708) If Dr. Dinshaw Mehta was not called in earlier, it was due to the view originally expressed by both Col.
('84', 431, 15, 18, 753813) Bhandari and Dr. Gilder that his services could not be of any use, but he was summoned as soon as the Government doctors revised that opinion.
('84', 431, 15, 19, 753956) Your letter of January 27, which did not reach the Government of India until February 1, made some reference to your wife’s wish to see an Ayurvedic physician, but no name was mentioned and it was not until February 9 that a definite requestfor the services of Vaidyaraj Sharma was received.
('84', 431, 15, 20, 754248) The request was then granted within 24
('84', 431, 16, 21, 754287) 1Vide “Letter to Additional Secretary, Home Department, Government of India”, 4 3 1944; 1 4 1944 and “Letter to M. G. Bhandari”, 2 4 1944.
('84', 432, 0, 1, 754426) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 433
('84', 432, 1, 2, 754473) hours and as soon as the Government of India were made aware of the difficulties resulting from his not being accommodated inside the Palace, the necessary permission was given for him to reside there.
('84', 432, 1, 3, 754675) In the circumstances, the Government of India feel that they did everything possible to ensure that your wife received all the treatment that you wished during her illness.
('84', 432, 2, 4, 754848) 2. As to the question of release, the Government of India still feel that the course they adopted was the best and kindest.
('84', 432, 2, 5, 754972) It was reported to them on January 25 that your son, Devadas Gandhi, had asked his mother whether she would like to be released on parole and she had replied that she would not like to leave the Palace without her husband.
('84', 432, 2, 6, 755195) Government have made no use of this report, since it was the record of a private conversation; but it confirmed them in the view expressed above.
('84', 432, 2, 7, 755341) The misunderstanding about the statement in America quite wrongly attributed to Sir Girjashanker Bajpai has been cleared up by answers to questions in the Legislative Assembly which you have doubtless seen.
('84', 432, 3, 8, 755548) 3. The arrangements for the funeral were understood here to be in accordance with your wishes.
('84', 432, 3, 9, 755643) The Government made enquiries on the point and were informed that you had no special preference between the first two alternatives mentioned in your letter.
('84', 432, 4, 10, 755800) 4. In these circumstances, the Government of India do not think that Mr. Butler’s reply to the parliamentary question was incorrect in substance.

('84', 432, 12, 17, 756114) APPENDIX III
('84', 432, 13, 18, 756127) LETTER FROM LORD WAVELL 1
('84', 432, 14, 19, 756153) March 28, 1944
('84', 432, 15, 20, 756168) DEAR MR. GANDHI,
('84', 432, 16, 21, 756185) I have your letter of March 9. You will receive a separate reply from the Home Secretary on your complaint about Mr. Butler’s answer to a question in the House of Commons.
('84', 432, 16, 22, 756357) I can only say that I deeply regret, if you are left with the impressionthat the
('84', 432, 17, 23, 756438) 1 Vide “Letter to Lord Wavell”, 9 3 1944 and 9 4 1944.
('84', 433, 0, 1, 756493) 434 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 433, 1, 2, 756535) Government of India have been unsympathetic in the matter of Mrs. Gandhi’s illness.
('84', 433, 1, 3, 756619) Miss Slade’s case will be examined in the light of what you say about her.
('84', 433, 2, 4, 756694) I do not think it profitable that we should enter into lengthy argument, and do not propose to answer in detail the points you raise in your letter.
('84', 433, 2, 5, 756843) But I think it best to give you a clear statement of my views on the future development of India and the reasons for your present detention.
('84', 433, 3, 6, 756984) The draft declaration of His Majesty’s Government which Sir Stafford Cripps brought to India stated in unmistakable terms the intention of His Majesty’s Government to give India self government under a constitution of her own devising, arrived at by agreement between the principal elements.
('84', 433, 3, 7, 757276) I need hardly say that I am in entire accord with that aim, and only seek the best means to implement it without delivering India to confusion and turmoil.
('84', 433, 3, 8, 757432) Much wisdom and a spirit of goodwill and compromise will be required to arrive at the right solution, but with good leadership, I am sure, a solution can be found.
('84', 433, 4, 9, 757596) Meanwhile there is much work to be done, particularly in the economic field, in preparing India to take her proper place in the modern world.
('84', 433, 4, 10, 757738) She must be ready to welcome change and progress in many hitherto unfamiliar directions and to raise the standard of living of her population.
('84', 433, 4, 11, 757881) Such work is primarily non political; it may well hasten a political settlement, but cannot await it.
('84', 433, 4, 12, 757983) It will give rise to many new and absorbing problems demanding the best abilities that India can bring to bear on them.
('84', 433, 4, 13, 758103) India cannot be expected to tackle these problems in isolation from the rest of the world, or without the aid that Britain can give and the services of an experienced administration.
('84', 433, 4, 14, 758286) But it is work in which leaders of all parties can co operate with the certainty that they are helping the country towards the goal of freedom.
('84', 433, 5, 15, 758430) I regret that I must view the present policy of the Congress party as hindering and not forwarding Indian progress to self government and development.
('84', 433, 5, 16, 758581) During a war in which the success of the United Nations against the Axis powers is vital both to India and to the world, as you yourself have recognized, the Working Committee of Congress declined to co operate, ordered Congress Ministries to resign, and decided to take no part in the administration of the country or in the war effort which India was making to assist the United Nations.
('84', 433, 5, 17, 758971) At the greatest crisis of all for India, at a time when Japanese invasion was possible, the Congress party decided to pass a resolution calling on the British to leave India, which could not fail to have the most serious effect on our ability to defined the frontiers of India against the Japanese.
('84', 433, 5, 18, 759270) I am quite clear that India’s problems cannot be solved by an immediate and complete withdrawal of the British.
('84', 433, 6, 19, 759382) I do not accuse you or the Congress party of any wish deliberately to aid the Japanese.
('84', 433, 6, 20, 759470) But you are much too intelligent a man, Mr. Gandhi, not to have realized that the effect of your resolution must be to hamper the prosecution of the war; and it
('84', 434, 0, 1, 759631) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 435
('84', 434, 1, 2, 759678) is clear to me that you had lost confidence in our ability to defend India, and were prepared to take advantage of our supposed military straits to gain political advantage.
('84', 434, 1, 3, 759852) I do not see how those responsible for the safety of India could have acted otherwise than they did and could have failed to arrest those who sponsored the resolution.
('84', 434, 1, 4, 760020) As to general Congress responsibility for the disturbances which followed, I was, as you know, Commander in Chief at the time; my vital lines of communication to the Burma frontier were cut by Congress supporters, in the name of Congress, often using the Congress flag.
('84', 434, 1, 5, 760290) I cannot, therefore, hold Congress guiltless of what occurred; and I cannot believe that you, with all your acumen and experience, could have been unaware of what was likely to follow from your policy.
('84', 434, 1, 6, 760492) I do not believe that the Congress party’s action in this matter represented the real feeling of India, nor that the Congress attitude of non co operation represents the opinion of anything like a majority of India.
('84', 434, 2, 7, 760708) To sum up, I believe that with general co operation, we can in the immediate future do much to solve India’s economic problems, and can make steady and substantial progress towards Indian self government.
('84', 434, 3, 8, 760913) I believe that the greatest contribution that the Congress party can make towards India’s welfare is to abandon the policy of non co operation and to join whole heartedly with the other Indian parties and with the British in helping India forward in economic and political progress—not by any dramatic or spectacular stroke, but by hard, steady work towards the end ahead.
('84', 434, 3, 9, 761286) I think that the greatest service you could do to India would be to advise unequivocally such co operation.
('84', 434, 4, 10, 761394) In the mean time, I regard it as my task, in the interests of India, of which I am a sincere friend, to concentrate all my efforts on bringing this war to a victorious conclusion, and to prepare for India’s advancement after the war.
('84', 434, 4, 11, 761628) In this task, I feel, I can count on very considerable co operation from the majority of Indians.
('84', 434, 5, 12, 761726) Yours sincerely,
('84', 434, 7, 13, 761743) Correspondence with Mr. Gandhi, pp.

('84', 436, 7, 9, 764266) WOMAN WORKER: You told us, we should be our own leaders after your arrest.
('84', 436, 7, 10, 764341) In the absence of the Working Committee, everyone of us was to think for himself or herself.
('84', 436, 7, 11, 764434) We acted according to our light.
('84', 436, 7, 12, 764467) Your recent utterances make us feel that we have been let down.
('84', 436, 8, 13, 764531) GANDHIJI: I have blamed no one.
('84', 436, 8, 14, 764563) But, when a thing is wrong, I must say so.
('84', 436, 9, 15, 764606) W.W. Will it not cause a set back?
('84', 436, 10, 16, 764641) G. No, we learn from our mistakes.
('84', 436, 10, 17, 764676) By correcting them we advance.
('84', 436, 11, 18, 764707) W.W. Some say: ‘If this is your narrow interpretation of non violence, we shall have none of it.
('84', 436, 11, 19, 764804) Call it violence or by whatever name you like, we cannot dislodge the Government without sabotage.’
('84', 436, 12, 20, 764904) G. It cannot succeed though for some time it may seem to or even actually succeed.
('84', 436, 12, 21, 764987) But I have said that those who do not believe in my way can say so openly, and courageously try their own method and see if they will succeed better.
('84', 436, 13, 22, 765137) W.W We admit that public opinion has veered round to your view.
('84', 436, 13, 23, 765201) The public has come to feel, whether through enlightenment or fear, that sabotage won’t do.
('84', 436, 13, 24, 765293) But you cannot expect everyone to become a perfect being, which your method implies.
('84', 436, 14, 25, 765378) G. I agree.
('84', 436, 14, 26, 765390) That is why I launched forth with imperfect men.
('84', 436, 14, 27, 765439) But whether the people develop the required non violence or not, I cannot play fast and loose with my principles.
('84', 436, 15, 28, 765553) W.W. What is the quickest way to reach our goal?
('84', 436, 16, 29, 765602) G. The straightest way, though it may appear to be long.
('84', 436, 17, 30, 765659) W.W. Then you do not visualize independence in the near future?
('84', 436, 18, 31, 765723) 1 Substitute nurse 2 Vide “Discussion with a Friend”, after 6 5 1944; “Letter to R. R. Diwakar”, 18 5 1944; “Letter to Ramanathan”, 5 7 1944 and “Statement to the Press”, 28 7 1944.

('84', 437, 1, 2, 765947) G. I visualize it in the nearest future, if my way is followed.
('84', 437, 2, 3, 766011) W.W. You want us to feel indignant and yet sit quiet.

('84', 437, 6, 12, 766568) The women worker was nonplussed.
('84', 437, 6, 13, 766601) Gandhiji noticed her dilemma.
('84', 437, 6, 14, 766631) Reassuringly he proceeded:
('84', 437, 7, 15, 766658) “However, you can say, ‘We do not follow your reasoning, but we yield to your experience.’ You can tell your co workers, ‘We went there.
('84', 437, 7, 16, 766795) We were not convinced.
('84', 437, 7, 17, 766818) But we could not convince him either.
('84', 437, 7, 18, 766856) Therefore, we will follow him as disciplined soldiers.’ But if this course does not appeal to them, it is equally open to them to say, ‘The Mahatma has told us to follow our own reason, if we have no faith in his way.’ That will be equally honourable—perhaps more.
('84', 437, 7, 19, 767121) I shall then defend them.”
('84', 437, 8, 20, 767148) Appa Pant, the Rajkumar of Aundh, had been advising and guiding underground workers.
('84', 437, 8, 21, 767233) He put before Gandhiji his dilemma: “With me truth and non violence are not a policy but my creed.
('84', 437, 8, 22, 767332) I know of underground workers who would not willingly hurt a fly.
('84', 437, 8, 23, 767398) They are patriots to the core.
('84', 437, 8, 24, 767429) I have to shelter them when they come to me and seek my advice.
('84', 437, 8, 25, 767493) I want to wean them from secret methods.
('84', 437, 8, 26, 767534) But, in doing so, I have myself to resort to secrecy.
('84', 437, 8, 27, 767588) I feel puzzled and perplexed.” Gandhiji replied:
('84', 437, 9, 28, 767637) “Your attitude is unexceptionable.
('84', 437, 9, 29, 767672) You cannot jump out of a running train, as it were.
('84', 437, 9, 30, 767724) No outside agency can give you effective guidance.
('84', 437, 9, 31, 767775) It must come from within.
('84', 437, 9, 32, 767801) If you dive within yourself and search prayerfully for an answer, a stage will come when suddenly your eyes will be opened and you will conceive such a disgust for untruth and secrecy that you will go to the underground workers and tell them that they will find you useless as a guide if they want to go their way.
('84', 437, 9, 33, 768116) They will then see it in your face and understand, and very likely it will be the beginning of a new chapter in their lives.”

('84', 438, 1, 2, 768380) APPENDIX VI
('84', 438, 2, 3, 768392) DISCUSSION WITH UNDERGROUND WORKERS 1
('84', 438, 3, 4, 768430) As the onslaught of Governmental repression gathered volume and intensity, more and more workers went underground.
('84', 438, 3, 5, 768545) Some of these friends wanted to meet Gandhiji soon after his release.
('84', 438, 3, 6, 768615) He sent them word that they could come at their risk.
('84', 438, 3, 7, 768669) Several of them accordingly came and saw him at Juhu and later at Panchgani.
('84', 438, 3, 8, 768746) They included R. R. Diwakar .
('84', 438, 3, 9, 768776) Annada Chowdhury .
('84', 438, 3, 10, 768795) Achyut Patwardhan and Aruna Asaf Ali .
('84', 438, 4, 11, 768834) Gandhiji’s advice to them was emphatic.
('84', 438, 4, 12, 768874) He held all secrecy to be sin.
('84', 438, 4, 13, 768905) “To the extent to which secrecy has crept in, it has hurt our cause.
('84', 438, 4, 14, 768974) We have not to think in terms of one or two, we have to think in terms of forty crores.
('84', 438, 4, 15, 769062) Today they feel lifeless.
('84', 438, 4, 16, 769088) We cannot revive them by resorting to secret methods.
('84', 438, 4, 17, 769142) Only by adhering to Truth and Non violence can we bring back lustre to their lustreless eyes.”
('84', 438, 5, 18, 769237) Looking at their immediate surroundings, he said to them, they might feel that if some of them had not gone underground, the movement would have suffered.
('84', 438, 5, 19, 769392) But this was only apparently so.
('84', 438, 5, 20, 769425) When you come to bigger issues, “you will find that it is only by eschewing all secrecy and working openly that you can advance.
('84', 438, 5, 21, 769554) Today you may be two, tomorrow you will be twenty, if you come out in open, and so the struggle will go on gathering momentum from day to day.”
('84', 438, 6, 22, 769698) Mahatm a Gandhi —The Last Phase, Vol. I, Book One, pp.

('84', 439, 2, 3, 770012) LETTER FROM V. S. SRINIVASA SASTRI 1
('84', 439, 3, 4, 770049) SVAGATAM, MYLAPORE, MADRAS, June 2, 1944
('84', 439, 4, 5, 770090) MY DEAR BROTHER,
('84', 439, 5, 6, 770107) This letter I mean only for you and your trusted friends.
('84', 439, 5, 7, 770165) Mr. T. R. Venkatarama Sastri, now on his way to Srinagar, will deliver it in person.
('84', 439, 6, 8, 770250) I must first thank you for your ‘sympathy in abundance’.
('84', 439, 6, 9, 770307) My philosophy is not so stoical but it needs the human touch.
('84', 439, 6, 10, 770369) You know, as only a very few do, how in simple words to get to a man’s heart.
('84', 439, 6, 11, 770447) It takes a big heart to do so.
('84', 439, 7, 12, 770478) Don’t fear a long political screed from me.
('84', 439, 7, 13, 770522) I do not see Government arresting you as soon as you are well for another term in jail.
('84', 439, 7, 14, 770610) You say in your letter to Jayakar, they will do so.
('84', 439, 7, 15, 770662) If you have reasons to think so, I don’t know them.
('84', 439, 8, 16, 770714) Listen to my story.
('84', 439, 8, 17, 770734) It shall be brief.
('84', 439, 8, 18, 770753) You can fill in the outline.
('84', 439, 9, 19, 770782) The greatest event to happen in the remaining days of your life will be the World Conference of Peace.
('84', 439, 9, 20, 770885) You must attend it.
('84', 439, 9, 21, 770905) If they won’t let you go as the representative of India, you must go still.
('84', 439, 9, 22, 770981) To the good and true men at the Peace table your name will be sufficient credential.
('84', 439, 10, 23, 771066) Don’t waste your energy on details.
('84', 439, 10, 24, 771102) Experts will handle them.
('84', 439, 10, 25, 771128) Concentrate on the sovereign issues.
('84', 439, 11, 26, 771165) I. Disarmament of all nations.
('84', 439, 11, 27, 771196) I would allow the International Authority to have some armed forces.
('84', 439, 11, 28, 771265) But you won’t.
('84', 439, 11, 29, 771280) Go ahead.
('84', 439, 11, 30, 771290) You will have valiant support all over the world.
('84', 439, 11, 31, 771340) What if you fail?
('84', 439, 11, 32, 771358) You will have given your evangel to a stricken and listening world.
('84', 439, 12, 33, 771426) Equality of economic as well as political opportunities for all peoples of this principle the implications are too many and too intricate for a single human brain.
('84', 439, 12, 34, 771590) The comprehending proposition is all you can safeguard.
('84', 439, 13, 35, 771646) Elimination of the colour bar in the British Commonwealth and in the world at large.
('84', 439, 13, 36, 771731) To fail under this head is to leave a wide door for future wars.
('84', 439, 13, 37, 771796) Whether India is within or without the Commonwealth, this issue is supreme.
('84', 439, 13, 38, 771872) At the Peace table one is a citizen of the world.
('84', 439, 14, 39, 771922) No doubt it would be a giant’s strength to be armed with the Government of
('84', 439, 15, 40, 771997) 1 Vide “Letter to V. S. Srinivasa Sastri”, 10 6 1944.

('84', 440, 1, 2, 772098) India’s authority.
('84', 440, 1, 3, 772117) Whether they made you the delegation’s leader or not, you would be looked up to as leader.
('84', 440, 1, 4, 772208) A necessary condition is the end of Section 93 rule and the restoration of popular government.
('84', 440, 1, 5, 772303) To this end I have been for nearly two years now pleading that:
('84', 440, 2, 6, 772367) (i) political prisoners and detenus should be released;
('84', 440, 3, 7, 772423) (ii) general elections should be held, and the Central and local legislatures be put back in power; and
('84', 440, 4, 8, 772527) (iii) a national government be formed at the Centre of which the personnel should be drawn from elected leaders.

('84', 441, 2, 3, 773598) LETTER FROM MIRABEHN TO M. K. GANDHI1
('84', 441, 3, 4, 773636) SUNDER BUN, JUHU, June 12, 1944
('84', 441, 4, 5, 773668) BELOVED BAPU,
('84', 441, 5, 6, 773682) I have your letter.
('84', 441, 5, 7, 773702) I had not realized the position regarding the fund kept in my name, and that my expenses were being drawn.
('84', 441, 5, 8, 773809) I had the impression that the whole sum was being kept intact and that I was receiving food, clothing, travelling expenses, etc., like some others who gave their whole time to the cause according to their individual capacity.
('84', 441, 5, 9, 774035) But this was a misunderstanding.
('84', 441, 5, 10, 774068) So, I will gladly put the matter straight at once.
('84', 441, 5, 11, 774119) I cannot bear any bargaining in such matters.
('84', 441, 5, 12, 774165) I, therefore, ask that Rs. 20,000 should be deducted from the total, which should cover the expenses incurred by the Ashram for me during these 20 years.
('84', 441, 5, 13, 774319) The remainder can be transferred to my name.
('84', 441, 6, 14, 774364) I had understood that when I had this money, I should be free to do constructive national work without let or hindrance, so long as I made it clear that the scheme of work was entirely my own and without your personal approval.
('84', 441, 6, 15, 774592) I did not realize that you would feel called upon publicly to express disapproval of my work.
('84', 441, 7, 16, 774686) You have given me my freedom with one hand and taken it away with the other.
('84', 441, 7, 17, 774763) To give me my money and freedom, and at the same time to say that as soon as I begin to use them you will publicly disapprove, is to sabotage anything I may try to do.
('84', 441, 7, 18, 774931) You at the same time sabotage any chance of my being able to prove to you that you are wrong.
('84', 441, 8, 19, 775025) You have brought up a whole lot of reports and prejudices against Sardarji.
('84', 441, 8, 20, 775101) I have avoided discussing these matters with you because I could see that everything I said excited you.
('84', 441, 8, 21, 775206) The result is that you have not understood my position.
('84', 441, 8, 22, 775262) You have made up your mind that I am completely under his influence.
('84', 441, 8, 23, 775331) It is you who have tried to urge me to that position, but as you know, I have protested all along.
('84', 441, 8, 24, 775430) You said I should have to join the Communist Party.
('84', 441, 8, 25, 775482) I said no.
('84', 441, 8, 26, 775493) You said as a true Hindu wife I should have to follow him in everything.
('84', 441, 8, 27, 775566) I said my opinion was the opposite, and that my whole instinct told me that I must resist him wherever necessary and live my own life according to the ideals in which I believe, by which means, he would some day know that I was right.
('84', 441, 8, 28, 775801) If I had followed his advice, I should not have undertaken my scheme but I knew that I must resist him and I did.
('84', 441, 8, 29, 775915) My faith in God is my guide.
('84', 441, 9, 30, 775944) 1 Vide “Letter to Additional Secretary, Home Department, Government of India”, 15 7 1943.
('84', 442, 0, 1, 776034) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 443
('84', 442, 1, 2, 776081) But now you propose to throttle, by the warning of public disapproval, any attempt on my part to put my ideals into practice.
('84', 442, 1, 3, 776207) My ideals have not changed in the last few days.
('84', 442, 1, 4, 776256) I am the same person that I was when we used to talk happily together.
('84', 442, 2, 5, 776327) Believing, as I did, that everything is finally settled I started the ball rolling.
('84', 442, 2, 6, 776411) I have put out enquiries regarding co workers, land, maps and other details.
('84', 442, 2, 7, 776488) I have explained the scheme (as my personal idea) to many people.
('84', 442, 2, 8, 776554) Must I now understand if I go on with my plans you will feel called upon to disapprove.
('84', 442, 2, 9, 776642) The fact that there will be Rs. 20,000 less does not worry me at all.
('84', 442, 2, 10, 776712) I can start in a smaller way and make up with donations.
('84', 442, 2, 11, 776769) But the possibility that you might broadcast public or semi public disapproval of my work, which statement I should feel obliged equally publicly to answer, means that for decency’s sake I must avoid any such catastrophe, and therefore cancel all my projects of work.
('84', 442, 2, 12, 777037) I would, in that case, take the balance of the money after the deduction of Rs. 20,000, invest it somewhere, and go to live in seclusion until time as you revised your ideas.
('84', 442, 3, 13, 777212) Yours ever devoted daughter,

('84', 443, 1, 2, 777413) APPENDIX IX
('84', 443, 2, 3, 777425) LETTER FROM P. C. JOSHI 1
('84', 443, 3, 4, 777451) BOMBAY,
('84', 443, 4, 5, 777459) June 14, 1944
('84', 443, 5, 6, 777473) DEAR GANDHIJI,
('84', 443, 6, 7, 777488) Your small chit came as a pleasant surprise that you were so eager to know more about us.
('84', 443, 7, 8, 777578) I am answering your points in a very brief manner.
('84', 443, 8, 9, 777629) 1. People in people’s war means all peoples the world over without exception.
('84', 443, 8, 10, 777707) It, of course, includes India’s millions and also the Negroes wherever they be.
('84', 443, 8, 11, 777787) This war has split the world into two camps.
('84', 443, 8, 12, 777832) On the one side .
('84', 443, 8, 13, 777850) Fascists are fighting the war for the imperialist domination of the world.
('84', 443, 8, 14, 777925) On the other side are the freedom loving peoples of the world.
('84', 443, 8, 15, 777988) the camp of freedom and democracy.
('84', 443, 8, 16, 778023) fighting Fascism is the only path of national liberation from imperialist domination for us today.
('84', 443, 8, 17, 778122) The more we unite our patriotic parties, the weaker and more isolated becomes the alien Government and the more irresistible our national and other demands, the greater our capacity to save and serve our people.
('84', 443, 8, 18, 778334) The more our patriotic parties engage themselves in those tasks which any war time government should successfully lead, but an alien Government cannot, the more speedily we get the united intervention of all the peoples of the world behind our national demand for national government in the common interest of fighting the common enemy.
('84', 443, 9, 19, 778671) 2. If you desire to examine the accounts personally, they will present themselves with all the registers where and when you desire.
('84', 443, 9, 20, 778803) If you decide to appoint a representative, he should besuch whom we also know to be an honest man and notalready prejudiced against us.
('84', 443, 9, 21, 778939) You will not find our accounts as well kept as by a commercial firm but I am sure you will give us a pass.
('84', 443, 9, 22, 779046) You will find some anonymous donors, but I believe that you also accept anonymous donors.
('84', 443, 9, 23, 779136) But to dispel any suspicion that “anonymous” may be code for Government cash, I am prepared to give you (not your representative) the names.
('84', 443, 10, 24, 779277) If you have yet any doubts left and in any case, I give you some references.
('84', 443, 10, 25, 779354) Iftikharuddin and his Begum, Shaukat Ansari and Zohra, N. M. Joshi.
('84', 443, 10, 26, 779422) You can ask Dr. and Mrs. Subbaroyan as to what they think is going to happen to their property when Mohan and Parvati (their children and our comrades) get it, and in fact what they know happens to the property of the whole time workers of the party.
('84', 443, 11, 27, 779673) 1 Vide “Letter to P. C. Joshi”, 11 6 1944 and 30 7 1944. Only excerpts are reproduced here.
('84', 444, 0, 1, 779765) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 445
('84', 444, 1, 2, 779812) 3. I know it is easy enough to make such a vile charge but very difficult to prove it.
('84', 444, 1, 3, 779899) Firstly, I believe, if you find that we are not paid by the Government, you will easily believe that we are not likely to hand over labour leaders to the police.
('84', 444, 2, 4, 780061) Secondly, our party, except in Ahmedabad and Jamshedpur, is as much the unquestioned leader of the working class as the great Congress is of the Indian people as a whole.
('84', 444, 2, 5, 780232) We gave up our strike policy because we considered it anti national in the conditions of today, aiding the Jap aggressors on the one hand and intensifying the economic crisis for our own people on the other.
('84', 444, 2, 6, 780440) That we successfully prevented the Indian working class from resorting to strikes even in a period of their worsening material conditions is the measure not only of our influence over it but its capacity to understand national interests as its own.
('84', 444, 3, 7, 780689) 4. There is no question of our “adopting the policy of infiltrating the Congress organization”.
('84', 444, 3, 8, 780785) We have been in the Congress ever since we were born as a party.
('84', 444, 3, 9, 780850) Whether our intent is hostile or not, it is for our fellow Congressmen to judge and for us to prove otherwise through our practice.
('84', 444, 3, 10, 780982) We are inside the Congress on our right, as patriotic sons and daughters of the people who join the common national organization, so that we may be able to fight our hardest and best in realization of the common goal of national emancipation and no slanders can ever provoke us to give up this stand and forgo the glorious privilege.
('84', 444, 4, 11, 781316) 5. The Communist Party decides its own policy as it understands the interests of its own people and of the peoples of the world.
('84', 444, 4, 12, 781445) As long as the Communist International was there, we were dubbed as ‘Moscow Agents’.
('84', 444, 4, 13, 781530) It is rather surprising to come across the same insinuation even after its dissolution.
('84', 444, 4, 14, 781618) The Communist Party is one great revolutionary brotherhood.
('84', 444, 4, 15, 781678) It exists in every country of the world.
('84', 444, 4, 16, 781719) All have the same ideology and are moved by the common aims of fighting for the liberation of their own and all peoples.
('84', 444, 4, 17, 781840) I can send you the journals and documents of the Communist Parties of Britain, U.S.A., South Africa, Australia, which have nailed down Amery & Co.
('84', 444, 4, 18, 781987) as slanderers and provocateurs after August 9 and which have unfalteringly demanded the release of the Congress leaders and settlement with India on the basis of a real national government.
('84', 444, 5, 19, 782177) P. C. JOSHI
('84', 444, 6, 20, 782189) Corres pondence betwee n Mahatm a Gandhi and P. C. Joshi, pp.

('84', 445, 2, 3, 782304) PASSAGES FROM “THE QUINTESSENCE OF GANDHISM” 1
('84', 445, 3, 4, 782351) Thou shalt fight for the protection of good men and the destruction of wrong doers and for the establishment of righteousness.
('84', 445, 4, 5, 782478) The side you take up and the weapons you wield are indeed important but the obligation to fight is perfectly absolute and independent of every other consideration, and the emphasis is all upon this obligation.
('84', 445, 4, 6, 782688) It may be that you take the wrong side in the conflict.
('84', 445, 4, 7, 782744) But if you are on the wrong side today, you may turn to the right side tomorrow.
('84', 445, 4, 8, 782825) But those who sit upon the fence have already qualified for admission into Dante’s Inferno.
('84', 445, 5, 9, 782917) Thou shalt fight for the right, for .
('84', 445, 5, 10, 782955) ‘Truth alone prevails, not untruth.’ .
('84', 445, 6, 11, 782994) You may not take the wrong side or employ questionable means to attain even a perfectly legitimate end, and still hope to succeed.
('84', 445, 7, 12, 783125) When you are ready to fight for the right, Gandhiji arms you with the all conquering and never failing weapon, namely .
('84', 445, 7, 13, 783245) suffering cum forgiveness.
('84', 445, 8, 14, 783272) Mankind must have recourse to love and non violence, if they will escape from the vicious circle of hatred and violence.
('84', 445, 8, 15, 783393) Two wrongs can never make one right.
('84', 445, 8, 16, 783430) Violence in response to violence only provokes more violence and so on ad infinitum.
('84', 445, 9, 17, 783515) For a true theist, the Gandhian is the only position he can take up consistently with his theism.
('84', 445, 9, 18, 783613) If God is there ever present—present in a more real sense than you or I—as Judge and Defender of the right, the theist, imperfect as he is in knowledge as well as in strength, will think it no business of his to judge his adversary or to punish him for what he thinks to be the adversary’s wrong doing.

('84', 446, 1, 2, 784032) APPENDIX XI
('84', 446, 2, 3, 784044) OPINION GANDHIJI‘S RESPONSIBILITY 1
('84', 446, 3, 4, 784080) February 2 6, 1944
('84', 446, 4, 5, 784099) We are asked to examine the question whether the authority conferred upon Mahatma Gandhi by the resolution of the A.I.C.C. dated the 8th of August, 1942, to “start a mass struggle on non violent lines” is still subsisting, apart from the legality or otherwise of the purpose for which the authority was given.
('84', 446, 5, 6, 784409) The authority conferred by the said resolution must be construed with reference to the circumstances under which and the purposes for which it was given.
('84', 446, 5, 7, 784563) It appears from the resolution as a whole that the steps to be taken under such authority were conceived by the framers of the resolution to meet the situation which had then arisen.
('84', 446, 6, 8, 784746) In our opinion, the recitals and the purpose of the said resolution and the circumstances under which the same was passed limit the authority so as to confine it to the immediate circumstances and the purpose which the A. I. C. C. had then in view.
('84', 446, 6, 9, 784995) The said authority was intended to be exercised for and in the then immediate situation.
('84', 446, 6, 10, 785084) Before Gandhiji could exercise such authority, he was arrested on the 9th of August, 1942, and was prevented from acting on the resolution by reason of his ceasing to be a free agent.
('84', 446, 6, 11, 785268) By his being so prevented, the exercise of the authority was rendered impossible and it came to an end.
('84', 446, 7, 12, 785372) The authority conferred upon him was neither permanent nor recurring and there can be no question of its revival by the recent release of Gandhiji in the present situation.
('84', 446, 8, 13, 785545) BHULABHAI J. DESAI
('84', 446, 9, 14, 785564) V. F. TARAPOREWALA
('84', 446, 10, 15, 785583) K. M. MUNSHI
('84', 446, 11, 16, 785596) Pilgri mage to Freedo m, pp.

('84', 446, 12, 18, 785808) 91), Gandhiji consulted the lawyers after his release which was on May 6.

('84', 447, 2, 3, 785937) STUART GELDER’S CABLE TO “NEWS CHRONICLE” 1
('84', 447, 3, 4, 785981) Mr. Gandhi is prepared to accept and to advise the Congress to participate in a war time national government in full control of the civil administration, leaving the Viceroy and the Commander in Chief in full control of the British and Indian armies.
('84', 447, 3, 5, 786232) It would be expected that the establishment of such a government would be accompanied now by a guarantee of Indian independence after the war.
('84', 447, 4, 6, 786375) Mr. Gandhi has also approved the proposals submitted to Mr. Jinnah by Mr. C. Rajagopalachari, which agree to a solution of the Hindu Pakistan dispute by a plebiscite and demarcation of the districts where Muslims are in a majority, if the Muslim League will endorse the demand for independence and co operate with the Congress in the formation of a provisional interim government for the transitional period.
('84', 447, 5, 7, 786784) Despite the fact that he is still far from well and wishes to be relieved as far as possible from being burdened by dealing with political problems in detail for the time being, I talked with Mr. Gandhi for more than three hours in Panchgani this week.
('84', 447, 5, 8, 787037) If the Muslim League accepts Mr. Rajagopalachari’s proposals and the Government will now discuss the situation with Mr. Gandhi, the deadlock can be solved and a new page opened in Indian history.
('84', 447, 5, 9, 787233) Mr. Gandhi pointed out that he had no authority to speak in the name of the Congress without consulting the Working Committee, but there is no doubt whatever that his views and the Hindu Muslim proposals as endorsed by him would be accepted by them without hesitation.
('84', 447, 6, 10, 787502) I asked Mr. Gandhi whether he would start civil disobedience, if the Working Committee were released from jail and the Government felt unable to give India what they wanted.
('84', 447, 6, 11, 787676) He replied:
('84', 447, 7, 12, 787688) “I have no intention of offering civil disobedience today.
('84', 447, 7, 13, 787747) I cannot take the country back to 1942. History can never be repeated.
('84', 447, 7, 14, 787818) Even without the authority of the Congress, if I wanted to do it, I could start civil disobedience today on the strength of my supposed influence with the masses, but I would be doing so merely to embarrass the British Government.
('84', 447, 7, 15, 788049) This cannot be my object.”
('84', 447, 8, 16, 788076) 1 Vide “Telegram to S. Sadanand”, 12 7 1944; “Statement to the Press”, 12 7 1944; “Telegram to S. Sadanand”, 13 7 1944; ”Interview to the Press”, 12 7 1944; 14 7 1944; “Letter to Stuart Gelder”, 14 7 1944; “Letter to Lord Wavell”, 15 7 1944; “Answers to Questions”, 15 7 1944 and “Letter to Mathuradas Trikumji”, 16 7 1944.
('84', 448, 0, 1, 788400) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 449
('84', 448, 1, 2, 788447) But Mr. Gandhi pointed out, the Working Committee could not sit still while the people were suffering.
('84', 448, 1, 3, 788550) It is his conviction that the food situation cannot beimproved and suffering ameliorated, unless power and responsibility for civil administration are transferred from British to Indian hands.
('84', 448, 2, 4, 788743) I told Mr. Gandhi that, with things as they are, I could not believe that the Government would transfer authority now or concede independence during the war.
('84', 448, 2, 5, 788901) He replied that there was a difference between what he would ask today and what was asked in 1942. Today India would be satisfied with a national government in full control of the civil administration.
('84', 448, 2, 6, 789103) This was not the position in 1942.
('84', 448, 3, 7, 789138) Such a government would be formed of people chosen by the elected members of the Central Assembly.
('84', 448, 3, 8, 789237) This would involve a declaration now of Indian independence after the war.
('84', 448, 4, 9, 789312) Such a national government would give the military all railway, port and other communication facilities they required, although these would be under the national government’s control.
('84', 448, 4, 10, 789496) The ordinance rule would give way to a normal civil administration by the government.
('84', 448, 4, 11, 789582) The Viceroy would remain and have complete control with the Commander in Chief of the British and Indian armies.
('84', 448, 4, 12, 789695) In other affairs he would be like the King of England guided by responsible Ministers.
('84', 448, 4, 13, 789782) Popular government would be automatically restored in all provinces, so that both the Provincial and Central governments would be responsible to the people of India.
('84', 448, 5, 14, 789948) The national government would be in the position of offering advice and criticism on military affairs, and the portfolio of Defence would be in the hands of the national government which would be genuinely interested in the defence of the country and would be in the position of being able to give valuable help in shaping policies.
('84', 448, 5, 15, 790281) Mr. Gandhi realizes that the Allies cannot defeat Japan without carrying on operations on the Indian soil and, therefore, they would continue to do so, but the expenses of these operations should not be borne by India.
('84', 448, 6, 16, 790500) When I asked Mr. Gandhi, if he would advise the Congress to participate in such a government formed under such conditions and with such stipulations, he replied “Yes”.
('84', 448, 6, 17, 790668) In view of Mr. Gandhi’s uncompromising pacifism, readers will ask what his position would be under such a government.
('84', 448, 6, 18, 790786) After independence had been assured by the formation of a provisional government and the declaration of Indian independence after the war, he would probably cease to function as adviser to the Congress.
('84', 448, 7, 19, 790989) As a teacher and exponent of non violence, he would have to stand aside, but he would certainly not offer any resistance to the government or to the Congress party participating in such a government.
('84', 448, 7, 20, 791189) His co operation would take the form of abstention from interfering with the even tenor of life in India.
('84', 448, 7, 21, 791295) He would continue to work in the hope that his influence would always be felt to keep India peace minded
('84', 449, 0, 1, 791400) 450 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 449, 1, 2, 791442) and to affect world policy in the direction of real peace and brotherhood among all without distinction of race or colour.
('84', 449, 2, 3, 791565) I am not in a position at present to write an account of all the details of my conversation with Mr. Gandhi.
('84', 449, 2, 4, 791674) Last week I visited Delhi to give the Viceroy a complete account of my talk with him in Poona.
('84', 449, 2, 5, 791769) I am now laying before him a complete report of my recent conversation with Mr. Gandhi.
('84', 449, 3, 6, 791857) This week, after Lord Wavell had declined to see him in the immediate future, I asked Mr. Gandhi what he would say to the Viceroy if he met him.
('84', 449, 3, 7, 792002) He replied:
('84', 449, 4, 8, 792014) “I would tell him that I sought the interview with a view to helping, and not to hindering, the Allied effort.
('84', 449, 4, 9, 792125) But I can do nothing without seeing the members of the Working Committee, for I believe that my authority under the August resolution ended with my imprisonment.
('84', 449, 4, 10, 792287) It was not revived by my release.”
('84', 449, 5, 11, 792322) I pointed out that, before the Viceroy would permit a meeting with the Working Committee, he would want to know how Mr. Gandhi would influence the members.
('84', 449, 5, 12, 792478) To this, Mr. Gandhi replied that history did not repeat itself.
('84', 449, 5, 13, 792542) “The whole situation has to be reviewed anew,” he said.
('84', 449, 5, 14, 792598) “The point, therefore, for me to discuss with the Working Committee is to know how they react to the knowledge I have gained since my release.
('84', 449, 5, 15, 792741) I have to take up the thread that was broken by the Government in 1942. I was first to negotiate and, on failure, to offer civil resistance, if I thought it necessary.
('84', 449, 5, 16, 792909) I want to plead with the Viceroy.
('84', 449, 5, 17, 792943) I can only do so when I know the Working Committee’s mind.
('84', 449, 6, 18, 793002) “But I tell you that the common talk among us is that, whatever the Viceroy may wish personally, he has no authority in the political sphere.
('84', 449, 6, 19, 793144) Mr. Churchill does not want a settlement.
('84', 449, 6, 20, 793186) He wants to crush me, if he has been correctly reported—he has never denied the report.
('84', 449, 6, 21, 793274) The beauty of it for me, the pity of it for him, is that no one can crush a satyagrahi, for he offers his body as a willing sacrifice, thus making the spirit free.”
('84', 449, 7, 22, 793439) There was deep disappointment, but no bitterness, in Mr. Gandhi’s voice when he expressed this fear.
('84', 449, 8, 23, 793540) Mr. Gandhi feels that, if the British Government has good intentions, there would be no difficulty about an agreement.
('84', 449, 8, 24, 793659) But there is an uneasy feeling among Indians of both extreme and moderate views that whatever the Viceroy may wish personally, Mr. Churchill does not wish a settlement now.
('84', 449, 8, 25, 793832) It may be ill founded, but it is of vital importance that Indian opinion should be officially reassured on this point.
('84', 449, 9, 26, 793951) It was expressed to me in friendly conversation with Mr. Rajagopalachari which was not intended to be an interview.
('84', 449, 9, 27, 794067) His view that the Congress should have accepted the Cripps offer and co operated in the war is well known, and he has been a sincere and outspoken critic of the policy of the Congress and of Mr. Gandhi, while
('84', 450, 0, 1, 794276) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 451
('84', 450, 1, 2, 794323) remaining a firm advocate of independence.
('84', 450, 1, 3, 794366) It seemed to me, therefore, that his appealand warning was of such importance and significance that I asked his permission to quote it for publication in the News Chronicle, and he gave his consent.
('84', 450, 2, 4, 794565) He said: “It seems that the British Government is not now interested in a settlement.
('84', 450, 2, 5, 794651) They have come to feel that power is the only real thing.
('84', 450, 2, 6, 794709) Ideals have been put aside and so they are content to drift.
('84', 450, 2, 7, 794770) They are not planning for the future.
('84', 450, 2, 8, 794808) They do not know what shape things will take after the war, and so they are not thinking of Indo British relationship.
('84', 450, 2, 9, 794927) But, if the war ends on this note, relations between India and Britain will be permanently embittered.
('84', 450, 2, 10, 795030) It would be a miserable ending for the war, so far as Asia is concerned.”
('84', 450, 3, 11, 795104) It is quite possible for the British Government to make a friend of Gandhiji.
('84', 450, 3, 12, 795182) Those who know him intimately would confirm this opinion of mine.
('84', 450, 3, 13, 795248) It may not be necessary for the British war effort to go out of the way to befriend him; but for the future of Indo British relationship, which is not unimportant, such befriending is necessary and the present is the psychological moment for it.
('84', 450, 3, 14, 795494) A victorious Britain would lose nothing by such a gesture, but gain a great deal of permanent value.
('84', 450, 3, 15, 795595) His mind today leans towards seeing a national government installed in India before the end of the war and advantage should be taken of this.
('84', 450, 4, 16, 795737) With Mr. Gandhi’s consent, I have discussed my talks with him with some people influential in Indian affairs.
('84', 450, 4, 17, 795847) They have included staunch supporters of the Congress, some strong critics of its policy and a member of the Viceroy’s Council.
('84', 450, 4, 18, 795975) Despite their difference in political outlook they all expressed the hope that a meeting between the Viceroy and Mr. Gandhi would be arranged.
('84', 450, 4, 19, 796118) One of them said to me: “There is no doubt that he is not only ready but anxious to be friendly and they would do well to take his hand now.
('84', 450, 4, 20, 796259) We are all suffering from a sense of frustration.
('84', 450, 4, 21, 796309) If a national government is formed and the Muslims will come in under the proposals for a settlement of differences, it will make a tremendous difference to the Indian war effort.”
('84', 450, 5, 22, 796490) I do not wish to place myself in the position of a political commentator but only a journalist who has discussed the situation fully and intimately with Mr. Gandhi and for what it is worth.
('84', 450, 5, 23, 796680) I would record my impression that the Government now has a better opportunity than at any time since Sir Stafford Cripps landed in India to put an end to the deadlock and create an India which, instead of being half hearted or sullenly indifferent, is enthusiastically on the side of Britain.
('84', 450, 5, 24, 796973) It will not depend entirely on the British Government.
('84', 450, 5, 25, 797028) The Congress is faced with a great responsibility to make a provisional government work.
('84', 450, 6, 26, 797117) At least it cannot now be argued that there are no new grounds for a resumption of relations.

('84', 451, 10, 12, 797783) APPENDIX XIV
('84', 451, 11, 13, 797796) LORD MUNSTER’S SPEECH 2
('84', 451, 12, 14, 797820) July 25, 1944
('84', 451, 13, 15, 797834) Mr. Gandhi had advanced the following views: Firstly, Mr. Gandhi said, he would never use the weapon of civil disobedience during the war unless for a very grave reason, such as the thwarting of India’s right to freedom.
('84', 451, 13, 16, 798055) Secondly, he would be satisfied with a national government during the war with full control of the civil administration, composed of persons chosen by the elected members of the Legislative Assembly.
('84', 451, 13, 17, 798255) Thirdly, the Viceroy would be, like the King of England, guided by responsible Ministers.
('84', 451, 13, 18, 798345) Fourthly, popular government would be automatically restored in all provinces, that is, provinces at the moment under Section 93. Fifthly, while under national government, the Viceroy and the Commander in Chief would have complete control of military operations, there would be a portfolio of Defence in the hands of the national government, which would be genuinely interested in the defence of the country and may render great assistance in the shaping of policies.
('84', 451, 13, 19, 798813) Sixthly, the Allied forces would be allowed to carry on operations on Indian soil, but the expense of such operations would not be borne by Indians.
('84', 451, 13, 20, 798962) Seventhly, Mr. Gandhi would advise Congress participation in the national government, if formed.
('84', 451, 14, 21, 799059) The procedure followed is a little complicated and a little difficult to
('84', 451, 15, 22, 799132) 1 Vide “Letter to Winston Churchill”, 17 7 1944. 2 Vide “Interview to the Press”, 26 7 1944 and “Letter to Lord Wavell”, 26/27 7 1944. Only excerpts are reproduced here.
('84', 452, 0, 1, 799302) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 453
('84', 452, 1, 2, 799349) understand.
('84', 452, 1, 3, 799361) A few days after Mr. Gandhi published these seven suggestions through the intermediary of the Press, he gave further explanations to Press correspondents, in which he emphasized that his statements constituted his personal effort to end the deadlock, but that if his suggestions are not acceptable to Mr. Jinnah or the powers that be, he would consider it a most unfortunate incident.
('84', 452, 1, 4, 799746) In clarification—if indeed it be clarification—of his offer to Mr. Jinnah, he stated that his proposals were wholly different from the Cripps offer which, he insisted, contemplated almost perpetual vivisection of India.
('84', 452, 1, 5, 799966) Frankly, it is difficult to understand if these statements by Mr. Gandhi have, in point of fact, definitely improved the chances of an inter communal settlement.
('84', 452, 2, 6, 800128) The main point, so far as His Majesty’s Government are concerned, is that he (Mr. Gandhi) is still clinging to precisely that claim which wrecked the Cripps Mission and put an end to negotiations in April 1942, for he is no more prepared today than he was then, to accept the formation of an interim government with the Viceroy maintaining his existing reserve powers.
('84', 452, 2, 7, 800497) He demands a so called ‘interim’ government in full control of the civil administration, with the Viceroy occupying the position of a constitutional monarch as we understand it in this country.
('84', 452, 2, 8, 800691) Let it not be forgotten that, if an agreement is set up under the present existing constitution, there are still a number of very important questions, not the least of which is the protection of the minorities, to be resolved.
('84', 452, 2, 9, 800918) All these matters must be settled before the final constitution can be evolved.
('84', 452, 2, 10, 800998) In this, it will seem that Government have not departed one iota from the pledge they gave some time ago, and which I will repeat now, that the proposals which were taken to India by Sir Stafford Cripps still stand in their entirety.
('84', 452, 3, 11, 801232) Referring, in conclusion, to the question by Lord Strabolgi, who asked whether the Viceroy was prepared to allow Mr. Gandhi to see the members of the Working Committee, Lord Munster said: “I would refer Lord Strabolgi to the letter which the Viceroy sent to Mr. Gandhi on June 22 last.
('84', 452, 3, 12, 801518) He said that another meeting between himself and Mr. Gandhi could only raise false hopes.
('84', 452, 3, 13, 801608) He said that Mr. Gandhi had publicly stated that he adhered to the ‘Quit India’ resolution which he (Mr. Gandhi) regarded as innocuous.
('84', 452, 3, 14, 801744) The Viceroy did see that as soon as Mr. Gandhi had any definite or constructive policy to put up, he would be very glad to consider it at that time.”

('84', 453, 3, 4, 802022) NEW DELHI,
('84', 453, 4, 5, 802033) August 15, 1944
('84', 453, 5, 6, 802049) DRAR MR. GANDHI,
('84', 453, 6, 7, 802066) Thank you for your letter of 27th July.
('84', 453, 6, 8, 802106) Your proposals are:
('84', 453, 7, 9, 802126) 1. That you should undertake to advise the Working Committee:
('84', 453, 8, 10, 802188) (a) that, in view of changed conditions, mass civil disobedience envisaged by the resolution of August 1942 cannot be offered, and
('84', 453, 9, 11, 802319) (b) that full co operation in the war effort should be given by Congress, provided that His Majesty’s Government (a) declare immediate Indian independence, and (b) form a ‘national government’ responsible to the Central Assembly, ‘subject to the proviso that, during the pendency of the war, the military operations should continue as at present but without involving any financial burden on India.’
('84', 453, 10, 12, 802719) 2. His Majesty’s Government remain most anxious that a settlement of the Indian problem should be reached.
('84', 453, 10, 13, 802826) But proposals such as those put forward by you are quite unacceptable to His Majesty’s Government as a basis for discussion, and you must realize this, if you have read Mr. Amery’s statement in the House of Commons on July 28 last.
('84', 453, 10, 14, 803058) They are indeed very similar to the proposals made by Maulana AbulKalam Azad to Sir Stafford Cripps in April 1942, and His Majesty’s

('84', 456, 3, 7, 810487) APPENDIX XVII
('84', 456, 4, 8, 810501) A RESOLUTION 1
('84', 456, 5, 9, 810516) The Working Committee have given their full and earnest consideration to the proposals made by the British War Cabinet in regard to India and the elucidation thereof by Sir Stafford Cripps.
('84', 456, 5, 10, 810706) These proposals, which have been made at the very last hour because of the compulsion of events, have to be considered not only in relation to India’s demand for independence, but more especially in the present grave war crisis, with a view to meeting effectively the perils and dangers that confront India and envelop the world.
('84', 456, 6, 11, 811036) The Congress has repeatedly stated, ever since the commencement of the War in September 1939, that the people of India would line themselves with the progressive forces of the world and assume full responsibility to face the new problems and shoulder the new burdens that had arisen, and it asked for the necessary conditions to enable them to do so to be created.
('84', 456, 6, 12, 811401) An essential condition was the freedom of India, for only the realization of present freedom could light the flame which would illumine millions of hearts and move them to action.
('84', 456, 6, 13, 811581) At the last meeting of the All India Congress Committee, after the commencement of the War in the Pacific, it was stated that: “Only a free and independent India can be in a position to undertake the defence of the country on a national basis and be of help in the furtherance of the larger causes that are emerging from the storm of war.”
('84', 456, 7, 14, 811921) The British War Cabinet’s new proposals relate principally to the future upon the cessation of hostilities.
('84', 456, 7, 15, 812029) The Committee, while recognizing that self determination for the people of India is accepted in principle in that uncertain future, regret that this is fettered and circumscribed and certain provisions have been introduced which gravely imperil the development of a free and united nation and the establishment of a democratic State.
('84', 456, 7, 16, 812363) Even the constitution making body is so constituted that the people’s right to self determination is vitiated by the
('84', 456, 8, 17, 812480) 1 A copy of the resolution, passed by the Congress Working Committee, was handed over to Sir Stafford Cripps on April 2, 1942. The Resolution however was released to the Press on April 11 after the negotiations failed.
('84', 456, 8, 18, 812699) Vide “interview to Shyama Prasad Mookerjee”, 5 8 1944.
('84', 457, 0, 1, 812754) 458 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 457, 1, 2, 812796) introduction of non representative elements.
('84', 457, 1, 3, 812841) The people of India have as a whole clearly demanded full independence and the Congress has repeatedly declared that no other status except that of independence for the whole of India could be agreed to or could meet the essential requirements of the present situation.
('84', 457, 1, 4, 813111) The Committee recognize that future independence may be implicit in the proposals but the accompanying provisions and restrictions are such that real freedom may well become an illusion.
('84', 457, 1, 5, 813298) The complete ignoring of the ninety millions of the people of the Indian States and their treatment as commodities at the disposal of their rulers is a negation of both democracy and self determination.
('84', 457, 1, 6, 813501) While the representation of an Indian State in the constitution making body is fixed on a population basis, the people of the States have no voice in choosing those representatives, nor are they to be consulted at any stage, while decisions vitally affecting them are being taken.
('84', 457, 1, 7, 813782) Such States may in many way become barriers to the growth of Indian freedom, enclaves where foreign authority still prevails and where the possibility of maintaining foreign armed forces has been stated to be a likely contingency, and a perpetual menace to the freedom of the people of the State as well as of the rest of India.
('84', 457, 2, 8, 814111) The acceptance beforehand of the novel principle of non accession for a province is also a severe blow to the conception of Indian unity and an apple of discord likely to generate growing trouble in the provinces, and which may well lead to further difficulties in the way of the Indian States merging themselves in the Indian Union.
('84', 457, 2, 9, 814445) The Congress has been wedded to Indian freedom and unity and any break in that unity, especially in the modern world when people’s minds inevitably think in terms of ever larger federations, would be injurious to all concerned and exceedingly painful to contemplate.
('84', 457, 2, 10, 814712) Nevertheless the Committee cannot think in terms of compelling the people in any territorial unit to remain in an Indian Union against their declared and established will.
('84', 457, 2, 11, 814884) While recognizing this principle, the Committee feel that every effort should be made to create conditions which would help the different units in developing a common and co operative national life.
('84', 457, 2, 12, 815083) The acceptance of the principle inevitably involves that no changes should be made which result in fresh problems being created and compulsion being exercised on other substantial groups within that area.
('84', 457, 2, 13, 815288) Each territorial unit should have the fullest possible autonomy within the Union, consistently with a strong national State.
('84', 457, 2, 14, 815413) The proposal now made on the part of the British War Cabinet encourages and will lead to attempts at separation at the very inception of a Union and thus create friction just when the utmost co operation and goodwill are most needed.
('84', 457, 2, 15, 815647) This proposal has been presumably made to meet a communal demand, but it will have other consequences also and lead politically reactionary and obscurantist groups among different communities to create trouble and divert public attention from the vital issues before the country.
('84', 458, 0, 1, 815927) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 459
('84', 458, 1, 2, 815974) Any proposal concerning the future of India must demand attention and scrutiny, but in today’s grave crisis, it is the present that counts, and even proposals for the future are important in so far as they affect the present.
('84', 458, 1, 3, 816200) The Committee have necessarily attached the greatest importance to this aspect of the question, and on this ultimately depends what advice they should give to those who look to them for guidance.
('84', 458, 1, 4, 816396) For the present the British War Cabinet’s proposals are vague and altogether incomplete and it would appear that no vital changes in the present structure are contemplated.
('84', 458, 1, 5, 816569) It has been made clear that the Defence of India will in any event remain under British control.
('84', 458, 1, 6, 816666) At any time defence is a vital subject; during war time it is all important and covers almost every sphere of life and administration.
('84', 458, 1, 7, 816801) To take away defence from the sphere of responsibility at this stage is to reduce that responsibility to a farce and a nullity, and to make it perfectly clear that India is not going to be free in any way and her Government is not going to function as a free and independent government during the pendency of the War.
('84', 458, 1, 8, 817119) The Committee would repeat that an essential and fundamental prerequisite for the assumption of responsibility by the Indian people in the present is their realization as a fact that they are free and are in charge of maintaining and defending their freedom.
('84', 458, 1, 9, 817378) What is most wanted is the enthusiastic response of the people which cannot be evoked without the fullest trust in them and the devolution of responsibility on them in the matter of defence.
('84', 458, 1, 10, 817569) It is only thus that even at this grave eleventh hour it may be possible to galvanize the people of India to rise to the height of the occasion.
('84', 458, 1, 11, 817714) It is manifest that the present Government of India, as well as its provincial agencies, are lacking in competence, and are incapable of shouldering the burden of India’s defence.
('84', 458, 1, 12, 817894) It is only the people of India, through their popular representatives, who may shoulder this burden worthily.
('84', 458, 1, 13, 818004) But that can only be done by present freedom, and full responsibility being cast upon them.
('84', 458, 2, 14, 818096) The Committee, therefore, are unable to accept the proposals put forward on behalf of the British War Cabinet.
('84', 458, 3, 15, 818207) The Indian Annual Regist er: 1942, Vol. I, pp.

('84', 460, 6, 29, 822483) September 10, 1944
('84', 460, 7, 30, 822502) DEAR MR. GANDHI,
('84', 460, 8, 31, 822519) With reference to our talk yesterday, September 9th, I understood from you that you had come to discuss the Hindu Muslim settlement with me in your individual capacity, and not in any representative character or capacity on behalf of the Hindus or the Congress, nor had you any authority to do so.
('84', 460, 8, 32, 822817) I naturally pointed out to you
('84', 460, 9, 33, 822848) 1Vide “Letter to M. A. Jinnah”, 11 9 1944.
('84', 461, 0, 1, 822891) 462 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('84', 461, 1, 2, 822933) that there must be someone on the other side with authority holding a representative status with whom I can negotiate and, if possible, come to a settlement of the Hindu Muslim question, and that for the position you had adopted there was no precedent, and that this raises great difficulties in my way.
('84', 461, 1, 3, 823237) As you know, I can only speak on behalf of Muslim India and the All India Muslim League, as the President of the organization which I represent, and as such I am subject to and governed by its constitution, rules and regulations.
('84', 461, 1, 4, 823467) I think you realize and will admit that the settlement of the Hindu Muslim question is the foremost and the major hurdle, and unless the representatives of these two nations put their heads together, how is one to make any headway with it?
('84', 461, 2, 5, 823707) Nevertheless, I explained to you the Lahore Resolution of March 1940, and tried to persuade you to accept the basic and fundamental principles embodied in that resolution, but you not only refused to consider it but emphasized your opposition to the basic position indicated in the resolution, and remarked that there was “an ocean between you and me”, and when I asked you what is then the alternative you suggest, you put forward a formula of Mr. Rajagopalachari, approved of by you.
('84', 461, 2, 6, 824193) We discussed it, and as the various matters were vague and nebulous, and some required clarification, I wanted to have a clear idea of what it really meant, and what were its implications, and asked you for explanation and clarification regarding the proposals embodied in that Formula.
('84', 461, 2, 7, 824480) After some discussion, you requested me to formulate in writing my points that I thought required or called for explanation and clarification, and to communicate with you and that you would reply in writing before our next meeting on Monday, September 11th, at 5.30 p.m.
('84', 461, 2, 8, 824751) I am, therefore, submitting to you the following points which required clarification:
('84', 461, 3, 9, 824837) 1. With regard to the preamble: in what capacity will you be a consenting party if any agreement is reached between you and me?
('84', 461, 4, 10, 824965) 2. Clause 1: With regard to “the constitution for free India” referred to in this clause, I would like to know first, what constitution do you refer to, who will frame it, and when will it come into being?
('84', 461, 5, 11, 825171) Next, it is stated in the Formula that “the Muslim League endorses the Indian demand for independence.” Does it mean the Congress demand for Independence as formulated in the August Resolution of 1942 by the All India Congress Committee in Bombay or, if not, what is the significance of this term, for you know the Muslim League has made it clear not only by its resolutions but also by its creed, which is embodied in its constitution, that we stand for the freedom and independence of the whole of this subcontinent, and that applies to Pakistan and Hindustan.
('84', 461, 6, 12, 825734) Next, it is stated that the Muslim League “will co operate with the Congress in the formulation of a Provisional Interim Government for the transitional period”.
('84', 461, 6, 13, 825896) I would like to know the basis or the lines on which such a Government is to be set up
('84', 462, 0, 1, 825983) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 463
('84', 462, 1, 2, 826030) or constituted.
('84', 462, 1, 3, 826046) If you have a complete and definite scheme, please let me have it.
('84', 462, 2, 4, 826113) 3. Clause 2: Who will appoint the Commission referred to in this clause and who will give effect to their findings?
('84', 462, 2, 5, 826229) What is the meaning of “absolute majority” referred to in it?
('84', 462, 2, 6, 826291) Will the contemplated plebiscite be taken district wise, or, if not, on what basis?

('84', 463, 4, 5, 827915) DEAR MR. GANDHI,
('84', 463, 5, 6, 827932) I received your letter of September 11 at 5 p.m.
('84', 463, 5, 7, 827981) I note that you have approached me as an individual, and I have already expressed my views about it.
('84', 463, 5, 8, 828082) Please do not take it that I acquiesce in the position that you have adopted, for which there is no precedent.
('84', 463, 5, 9, 828193) Nevertheless, I proceeded to discuss matters with you naturally because I am anxious to convert you to my point of view, if possible.
('84', 463, 5, 10, 828327) I urged you that the only solution of India’s problem is to accept the division of India as Pakistan and Hindustan, as briefly laid down in the Lahore Resolution of March 1940, and proceed to settle the details forthwith.
('84', 463, 5, 11, 828549) You say the Lahore Resolution is indefinite.
('84', 463, 5, 12, 828594) You never asked me for any clarification or explanation of the terms of the Resolution, but you really indicated your emphatic opposition to the very basis and the fundamental principles embodied in it.
('84', 463, 5, 13, 828797) I would, therefore, like to know in what way or respect the Lahore Resolution is indefinite.
('84', 463, 5, 14, 828890) I cannot agree that Rajaji has taken from it its substance and given it shape.
('84', 463, 5, 15, 828969) On the contrary, he has not only put it out of shape but mutilated it, as I explained in my speech which I delivered at the meeting of the Council of the All India Muslim League at Lahore on the 30th of July, 1944.
('84', 463, 6, 16, 829184) 2. You say the “first condition of the exercise of the right of self determination is achieving independence by the joint action of all the parties and groups composing India.
('84', 463, 6, 17, 829360) If such joint action is unfortunately impossible, then, too, I must fight with the assistance of such elements as can be brought together”.
('84', 463, 6, 18, 829500) This in my opinion is, as I have repeatedly said, putting the cart before the horse, and is generally opposed to the policy and declarations of the All India Muslim League, and you are only holding on firmly to the August Resolution of 1942. In order to achieve the freedom and independence of the peoples of India, it is essential, in the first instance, that there should be a Hindu Muslim settlement.
('84', 463, 6, 19, 829904) Of course, I am thankful to you when you say that you are pledged to use all the influence that you have with the Congress to ratify your agreement with me, but that is not enough in my judgement, although it will be a very valuable help to me.
('84', 463, 6, 20, 830149) I once more ask you, please, to let me know what is your conception of the basis for the formation of a Provisional Interim Government.
('84', 463, 6, 21, 830285) No doubt it will be subject to agreement between the League and the Congress, but I think in fairness you should at least give me some rough idea of the lines of your conception, for you must have thought it out by now, and I would like to
('84', 463, 7, 22, 830525) 1 Vide “Letter to M. A. Jinnah”, 11 9 1944.
('84', 464, 0, 1, 830569) VOL. 84 : 27 JANUARY, 1944 1 OCTOBER, 1944 465
('84', 464, 1, 2, 830616) know what are your proposals or scheme for the formation of a Provisional Interim Government, which can give me some clear picture to understand it.
('84', 464, 2, 3, 830765) 3. You have omitted to answer my question as to who will give effect to the findings of the Commission, and also it is not clear to me what you mean by absolute majority, when you say it means “a clear majority over non Muslim elements as in Sind, Baluchistan or the Frontier Province”.
('84', 464, 2, 4, 831052) You have not even replied to my question as to who will decide the form of the plebiscite and the franchise contemplated by the Formula.
('84', 464, 3, 5, 831189) 4. The answer does not carry any clear idea when you say “all parties means parties interested”.
('84', 464, 4, 6, 831286) 5. You say “mutual agreement means agreement between contracting parties”, who are the contracting parties once a Provisional Interim Government is established of your conception?
('84', 464, 4, 7, 831466) Who will appoint the Central or Joint Board of Control, which will safeguard defence, etc., and on what principle, through what machinery and agency, and subject to whose control and orders will such a Central or Joint Board be?
('84', 464, 5, 8, 831695) 6. You say “the power is to be transferred to the nation, that is, to the Provisional Government”.
('84', 464, 5, 9, 831794) That is all the greater reason why I would like to know full details of the Provisional Government as contemplated by you and of your conception.
